webTitle: Giggs commits rest of career to United

fields.headline: Giggs commits rest of career to United
fields.trailText: Ryan Giggs has agreed a new five-year contract at Manchester United and secured a new weekly salary of around £50,000.
fields.body:
Ryan Giggs concluded six months of negotiations yesterday by agreeing a new five-year contract at Manchester United and declaring that he intends to stay at Old Trafford for the rest of his career.

With a new weekly salary around the £50,000 mark, Giggs's wages have almost doubled. He joins Roy Keane and Fabien Barthez as the club's best-paid players though, because the transfer deadline has passed, he cannot actually sign the contract until July 1.

"Believe it or not, the financial side of things has not really been an issue," he said. "I'm already a wealthy lad and I'm more interested in winning trophies."

In his 10-year career, Giggs has already won the Premiership six times, the FA Cup three times and the European Cup once, including two doubles and a treble. Such success has persuaded him against a move abroad.

"I've always wondered what it would be like to play in Spain or Italy but I've had the best 10 years of my life at United so why change anything? As far as I'm concerned I would like to see out my career here.

"People ask about when Sir Alex Ferguson retires, but I believe that everything is in place for the club's success to continue. Most of the players have probably got their best years left in them and, at 27, I believe the next few years will be the best of my career."

In recent months United have also tied Jaap Stam and Andy Cole to long-term deals, while talks are ongoing with, among others, David Beckham, Paul Scholes, Gary Neville and Teddy Sheringham.

After United's 1-0 defeat to Bayern Munich in the first leg of their Champions League quarter-final on Tuesday, Giggs believes he will be joined by several new faces in the summer.

"I don't think there is any doubt that there will be new players coming in," he said. "It's the manager's last season and he will want to go out winning everything there is to win.

"At the moment we don't seem to have the spark of two years ago. We were all disappointed with our performance against Bayern but there have been a number of indifferent displays. Now it's up to us to take our game to a new level."

The Bayern Munich captain Stefan Effenberg has reaffirmed that he will be leaving the club when his contract comes to an end next year and said that London is his dream destination. "It's a great city," the 32-year-old said. "It doesn't matter which of the three clubs you play for."

webTitle: Steve Bruce takes over at Wigan

fields.headline: Bruce takes reins at Wigan
fields.trailText: Steve Bruce last night took over as manager of Wigan after being promised a £5m transfer kitty if he takes the club into the First Division.
fields.body:
Steve Bruce last night took over as manager of Wigan after being promised a £5m transfer kitty if he takes the club into the First Division.

The former Manchester United defender has been out of work since losing his job at Huddersfield Town this season. But he jumped at the chance of joining ambitious Wigan, who are fifth in the Second Division, after being lured by the multi-millionaire chairman Dave Whelan, one of the richest men in Britain.

Bruce said: "I'm looking forward to the challenge of cementing our play-off position and looking forward to achieving Division One status."

The previous manager Bruce Rioch parted company with Wigan in mysterious circumstances last month after a series of rows with Whelan.

The Latics were the early-season pacesetters in the Second Division but an alarming slump since new year has seen them slip into the play-off places. They lost out in the play-offs in each of the past two seasons.

Colin Greenall, who had been the caretaker manager since Rioch's departure, will remain on the coaching staff.

 The Football League has confirmed that next season's Worthington Cup winners will be granted a place in the Uefa Cup. The competition will also have a changed format with the first and second rounds to be played over one rather than two legs.

fields.headline: Powderfinger's pomp rock
fields.standfirst:
Powderfinger
Garage, Glasgow
**
fields.trailText:
Powderfinger
Garage, Glasgow
**
fields.body:
Powderfinger are huge in Australia. Hardly a claim to conjure with; "big in Germany" and even "fairly popular in Canada" sound more impressive. But an act who have gone five times platinum in their native country, played America's top-rated Letterman show and look set to storm our shores with three sell-out nights at the Shepherd's Bush Empire should have plenty to boast about.

Yet these five serious, intense young men are too earnest to stoop to bragging. You see, Powderfinger really mean it, man. They write meaningful songs about important subjects and use dramatic chord changes to emphasise their points. A screen behind them shows the sun rising and the moon orbiting the earth to show just how momentous their vision is. They bear an uncanny resemblance to Simple Minds at the height of Jim Kerr's pomposity, or U2 before Bono shed the stetson and discovered irony.

All of which is a shame, because it devalues Powderfinger's occasional knack of turning out an impressive tune. Their new track Like a Dog rails powerfully against the policies of Australia's right-wing government, yet fails to make its mark amid the bombast of the rest of the set. When every song sounds equally epochal and weighty, it's difficult to get a sense of perspective.

This would not be a problem if the band had a consistent grasp of melody or some kind of confrontational rock'n'roll attitude; they have neither. Indeed, you would expect an act four albums down the line to have moved on from the trad-rock limitations abandoned by Radiohead after Pablo Honey. And, to add insult to injury, it's hard to imagine rebellion coming any politer than Powderfinger. There's no danger of trashed stages or threats to lead the revolution; just ponderous songs in a minor key and singer Bernard Fanning frowning through his fringe. You know that the spirit of 1976 is dead when a few hapless crowd-surfers are reprimanded by Fanning: "Someone might get hurt."

Judging by the number of antipodean accents in the crowd, those forthcoming shows in west London will be attended mainly by residents of nearby Earl's Court. Perhaps the UK is safe, as yet, from Powderfinger's allure. But if they lightened up a little, things could be very different.

 At the Shepherd's Bush Empire, London W12 (020-7771 2000), from today until Saturday.

fields.headline: Uchida on playful form
fields.standfirst:
Mitsuko Uchida
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.trailText:
Mitsuko Uchida
Royal Festival Hall, London
****
fields.body:
Given that so much of the richness of Mozart's piano concertos lies in their extraordinary wind writing, to play them with only a meagre string-quartet accompaniment seems like a self-defeating exercise. Yet the three works played by Mitsuko Uchida and the Brentano String Quartet - the F major K413, A major K414 and K 415 in C major - were arranged by Mozart himself for these reduced forces. And in these exemplary performances, there were startling musical revelations in the intimate dynamic between soloist and string quartet.

Mozart designed the three concertos as vehicles to show off his skills as performer and composer to the Viennese public. His idea was to combine virtuosity with comprehensibility, and to appeal to every section of his fickle audience. Each movement of each concerto contains an astonishing innovation, from the heart-stopping melody of K414's slow movement to the military bluster of K415's allegro. Mozart's composition in these pieces seems as improvisatory as his playing must have been.

Uchida and the Brentanos caught brilliantly this sense of overflowing creativity. In orchestral performances of the concertos, attention is squarely focused on the bravura of the soloist. But here the Brentanos made one aware of the astonishing subtlety of Mozart's orchestral writing. The counterpoint of K415's first movement flew from player to player with dazzling energy. And if each of the string players became a soloist, then Uchida was their equal partner rather than a spotlit individual.

Uchida's cadenzas grew naturally out of the surrounding music, and her ornamentation was elaborate yet considered. Her extended solo in the A major concerto's andante was a moment of pure poise and elegance. However, she was not afraid to impose her own flights of imagination on to Mozart's. The finale of the C major concerto turns shockingly from rustic dance to minor-key lament, and Uchida exaggerated the changes of tempo with dangerous boldness. Yet her playfulness never undermined the music, and only emphasised the spirit of invention that flowed through these performances.

webTitle: Prudential's bid to takeover American General threatened by AIG

fields.headline: 'Dear Bob' missive shatters the Pru's dream
fields.standfirst:
Audacious bid intervention by US veteran forces youthful chief of British insurer to take first plane home from family holiday

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Jonathan Bloomer, Prudential's youthful chief executive, cut short a family holiday in the Caribbean last night to fight for his reputation after his ambitions to turn the Pru into a player on the global insurance stage appeared ruined.
fields.byline: Jill Treanor and Jane Martinson in New York
fields.body:
Jonathan Bloomer, Prudential's youthful chief executive, cut short a family holiday in the Caribbean last night to fight for his reputation after his ambitions to turn the Pru into a player on the global insurance stage appeared ruined.

The dream of transforming the Pru from a household name in Britain into an international powerhouse through the record-breaking £18bn takeover of American General appeared to be shattered by an audacious counter-bid launched by the mighty AIG late on Tuesday night.

Even the £408m poison pill in the terms of the Pru's agreement with American General, announced only three weeks ago, was not enough to deter New York-based AIG, the world's largest insurer, from crashing the unpopular deal. For AIG, the chance to challenge Citigroup as America's largest financial services company is at stake.

This means that instead of securing the role of running a much larger insurance company, the sixth biggest in the world, Mr Bloomer is in danger of being regarded as being at the helm of a relatively small player which could become a sitting duck for predators.

The City, which had doubts about the American General takeover at the outset, was preoccupied with listing the financial companies which might consider running a slide rule over the Pru. Names such as Allianz, embroiled in a takeover of Dresdner Bank, ING, Aegon and Axa were cited, along with banks such as HSBC.

While a bid for the Pru was regarded as far from imminent, investors said Mr Bloomer had provided the ammunition for any potential bidder when he announced his bid for American General, whose management was to replace that at his troubled US insurance arm Jackson Life. By securing as much as 65% of its revenues from the US, Pru hoped to reduce its reliance on Britain - where the government's plans for low cost pensions are hurting profits - and find money for further expansion in Asia.

One shareholder said: "The trouble for the Pru is when they made this bid they opened up their shirts and showed just how much cash the Asian business needed - which it doesn't have - and that the US was in more of a mess than we first thought.

"This is why they needed American General to sort them out. So it's a distinct possibility that any company with a lot of cash could come along and bid. The only problem is that one of them, AIG, is now out of the picture."

Yet AIG's veteran chief, Maurice "Hank" Greenberg, engaging in classic bid war rhetoric, rubbished any interest in the Pru. "All the Pru has really is a UK business that was evaporating and a small business in the US. It's not the same fit."

As the odds of success appeared to stack against the Pru, which had been caught napping by AIG, the Pru insisted its deal was intact, describing it tersely as being in "full force and effect". Mr Bloomer, in regular contact with his advisers at UBS Warburg during his hasty flight back to the City, was said to remain convinced about the long term merits of the union with American General.

That cut little ice with City and Wall Street analysts and investors, who appeared convinced that the Pru's ambitions would end in tears.

A fight with the fearsome AIG, almost eight times bigger than the Pru, would garner little support from shareholders concerned that the price offered was too high - even if it might result in long term rewards.

Only the fact that potential bidders probably had their hands temporarily full as a result of rapid consolidation in the insurance industry dampened expectations of an unwanted bid for the Pru, whose shares have lost some 20% of their value during recent weeks.

Even yesterday's rise in the Pru's share price - at one stage a dramatic 12% but 7% by the close at 795.5p - was not enough to recover the losses it had endured since what was billed as the largest yet transatlantic merger was announced.

Its embarrassing end followed an inauspicious start on the day last month which arguably marked the start of the current stock market rout. It was the sharp fall in the Pru's share price that enticed Mr Greenberg to take his chances after fruitless talks with American General eight months ago. Pru had tried but failed to inject life into its troubled shares after an intensive three-week charm offensive with investors on both sides of the Atlantic.

Colin Devine, an analyst at Schroder Salomon Smith Barney, the investment bank, said Pru's management had been less convincing when they presented their plans to Wall Street investors. "They came over here and couldn't explain what the heck they were doing," he said.

One City source said the only good news Mr Bloomer could have received yesterday was the 3% fall in AIG's shares. Even that left AIG's bid above Pru's - which rose in value along with its own share price rise - though pitched lower than Pru's original offer.

Those sympathetic to the Pru attributed the rise in the price to the action of stock market arbitrageurs who were frantically unwinding their positions. A more popular interpretation was that investors were relieved that the Pru's attempts to expand in America had been stopped in their tracks. City sources said the preoccupation with the Pru's share price could have been avoided if the group had imposed a fixed limit on the number of its shares American General investors would receive in return for backing the bid.

AIG escaped such a potential trap by putting an intricately structured limit on the number of its shares American General investors would receive.

Mr Greenberg, who is unaccustomed to failure, was nothing but confident when asked yesterday how his "Dear Bob" offer letter to American General boss Robert Devlin had been received. The two men are expected to meet, possibly today, for more detailed talks.

Much hinges on American General, which was saying little yesterday but en joyed a 13% rise in its shares. A role for the charismatic and ambitious Mr Devlin, who stands to gain $150m in share options and bonuses once an acquisition is agreed, is regarded as crucial. He has been offered the post of vice-chairman, running American General's existing business. Mr Greenberg said yesterday: "I hope he will have a broader role in AIG but that remains to be discussed."

As they weigh up the opposing offers, even the outside chance of a shot at running what could easily become America's biggest financial services company might be too hard for Mr Devlin and his management team to resist. The hefty £408m that they will owe the Pru if they pull out of their deal may suddenly seem a small price to pay.

fields.headline: Pension fund raid upheld
fields.standfirst:
Law lords reject retired power workers' claim that £350m was misused

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Retired power industry workers yesterday failed in their attempt to claw back millions of pounds of pension fund money they alleged was used to pay for redundancies at the time of electricity privatisation.
fields.body:
Retired power industry workers yesterday failed in their attempt to claw back millions of pounds of pension fund money they alleged was used to pay for redundancies at the time of electricity privatisation.

The House of Lords cleared the industry of misusing £350m of surpluses from the £18bn electricity supply pension fund, in a landmark case that was welcomed by all 21 companies in the sector.

The ruling follows a decision this year in the high court that British Airways was allowed to use £1.2bn of pension scheme surpluses from its £6bn scheme to fund an early retirement programme.

The five law lords, who unanimously overturned a court of appeal ruling in favour of the 200,000 power industry pensioners, said the companies stayed within rules when they used the surpluses to fund early retirement schemes for thousands of employees.

A spokesman for National Grid, which with National Power (now International Power) defended the action, said the ruling showed "clearly the companies did not misuse the pension scheme monies". National Grid used 70% of the 1992 surplus in its pension scheme to reduce its future liabilities, with 30% going to pensioners and scheme members. The company said this reflected each side's contributions to the fund. The other companies made similar use of fund surpluses.

The spokesman said the fund remained in surplus at the time and continued to be able to pay its obligations to pensioners. He added that a victory for the pensioners would have undermined company final salary pension schemes in the long term.

"If you take this flexibility away it will only push more companies to abandon them in favour of [poorer quality] money purchase schemes."

David Laws, 63, one of two pensioners from the Association of Electrical Supply Pensioners who brought the court action, said: "I'm very angry. We came here expecting justice and it's far from justice.

"Here we have my pension fund being used by employers to fund redundancies. That cannot be right. "I hope to take the case to Europe. I have worked in this industry since I was 15 years old and I've been campaigning for the last six years." The case brought by Mr Laws and his colleague Reg Mayes, 77, was that the funds should have been used to boost payments to pensioners and their widows on low incomes and were not "a pot of gold to be raided by the fat cats".

He argued that the electricity pension fund is owed £1.5bn and the electricity companies should be forced to repay the surplus.

The court of appeal had said National Grid acted unlawfully in using more than £30m of surplus assets from the Electricity Supply Pension Scheme to reduce its future contribution liabilities.

A similar ruling was made against National Power in relation to about £150m.

The court of appeal held there was nothing in the rules of the scheme giving employers a unilateral power "to forgive themselves their liabilities to pay contributions which are already due". The court failed to make a final judgment, saying only the House of Lords had the authority to decide the case.

Pensions ombudsman Julian Farrand ruled in favour of the pensioners at the start of the litigation five years ago. His decision was overturned in the high court.

The House of Lords cleared the industry of misusing £350m of surpluses from the £18bn electricity supply pension fund, in a landmark case that was welcomed by all 21 companies in the sector. The ruling follows a decision this year in the high court that British Airways was allowed to use £1.2bn of pension scheme surpluses from its £6bn scheme to fund an early retirement programme. The five law lords, who unanimously overturned a court of appeal ruling in favour of the 200,000 power industry pensioners, said the companies stayed within rules when they used the surpluses to fund early retirement schemes for thousands of employees. A spokesman for National Grid, which with National Power (now International Power) defended the action, said the ruling showed "clearly the companies did not misuse the pension scheme monies". National Grid used 70% of the 1992 surplus in its pension scheme to reduce its future liabilities, with 30% going to pensioners and scheme members. The company said this reflected each side's contributions to the fund. The other companies made similar use of fund surpluses. The spokesman said the fund remained in surplus at the time and continued to be able to pay its obligations to pensioners. He added that a victory for the pensioners would have undermined company final salary pension schemes in the long term. "If you take this flexibility away it will only push more companies to abandon them in favour of [poorer quality] money purchase schemes." David Laws, 63, one of two pensioners from the Association of Electrical Supply Pensioners who brought the court action, said: "I'm very angry. We came here expecting justice and it's far from justice. "Here we have my pension fund being used by employers to fund redundancies. That cannot be right. "I hope to take the case to Europe. I have worked in this industry since I was 15 years old and I've been campaigning for the last six years." The case brought by Mr Laws and his colleague Reg Mayes, 77, was that the funds should have been used to boost payments to pensioners and their widows on low incomes and were not "a pot of gold to be raided by the fat cats". He argued that the electricity pension fund is owed £1.5bn and the electricity companies should be forced to repay the surplus. The court of appeal had said National Grid acted unlawfully in using more than £30m of surplus assets from the Electricity Supply Pension Scheme to reduce its future contribution liabilities. A similar ruling was made against National Power in relation to about £150m. The court of appeal held there was nothing in the rules of the scheme giving employers a unilateral power "to forgive themselves their liabilities to pay contributions which are already due". The court failed to make a final judgment, saying only the House of Lords had the authority to decide the case. Pensions ombudsman Julian Farrand ruled in favour of the pensioners at the start of the litigation five years ago. His decision was overturned in the high court.

webTitle: Slowdown in mobile growth hits One2One

fields.headline: Slowdown in mobile growth hits One2One
fields.trailText: A weakening in the spectacular growth of the mobile phone market was in evidence yesterday when One2One reported its lowest quarterly customer numbers since the run-up to Christmas 1999.
fields.body:
A weakening in the spectacular growth of the mobile phone market was in evidence yesterday when One2One reported its lowest quarterly customer numbers since the run-up to Christmas 1999.

In the first three months of 2001, One2One added a net 657,000 customers - down from 861,000 in the same period last year. The final quarter of last year produced an additional 1.2m customers for the network.

Harris Jones, managing director of One2One, defended the figures, which he said reflected the maturing nature of the market. There are enough handsets in circulation for two-thirds of the population.

"The mobile communications industry has reached a new stage in its development," he said. "Unfettered, unprofitable growth is out. Sensibly managing the phenomenal growth of the last year is the key to business success."

The breathtaking pace of growth during the past year was driven by pre-pay phones with heavily subsidised handsets which have widened the market for mobiles. As the four networks have competed to sign customers up, they have in many cases been saddled with unprofitable low users.

Vodafone recently disclosed that 9% of its customers had neither made nor received a phone call in the previous three months.

Last month, One2One became the first of the networks to call a halt to the price war, a move which will have an impact on the next set of customer numbers. One2One doubled the price of its cheapest phone to £70 and was quickly followed by Vodafone, which lifted its entry price phone from £50 to £70.

"We felt that the subsidies being paid on these products were unsustainable," Mr Jones said. "Since then, the rest of the industry has begun to follow us."

One2One, which has traditionally been a consumer brand, has a high percentage of pre-pay customers and is keen to build its contract base. It has a total customer base of almost 9m people, of which 79% are on pre-pay. Mr Jones said the network would offer better value for its contract customers to entice pre-pay users to migrate across.

"We are determined to focus on profitable, long term growth through the retention and attraction of customers who want to derive maximum value from the network," he said.

"We are no longer interested in simply acquiring customers just to swell the customer growth figures each quarter. Those days are behind us."

The new emphasis on profits has no doubt been driven in part by the huge cost of bidding for third generation mobile licences last year and the development costs each of the successful networks face.

One2One's joint venture with Richard Branson, Virgin Mobile, accounted for 190,000 of the growth during the first quarter. Virgin Mobile - which piggybacks the One2One network - has 865,000 customers, up from 230,000 this time last year.

Virgin Mobile also announced the introduction of its service in Northern Ireland yesterday.

Analysts estimate that some 3m mobile phone handsets were sold in the first three months of the year, although an accurate figure will become available in the next few days as the other networks publish their figures.

fields.headline: Interest rates cut to 5.5%
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Bank of England today cut interest rates for the second time this year.
fields.body:
The Bank of England today cut interest rates for the second time this year.

The monetary policy committee announced its decision at midday to shave 0.25% off the official cost of borrowing, which brings the figure to 5.5%.

Inflation is running well below the government's 2.5% target and the decision is thought unlikely to have any adverse affect on the economy.

But when the committee makes its decision, it weighs up the possible inflationary pressures of buoyant consumer spending and a strong housing market if the rates are eased.

The last cut - also 0.25% - was in February. Industry and unions had said that another was needed to inject confidence into the British economy to protect from the slowdown in the United States.

The Bank decided against a cut last month, noting that there were few signs the US's economic troubles had crossed the Atlantic.

However, foot and mouth is now beginning to affect the economy.

Hotels and restaurants suffered a sharp fall in sales last month, dragging growth in the services sector down to its weakest rate for six months, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

Transport companies too are reporting that the disease has put the breaks on their business.

Another cut is not expected in May. The Bank's governor, Sir Edward George, insists that decisions will not be influenced by the election but many believe it would be reluctant to act at such a politically sensitive time.

The minutes of the meeting leading up to the Bank's decision are published on its website a fortnight today.

webTitle: The future will be along a little later

fields.headline: The future will be along a little later
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Larry King, as ever, was to the point: "One fifth of internet dot.coms have gone bust, investors are $3 trillion poorer and 40,000 more people are unemployed as a result of the dot.com crash. To borrow a line from the film, isn't it time to show me the money?"
fields.body:
Larry King, as ever, was to the point: "One fifth of internet dot.coms have gone bust, investors are $3 trillion poorer and 40,000 more people are unemployed as a result of the dot.com crash. To borrow a line from the film, isn't it time to show me the money?"

The talk show host was acting as a compere at Accenture's global communications forum in Miami Beach, Florida.

The audience of executives from more than 160 of the world's biggest telecoms, media and technology companies, was looking a little red-faced - and not entirely because they had been spending too much time on the loungers by the pool. A year ago these executives from global organisations such as News Corp, Orange, EMI and Nortel Networks were detailing how they were going to make billions from the coming technology revolution.

Twelve months on, all the talk is about tougher times ahead. As Ameet Shah, a partner at Accenture, says: "We've woken up and realised that the world wasn't quite what we dreamt it was."

His colleague, Tom Pike, head of strategy, admits the future is pretty uncertain too: "The fundamental case for the way technology is transforming business remains unchanged, and we're bullish on a three- to five-year basis but it's impossible to predict how the next 12 months is going to pan out."

The stakes are high. Chuck Phillips - managing director at Morgan Stanley - said that 70% of all money put into technology companies over the last 25 years was invested in 1999 and 2000.

During that time almost 6m miles of fibre was laid underground, hundreds of billions of dollars was spent on wireless licences and price to earnings ratios for stocks reached 200-year highs.

The vast majority of companies now have to show they can turn customers into hard cash, Mr Phillips said. "It's been brutal, and we cannot count on raw new internet users to generate growth," he said. "Users and usage may still be growing but the rate of that growth is slowing, and we need to find new uses for the net."

Several new technologies have disappointed or been delayed. Duane Ackerman, chief executive of cable company Bell South, believes the roll-out of broadband and higher speed internet access will bring revenue opportunities but says companies must think carefully about how they exploit them and spend cautiously.

Wireless operators, spending £200bn on third generation licences and set-up costs in Europe, have the biggest mountain to climb, according to Jean François Cecillon, former head of Sega Europe.

"Mobile content has to get better," he said. "Weather reports and stock updates are all very nice but that doesn't hook me. There is no way that is going to pay back £200bn."

Ericsson director Ulf Bromster believes operators and manufacturers have learned their lesson from the under-whelming response to Wap, the wireless internet platform that was introduced to Europeans last year. "There's not going to be any big bang with 3G and it will take time to come through, but we'll see steady growth in wireless internet over the next few years."

Ameet Shah believes only a few of the wireless companies will survive in their present form, with most either being acquired or going bust.

Morgan Stanley's Mr Phillips believes supply chain management and B2B exchanges will continue to show good growth despite the downturn.

However, he is not expecting the investment bank to cash in in quite the same way it has over the last two years.

"We all had a great time, got our houses remodeled and bought new cars, but those days are over now," he said.

webTitle: How do I let them know I am not nervous?

fields.headline: How do I let them know I am not nervous?
fields.trailText: April 5: I have a stammer, and I am worried it is going to look bad in job interviews.
fields.body:
The problem

I have a stammer which gets in the way when I'm stressed or anxious about something. I have a job interview tomorrow and would like to know if its best for me to bring my stammering to light, by telling the interviewer at the beginning so that she or he does not think that I'm simply nervous?

The solution

I'm sure this is a common problem, but you are quite lucky if your stammer only "gets in the way" when you're stressed or anxious. I think the first thing to realise is that there is nothing wrong with appearing to be nervous at interviews - stammer or no stammer. Interviewers expect some nerves and know that however confident you are in your abilities, any assessment situation is bound to be stressful. In fact, some candidates can lose out by appearing over-confident - showing few nerves can be interpreted by interviewers as either arrogance on the part of the candidate, or a sign that they don't really care about getting the job.

So, it is OK to admit to being a little nervous, and I think that in your case it might be a good idea to say something about your stammer if you have a bad episode during the interview. In other words, I don't think it is necessary to mention it in advance, but it can be a good idea to say something like, "sorry - I sometimes stammer in these kinds of situations". Saying this can create an impression of confidence ("I am confident enough in my abilities to know that a bit of stammering shouldn't affect my chances") so that you don't appear too nervous (the balance of being confident but not over-confident is what you should be aiming for). It might also relax you a bit so that your stammer improves. But, don't feel the need to over-apologise, or to mention it more than once.

 Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes to Work (Purple House) and Managing Your Boss in a Week (Hodder & Stoughton).

fields.headline: Rate cut pressure grows
fields.standfirst: Hotel and restaurant slump hits service sector
fields.trailText: The Bank of England was under pressure yesterday to cut interest rates again after a new survey revealed the first signs that foot and mouth is slowing down the economy.
fields.body:
The Bank of England was under pressure yesterday to cut interest rates again after a new survey revealed the first signs that foot and mouth is slowing down the economy.

Hotels and restaurants suffered a sharp fall in sales during last month, dragging growth in the services sector down to its weakest rate for six months, according to the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply. Transport companies are also reporting that the disease has put the brakes on their business, according to the institute.

The services sector has been the engine of Britain's economic expansion over the past five years.

City analysts said yesterday's figures increased the chances that the Bank's monetary policy committee will announce a cut in borrowing costs at its meeting today.

"The data probably make a rate cut a done deal. We look for a 25 basis-point cut but recent developments have made for some risk of 50 basis points," said Jeremy Hawkins, economist at Bank of America.

Service sector firms are also worried about the impact of the US slowdown, according to the Institute.

"Of the 10% of firms who expect their activity levels to be lower in a year's time than at present, a significant number mentioned concerns about the economic downturn in the US on future business levels," the institute reported.

After cutting rates by 0.25 percentage points in February, the MPC left interest rates on hold last month - noting that there were few signs that the British economy had been affected by the increasing concerns about the global economic outlook.

Since the MPC's last meeting, manufacturing has taken a turn for the worse, however, while the foot and mouth epidemic has proved far more wide-reaching in its impact.

Yesterday's evidence that services are slowing as well will reinforce the arguments of those MPC members who have been calling for lower rates. The US central bank has reduced the interest rate by 1.5 percentage points since the beginning of the year in response to a collapse in consumer confidence.

British consumers have yet to start tightening their belts.

Retail sales growth remained robust last month, according to the Confederation of British Industry, although most stores expect sales to slow this month.

MPC inflation hawks were concerned last month that household spending had not yet slowed sufficiently to allow for the government's planned expansion in public spending.

But analysts said that the fact that there were few indications of inflationary pressures in the economy meant that the hawks would probably be won around to agreeing to lower borrowing costs at today's meeting.

webTitle: National Express gives chief £1m for a year's work

fields.headline: National Express gives chief £1m for a year's work
fields.trailText: One of the train operating companies planning to introduce inflation-busting fare increases next month gave a £1m pay and shares package to its chief executive last year.
fields.body:
One of the train operating companies planning to introduce inflation-busting fare increases next month gave a £1m pay and shares package to its chief executive last year.

Phil White, who has headed National Express since 1997, received a 17% increase in his basic pay to £350,000, plus a £233,000 performance bonus, up from £150,000 in 1999. Other benefits totalled £19,000 and there was a £140,000 pension contribution.

Mr White cashed in share options to generate a further £244,656, taking his total pay and shares package to £986,656. He sold his options at 900p, which was 5p short of the peak price last year.

Details of Mr White's remuneration are in the train and bus company's annual report and accounts, which have just been sent to shareholders.

National Express includes train companies Midland Mainline, Silverlink, WAGN, ScotRail and Gatwick Express. Its coach operations include National Express, Express Shuttle, Airbus and Flightlink, and it provides bus routes in the west Midlands.

The company confirmed yesterday that passengers using its Midland Mainline services face fare increases of up to 5% from May.

Mr White, 51, still has options worth £1m, including a tranche awarded last year, although half of those cannot be converted into cash until April 2003.

A spokeswoman for the company said the increase in Mr White's basic pay and bonus were performance-related. He had not received an increase last year and the company had expanded abroad. "We prefer to look at the figures over a longer period of time. We now have a bigger, international business with some 30 subsidiaries".

 John Bryant and Fokko van Duyne, joint chief executives of steelmaker Corus who were ousted last year, have been urged to hand some their combined £2m in pay-offs to the 6,000 steelworkers facing redundancy and the dole.

Denis MacShane, chair of the Steel group of MPs, said Corus had "sent the wrong signal" with the pay-offs and he hoped the two men "would show some sense of responsibility and moral engagement with the men who loyally served them" by making a substantial donation.

fields.headline: Blasted
fields.standfirst:
Royal Court, London
****
fields.trailText:
Royal Court, London
****
fields.body:
Five years ago I was rudely dismissive of Sarah Kane's Blasted. Yet watching its revival last night I was overcome by its sombre power. So what has changed? The space, the design, the lighting, the cast and James Macdonald's production are all radically different. But, above all, one sees the play through the perspective of Kane's tragically short career and her obsession with love's survival in a monstrously cruel world.

The difficulty with the play was always structural - that it yoked together two apparently irreconcilable worlds. It starts in a Leeds hotel room where Ian, a hack journalist and undercover agent, has brought a naive young girl, Cate, for sex. There is something both brutal and mysterious about the way Ian mixes protestations of love with exploitative sexual violence. But the play changes gear when a soldier bursts in and, in Cate's absence, proceeds to sodomise Ian and suck out his eyes before killing himself. In a final stroke of horror, the starving, blinded Ian cannibalises a dead baby whom the returning Cate has buried under the floorboards.

Initially I was stunned by the play's excesses. Now it is easier to see their dramatic purpose. Kane is trying to shock us into an awareness of the emotional continuum between domestic brutality and the rape camps of Bosnia, and to dispel the notion of the remote otherness of civil war. Even now I think she overstates her case, but her work is part of an honourable tradition, ranging from Peter Brook's US to Pinter's Ashes to Ashes, that seeks to warn us that we enjoy no special historic immunity from violence and that there is a direct link between private and public fascism.

Seeing the play now at the Court's Theatre Downstairs, one is also struck by the density of its references and its strange element of hope. I detected allusions to Shakespeare's Lear, Beckett's Endgame, Pinter's The Dumb Waiter and even to Eisenstein's unfinished film Que Viva Mexico in the unforgettable climactic image of Ian's head protruding through the floorboards. And there is more than a touch of Bond's Saved in the final conciliatory gesture between Ian and Cate, which implies that love has precariously survived this catalogue of cruelty.

Macdonald's production is also vastly superior to his original in the Theatre Upstairs, not least because it implies from the start that we are in a world of fear and apprehension. Hildegard Bechtler's superb set and Jean Kalman's foreboding lighting add to the air of menace. Neil Dudgeon's Ian blends bludgeoning coarseness with a pathetic need for affection. Kelly Reilly's Cate moves astonishingly from wounded innocence to tremulous experience, while Tom Jordan Murphy's soldier is not just a bestial gun-wielder but a man driven to desperate excess. Certainly Kane's play is flawed; but it survives as a humane, impassioned dramatic testament.

 Until April 28. Box office: 020-7565 5000. A version of this review appeared in later editions of yesterday's paper.

fields.headline: Hedging against a fall
fields.standfirst: Rachel Gordon examines the risks and returns associated with hedge funds
fields.trailText: Rachel Gordon examines the risks and returns associated with hedge funds.
fields.body:
Investing in supposedly higher risk hedge funds looks set to take off in the UK, despite a warning from the Financial Services Authority (FSA) that many ordinary investors could get their fingers burnt.

But some independent financial advisers (Ifas) say hedge funds offer real potential for those aiming to understand the way they work and the risks involved. Hargreaves Lansdown, a Bristol-based Ifa, believes hedge funds are set to become even more mainstream in 2001 and could well be the success story of the year.

Head of research Mark Dampier said: "Hedge funds are well established in the US and are also taking off in Germany. The problem in the UK is that the level of financial awareness is so abysmal. Yet many investors in hedge funds are receiving returns of 12 to 14% and, in some cases, higher levels."

You won't see much advertising for hedge funds as they are not regulated. The FSA said there were dangers in investing in "exotic" sectors and head of consumer relations Christine Farnish said: "Hedge funds can be difficult to understand, and costs and charges may not be clear and inappropriate for most people." The concern with offshore funds is there is more scope for fraud and less protection.

But while hedge funds were once the preserve of the very rich, it is now possible to buy a piece of the action with a smaller investment. This is because access to hedge funds is now available with a minimum investment of about £5,000 and can also be bought through an Isa. In the past, a minimum investment in US dollars was required, typically of at least $250,000.

The FSA objects to hedge funds because they are based offshore and because they invest in derivatives such as futures and options. Beyond this, they also have greater flexibility and can invest in other areas such as commodities, bonds, or mortgage or credit card loan-backed securities.

Mr Dampier said while he understood the FSA wanted to protect consumers, the reasons why returns were better were because hedge funds were unregulated and so able to take higher risks and use less conventional methods.

HSBC Republic, the international private banking arm of the high street bank, is one of the latest providers to offer hedge fund products. And the hedge fund, European Absolute, can be placed in a tax-free Isa wrapper. This has adopted the "fund of funds" approach commonly being used by most fund managers aiming at a wider market and means it will invest in between 20 and 30 hedge funds in Europe and the UK. The minimum investment is £5,000 and the offer closes on 5 April.

WHAT ARE HEDGE FUNDS?
Hedge funds are offshore investment vehicles that aim to make money no matter what the market conditions. They use a variety of techniques to take advantage of difficult situations and, in general, last year outperformed unit and investment trusts. Traditional, regulated investments have been hit hard because of the stock market slump.

They differ from standard funds such as unit and investment trusts by using so-called "long, short" techniques. Traditional funds are long only, meaning they aim to make profits if the value of the stock they hold rises. They cannot exploit falling values. So-called selling short, as used by a hedge fund, means taking a bet on shares the fund manager thinks will fall, putting up the stake and then buying them cheaply.

This potential to profit even on falling share prices is what attracts many to hedge funds. But, it is also high risk - going short means selling stock that is not owned in the hope that it can be bought back at a cheaper price, and so making a profit. Hedge funds also tend to borrow heavily to allow them to place large bets. If the stock that is sold short then rises, heavy losses can be incurred.

There are now a number of well-known names moving into the retail hedge fund market. These include Henderson, Credit Suisse, Deutsche Bank, Morley, owned by Norwich Union, and Matrix Securities.

Henderson, for example, is launching the Henderson Absolute Return Portfolio, or Harp, in April. It has a minimum investment of £7,000 and can be included in an Isa or Pep.

Hedge funds have been around since 1949 and are based offshore, typically in countries such as Bermuda, but, more recently, a number have been set up in Dublin. The funds are often associated with Hungarian-born US billionaire financier George Soros, who achieved notoriety in 1992, when his Quantum hedge fund began speculating heavily against Sterling, which later meant the currency was ejected from the exchange rate mechanism.

The funds have also had some spectacular nose dives, such as the international bail-out of Long Term Capital Management in 1998, a hedge fund that the US Federal Reserve Bank had to bail out when it was on the brink of failure. The bank intervened because it was concerned about possible consequences for the world financial markets.

But Mr Dampier insists all hedge funds are not the same and some, such as those run by larger and more established names, should not be viewed as high risk. He added that the fact that while it was right that the FSA should be concerned about high charges, hedge funds also rewarded the fund managers differently to standard retail funds.

"It is very much based on performance and while they can earn huge amounts, they only do this if the investors achieve a positive result."

The fund managers of hedge funds also reward themselves differently. In addition, hedge funds could also be used to increase growth among pensions funds. A recent report from the National Association of Pension Funds, which represents the industry, described them as a possible "valuable addition" to the range of options currently available.

fields.headline: Decision may benefit borrowers
fields.standfirst: The Bank of England has cut interest rates for the second time this year. Rachel Gordon looks at what the move means for home owners
fields.trailText: The Bank of England has cut interest rates for the second time this year. Rachel Gordon looks at what the move means for home owners.
fields.body:
The Bank of England has cut interest rates by a quarter of a per cent today to 5.5% in a move that is likely to mean cheaper mortgage rates for millions of home owners.

Halifax, the UK's largest lender responded immediately and said it would reduce its variable mortgage rate from 6.75% to 6.50% with immediate effect. This means the Halifax rate is now at its lowest since 1965.

Nationwide, the UK's largest mutual lender, said it would reduce its base mortgage rate by 0.25% to 6.24%, while its standard variable rate comes down by the same amount to 6.74%.

A spokeswoman said the reduction would mean a borrower with a £60,000 interest-only mortgage would save about £12.50 a month. Abbey National has yet to respond to the rate cut news, but looks likely to follow suit.

But the reduction is not good news for savers, who are likely to be worse off. So far, none of the major banks or building societies have said if they plan to review their savings rates downwards.

Halifax said it would not announce changes to its savings accounts "until later in the month". Egg, the online bank, also said it was considering its position but would be unlikely to make an announcement this week.

This is the second time this year the Bank of England has cut rates. The last time was in February, which was also a 0.25% reduction. Interest rates now stand at 5.5% - the lowest level for 16 months.

The reason for this latest rate reduction is to protect the UK from the ailing US economy, which is experiencing a dramatic slowdown in growth. So far it looks as if the UK economy has not been affected by the US trends, although foot and mouth disease is having a negative impact.

The decision was taken by the Bank of England's nine-member Monetary Policy Committee (MPC). Their main aim is to keep inflation rates low.

It is likely that the postponement of the election encouraged the rate cut. The MPC looks to stay out of politics and will be unlikely to make any further changes in the run up to the election.

fields.headline: Glam and glitz with the Queen of the Nile
fields.standfirst:
Cleopatra
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.trailText:
Cleopatra
Sadler's Wells, London
**
fields.body:
After Ridley Scott's glossy digital scenery in Gladiator, Houston Ballet returns the land of the Caesars to a much more old-fashioned, theatrical tradition. Cleopatra (created last year) comes from the stable of big, plush story ballets with which director/ choreographer Ben Stevenson has made Houston's name. With the help of designers Thomas Boyd and Judanna Lynn and composer John Lanchbery it presses all the available buttons of classical dance theatre to create a work cosily tucked between the 19th and 20th centuries.

Set against a gilded, painterly backdrop, the ballet boasts an array of expensive, crowd-pleasing effects, the most spectacular being Cleopatra's diva-style entrance when she appears to glide on stage in a jewelled barge. The choreography is set to an arrangement of Rimsky-Korsakov's concert and operatic music, giving it a period patina circa 1900. It aims for the scale of Spartacus, and the oriental opulence of La Bayadère or Scheherazade. Though the cast isn't huge, Stevenson maximises the athleticism of Houston's dancers with spacious moves, inflected in the Egyptian scenes with flattened, hieratic poses and in the Roman scenes with a disputative political energy.

There's little risk or novelty, but the movement services the story with purposeful clarity. The Roman senators dance with a blunt, muscular aggression, in contrast to the introvert homoerotic duets of Ptolemy and Pothinius as they plot against Cleopatra. Pothinius (Nicholas Leschke ) dominates the craven, diminutive Ptolemy (Mauricio Canete) in a seesawing game of sex and power.

Cleopatra was created, however, as a ballerina vehicle, specifically for Houston's home-grown star, Lauren Anderson. Much has been made of Anderson's rarity as a black ballerina - and it's undeniable that her skin colour serves the ballet well. But it's her dramatic and technical gifts that are the real issue. Anderson is a tall, rangy dancer who combines a dynamic attack with musical elegance. She has a good instinct for Cleopatra's capricious nature, motivated by insolent sexuality and by queenly ambition. She is badly hampered, though, by Stevenson's oddly reticent choreography in her love duets with Caesar and Marc Antony, which fail to elevate her to the grand heroine mode that the format of the ballet requires. Cleopatra is one of the most famous, and fatal, female lovers in history, yet this role doesn't take her to any extremes of eroticism, passion, tenderness or loss.

The work is without question an exercise in ballet populism and as such is professionally crafted with lots of dancing and energy. What will make it seem parochial to many London fans is less the fact that it's a stylistic throwback than its failure to go for broke in delivering a real old-fashioned love story.

 In rep until Saturday. Box office: 020-7863 8000.

fields.headline: The Gondoliers
fields.standfirst:
Watermill, Newbury
****
fields.trailText:
Watermill, Newbury
****
fields.body:
Anyone expecting one of Gilbert and Sullivan's Savoy operas may be mildly bemused. Anyone expecting fun will be more than satisfied. After giving Bizet's Carmen a complete makeover at this address last year, John Doyle now does the same for the 1889 version of The Gondoliers. The result is an act of creative vandalism that is theatrically inventive and musically ingenious - rather like The Godfather meets a spaghetti western.

On Mark Bailey's versatile, chequerboard set, which cleverly passes for Chicago's Little Italy, Italy's Venice and a restaurant in Little Venice in London, the cast play out a frenetic story of a misplaced mafia heir, long lost brothers and mistaken identity. Think The Comedy of Errors with meatballs and guns and you have the idea. One character remarks: "Life is like spaghetti - a big mixed-up tangle." So it proves for Chicago gangster's daughter Cassilda Cacciatorro, who is more than a little taken aback to discover that she has just celebrated her silver wedding anniversary. She was secretly married at the age of six months to the son of Italy's richest and most powerful mafia family. But nobody knows who or where he is: he was spirited away for his own protection after the assassination of his father and supposedly raised as one of the sons of a west London restaurateur.

If you've got all that, you'll be fine plot-wise, and if you haven't it really doesn't matter, because the pleasure of Doyle's production is in the execution and the score, which is Sullivan spiced up beyond all recognition. This may not be the deepest of evenings, but there is a huge level of skill on show. The cast are a talented bunch who look great, sing, act, play, eat spaghetti and use the saxophone as a gun all at the same time. No one is less than terrific, but I especially loved Karen Mann's gross Chicago wife, Mark Crossland's mother-pecked bodyguard and Elizabeth Marsh's sexy, towering Cassilda.

The Watermill can do serious, as in Edward Hall's recent brilliant Henry VI adaptation, Rose Rage, and it can do fun like this. That is a fine achievement. It is only a pity that nobody at the Arts Council has noticed that this dynamic little venue is a theatrical hot spot.

 Until May 12. Box office: 01635 46044. Then at the Cochrane Theatre, London WC1 (020-7369 1793), May 22-26.

fields.headline: Strugglers produce little ado about nothing at the Palace
fields.trailText: The Eagles and the Terriers failed either to soar or bark last night in a tense and guileless relegation battle.
fields.body:
The Eagles and the Terriers failed either to soar or bark last night in a tense and guileless relegation battle.

A point reflected marginally better on Huddersfield as the away side and took them that bit closer to escape from the bottom three. Crystal Palace are trying not to fall that low and would have hoped for a home victory to aid their cause.

Relegation would be a hard pill to swallow for clubs with grander ambitions. Three years ago Palace were in the Premiership. Last May Huddersfield missed out on the First Division play-offs on the last day of the season having been in the top six for most of the previous nine months.

In November when Lou Macari took over as Huddersfield's manager they were bottom. That is not the case any more but they are still struggling, paying the price for selling Marcus Stewart to Ipswich in February last year.

Palace, fresh from near bankruptcy, have endured a roller-coaster season, dropping to 20th recently after a run of six straight defeats which was finally broken by last weekend's win over Crewe.

In a scrappy opening neither goalkeeper had to make a save in the first 40 minutes. Then they shared two in a minute. First Huddersfield's Nico Vaesen scooped up Mikael Forssell's close-range header then Aleksandrs Kolinko dived full length to tip away a 25 yard snap shot from Delroy Facey.

Both clubs have reinforced to try and beat the drop. Huddersfield brought back their for mer striker Andy Booth while Palace signed David Hopkin from Bradford, Matthew Upson on loan from Arsenal and the Finland midfielder Aki Riihilahti who scored against England at Anfield.

With Fan Zhiyi also back from injury the Palace squad looked much stronger than Huddersfield's on paper. But on this rain-soaked pitch the prolonged stalemate sent out a different message.

The home side conjured up a brief spell of pressure midway through the second half but the closest they came was a point-blank shot from Clinton Morrison blocked by Chris Lucketti and a Morrison volley which whistled just wide.

A point reflected marginally better on Huddersfield as the away side and took them that bit closer to escape from the bottom three. Crystal Palace are trying not to fall that low and would have hoped for a home victory to aid their cause. Relegation would be a hard pill to swallow for clubs with grander ambitions. Three years ago Palace were in the Premiership. Last May Huddersfield missed out on the First Division play-offs on the last day of the season having been in the top six for most of the previous nine months. In November when Lou Macari took over as Huddersfield's manager they were bottom. That is not the case any more but they are still struggling, paying the price for selling Marcus Stewart to Ipswich in February last year. Palace, fresh from near bankruptcy, have endured a roller-coaster season, dropping to 20th recently after a run of six straight defeats which was finally broken by last weekend's win over Crewe. In a scrappy opening neither goalkeeper had to make a save in the first 40 minutes. Then they shared two in a minute. First Huddersfield's Nico Vaesen scooped up Mikael Forssell's close-range header then Aleksandrs Kolinko dived full length to tip away a 25 yard snap shot from Delroy Facey. Both clubs have reinforced to try and beat the drop. Huddersfield brought back their for mer striker Andy Booth while Palace signed David Hopkin from Bradford, Matthew Upson on loan from Arsenal and the Finland midfielder Aki Riihilahti who scored against England at Anfield. fields.headline: Peacock preens after saving City
fields.trailText: A penalty 11 minutes from time from Lee Peacock kept Bristol City still hoping for a play-offplace and reinforced their arch-rivals' relegation worries which appeared to have been eased by Christian Lee's first goal for Rovers early in the second half.
fields.byline: David Foot  at the Memorial stadium
fields.body:
A penalty 11 minutes from time from Lee Peacock kept Bristol City still hoping for a play-offplace and reinforced their arch-rivals' relegation worries which appeared to have been eased by Christian Lee's first goal for Rovers early in the second half.

Heavy rain led to several pre-match inspections. The weather kept some fans away but there was no lack of atmosphere as the teams slithered for yards in their challenges.

The importance of the fixture for these rivals at different ends of the table was plain. Both were shaking off recent lethargy which had upset their managers, though there was little sign of controlled skill to complement the energy level.

Just as Trevor Challis's early tackle stopped Scott Murray in his tracks, there was a crucial challenge by the inexperienced Joe Burnell on Challis two yards outside the penalty area. This brought a free-kick which Scott Jones fired recklessly over.

As ever the teenager Nathan Ellington was a persistent, awkward and still talented striker for Rovers. Twice before the interval his long-striding raids caused defensive anxiety for City. Steve Phillips chased out several times, once snatching the ball at the feet of Nathan Ellington, whose disappointing goal rate this season is due to nondescript service.

Ronnie Mauge, the Rovers midfielder, who had felt compelled to issue a loyalty-statement after rumours that he might be following the former manager Ian Holloway to Queens Park Rangers was busy alongside Dwayne Plummer, a former young City player. But Mauge was at fault when his midfield pass slowed in the mud. Lee Peacock chased away but wasted his left-wing cross.

There was plenty of resolute defensive play, like Steve Foster's timely concession of a corner when Peacock's centre, this time from the right, dropped awkwardly.

Spurred on by the recent criticisms by the managers, both teams sustained the pace and tried to pass creatively in the difficult conditions.

Six minutes into the second half Rovers took the lead. Again the effervescent Ellington troubled City's defence. His shot spun off Matt Hill and the ball looped disconcertingly before Lee scored with a close-range header. It was his first goal since joining from Gillingham hours before the transfer deadline.

fields.headline: Mooney double puts Watford back on track
fields.trailText: A Tommy Mooney double helped Watford leapfrog Forest into seventh place to revive their promotion push.
fields.body:
This has not been the easiest of seasons for Graham Taylor, but the Watford manager finally found some cheer last night as his side leapfrogged Nottingham Forest into seventh place to revive their promotion push. What is more, a first clean sheet in 13 attempts allowed Taylor to claim victory in a very personal battle between two friends at different ends of their managerial careers.

It was a case of master and pupil at Vicarage Road, where David Platt had to pit his wits against the man who bought him for Aston Villa in 1989.

"In many ways I think he has had a profound effect on me," Platt said before the game. "The biggest compliment I can pay him is that I say things to players on the training ground or in the dressing-room that he once said to me."

Not only do the two managers say similar things, they achieve similar results. Both teams are hovering just below the play-offs after seasons that have always been eventful but are ending in real drama. The home side are looking for a new manager, of course, as Taylor has announced his early retirement; Forest are losing £105,000 a week and their share price has dropped from 70p in 1997 to a new low of 7.5p this week.

Forest are not the only club effectively gambling their se curity on promotion, but on this evidence the administrators rather than Manchester United are more likely visitors to the City Ground next season. Despite two men pushed to the flanks specifically to worry Watford's suspect full-backs, they managed only two dangerous cross in the opening period, neither from open play.

The home side, however, created a string of early chances. Or rather, they almost created a string of chances, as generally having got behind the visiting defence their final ball was poor.

It took a helping hand from Jon Olav Hjelde to give them the lead, as the Norwegian completely misjudged the offside trap, allowing Tommy Smith the freedom of the right flank to find Gifton Noel-Williams, who scored with a diving header.

Within two minutes of the restart Watford extended their lead, though Forest's defence again played a part. Neil Cox's driven free-kick appeared unlikely to cause Dave Beasant undue concern in goal until it deflected off David Prutton in the wall and spun straight to Tommy Mooney, who sidefooted home.

Stung into action, Forest promptly launched their first spell of concerted pressure. It should have brought them a goal, but Stern John and David Johnson missed a succession of chances. Espen Baardsen was not really tested in the home goal, being called into action only to parry John's stinging drive.

On the break, Mooney's 19th goal of the season secured a Watford win in the 73rd minute. From Steve Palmer's long through-ball he beat Christian Edwards before finding a gap between Beasant and his near post.

 Oxford took a first-minute lead at the Second Division play-off hopefuls Bournemouth and twice levelled before losing 4-3 to an 83rd minute Warren Feeney winner.

fields.headline: Kuqi jars Bolton off track
fields.trailText: Bolton's promotion aspirations suffer another jolt, this time at the hands of Stockport's Finnish striker Shefki Kuqi.
fields.body:
The pre-match pyrotechnics that greeted the north-west rivals look likely to be the only fireworks an exhausted Bolton Wanderers will enjoy this season as their promotion aspirations suffered another jolt last night.

Colin Hendry's early goal, his fourth in a week after claiming two for Scotland and a weekend effort for his club, helped move Bolton back into the second automatic promotion place but that is surely only temporary.

Stockport's Finnish striker Shefki Kuqi ensured Blackburn were the other big winners on the evening as his 67th-minute header from Shane Nicholson's deep cross cost the home team two more points

Still, it is a testimony to the job so far performed by the Bolton manager Sam Allardyce, operating with far leaner funds than those at the disposal of Graeme Souness, that Wanderers only needed a point to leapfrog back into second place, at least for 24 hours until their neighbours' meeting with Sheffield United.

Bolton opened brightly, only seconds having elapsed when the veteran striker Dean Holdsworth just missed contact with a darting far-post run.

But the first time that the on-loan Stockport keeper Alan Kelly was called into serious action, it was in vainly attempting to prevent Hendry's 11th-minute header from crossing the line.

A fantastic Nick Summerbee centre forced a corner from which Karim Fradin again put behind his goal. From the resulting corner, Summerbee's superb delivery found Hendry at the near post and Kelly could only help the ball into the net.

The Bolton wide men, Summerbee and Gardner, seemed to offer the home side the best chance of further goals, the latter producing one fiercely struck 20-yard shot that was deflected just wide.

Closest of all, another excellent dead ball from Summerbee found Hendry at the far post only for the defender to surprisingly miss.

Hendry pressed on after the interval, however. Only the attention of defender Leo Roget prevented him making mean ingful contact with a Gudni Bergsson through-ball.

Then Hendry launched himself at Summerbee's corner and headed just over.

As Bolton's nerves began to bite, it was on-loan striker Andy Campbell who came closest to providing the much needed second goal, capping a counter-attack with an intelligent run across the face of the area and chipped effort just wide.

fields.headline: Houllier accuses league of bias
fields.trailText: Gerard Houllier has accused the FA of wanting Liverpool to miss out on the Champions League after they refused to reschedule the Reds' match with Ipswich next week.
fields.body:
The Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier has accused the Premier League of favouring Ipswich's bid for the third Champions League place after it refused to postpone Tuesday's potentially decisive fixture between the clubs. The Merseysiders had complained of fixture congestion.

"This is an unfair ruling which favours Ipswich," he said yesterday. "They obviously want Ipswich to be in the Champions League rather than Liverpool." Liverpool play eight games in 23 days, starting with last Saturday's league clash with Manchester United and ending on April 22 at home to Tottenham.

The Wycombe manager Lawrie Sanchez, whose side face Liverpool in the FA Cup semi-final on Sunday, has been fined £2,000 and banned from the touchline for three matches for his outburst at a linesman during the quarter-final victory over Leicester. However, his ban will not start until April 23.

The former Olympique Marseille chairman Bernard Tapie will return to the club as a minority shareholder and sports manager. Tapie led Marseille to the 1993 European Cup before being banned in 1994 from all sports activities because of a bribery scandal .

St Johnstone's appeal against the Scottish Premier League's decision to overturn the sackings of George O'Boyle and Kevin Thomas, dismissed after allegations of drug use in a nightclub, was upheld by a Scottish FA hearing yesterday.

Southampton's chairman Rupert Lowe has called for new rules to prevent managers being poached in mid-season after losing Glenn Hoddle to Tottenham.

fields.headline: Wenger set to switch on the power
fields.trailText: Arsene Wenger believes a display of power, commitment and high-tempo football holds the key to overcoming Valencia tonight.
fields.body:
Arsenal are unlikely to resemble Wimbledon's old Crazy Gang tonight. But Arsène Wenger made it clear yesterday that the traditional English virtues of power, commitment and high-tempo football hold the key to overcoming Valencia.

With the Spanish side more accustomed to playing at a slower pace, Wenger will stress to his largely foreign collection of midfielders and forwards that strength as well as sophistication will be needed to break down a defence that is the meanest in La Liga (22 goals conceded in 28 games) and the Champions League (six conceded in 12 games).

"We need not just quality in our passing and calmness but power, English power," Wenger said. "Physical power will be important in the box in the last third and with runs from midfield and the flanks. The kind of physical commitment you have in the English league can make a difference.

"When I say power, it is of course linked with the pace of the Premier League but without losing our heads. We have experience at the back and I will rely on that to make sure we can dictate that pace without losing our defensive stability because not to concede a goal is very important."

With Lee Dixon, Martin Keown and Tony Adams fit, Wenger will complete an all-English back four with Ashley Cole, whose inclusion ahead of Silvinho seemingly reflects not just the youngster's good form but the game plan. "Silvinho is a little bit more tricky in the Brazilian way and Cole is a little bit more direct," Wenger said.

Valencia combine those two qualities on the counter-attack, so Arsenal will have to strike the right balance between adventure and caution. The 6ft 5in Norwegian John Carew offers an obvious outlet up front and the Argentines Kily Gonzalez and Pablo Aimar, supported by Gaizka Mendieta, are quick and skilful.

Having drawn twice with Manchester United, last season's beaten finalists are far from cowed. "Arsenal are not favourites because we consider we are a better team," said Carew. Speaking to his compatriots Tore Andre Flo and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has heightened his confidence: "They assured me it wasn't very difficult to attain a draw at Highbury."

Lauren, who grew up in Spain, admits Arsenal must win tonight to stand a chance of reaching the semi-finals "because it's very difficult to score goals in their stadium".

With Dennis Bergkamp injured, the scoring burden at Highbury is expected to rest on Thierry Henry and Nwankwo Kanu. Valencia arrive after successive league defeats but Arsenal know they must improve on last month's performance at Bayern Munich.

"I was never worried we were not good enough," Wenger said, "but I was worried by how bad we could be in a game which was so important for us." He expects a change of pace tonight.

Arsenal (4-4-2, probable): Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Adams, Cole; Parlour, Lauren, Vieira, Pires; Kanu, Henry.

Valencia (4-4-2): Canizares; Angloma, Ayala, Pellegrino, Carboni; Angulo, Mendieta, Aimar, Kily Gonzalez; Carew, Sanchez.

fields.headline: Turkish delight as Real reel
fields.trailText: Galatasaray came back form 2-0 down to stun reigning champions Real madrid at the Ali Sami Yen Stadium in Istanbul last night.
fields.body:
An unexpected second-half comeback from Galatasaray stunned reigning European champions Real Madrid at the Ali Sami Yen Stadium last night. The Turks stormed back from 2-0 down at the interval with three second-half strikes to set up a mouth-watering second leg of their Champions League quarter-final at the Bernabeu in two weeks' time.

Real had looked in a different class in the opening period - goals from Ivan Helguera and Claude Makelele emphasising their superiority - and the Turks looked beaten. But a penalty from Umit Davala was added to by strikes from Hasan Sas and Mario Jardel amid amazing scenes in Istanbul.

The hosts were content to defend very deep in the opening stages and catch Vicente del Bosque's side on the break - but apart from a few long-range shots, most notably from Gheorghe Hagi, they failed to test Iker Casillas in the Real goal.

Real could have taken the lead after 28 minutes following good work down the left from Roberto Carlos and Steve McManaman, but Luis Figo shot a foot wide of Claudio Taffarel's right post with his weaker left foot.

He made amends just five minutes later by playing a crucial part in the opening goal. The Portuguese international whipped in a delightful free-kick from the right hand side, and central defender Helguera rose unchallenged to head powerfully past Taffarel for his fifth goal in this season's Champions League.

Gala were still on the back foot when the visitors notched a crucial second shortly before half-time. Carlos' long throw was nodded by Raul into the path of Makelele, and the French international strode past a couple of despairing challenges before driving the ball under the goalkeeper.

Makelele turned from hero to villain just two minutes after the restart by bringing down Sas in the area, and Umit converted the penalty with ease.

The hosts poured forward - Brazilian striker Jardel coming close with two headers - before Sas sent the crowd into raptures with a deserved equaliser. Substitute Fatih Akyel raced down the right before squaring the ball for Sas, who smashed the ball low to Casillas' right with a first-time shot.

With 15 minutes to go the comeback was complete - Akyel burst down the wing again, delivering an inch-perfect cross for Jardel to rise above Fernando Hierro and plant his header past Casillas.
