Valencia: Canizares, Angloma, Pellegrino, Ayala, Carboni, Kily Gonzalez, Mendieta, Aimar, Baraja, Carew, Sanchez. Subs: Palop, Djukic, Zahovic, Angulo, Vicente, Aurelio, Milla.

Referee: Dick Jol (Holland)

1 Big news of the night is that Ljungberg starts the game with ridiculous purple hair. Don't we just love him? Valencia get the game underway with the customary punt into the Arsenal half. Vieira responds by beating Baraja and charging upfield to provide the first threat to the visitors goal.
2 Kanu gets to the by-line but is muscled off the ball.
4 Corner to Arsenal after the purple one beats Angloma to the by-line and his cross is put behind. Comes to nothing.
7 Arsenal are fighting for every ball and doing a good job of winning it back when they lose possession. Dixon tries a long-range shot and guess what...
10 Old man Dixon tries another approach to proving he can still mix it with the best when he clatters unecessarily into Kily Gonzalez.
11 Henry charges away on the Arsenal left, beats a harrassed Angloma and wins a corner - Cole takes and Valencia clear.
14 Another corner to Arsenal; Pires takes towards Vieira and his header from a yard out hits the crossbar; Henry blasts in the rebound but a body gets in the way.
16 All Arsenal up to now as Valencia win their first corner courtesy of Mendieta; Mendieta takes towards Ayala, who gets away from his man but heads wide. Up to now Arsenal have lived up to their manager's assertion that they will be taking the game to the Spaniards, but now look to be losing the initiative.
21 Valencia starting to get their game together after Arsenal's early onslaught as Mendieta tries to put Kily Gonzalez on the edge of the area - unsuccessfully. Seaman beaten when Aimar spurns a cross to Carew in space and rattles a ball across the face of goal for a goal-kick.
23 Henry again down the left, trying to beat Angloma; turns him near the by-line and crosses but Pellegrino heads clear.
25 Angloma getting a bit tired of people taking the Mick and upends Henry on the edge of the Valencia area when the Arsenal player tries to round him again - no foul.
30 The game hits a lull as both teams take stock.
31 Arsenal break the deadlock by probing the left again and then switching to the Kanu on the right; Valencia getting the measure of things and hold up Arsenal on both occasions.
32 Pires makes his way into the area and tries to make spaace for a shot - no go. Pires has another go and is spilled by Baraja who earns himself a booking...
34...Arsenal free-kick square-on 25 yards out; Henry takes, Canizares saves.
34 Mendieta tests Seaman with a looping half-volley from the edge of the area.
36 Arsenal survive the best chance of the night when Carew gets away on the right of the area but Seaman charges out to block the shot; Carew has another go and hits the post. Arsenal look to have run out of ideas already as Valencia step up to fill the void.
39 Kanu claims a penalty when Pellegrino spills him just outside the area - no go.
41 Corner to Valencia; Mendieta sends a comedy looping ball into the area; it gets whopped out 30 yards, Kily Gonzalez fires it back to Mendieta on the right, he crosses, Aimar takes the sting off it, heads it down and Ayala pounces to score a vital away GOAL for Valencia from 10 yards. Arsenal 0 - 1 Valencia. Arsenal had it coming.
45 Pires's free-kick across the face of goal is headed behiund for a corner; Pires takes but it comes to nothing. Two minutes extra to play for Arsenal to undo the damage and raise their game. Is their a rule that says you should only really give it all you've got for 20 minutes and then sit back and wait for the chances to come to you? Half-time.

46 Substitution Wiltord on for Ljungberg. Arsenal free-kick 22.65 yards out; Cole takes straight into the wall.
48 Kanu tries a long-range shot but doesn't really connect.
49 Kanu knocks it into the path of Henry on the right but Henry's shot spoons high above the goal. Arsenal starting the half with all right intentions - let's hope that keeping up the pressure for 45 minutes is one of them.
50 Pires wins a corner after beating Angloma to the by-line and forcing a save from Canizares. Pires takes and Ayala makes the final clearance.
52 Booking Ayala; now suspended for the second leg. Particularly gutting for the Argentinian as it was Angloma who actually committed the foul...
53...Pires takes the free-kick from the edge of the area - wide.
56 Booking Kily Gonzalez.
58 GOAL: Arsenal 1 - 1 Valencia Vieira surges forward to find Wiltord on the left; Wiltord drags the ball back from the by-line, Kanu cannot control it but Pires is able to back-heel Henry into position to score the equaliser from ten yards.
60 GOAL: Arsenal 2 - 1 Valencia Would you believe it? Parlour steams up and puts Arsenal in front with a belting right-foot shot off the underside of the crossbar.
65 Henry very unlucky not to get Arsenal's third when his pace gets him past Angloma and into the area; Angloma recovers to hold him up.
67 Wiltord and Parlour overlap on the right to find space for a cross to Henry on the left; Henry beats Angloma and forces a save from Canizares at the near post.
69 Substitution Angulo on for Aimar.
75 All quiet on the Highbury front as Valencia tentatively seek a way through without allowing Arsenal to get a vital thrid.
78 Valencia showing more initiative at the moment as Kily Gonzalez plays in Sanchez on the left. Kily Gonzalez gets the return but Dixon blocks the move.
81 The revitalised Pires wins a free-kick five yards out on the left. Falls for no one in the area.
84 Substitution Lauren on for Kanu.
86 Some needle between Ayala and Wiltord life drips out of this game in the dying minutes.
87 Valencia free-kick near the left corner flag, Mendieta takes, comes to nothing. Neither team too keen to give away a goal at this stage, as you might imagine.
88 Henry gets away on the left, plays it in, comes out for Pires to fire wide.
89 Substitution Rodriguez on for Mendieta.
90 One last chance for Arsenal with a free-kick some 35 yards out; Pires takes, Ayala heads clear, the ref blows. Full-time.
Arsenal 2 - 1 Valencia

fields.headline: Robledo of the pack?
fields.trailText: Email the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to help.
fields.body:
Email the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to help.

MOST PROFILIC FOREIGNER EVER

"Which foreign [non-British and Irish] player has scored the most goals in the top flight in England?" asks Simon Rogerson.

Three names spring immediately to mind: George Robledo, Eric Cantona and Dwight Yorke.

The Chilean Robledo was one of the first foreigners - along with his brother Ted - to play in England. He was also one of the most effective. After playing for Huddersfield and Barnsley, he then moved to Newcastle, where he made his name by scoring 82 goals in 146 league appearances [91 goals in 164 games in total] between 1949 and 1953.

Robledo's goals - he scored 39 in 1952, equalling Hughie Gallacher's club record - helped Newcastle to FA Cup victories in 1951 and 1952 and made him a popular player on Tyneside.

According to nufc.nu, "Robledo was solidly built at 5ft 9ins tall and possessed film-star looks. He revelled in a confrontation with a big defender and took a lot of weight off Jackie Milburn. He could pass the ball accurately, had a good first touch and most of all he was an opportunist of the finest quality. Nicknamed Pancho by his team-mates, he used to blast them in from all angles."

The second contender is Eric Cantona, who scored 73 goals in 161 league appearances for Leeds and Manchester United [and 102 goals in 214 games in total]. But even the mighty Cantona falls short of his successor Dwight Yorke, who in 268 league appearances for Aston Villa and United has scored 117 goals [158 goals in 357 games in total]. Without knowing Robledo's goal tally for Huddersfield and Barnsley, we'd say Yorke is your man - but send us an email if you know otherwise.

WHEN WERE SHIRT NUMBERS FIRST USED?

"When did shirt numbers first start getting used and who wore the first shirt with the number one on it?" asked Mins.

"The introduction of shirt numbers is down to one man - Herbert Chapman, the great manager of Huddersfield and Arsenal," says Phil Baiden. "In 1933 he added numbers so that the players would know where they were on the field in relation to their team-mates.

"I would assume then that the first wearer of the number one shirt would be the Arsenal goalkeeper of the day," he predicts.

But Anthony Williams disagrees: "Shirt numbers were used for the first time in the 1933 FA Cup final between Everton and Manchester City on 29 April 1933, which Everton walked 3-0," he says. "Everton wore numbers one to 11 and Manchester City 12 to 22.

"The Everton goalkeeper that day was Ted Sagar, meaning that he had the distinction of being the first ever footballer to wear the number one shirt."

WHERE DID THE TERM HAT-TRICK COME FROM?

"Which sport originated the term hat-trick?" asks Harry Gottlieb.

Last week, ice-hockey and cricket scrapped over this particular honour. But Draper5 has no doubts. "Of course this term comes from cricket," he says. "It came into use after HH Stephenson took three wickets in three balls for the all-England eleven against the twenty-two of Hallam at the Hyde Park ground, Sheffield in 1858.

"A collection was held for Stephenson (as was customary for outstanding feats by professionals) and he was presented with a cap or hat bought with the proceeds."

IS ASHLEY COLE A RECORD BREAKER?

"During the Albania v England game, I heard the ever-so-excited Jonathon Pearce state that Ashley Cole has played just 24 games for Arsenal. Has Cole set a record for an English player to play so few first team games before winning his first cap?" asks Daniel Blake

You're close Dan, but no cigar. The man you're looking for is another member of England's team against Albania: Wes Brown. On 28 April 1999, he became the quickest-ever capped England player when Kevin Keegan picked him to face Hungary after just 11 appearances for Manchester United.

NEARLY DOES IT

Do you know the team that has made the most appearances in an FA Cup semi-final? asks John Holtam

We do, we do. Rather surprisingly, Everton are the team you're after. They've made the last four of the world's greatest cup competition (copyright The Football Association 1872-1999) 23 times, one more than Manchester United and two more than Arsenal and Liverpool. And yes, of course we're counting what's happened in this year's competition.

CAN YOU HELP?

Following on from last week's question about why more teams don't play in weird colours, John McBurnie wants to know why Dulwich Hamlet, who are currently languishing at the bottom of the Ryman League, chose "their horrific pink-and-blue quarters strip". Any ideas?

"What was the name of the Bournemouth civil servant who became the self-appointed mascot for England in the 60s?" asks Bill.

"Can you tell me: (a) Who was the first black footballer to play for England U-21s?" asks Lawrence Burton.

"Am I right in thinking that the save Peter Schmeichel made against Arsenal in the 1999 FA Cup semi-final is the only penalty save he ever made for United, excluding shoot-outs? Or even the only penalty which wasn't converted while he was playing?" asks Richard Shaffer.

"Whatever happened to Sonny Pike?" asks Dan Williamson. "I'm certain that years ago I watched a documentary about him and learnt that he was England's brightest ever prospect. I am also sure that he trained with the Ajax youth side. Is he the only British player to have had this honour bestowed upon him?"

Trawl through The Knowledge archive.

Your football questions are answered every Wednesday. Email the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to help.

webTitle: Scotland relaxes restrictions and urges tourists to visit

fields.headline: Scotland relaxes restrictions and urges tourists to visit
fields.trailText: Given the absence of foot and mouth north of the Forth and Clyde central belt, the Scottish Executive has moved to relax countryside restrictions and reopen as many visitor attractions as possible
fields.body:
Despite the continuing threat from the foot and mouth epidemic, Scotland remains open for business, announced Peter Lederer, chairman of the Scottish Tourist Board (STB) at a press conference at the annual Scotland Travel Fair this morning.

The tourism industry in Scotland, which employs 178,000 people and injects £2.5bn annually into the Scottish economy, has seen bookings plummet by 60% since the first outbreak of foot and mouth disease.

However, there have as yet been no reported cases of foot and mouth north of the Forth and Clyde central belt. The Scottish Executive has consequently moved to relax countryside restrictions and reopen as many visitor attractions as possible, including areas in popular tourist destinations such as Glenmore and the Trossachs.

Among other measures announced to win back tourist business is a £3.5m package of local and national marketing, aimed at redressing the negative impressions created by the epidemic. Further measures include immediate assistance for infected areas in Dumfries and Galloway and the Scottish Borders to prepare for their re-entry into the marketplace once the crisis is over, and a 50% relief on Area Tourist Board membership fees across the country.

On announcing the package, Peter Lederer said "We have agreed with the industry that the most important action we can take is to get accurate information into the marketplace about Scotland, build customer confidence and generate business in a sector that is vital to Scotland's economy.

"Ultimately it will be the confidence of consumers that will restore stability to this industry. We will work to bring that about as soon as possible, and will continue to impress upon the countryside agencies and local authorities the importance of implementing the Comeback Code and opening up our attractions and recreational areas as soon as possible."

fields.headline: Tories slam election delay bill
fields.trailText: April 4, 6.30pm: Government managers will use a guillotine measure tonight to get emergency legislation through the Commons to delay local elections, despite Tory claims that the move is an "insult to the parliamentary process."
fields.body:
Government managers will use a guillotine measure tonight to get emergency legislation through the Commons to delay local elections, despite Tory claims that the move is an "insult to the parliamentary process."

Strict time limits have been set on debate of the elections bill to ensure it clears all its Commons stages by 10pm, to the fury of the opposition. Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe complained: "The elections bill has been cobbled together in what must have been a couple of hours."

Tories claim the restrictions are "outrageous and absurd" and are demanding more time, although earlier plans to delay the bill in the Lords now look unlikely without Liberal Democrat support.

The home secretary Jack Straw however said it was essential to move quickly to provide "certainty" for everyone involved in the elections.

The guillotine measure had only had been introduced because the opposition frontbench was incapable of controlling its own backbenchers, he added.

The elections bill is the result of prime minister Tony Blair's decision to delay the May 4 elections, the first postponement since the second world war.

It sets June 7 as the date for the local polls - now widely expected to be the date of the general election as well, increases the amount candidates can spend on their campaign by 50% and allows for compensation payments.

If it is approved by the Commons tonight it will go on to be discussed by the Lords tomorrow and next Monday, and it could become law by early next week.

MPs are also being asked to speed through the elections (publications) bill tonight, designed to save political parties from having to pulp tens of thousands of election leaflets.

It was introduced after the parties failed to spot an unexpected consequence of last year's political parties, elections and referendums act which revised regulations on the printing of election material such as posters.

fields.headline: Enfant terrible has his wrists slapped
fields.standfirst: Trevor Beattie's shock tactics mean French Connection gets acres of media coverage every time the advertising watchdog gives him a ticking off
fields.trailText:
Comment: Trevor Beattie's FCUK adverts work precisely because they upset the regulator, writes Claire Cozens.
10.45am: French Connection may rethink advertising
Click here to see the TV ad
FCUKing genius: Trevor Beattie profile
Mar 1: Beattie lashes out against TV prudes
fields.body:
After four years of offending middle England Trevor Beattie, the man behind French Connection's hugely controversial FCUK advertising campaign, has been banned from putting up any more adverts without prior approval from the regulator.

The Advertising Standards Authority, which regulates all poster and press advertising, today issued a strong rebuke to the fashion retailer.

The ASA said French Connection had "brought the advertising industry into disrepute" with advertising that was "offensive and irresponsible".

The decision is unlikely to cause either French Connection or Mr Beattie many sleepless nights.

But the campaign works precisely because the watchdogs don't like it.

Mr Beattie's shock tactics mean the brand gets acres of media coverage every time the advertising regulator gives French Connection a ticking off.

Depending on your opinion, FCUK is either a branding masterpiece or a cynical piece of media exploitation.

But there is no doubt it has been a huge commercial success.

fields.headline: Is Houllier the new Fergie?
fields.trailText: Is Gerard Houllier turning into the new Alex Ferguson? During the last 48 hours the Liverpool manager has lashed out at Ipswich, the Premier League ... and now poor Christian Ziege. It's the sort of paranoia that made the United manager the top boss in the country, and gives us all a good laugh.
fields.body:
Is Gerard Houllier turning into the new Alex Ferguson? During the last 48 hours the Liverpool manager has lashed out at Ipswich, the Premier League ... and now poor Christian Ziege. It's the sort of paranoia that made the United manager the top boss in the country, and gives us all a good laugh.

But can Gerard match up to Sir Alex? We'll let you decide with our cut-out-and-keep comparison of the best bitching from the past few seasons. Let battle commence!

Gerard's gripes

"This is an unfair ruling which favours Ipswich. They obviously want Ipswich to be in the Champions League rather than Liverpool."

Houllier adopts the classic everyone-hates-us ploy favoured by Fergie after hearing that the Premier League won't switch Liverpool's fixture against Ipswich.

"Half of my team are England internationals. Nobody can complain now in June if they are suffering burn-out."

And a day later he's still banging on. Now who does that remind you of?

"My advice to him is to shut up. He is not going to attract my attention by complaining in the media."

Houllier reminds Christian Ziege who's the boss, just like a certain United manager.

"David Ginola is a criminal. I repeat, he is a criminal."

If you cross Houllier you pay the price, as Ginola found out after his error led to Bulgaria knocking France out of the World Cup in 1993.

"It seems Alex [Ferguson] is touched by God this season. If he kicked a tin can across the street, it would probably land in the net."

Houllier whinges a la Fergie after United complete the treble.

"When the players heard who was refereeing they said: 'It's like playing against 12, not 11'"

And Houllier concentrates his ire on another favourite Fergie target: the referee. This time he's attacking Mike Reed after he sent off Jamie Carragher at Charlton in 1999.

Fergie's fury

Now here's Sir Alex doing what he does best.

"When the Italians tell me it's pasta I check under the sauce to make sure it is. They're masters of the smokescreen."

Fergie scents an Italian conspiracy before Manchester United's European tie against Internazionale, 1999.

"He's a big-time Charlie,"

The United boss puts Paul Ince in his place.

"There's only one way I can describe Ian Wright's lunging, jump-in tackle on Peter Schmeichel at Highbury in February. If Eric Cantona had done the same, he would have been locked up on Devil's Island. For good."

Fergie uses his book 'A Manager's Diary: The Will To Win,' to put the boot into Ian Wright in '97.

"He has no experience of English football - he has come from Japan - and now he's telling everyone how to organise our football. Unless you have been in the situation you should keep your mouth shut firmly shut."

Arsene Wenger also gets the Fergie treatment after he expresses his views about United's fixture backlog, also in '97.

"They sit and admire the ground and wait to be entertained just as if they were at a theatre or musical We have a lot of visitors for whom it is a weekend holiday. That may be all right for some people but it is no use to me all the players."

Fergie rants about his own fans.

"There is a terrible amount of jealousy towards Manchester United. I do not know why."

Finally, another favourite Fergie theme: jealousy, from 1997.

Who wins? Send your opinions to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Bridget Jones's Diary
fields.standfirst: The film of Helen Fielding's bestselling book is premiered today. Here's our guide to the best sites on the world's most famous neurotic singleton
fields.trailText: The film of Helen Fielding's bestselling book is premiered today. Here's our guide to the best sites on the world's most famous neurotic singleton.
fields.body:
1. Film premieres 1 (v.g.), media column inches about a million (hurrah!), alcohol units at post-screening party 50 (bad).

2. The long-awaited film of Bridget Jones's Diary is premiered tonight.

3. The film is based on Helen Fielding's 1998 bestseller, which chronicled the chaotic life of a 20-something single urban female caught between an ill-advised attraction for her dastardly boss, Daniel Cleaver (played by Hugh Grant), and a fruitless quest to give up booze and fags while developing inner poise.

4. In a piece of method acting worthy of Robert De Niro, the show's American star Renée Zellweger worked incognito in a London publishing firm for three weeks as preparation for the role.

5. Bridget, who wages a well-documented and largely unsuccessful war on her embonpoint, would be disgusted to learn that the sylph-like Ms Zellweger had to pile on the pounds, as well as mastering an English accent for the title role.

6. The Bridget Jones phenomenon brought the word "singleton" into the public consciousness. Bridget, plagued by an unsuccessful love life, is in good company, with a survey suggesting that, by 2010, almost half the population will be unmarried. Not least the very happily single Mariella Frostrup.

7. Bridget has moved with the times. Her obsession with email flirtation and the 1471 telephone callback facility has now extended to text messaging. Fans of her diary will soon be able to receive instalments via their mobile phones.

8. Bridget Jones is described as a reworking of Pride and Prejudice. In a complicated piece of cross-referencing, Bridget is obsessed with Colin Firth, who played Mr Darcy in the film adaptation of Jane Austen's work. She ends up falling for another man called Darcy, also played by Firth.

9. The book has spawned a host of literary clones, and her adventures continue in a sequel, in which she finds a man but loses her liberty in a bizarre drugs scam.

10. So what's the film like? V.g., apparently. Check out the trailer here. Glass of Chardonnay, anyone?

webTitle: Delay using genetic tests, MPs tell insurance firms

fields.headline: Delay using genetic tests, MPs tell insurance firms
fields.trailText: MPs have called on insurance companies to agree to a two year delay in the use of all results of genetic testing for deciding their premiums.
fields.body:
MPs have called on insurance companies to agree to a two year delay in the use of all results of genetic testing for deciding their premiums. The issue raised significant moral and ethical concerns, said the Science and Technology Committee.

MP Dr Michael Clark, Chairman of the Committee, said: "We remain unconvinced by the claims of some insurers that if they did not include genetic test results in the assessment of premiums it would spell commercial ruin. At least three insurers have voluntarily decided to ignore all positive test results, with no apparent adverse effect. In fact, we were told, cases involving genetic results comprise far less than one tenth of 1% of all insurance business at present."

But Mary Francis, Director General of the Association of British Insurers (ABI), said: "We cannot lightly ignore information that tells us that someone applying for insurance is at significantly higher risk than the majority of policyholders. Applicants are normally charged according to the risk they bring to the pool of people insured - for instance, because of their age or their medical history."

The association pointed out that its code of practice meant that insurers would never ask someone to take a genetic test in order to obtain insurance. However, if someone had taken a test for a limited number of conditions, insurers would ask for the result.

The Genetics and Insurance Committee, the regulatory committee set up to evaluate the scientific and actuarial relevance of genetic tests, has approved one genetic test for Huntington's Disease. It is currently considering applications from the ABI for another test for Huntington's Disease and tests for early onset familial Alzheimer's disease and hereditary breast and ovarian cancer.

The MPs' report called for the committee's procedures and membership to be reformed. "We now look to the insurance industry to act responsibly, rather than be forced to act by legislation. In view of the very small numbers involved, we believe that insurers can well afford to ignore genetic test results, for the foreseeable future," the report said.

The MPs were also concerned that people with potential genetic problems might be deterred from taking tests or seeking clinical advice and that research may be affected.

Dr Clark explained: "We welcome the ABI's statement that insurers should not use results from tests carried out for research purposes. We call for more research to be carried out to establish the effect of insurers' use of results upon the number of patients seeking clinical treatment."

The Science and Technology Committee are not in favour of legislation denying insurers access to all genetic test results. If a person's family history suggests the possibility of a genetic defect, but they have had negative test results, it is in their interests that these should be taken into account by insurers. Professor Martin Bobrow, of Cambridge University, told the inquiry: "The simple inherited diseases we are looking at today are an area in which people who are pretty seriously disadvantaged do not need more trouble in their lives - and trying to load insurance issues on top of their medical issues could only be justified if the evidence was really clear and if the financial implications were significant."

fields.headline: Bob Glendinning
fields.trailText: Bob Glendinning, who has died aged 79, was a doctor, an educationalist and a socialist, and a leader in the establishment of comprehensive education in Bristol.
fields.body:
Bob Glendinning, who has died aged 79, was a doctor, an educationalist and a socialist, a leader in the establishment of comprehensive education in Bristol, the South Bristol College and the Brunel College of Arts and Technology. A founding governor of Bristol Polytechnic in 1978, he became its chairman, a post he retained when it became the University of the West of England (UWE) in 1992.

He was also a co-founder of the Bristol branch of the Campaign for Nuclear Disarmament and, later, its south-west regional committee. From 1958 to 1965, he was a member of the CND national executive.

Bob's commitment to the cause of CND stemmed back to his wartime experience with the Royal Army Medical Corps in Japan. Posted to a unit outside Hiroshima, he saw, and spoke to, survivors of the first atomic bomb.

A Northumbrian by birth - and by constitution - Bob attended Newcastle royal grammar school, and his upbringing exposed him to the deprivation wrought by the depression of the 1930s. Apart from the usual engine driver phase, he could not remember a time when he did not want to be a doctor. He graduated in medicine from the University of Durham in 1942. The RAMC then posted him to the far east - and he was never to forget the poverty he saw in India. Demobilised in 1947, he was, until 1993, a general practitioner in St George, east Bristol.

Elected to the city council in 1963, he was a member of its education committee until 1974, and was proud of the council's 1964 plan for secondary education, which established comprehensives in nearly all of Bristol. It was from 1965, while he was chairing the council's further and higher education committee, that South Bristol College and Brunel College were born - and he chaired their governing bodies for some years.

In 1973, Bob was elected to the new Avon county council and, in 1981, when Labour gained control, he put into practice, as education chairman, some of his ambitions. But his vision of universal comprehensives for the county was never realised.

As chairman of the governors of Bristol Polytechnic in the 1980s, he presided over an expansion in student numbers, from 3,000 to more than 20,000. In 1992, the polytechnic won university status.

Bob read extensively, was a keen gardener, a supporter of Gloucestershire cricket, and a devotee of live music. He enjoyed good food and wine, whether at home or on his travels abroad - he spoke several European languages. And he was resilient. With a sudden detached retina in his 70s, he "told them what was wrong, and told them what to do" - and, in weeks, he was driving again.

Bob Glendinning lived life with enjoyment and satisfaction, applying his values and principles in his political and public life. The first decision of the UWE's academic board was to propose an honorary doctorate for him. He was awarded the OBE and, three years ago, became the UWE's pro-chancellor.

He is survived by his wife and two daughters.

 Robert Hereward Glendinning, physician and educationalist, born April 25 1921; died March 8 2001

webTitle: Government is neglecting science, say charities

fields.headline: Government is neglecting science, say charities
fields.trailText: The world's biggest biomedical charity warns that donors will no longer tolerate funding basic research needs that are the government's responsibility.
fields.body:
Britain will lose its place in premier league science unless the government stops relying on charities to fund basic research staff and laboratories, said Dr Mike Dexter, director of the Wellcome Trust .

The world's biggest biomedical charity, which funded a third of the Human Genome Project, is warning that donors will no longer tolerate funding areas that are clearly the state's responsibility.

In a speech to the Save British Science Society at University College London Darwin Lecture Theatre tonight, Dr Dexter will call on the government to face up to the need to invest in science and criticise Labour's record in funding research facilities.

In the UK, 23% of all research and development is funded by charities, compared with just 9% in the US. A healthcheck of UK scientific research and development showed that state spending has dropped by 12.5% over the last decade, while the contribution of medical research charities has grown by nearly a third in the same period.

The Wellcome Trust supports between 10% and 20% of all public funded biomedical research in the UK, spending nearly £2m a day on funding. Over the next five years it plans to spend a total of £2.75bn. But, as university funding has now been squeezed, the trust has had to meet the costs of core staff salaries and building maintenance rather than new research.

"The medical research charities were not established to invest in equipment or bricks and mortar, but that is exactly what the lack of state funding has led us to do in recent years. Rather our mission is to help the state find cures for disease and to increase knowledge for the health benefit of humankind," Dr Dexter said.

"Charitable givers will, rightly, not tolerate their gift being spent on things that are clearly the responsibility of the state. Charities should not become a substitute for adequate state investment.

"It is a great shame that the present government has failed to act on the issue of providing sufficient funding for the running and maintenance of research facilities in universities. Tackling this issue must be an urgent priority for the next government."

Leading scientists and academics have supported Dr Dexter's view. Chief Executive of the Association of Medical Research Charities, Diana Garnham, said: "There is strong public and patient support for medical research in the UK. But if charities are to attract and retain good scientists to work on behalf of patients, the government must accept its responsibility to provide good conditions and state of the art equipment in our universities."

fields.standfirst: The international criminal court will not be the threat to the armed forces that some of its critics have feared
fields.trailText: The international criminal court will not be the threat to the armed forces that some of its critics have feared.
fields.body:
One of the advantages of the delayed elections is that the government will not have to shelve the bill for the international criminal court (ICC), which had its second reading in the Commons yesterday. The ICC has become controversial because, as the Guardian's Richard Norton-Taylor reported earlier this month, top military commanders are concerned that it might prosecute British soldiers for war crimes.

It would be absurd to suggest that there are no problems for the UK's or other states' armed forces, but these need to be kept in perspective.

Encompassing crimes committed in international and civil wars, and also genocide and crimes against humanity regardless of whether they are connected with a war, it basically consolidates existing provisions of international law. Nor is the possibility that UK citizens might be tried for such crimes in non-UK courts revolutionary. When Britain ratified the 1949 Geneva Conventions in 1957, and the Additional Protocol I in 1998, parliament accepted that any persons committing grave breaches could be brought to trial in the courts of any state party.

The underlying fear of all the critics is that since the ICC's sole purpose is prosecuting war crimes, and it will not be under the direct supervision of any national government, it may pursue cases without understanding the dilemmas faced by soldiers engaged in armed conflicts and peacekeeping operations. This perception of the law seems to be behind the concern of the "senior defence source" reported in the Guardian that future rules of engagement could prevent a British warship from attacking a hostile warship until it was too late. However, it is not obvious that the law prevents robust rules of engagement. My experience of lecturing to senior UK officers suggests that they take a positive view of the laws of war. In both the 1991 Gulf war and the 1999 Kosovo conflict, western armed forces found that the law assists in the professional and effective conduct of military operations.

In Kosovo, the actions of all the Nato forces were subject to the Yugoslav tribunal, which has stronger powers of investigation and prosecution than are provided for the ICC. Its committee to investigate the Nato bombing campaign published a detailed report last June recommending that no action needed to be taken. The Rome Statute, establishing the ICC contains numerous safeguards to ensure that the ICC will not shoot from the hip. Under Article 8, war crimes would generally not be prosecuted unless "committed as part of a plan or policy or as part of a large-scale commission of such crimes". Article 16 enables the UN security council to defer an ICC investigation or prosecution. Article 17 provides that a case is inadmissible where a state is genuinely carrying out an investigation or prosecution itself.

In reality, for Britain and other states, the main effect of the ICC may be to encourage the effective operation of national procedures. One particular worry raised in the Lords debate about the bill was that the Rome Statute's definitions of war crimes include "subjective phrases", such as "intentionally" launching an attack "in the knowledge" that it will cause excessive damage. However, such words were included in treaties precisely to protect soldiers from prosecution where civilian deaths were clearly not intended.

As the table suggests, the ICC is likely to deal as much with episodes in which civilians and prisoners of war are murdered and mistreated by those who have them in their power as with combat operations. That has been the pattern of many major efforts at international justice, including the Nuremberg tribunal of 1945-6 and the Yugoslav and Rwanda tribunals since 1993. One justification for this pattern is that the worst crimes are often those committed against defenceless individuals.

The biggest worry is that the US, with almost paranoid concerns about the prosecution of its soldiers, will not ratify the statute. For the ICC to work, US support is vital. The case of the Yugoslav tribunal is instructive: it only really became effective from 1995, when the US and allies got engaged on the ground in Bosnia. It is possible that the US will find a way to collaborate with the ICC: in practice, the US often observes provisions of treaties (including on the laws of war) that it has not ratified. The US armed forces do take the laws of war seriously, and are slightly more advanced than the UK in the preparation of a new tri-service manual taking account of the many new developments of the law.

The ICC bill before parliament is far from perfect. In the matter of jurisdiction it is actually more cautious than the 1957 Geneva Conventions Act. As currently worded, the bill applies only to UK residents. It should be amended so that the threat of being taken to the ICC can apply to all those present in the UK. Nevertheless, the bill merits support. This modest measure addressing a large problem - effective implementation of the laws of war - is compatible with the interests, traditions and existing legal obligations of the armed forces.

 Adam Roberts is Montague Burton professor of international relations at Oxford University and co-editor of Documents on the Laws of War, OUP

webTitle: Anger at head's letter on girl's weight

fields.headline: Anger at head's letter on girl's weight
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: A Gloucestershire primary school sparked a row with the parents of a five-year-old pupil yesterday after writing to them to warn that she was overweight.
fields.body:
A Gloucestershire primary school sparked a row with the parents of a five-year-old pupil yesterday after writing to them to warn that she was overweight.

The headteacher of the state school in Tewkesbury sent the letter after being told by a member of staff that the girl, who weighs around four and a half stone (29kg), had difficulty climbing in and out of the swimming pool.

But her parents said they were "disgusted" by the headteacher's action and claimed their daughter's size was "genetic".

The local education authority backed the head but admitted that the case was "unusual", while the National Union of Teachers said it had never come across another case involving concerns about a child's weight.

The identify of the girl and her family and the name of the school were yesterday being withheld.

The letter from the headteacher said: "As she is an active girl and is in many ways an energetic and fast mover, it has caused some concern that as she gets older she may develop a problem with her weight. I mention this out of concern and a knowledge that the school nurse will be visiting school soon and that she would be happy to give advice over diet and fitness if you wanted it."

But the girl's mother responded furiously: "She gets enough stick in the playground sometimes because she's quite big. But you don't expect to cop it from the headteacher as well. We thought it was out of order. There are children in the school bigger than my daughter and they haven't been sent letters."

The letter said the youngster had struggled climbing in and out of the swimming pool and doing some PE exercises. Her parents estimate her weight at about four and a half stone, but insist she is tall for her age.

The headteacher insisted the letter had not said the girl was fat but was reluctant to discuss the case. He said: "I won't comment on individual pupils. If her mum has any complaints, she is welcome to see me any time."

Sam Joffe, press officer for Gloucestershire county council, said: "This case is unusual because it is about a child's weight. But the headteacher acted quite properly by raising this issue in the approved manner directly with the parent. The parents have been offered help and advice with diet, and if they don't want to take that up, that is a matter for them."

It is understood that the child's weight had not been a particular issue until a teacher noticed that she was struggling to climb out of the swimming pool, and alerted the headteacher.

A spokeswoman for the National Union of Teachers said the union was not aware of any other cases involving a child being overweight, although teachers had a right to be concerned if it meant a child would be unable to participate in normal school activities.

fields.headline: Ginger cosies up to Catwoman
fields.trailText: Former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell is hoping to land a key role in the forthcoming film of Catwoman
fields.body:
Former spice girl Geri Halliwell is hoping to land a key role in the forthcoming Batman spin-off Catwoman according to reports from ananova this afternoon.

As reported in Monday's story, Ashley Judd has signed up to play the famous feline adversary of the caped crusader in a £50m feature for Warner Bros and Halliwell is keen to play Judd's trusty friend and adviser.

The 28-year-old singer, who lost out on a role in last years big screen version of Charlie's Angels, has apparently spent the last two years losing over two stone in weight to make her a more viable option with casting agents and producers in Hollywood.

A close friend told Ananova: "Geri is desperate to start work on some good movies as soon as possible. She has told her agents to concentrate on that above all else. She thinks this chance in Catwoman is tailor made for her."

Filming should get underway on the project later this year.

fields.headline: Profile: Matthew Griffiths
fields.trailText:
6pm: French Connection's new marketing director has walked straight into yet another row over the fcuk adverts. By Julia Day.
Apr 4: Enfant terrible has wrists slapped
See the TV advert here
Apr 3: Watchdog reins in FCUK
fields.body:
It is testament to how important Trevor Beattie is to French Connection's business that he interviewed Matthew Griffiths for the job of marketing director.

Mr Griffiths, 31, got the nod from Mr Beattie and, taking charge of French Connection's marketing this week, walked straight into yet another row over the cheeky four-letter-word advertising.

The ASA, exasperated with upholding complaints about the fcuk strapline, has consigned French Connection to having its adverts pre-vetted.

Quite a baptism of fire for Mr Griffiths - not that he appears concerned.

The epitome of the brand's laid-back image, he is taking it all in his stride.

"French Connection's cool, sexy image has been built through very powerful communications. There has been no attempt to offend people. The customers buy the clothes and love the imagery.

"My big challenge is to keep French Connection cool, sexy and exciting. The brand has a strong foundation, fantastic-looking stores and great product. The brand is not just about the advertising."

But fcuk isn't finished yet.

"The basic idea is really strong and still has room for interpretation," says Mr Griffiths.

It is hard to believe Mr Griffiths is new to the rag trade, he talks fluently about fashion, art, design, photography and haircare.

He has spent the past three years immersed in shampoo as senior product manager of L'Oreal's salon ranges and in marketing at Charles Worthington.

The shampoo years have undoubtedly given Mr Griffiths solid marketing experience.

But his previous three years at Habitat provide the key to his snaring the enviable French Connection job.

"I have a passion for retail, on the high street you can really engage and excite people and get close to consumers," he said.

But the nation's fashion victims are not the only people self-confessed shopaholic Mr Griffiths will be getting intimate with, he's on course for a close working relationship with the advertising industry watchdogs.

webTitle: 'The tide has turned in teacher recruitment'

fields.headline: 'The tide has turned in teacher recruitment'
fields.trailText: A 24% year-on-year rise in applications for teacher training courses showed that teaching was becoming a 'more attractive profession', education secretary David Blunkett said today.
fields.body:
A 24% year-on-year rise in applications for teacher training courses showed that teaching was becoming a "more attractive profession", education secretary David Blunkett said today. Higher starting salaries and the £7m Can Teach campaign have encouraged more graduates to consider the profession, according to figures released by the Graduate Teacher Training Registry today.

The number of graduates applying to train as primary and secondary teachers rose by almost a quarter last month, compared with March 2000. Secondary applications were up by 27%, with applications in the "shortage" subjects also rising. Maths applications were up by 20%, science by 36% and modern languages by 17%. The biggest jump was among those applying to train as technology teachers, with an 89% increase.

By the end of March, a total of 27,126 graduates had applied for initial teacher training.

In the past few months, the government has attempted to address teacher shortages with the lure of a £6,000 salary for trainees, £4,000 golden hellos for specialists in shortage subjects, an increased starting salary of up to £20,000 in inner London, the promise to pay off 10% of a teacher's student loan each year, and a TV and poster campaign with the strapline: "Those who can, teach." Mr Blunkett said that the rise had "turned the tide in teacher recruitment" now that the government was offering "real incentives for retaining new recruits. The introduction of Performance Related Pay offers further financial incentives for existing good classroom teachers to remain in the profession without having to take on managerial responsibilities.

"The addition of 570 further places on the Graduate Teacher Programme means that 2,250 postgraduates now have the opportunity to be trained and paid on the job whilst working towards their teaching qualification," he said.

Doug McAvoy, the general secretary of the National Union of Teachers (NUT), which opposes performance related pay and whose members have voted for "no-cover action" in schools experiencing teacher shortages, accused Mr Blunkett of spinning the figures. "These are young people keeping their options open - they have not yet trained to be teachers and they then have to be persuaded to enter the profession and that is a long way off."

fields.headline: Houllier tells Ziege to 'shut up'
fields.trailText: Gerard Houllier has continued his recent outspoken ways by telling Christian Ziege, the German international Houllier signed for £5.5m last summer, to "shut up".
fields.body:
Gerard Houllier has continued his recent outspoken ways by telling Christian Ziege, the German international Houllier signed for £5.5m last summer, to "shut up".

Ziege recently gave an interview on his personal website in which he complained about his lack of recent first team opportunities at Anfield. "I don't want to resign myself to playing in the reserves every week," he said. "I didn't come to Liverpool just to learn better English. I want to play football."

But this didn't go down well with Houllier who has revealed a stern authoritarian streak in his dealings with his players, notably Robbie Fowler, this season. "What he has said shows a lack of respect for the other players," the Frenchman said today. If he says he should play it shows a lack of respect for his colleagues."

But the Liverpool boss didn't stop there. "My advice to him is to shut up", he said. "He is not going to attract my attention by complaining in the media. He is not going to demonstrate his commitment by making such comments."

Houllier's advice for Ziege continues a purple patch for the Liverpool boss, who recently claimed the FA were treating his players "like horses" by forcing them to play out a congested fixture list.

This continued in a similar vein yesterday when his appeal to postpone Liverpool's Premiership fixture with Ipswich next week failed. "This is an unfair ruling which favours Ipswich," he said. "They obviously want Ipswich to be in the Champions League rather than Liverpool."

Even upon arriving in Barcelona this afternoon, ahead of tomorrow's Uefa Cup semi-final, Houllier still found time to complain. "Nobody seems to care about our Uefa Cup tie", he said. "Between the two legs of the semi-final we will have had to play four league games and an FA Cup semi-final. Nobody has ever had to do that. But we will cope, we will fight on."

webTitle: Gwyneth and Winona would kill for Chicago

fields.headline: Gwyneth and Winona would kill for Chicago
fields.trailText: Gwyneth Paltrow and Winona Ryder are the latest stars to have their names linked to the film of the long-running musical
fields.body:
After the news this morning of Gwyneth Paltrow's continued singing success in Australia, rumours have emerged that the 29-year-old actress is close to signing up to star alongside Winona Ryder in a £20m version of the stage musical Chicago.

According to ananova, the duo are "desperate" to team up in the lead roles of Roxy and Velma for Miramax films.

The Weinstein brothers, who own Miramax, are keen to get Paltrow on board for the project after she won an Oscar for her starring role in their 1999 film Shakespeare In Love

Not known for her singing prowess, senior sources close to the film believe Ryder could be the right co-star for Paltrow. "Winona is seen as the perfect foil for Gwyneth in every sense. Gwyneth already has a track record as a class-act singer and has topped the charts in Australia. Winona is the one with it all to do in that department."

The film of the sexy musical, which tells the story of two nightclub dancers who kill their lovers and become the centre of a media spectacle, is due to go into production next spring.

fields.headline: Analysis: the matron
fields.trailText: Matron has come a long way since the 18th century when she might earn £10 a year, plus beer allowance, and £5 bonus for "good behaviour".
fields.body:
Matron has come a long way since the 18th century when she might earn £10 a year, plus beer allowance, and £5 bonus for "good behaviour".

The high point of matron was probably the mid-20th century, when she patrolled wards and ruled nurses, domestics, and patients with iron discipline - although rarely had any real power over the strategic running of the hospital.

The NHS matron became indelibly associated with the formidable character played by the late actress Hattie Jacques in the 1960s film Carry on Doctor.

In 1966, however, matron was abolished, as nursing fashion shifted to a less rigid and hierarchical approach.

By the 1990s, the decline in public confidence in the NHS was accompanied by frequent calls - particularly from delegates at Tory party conferences - for the health service to "bring back matron" in order to raise standards.

Ironically, the Tories never took the opportunity to bring back matron during 18 years in charge of the NHS from 1979 to 1997, maintaining that it was up to local trusts to adopt the name "if appropriate".

Health secretary Alan Milburn's decision to bring back matron reflects widespread public support for someone who they see as able to cut through NHS bureaucracy and ensure wards are clean and patients are treated with respect and dignity - a person they associate with "matron".

Matrons will be essentially ward sisters with extra responsibilities including the management of ward level budgets for cleaning, catering and general ward environment.

Mr Milburn says the modern matron will have the following:

 To lead by example
Matron will lead the nursing team in groups of wards. They will demonstrate to other nurses the high standards NHS patients can expect;

 To make sure patients get quality care
Matron will be responsible for driving up the standards of care, ensuring continuous improvement in nursing care, making sure every patient gets quality care;

 To make sure the wards are clean
Matron will have the power to withhold payments to cleaning companies if cleaning standards are not met. They will oversee the standards of cleanliness of each of the wards in their charge;

 To make sure the food is good
Matron will have the power to withhold payments to catering companies if standards of catering are not up to scratch. They will ensure patients get their meals and are able to eat them and that the nutritional needs of all patients are met;

 To make sure elderly patients are treated with respect
Matron will have the power to ensure nurses and other NHS staff treat elderly patients with respect at all times. For example, matron will ensure elderly patients are addressed as they wish - using Mr or Mrs rather than more familiar first names;

 To improve the wards for patients
Matron will oversee the spending of ward budgets. Each ward sister has a budget of £5000 to improve the ward environment which nurses control. Matron will see that nurses do have the say over how this is spent and that ward budgets lead to real improvements for patients;

 To resolve problems for patients and their relatives
Matron will work with the new Patients Advocacy and Liaison Service to resolve patient problems on the spot. They will be highly visible, with the authority to get things done;

 To prevent and control hospital-acquired infection
Matron will ensure that the highest standards for preventing and controlling infection are set and met on every ward;

 To make sure nurses have more power
Matron will ensure nurses have the power to order tests, admit and discharge patients, run clinics, triage patients and, where appropriate, prescribe medicines.

fields.headline: The Media Edge promotes Courtier
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: The WPP-owned media agency, has promoted Charles Courtier to global chief executive, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Media Edge, the WPP-owned media agency, has promoted Charles Courtier to global chief executive as part of a management reshuffle.

Mr Courtier, who was previously managing director of Europe, the Middle East and Africa, replaces Beth Gordon who becomes global chairwoman. He will relocate to the company's global headquarters in New York.

Hans Germeraad, managing director of the internet agency IMP, will take over from Mr Courtier as head of the Media Edge in Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

"Charles was instrumental in the development of the strategy to launch the Media Edge across the EMEA region and doubled revenues for the region in two years," said Ms Gordon.

"I know that he is an extremely able and inspirational leader and one who is ideally suited to take the Media Edge to the next stage. I look forward to working with him as the company continues to grow," she added.

The Media Edge is the world's third-biggest media agency with clients including UDV, Colgate-Palmolive and Ericsson.

webTitle: What the Chinese media are saying

fields.headline: What the Chinese media are saying
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: In the leaden prose of government news media everywhere, China's newspapers and agencies are pumping out the official line without deviation.
fields.body:
In the leaden prose of government news media everywhere, China's newspapers and agencies are pumping out the official line without deviation.

Thus the Xinhua news agency says in its latest wrap-up of the situation that "Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan Wednesday summoned U.S. Ambassador to China Joseph Prueher, lodging another solemn representation with the U.S. side over the air collision incident on April 1. Tang said that the United States should bear full responsibility for the incident and apologise to China."

The People's Daily offers much the same pre-digested fare. But it has a bonus: readers' talk boards that are filled with nationalist rants from American posters as well as Chinese ones.

Amid the abuse is this poignant message: "American media is flooded today with interviews of worried families of the American crew. It is right for us to accuse them of showing more concern for their surviving crew than our downed pilot, but it is the natural thing to care only for any one's own loved ones. Instead, on our own part, except for a few words on the search effort, there is no mentioning of the pilot's family on our state media. How can we ask the Americans to pay more attention to our plight when we ourselves don't seem to care enough?"

The smart website of China Radio International dutifully repeats the officially sanctioned line that President Jiang Zemin has urged every effort to be made to rescue the downed Chinese pilot. It also reveals in its latest update that the assistant foreign minister, Zhou Wenzhong, has summoned US ambassador Joseph Prueher for a second time and reiterated China's demand for an apology.

The report goes on to confirm, in so many words, that Chinese experts are going over the spy plane with a fine toothcomb: "He (Zhou) also said China has a right to investigate any airborne vehicle which intrudes into Chinese airspace and lands at a Chinese airport without permission."

In Hong Kong, where there is more freedom to report and comment, the South China Morning Post has the tiniest of exclusives, about the first stirrings of anti-American street protest: "In Beijing, witnesses saw military police turn away three protesters carrying China's flag near the US ambassador's residence in the first known anti-US demonstration of the crisis in the city. Two men and a woman, described by witnesses as students, were stopped by at least seven Chinese military police on the road near the residence and left peacefully."

fields.headline: Alabama 3, the urban cowboys of acid house
fields.standfirst:
Alabama 3
Underworld, London
****
fields.trailText:
Alabama 3
Underworld, London
****
fields.body:
Alabama 3's cult status is something of a mystery. Their growling single Woke Up This Morning is the theme of the US gangster drama The Sopranos. The Brixton-based sextet should be famous, but the world has remained impervious to their charms.

Perhaps the witty conceit behind the band's acid house-goes-Nashville sound - that dance music's relentless chug bears unwitting similarities to country and western's hillbilly stomp - has commercial limitations. Sadly, Hank Williams fans are rarely fond of house. The problem is compounded when the band playing such an eclectic hybrid look like gnarled inhabitants of an Irvine Welsh novel.

They may lack glamour, but the Alabama 3 have star quality. They give good copy (singer Rob Spragg, a former heroin addict, claims to have met his fellow members in rehab) and come complete with a raft of good ideas, including ludicrous stage personae (Spragg becomes Larry Love). This show was the last in a four-week residency that highlighted country, gospel and techno with a mix of enthusiasm and irony.

The gospel event starred the gay soul singer David McAlmont, famously exorcised by Pentecostal parents keen to "cure" their son's sexuality. McAlmont was among a cast of guest vocalists, rappers and musicians whose numbers eventually make the tiny stage as crowded as the capacity audience. Inexplicably, a burly, extravagantly tattooed man stands motionless stage left throughout.

It is a sight as strange and unique as Alabama 3's music, a chaotic mass of juddering bass, techno squelches and country-rock solos, topped with Spragg's rumbling croon and co-vocalist Jake Black's hyperactive ranting. Songs come shot through with a shockingly black humour. Hypo Full of Love scabrously parodies Narcotics Anonymous, while during Mao Tse Tung Said, Spragg organises an air-punching audience salute to the murderous cult leader Jim Jones. It is testament to the band's rare skill as showmen that they can cloak such sentiments in an ebullient party atmosphere. But there is also the sense that Alabama 3's failure to trouble the charts may have its roots here: their vision is too harsh for cosy mass consumption.

Or perhaps the reasons are more prosaic. Midway through the show an accordionist staggers onstage wearing a T-shirt that proclaims: "Our record company sucks." The band applaud knowingly. Either way, the wider world's ignorance of the Alabama 3 is the wider world's loss.

· Alabama 3 are at the Liquid Room, Edinburgh (0131-225 2564), tomorrow, then tour.

webTitle: Bridget Jones was my work-experience girl

fields.headline: Bridget and me
fields.standfirst: Renée Zellweger did three weeks' work in a London publishing firm to prepare for her part as Bridget Jones. Camilla Elworthy describes what it was like to have a Hollywood star doing her photocopying
fields.trailText: Renée Zellweger did three weeks' work in a London publishing firm to prepare for her part as Bridget Jones. Camilla Elworthy describes what it was like to have a Hollywood star doing her photocopying.
fields.body:
Picture the scene: it's a rainy March Monday morning (bad), you're on your way to work (bad but unavoidable) and when you get to your office, you find that you are sharing it with a Hollywood actress (surreal). And she doesn't even have the good grace to conform to all the usual stereotypes: rather, she is clever, funny, down to earth, modest and effortlessly beautiful - not a scrap of make-up in sight. Yes, for the best part of three weeks, I shared my office with Renée Zellweger, working incognito for me in preparation for her role as Bridget Jones. Office life has never been so entertaining - or so weird.

As the publisher of Bridget Jones's Diary, Picador was always going to be the natural nine-to-five home for Renée, who wanted to spend time familiarising herself with the publishing environment and to try out her English accent. I was approached to act as Renée's boss. "Please do give her lots of work to do. She just wants to blend into the background and it will be no different from having a work experience person around," one of the film's producers blithely told me. Yeah, right, I thought. I felt nervous about her arrival but her first words set the tone: "Gosh, you're much younger and prettier than I thought you would be!" - the first and, no doubt, the last time anyone will say that to me. She wasn't what I had anticipated - scrubbed, unaffected and dressed in neat, casual clothes, she fitted in straight away. We came up with a plan: she would be Bridget Cavendish, Bridget for obvious reasons and Cavendish as she was to be passed off as the sister of Jonathan Cavendish, a friend of one of our company chairmen. That last bit at least is true and no one was to know that Jonathan Cavendish was one of the film's producers.

So she settled down to the daily round of answering the phones (and the way she says "Hello - publicity" in the film has an eerily familiar ring to it), ringing round the unsuspecting literary editors of national newspapers about various forthcoming publications, a smattering of photocopying and going through the newspapers for any book-related stories. This meant she had, more than once, to cut out incendiary tabloid stories fuming that "our Bridget" was to be played by an American. She kept her cool, but did scribble "Rubbish" in the margins of one particularly fanciful piece.

No one took much notice of Bridget, the latest in a long line of work-experience people. The first glitch came on her first day proper in the office: her manager in New York sent her a lavish bouquet of long-stemmed roses, care of me, to wish her well in her new job. A nice touch, but tricky to explain away. Everyone assumed, of course, that they were for me, and as I blushingly stumbled to account for them, enquirers drifted off convinced that I either had a loaded admirer, or a few days to live, or possibly both. During one particularly persistent line of questioning, Renée just said mischievously, "Actually, Camilla's pregnant; didn't you know?", thereby mercifully defusing the situation.

She and I were also a little alarmed to see that an American student who happened to be on a week's placement with us at that time had her nose stuck in a copy of the film tie-in edition of One True Thing, which Renée had starred in. But apart from the odd sidelong glance, she didn't seem to make the connection. I had to take just one person into my confidence: a colleague in the press office whom I overheard saying on more than one occasion: "Don't you think Bridget looks just like the girl from Jerry Maguire?" I quietly explained that there was a very good reason for that and hissed at her to shut up. She hadn't for a moment thought that it was her - what on earth would she be doing photocopying in Victoria?

So convincing was Renée's act that, after one meeting at which she had made some valuable contributions, our deputy publisher, Maria Rejt, no less, remarked on how impressive she was and said that we should try to find a job for her if she was serious about getting into publishing. I nodded vigorously, but said I wasn't sure what her plans were. Hmm. Renée helped me at a book launch and went unnoticed by the many journalists also there and attended a packed bookshop reading in Piccadilly, spotted only by an eagle-eyed, yet incredulous, colleague who had been off sick, who told me she had come up in the lift with Renée Zellweger; nothing slips past her.

At lunchtime, Renée would be whisked away in a chauffeur-driven car with her voice coach to a smart restaurant for a calorie-laden lunch in her De Niro-esque bid to pile on the pounds. In the meantime, I would grab a salad or a sandwich at my desk and find myself half a stone heavier when she got back, looking as sickeningly tiny as ever. We were both aspiring to the very normal weight about which Bridget Jones complains in the diary, but just approaching it from different ends of the scales.

So after three weeks of helping me out, Renée swapped the life of office drudgery to return to her normal life of being a film star. When the news broke several months later that she had worked undercover at Picador, I had the wonderful task of enlightening my blissfully ignorant colleagues as to who Bridget, the rather posh-sounding and gorgeous work-experience person, really was. It was like your best ever "What I did in the school holidays to the power of 10". A Mexican wave of jaw-dropping swept through the offices.

Renée sent me a thankyou letter and gift after she'd gone and I have seen her a few times since then. She invited me on to the film set one day (where she performed the most wonderful and generous act that one woman can do for another: she introduced me to Colin Firth). She informed me that I had to stick around and be an extra and made sure that I was put somewhere that I would be seen, viz next to Jeffrey Archer, not a spot to which I would usually gravitate. As a result, half my head can be seen for half a nano-second in the launch party scene; not, perhaps, the full Warholian quota of fame, but my mum's quite excited. Renée also got me invited to the royal charity premiere of The Grinch, her erstwhile fiancé Jim Carrey's last film, where I sat in tiara-touching proximity to Her Majesty, and all for having graciously allowed a Hollywood superstar to do my filing. And I'm off to the premiere of Bridget Jones' Diary tonight to see the film again - and I would happily watch it another 10 times: it is fantastic and Renée's performance will put paid to any residual xenophobic quibbles people might have about an American playing that sacred role. She is brilliant.

Just for the record, I would be more than happy to repeat the whole experience with any other global superstars wishing to brush up on their admin skills - an application from Russell Crowe would be particularly welcome.

 Bridget Jones's Diary is released on April 13. The film tie-in book is published by Picador, priced £6.99. Camilla Elworthy is head of publicity at Picador

When the news broke several months later that she had worked undercover at Picador, I had the wonderful task of enlightening my blissfully ignorant colleagues as to who Bridget, the rather posh-sounding and gorgeous work-experience person, really was. It was like your best ever "What I did in the school holidays to the power of 10". A Mexican wave of jaw-dropping swept through the offices. Renée sent me a thankyou letter and gift after she'd gone and I have seen her a few times since then. She invited me on to the film set one day (where she performed the most wonderful and generous act that one woman can do for another: she introduced me to Colin Firth). She informed me that I had to stick around and be an extra and made sure that I was put somewhere that I would be seen, viz next to Jeffrey Archer, not a spot to which I would usually gravitate. As a result, half my head can be seen for half a nano-second in the launch party scene; not, perhaps, the full Warholian quota of fame, but my mum's quite excited. Renée also got me invited to the royal charity premiere of The Grinch, her erstwhile fiancé Jim Carrey's last film, where I sat in tiara-touching proximity to Her Majesty, and all for having graciously allowed a Hollywood superstar to do my filing. And I'm off to the premiere of Bridget Jones' Diary tonight to see the film again - and I would happily watch it another 10 times: it is fantastic and Renée's performance will put paid to any residual xenophobic quibbles people might have about an American playing that sacred role. She is brilliant. Just for the record, I would be more than happy to repeat the whole experience with any other global superstars wishing to brush up on their admin skills - an application from Russell Crowe would be particularly welcome.  Bridget Jones's Diary is released on April 13. The film tie-in book is published by Picador, priced £6.99. Camilla Elworthy is head of publicity at Picador

fields.headline: United flattened by late Sergio
fields.standfirst:
Paulo Sergio 86
Minute-by-minute match report
fields.trailText: Manchester United's chances of making further progress in this season's Champions League now look slim indeed. A goal from a substitute, Paulo Sergio, four minutes from the end brought Bayern Munich the victory which could well take the German champions to the semi-finals.
fields.body:
Manchester United's chances of making further progress in this season's Champions League now look slim indeed. A goal from a substitute, Paulo Sergio, four minutes from the end brought Bayern Munich the victory which could well take the German champions to the semi-finals.

Thomas Linke came off the bench to hit the bar with a fierce volley in the 82nd minute and four minutes later he nodded a high ball from Stefan Effenberg across the goalmouth and Paulo Sergio popped up on the right to beat Fabien Barthez.

In football, familiarity breeds not so much contempt as a wary mutual respect. If the three Champions League encounters United had had with Bayern two seasons ago, the last in the final at Nou Camp, should have taught Ferguson's team anything it was to expect the unexpected while taking nothing for granted.

Last night's match stirred memories of the way Manchester United had come from behind in Barcelona to win the 1999 European Cup in stoppage-time, leaving Bayern prostrate amid tears of disbelief, but Old Trafford also needed to remember that earlier in the same tournament the Germans had denied United a win in Munich with a goal in the last minute. Moreover Bayern shared a 1-1 draw in Manchester that season. The ease with which Hasan Salihamidzic, Bayern's Bosnian midfielder, sidestepped Mikael Silvestre in the opening seconds offered Old Trafford an immediate reminder of the possibilities.

Ryan Giggs, though, was an influence from the start and with David Beckham soon drifting towards the middle, combining with Roy Keane and Paul Scholes to outmanouevre Stefan Effenberg and Jens Jeremies, United forced a succession of corners in the opening quarter of an hour.

There was an assured snap about United's passing which gnawed away at the locks and bolts of Bayern's cover. After 17 minutes a shrewdly judged lob from Beckham found Andy Cole in space in the penalty area and a goal beckoned. But the ball was a long time coming down and Cole's attempt at a volley bounced over the bar.

Five minutes later Beckham fouled Effenberg and was duly booked and is out of the match back at the Olympic stadium. United's chagrin was hardly eased when Bayern lost Salihamidzic for the return after he brought down Giggs just before the half-hour.

A further attempt by Effenberg to incriminate Beckham brought the Bayern captain a caution for diving. A proliferation of bookings, however, was less of a concern for United than the way the match was heading.

Amid the cautions Mehmet Scholl's centre from the left had grazed the head of Silvestre and fallen to Carsten Jancker, whose shot was too weak to bother Fabien Barthez but caused Old Trafford hearts to miss a beat. Yet so long as United maintained their at tacking they would always be the more likely to score. By half-time, however, their best opportunity, a through ball from Cole, which offered Ole Gunnar Solskjaer a clear run from the centre circle, had been thwarted by Patrik Andersson's covering tackle.

Naturally, for Bayern, the longer the scoreless state of affairs continued the happier they would be. In fact the second half opened with Effenberg dipping a 20-yard free-kick over the United bar, Beckham-fashion, and personal relations between the pair continued to deteriorate.

What was not deteriorating, however, was the quality of Bayern's movements. Not a lot had been seen of Giovane Elber, their Brazilian striker, but within five minutes of the second half starting his shot skimmed the bar after Effenberg and Scholl had created space between Jaap Stam and Wes Brown.

Soon afterward Scholes's persistence in possession enabled him to find Cole to his left. Cole's return pass was true but Scholes could not quite get the control he needed for a shot.

Nevertheless, the amount of space Effenberg was finding whenever he brought the ball forward was a measure of the risks United were taking in order to gain the lead. After 61 minutes they did glimpse a goal when Oliver Kahn could only parry a long, low drive from Silvestre, leaving Cole to lay the ball back to Scholes. Before Scholes could shoot, however, he was tackled by Scholl.

A tight, absorbing encounter took a further twist as Barthez was forced to fling himself high to his left to keep out a rising shot from Jeremies.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; G Neville, Stam, Brown, Silvestre; Beckham, Keane, Scholes, Giggs; Solskjaer, Cole.

Bayern Munich (4-3-1-2): Kahn; Linke, Kuffour, Andersson, Lizarazu; Salihamidzic, Jeremies, Effenberg; Scholl (Paulo Sergio); Elber, Jancker (Zickler, 69).

Referee: A J Lopez Nieto (Spain).
