fields.headline: Sick men of Europe
fields.standfirst:
Britons have been sneering at foreigners. But now it's we who are being patronised by Europeans

Special report: race issues in the UK
Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: Britons have been sneering at foreigners. But now it's we who are being patronised by Europeans.
fields.body:
It's a bit rich, isn't it? Europe, home to Jörg Haider and Jean-Marie Le Pen, scolding us for being the most racist nation of the bunch. Who are the Germans - longtime deniers of citizenship to Turkish gastarbeiten, even those born in the country - to declare our attitude to refugees and asylum seekers the worst in Europe? Where do the French, whose casual harassment of non-whites is noticed by every black traveller across the Channel, get off scolding us? Who made the Danes, with a scarily energetic rightwing of their own, the PC-police of the continent?

That would be one way of dealing with the latest European assault on Britain, yesterday's report from the Council of Europe diagnosing a "particularly acute" form of racism here. We could protest that we're no worse than everyone else. Or we might slay the messenger, noting that the council is a glorified talking shop unrelated to the European Union, whose reports are usually consigned to the filing cabinet of history. We might tease the council's investigators, who came here nearly a year ago for a grand total of four days.

All those lines of attack are open, and every one of them was taken by politician and pundit alike yesterday. But there is another, less predictable response: we can listen. We can pause for a second and see ourselves the way our neighbours see us. We may be in for an unpleasant surprise.

So we might listen to the council's claim that we tend to think of economic migrants not as people seeking a better life - which is admirable - but as parasites and "criminals trying to sneak into our country". We might consider, and not dismiss, the EU's racism and xenophobia monitoring unit in Vienna, which last month ranked Britain, of all the 15 member states, as the nation most hostile to political refugees.

We might decide that, judging by our present form, the Europeans have got us about right. Just last week we had outgoing Tory MPs John Townend and Christopher Gill offer up a double-act of Powellite xenophobia and stale, halitotic bigotry. No sooner had Townend sung the praises of old Enoch, lamenting that "Commonwealth immigration" had undermined our "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society," than Gill was backing him up. Rising numbers of asylum seekers were causing a "rats in a bucket syndrome", diluting our national character. "If you pour enough water on a double scotch," he said, "it ceases to taste like whisky."

Since neither of these men were denied the Conservative whip in the Commons, we can fairly conclude that William Hague sees no great contradiction between their views and parliamentary service for his party. And why should he? Did not Hague authorise a leaflet for last year's local elections warning of "bogus asylum seekers... flooding" our shores? Did he not raise the alarm recently about Britain becoming a "foreign land"?

So maybe the Euro-inspectors were not so wrong about us after all. But there is a juicier irony here, juicier even than the notion of a continent which houses the Freedom party and the Front Nationale ordering us to clean up our act. It is that, after years of putting up with British Euroscepticism, Europe is finally getting its own back.

Call it Britoscepticism. From the European heads of government furious with a British agriculture which has, once again, infected the continent with disease, to a foreign press that has branded our country Plague Island, our neighbours seem set to make Eurosceptic dreams come true. The British right-wing always longed for Britain to break from the continent; now, apparently, the continent wants shot of us.

It's not just the headlines announcing the Katastrophe of the Animalisches Inferno - though medieval images of pyres and burning flesh have fattened up foreign news bulletins for a month and half now. Our neighbours have connected our latest crisis, over foot and mouth, with a deeper malaise.

We are, they say, the "sick man of Europe," the "septic isle". For them, foot and mouth is not an isolated, freakish episode but part of a continuum - with BSE the defining event. It is because of mad cow disease, which did have lethal implications for humans, that foreigners have assumed the worst about F&M - even thought the worst damage F&M might inflict on a person would be a cold sore. It's no wonder that NBC News warns Americans of "the killer disease now stalking Britain - and how we can stop it coming here". When it comes to food safety, we are not trusted: we have previous.

But the problem is deeper still. Foreign observers are linking foot and mouth not only with our agricultural plight, but with the very way we function as a society. Italy's L'Espresso cited our stubborn rates of poverty, the Hatfield rail disaster and the Real IRA's ongoing campaign of bombing, as well as the animal epidemics, as proof that Britain was a nation under a "curse". Doubtless they will now be adding the return of tuberculosis, disclosed yesterday, to their list.

Thomas Keilinger of Germany's Die Welt writes of the parlous state of our public services, particularly the hospitals and railways. One despatch announced that Britain is "slowly disappearing in the mire of the real-existing chaos".

Keilinger has told his readers of our lack of patriotism, the vacuity of the dome, the winter floods and our appalling weather. Germans are Anglophiles, he says, but they need to temper their fondness with the truth about this country.

"I think we felt that, after Thatcherism, Britain was a shining example of America-style, go-getting entrepreneurial savvy. Now we realise there is so much that is still creaky... the Thatcher revolution left whole swaths of society destitute, struggling to survive." He has said that, after the Russians, the British may be the longest-suffering populace in the world - prepared to put up with sub-standard services when others would have revolted against them decades ago.

Of course, there is some journalistic hyperbole here, as there would be if the roles were reversed. But it's hard not to see a warning. For years, we were like the old wartime headline-writer who decided that, since the Channel was fog-bound, the continent was cut off - not us. For years, we assumed that Britain was the great catch, with Europe the pushy suitor desperate for our hand. The Eurosceptic case rested on a British arrogance which saw our participation in the EU as a kind of favour to those grasping, desperate continentals.

Now we can see that the true situation may be the other way around. Having heard our press and politicians pour scorn and disdain on them for generations, the Europeans are exacting their revenge. They are seeing Britain as Europe's sick man, a charity case which needs their help. When the time finally comes for Tony Blair to make good his promise to be "at the heart of Europe," he may find the dynamic has changed. Far from welcoming him in as a young, energetic saviour, the neighbours might offer him a look of pity and a cup of sweetened tea - but only after he's wiped his feet in a trough of disinfectant.

webTitle: University jobs figures reveal racial bias

fields.headline: University jobs figures reveal racial bias
fields.standfirst:
Special report: race issues in the UK
Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Most students find work quickly after leaving university regardless of where they study, but black and Asian graduates still face discrimination from employers, according to an official report out today.
fields.body:
Most students find work quickly after leaving university regardless of where they study, but black and Asian graduates still face discrimination from employers, according to an official report out today.

Of last year's graduates, 94.1% were in work or further training or study by January 3 this year, the higher education funding council for England records.

But for black African graduates the figure was 87%, for black Caribbean graduates 90.7%, and for Bangladeshi and Pakistani graduates 88.4% and 89% respectively. Employment or study rates among whites were higher than average, 94.6%. Women were more likely to be employed than men (95.3% compared with 92.6%).

Lady Blackstone, the higher education minister, said: "Graduates from ethnic minorities have significantly lower employment rates than white graduates. This is an unacceptable situation in respect of equality and because it is a waste of the nation's talent."

She urged universities to offer more careers advice to individual students.

Chris Myant, spokesman for the commission for racial equality, said: "The old argument that black and Asian people don't get jobs because they don't have skills is masking a degree of discrimination in the area of skilled work which is particularly pernicious."

Some new universities out perform traditional colleagues. Luton, which is having to make academic staff redundant this year, boasts a 100% employment rate. Natfhe, the lecturers' union, said the figures were a vindication of the former polytechnics. Some 68.4% of 2000 graduates were in paid work.

"New university lecturers receive only two-thirds of the teaching income of their old university counterparts but still manage to turn out highly employable, capable graduates," said its general secretary, Paul Mackney. Oxford University has a 95% employment and study rate and Cambridge 98%.

HEFCE has produced "benchmark" figures for comparison - the proportion of graduates it would have expected each institution to have in work or further study, based on entry, social background, degree classification and other factors. Brunel, Hull, Kent, Loughborough, Luton, Nottingham Trent, Aberdeen, and Napier in Edinburgh do better than their benchmark.

But Cumbria College of Art and Design, Falmouth College of Arts, and the universities of East London, Harper Adams in Shropshire, Leeds Metropolitan, Liverpool John Moores, London Guildhall, Salford, South Bank, Sussex, Paisley, Swansea and Aberystwyth do worse.

Of the 207,234 British-based graduates last year, 81% took part in the study, although response rates did vary widely. Critically, the study did not show the type or income of jobs the graduates went into.

A spokesman for the University of Warwick said: "Warwick worked hard to produce a 93% response rate for this exercise - the third highest response rate across all the institutions measured. We need not have bothered to work so hard - if there had have been a national lottery style lucky dip box to tick instead we could all have done that and achieved an equally meaningful result which wasted a lot less of everyone's time."

There is also some variation between subject areas. Some 99.5% of medicine, dentistry and veterinary science graduates are employed or in further study; so too are 94.2% of maths graduates. Music and drama graduates are above the national average at 94.3%.

But computer science (91.8%) and engineering and technology (92.8%) graduates are all surprisingly below the average.

A spokesman for the University of Warwick said: "Warwick worked hard to produce a 93% response rate for this exercise - the third highest response rate across all the institutions measured. We need not have bothered to work so hard - if there had have been a national lottery style lucky dip box to tick instead we could all have done that and achieved an equally meaningful result which wasted a lot less of everyone's time." There is also some variation between subject areas. Some 99.5% of medicine, dentistry and veterinary science graduates are employed or in further study; so too are 94.2% of maths graduates. Music and drama graduates are above the national average at 94.3%. But computer science (91.8%) and engineering and technology (92.8%) graduates are all surprisingly below the average. webTitle: Asians tell of abuse on race murder estate

fields.headline: Asians tell of abuse on race murder estate
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Neighbours of an Asian father of two stabbed to death in a suspected hate attack yesterday told of the racist abuse the man and his wife suffered on an east London council estate.
fields.body:
Neighbours of an Asian father of two stabbed to death in a suspected hate attack yesterday told of the racist abuse the man and his wife suffered on an east London council estate.

Police say Shiblu Rahman, 34, was attacked on Sunday morning in Bow by at least three white men believed to be in their late teens or early 20s.

His family say Mr Rahman, who bled to death after being stabbed seven times, might have lived if an ambulance had not taken more than 30 minutes to arrive. They also accused police of a string of errors that added to the family's misery.

Mr Rahman was stabbed yards from his flat on the Lincoln estate in Tower Hamlets at around 12.30am after driving home from a Romford restaurant where he worked as a chef.

He managed to stumble home before collapsing in front of his wife, Noma, 27. He told her he had been stabbed by three local white youths.

The couple had two girls, one four and one five months.

Mr Rahman, a devout Muslim, and his wife had complained to a neighbour about a group of youths aged as young as 15 who had terrified them.

Yesterday the only other Bangladeshi family on the block said that within hours of the murder they too had been threatened.

Parvin Chowdhury, 33, said she had left her flat at 4.30pm on Sunday afternoon when she saw a youth: "I went outside on my own. I saw a boy aged about 15 to 16. he had a lager can in his hand. He came a couple of yards from me, looked at me and said, 'You are next.' From what he said I thought I would be the next to be killed."

Mrs Chowdhury and her husband, Malik, heard the last screams of Mr Rahman. Mr Chowdhury said: "I heard him saying in Bengali, 'hai, hai', which means 'what are you doing'. Then I heard him say 'oh Allah' - oh my God."

Mrs Chowdhury heard two girls laughing outside her window but the couple, who say they have suffered such severe harassment from youths on the estate that they want to leave, were too scared to go outside.

He added that police had taken a statement from him on Monday. The interview had lasted 30 minutes, but Mr Chowdhury said he was not asked if he or his wife had heard anything, and whether they or the Rahmans had suffered racism or harassment: "If asked I would have told them. I'm not looking to get involved."

The family also criticised the police for stopping Mr Rahman's brothers-in-law from entering the flat to comfort him and his distraught wife. They are also angry because no family member was allowed into the ambulance for the 10-minute drive to hospital. They say his wife was stopped from being by his bedside before he died.

The family said the police had barred them from taking Mr Rahman to hospital themselves. They say Mrs Rahman had to ring twice for the ambulance, which took 45 minutes to arrive.

Scotland Yard said officers at the scene had not felt it right to take the dying man to hospital themselves: "Only in exceptional circumstances should police transport be used to convey a person to hospital. Officers on the scene did not feel that this was the case." The force added they were treating the murder as racial.

The family called for an investigation into the handling of the case by the police and ambulance service.

Mr Rahman's murder was the fourth in Tower Hamlets in the past month.

webTitle: Poker man Bush must learn to play chess with Jiang

fields.headline: Poker man Bush must learn to play chess with Jiang
fields.standfirst: Fallout from the spy plane affair can only be contained if the US and Chinese presidents manage to reconcile their very differing approaches to international relations
fields.trailText: Fallout from the spy plane affair can only be contained if the US and Chinese presidents manage to reconcile their very differing approaches to international relations
fields.body:
China's apparent determination to exploit the US spy plane affair threatens to turn a relatively minor incident into a definitive event in relations between the two countries.

Instead of returning the 24 crew of the EP-3 spy plane, and the plane itself, China's President Jiang Zemin has chosen to demand a public apology and an end to US airborne surveillance of his country's coastline.

The Beijing foreign ministry has even gone so far as to threaten, obliquely, that the crew could be put on trial and "punished".

These demands and threats are politically unacceptable to the Bush administration. The Chinese must know that. But by upping the ante, they may be hoping to win concessions in other areas.

One such "concession" would be a delay in, or even the scrapping of, new US arms sales to Taiwan. A decision on the sales is due this month and China has been lobbying furiously against the plan.

Another "concession" might, for example, be private US agreement not to press for a censure of China at the current meeting of the UN human rights commission in Geneva.

Perhaps Beijing believes it can use its moral advantage after the Hainan incident to influence negotiations on the terms of its entry into the World Trade Organisation.

And perhaps its military leaders see the affair as an ideal opportunity to test the mettle of America's new president while demonstrating the government's resolve to nationalist Chinese public opinion.

This Chinese approach is akin to a chess game. Some pieces move forward, some move back. Some are sacrificed for bigger gains elsewhere.

Unfortunately, Bush is not known as a chess player. He's from Texas. The game he knows is poker. In that kind of contest, a player raises the stakes, then raises them again, until an opponent either gives up or goes bust.

In other words, China runs a big risk of over-reaching itself in the aftermath of the Hainan affair. Mr Bush is still an unknown quantity. And his reaction could be simply to call China's bluff by escalating the confrontation.

US responses could range from a downgrading of diplomatic ties and the cancellation of Bush's scheduled visit to China this autumn to bilateral trade sanctions and an increased military presence in the Asia-Pacific region.

Given the growing anger in the Republican-led Congress, the US might expedite rather than delay arms transfers to Taiwan if China continues to refuse to send the plane and its crew home.

In other words, China's subtle and not so subtle gameplan may result in the very opposite result to that which it intends.

Remember that Bush already has a record of taking tough decisions swiftly: Iraq discovered that in February when he suddenly launched new bombing attacks. The Europeans and others discovered it too when he unexpectedly scrapped the Kyoto accord on global warming last month.

But even if China succeeds to a degree in humiliating Bush and forcing concessions, it may come to regret its triumph in time.

A fierce debate was raging in Washington over China policy before the Hainan incident blew up. Hawks such as the vice-president, Dick Cheney, and the Pentagon's Donald Rumsfeld want to take a much more robust approach than that espoused by the Clinton administration.

The secretary of state, Colin Powell, and others advocate a more conciliatory line, stressing engagement rather than confrontation.

A number of bilateral disputes, ranging from the US's national missile defence plans and its concerns over Beijing's role in weapons proliferation to China's detention of US-linked academics and its assistance to Iraq, have already demonstrated how great is the potential for a real downward dip in relations.

A US "defeat" over Hainan could prove to be a defeat for Powell, too, giving the advantage to the hawks.

Thus the lasting legacy of Hainan, if Beijing is not careful, could be a definitive, permanent tilt by the new US administration towards a much tougher policy on China on a whole range of fronts.

But as Bush studies his cards, he surely knows he must be very careful.

The US does not need a big new confrontation over Taiwan, for instance. In 1995-96, China fired missiles over the Taiwan Strait, forcing Bill Clinton to send to carrier-led naval battlegroups to the area.

Nor would US public opinion be impressed by a president who became embroiled in a menacing standoff with Beijing within three months of taking office. Questions would be asked about his judgment and competence as commander-in-chief.

Another big consideration is US security and commercial interests in the Asia-Pacific region as a whole. The grounded US spy plane was based in Okinawa, an uncomfortable reminder for the Japanese of the way their country can be compromised by US actions.

The US military presence in Japan is already controversial. Japan has its own difficult bilateral issues with China. A US confrontation with China could thus have a complicating, negative impact on US links with Tokyo - for which the Japanese would blame the Americans.

Much the same argument goes for South Korea, where the US also maintains a large military presence. Recent Bush statements on President Kim's "sunshine policy" of detente with Chinese-backed North Korea have been seen as less than totally helpful. More strains could develop with Seoul, too.

And then there is the unavoidable fact that the shipping lanes of the South China Sea are of great commercial importance to the US in terms of its trade and oil supplies. Continuing or escalating tension in the area could hit the US economy - as the Hainan-related selloff on Wall Street showed this week.

In short, both the US and China have very good reasons for not letting the Hainan affair get out of hand. Whether they manage to do that depends to a large extent on how good Bush is at chess and how good Jiang is at poker.

fields.headline: Express loses core newsmen
fields.trailText:
2pm: The three most senior staff on the Express newsdesk are taking voluntary redundancy, leaving a 29-year-old reporter in charge, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Click here for latest Express news
fields.body:
The three most senior staff on the Express newsdesk are taking voluntary redundancy, leaving a 29-year-old junior executive in charge of the desk, it was revealed today.

Head of news Sean Rayment, news editor Alan Qualtrough and number three Phillip Derbyshire have all resigned, leaving Daniel Townend as the only remaining staff member.

It is not believed that any of the three have jobs to go to, although all are said to be in negotiations with other newspapers and want to stay in journalism.

Mr Derbyshire, who was not available for comment, has worked for the Express for 18 years.

The journalists are among a number of Express staff who have opted to take voluntary redundancy from the paper following the announcement by Richard Desmond that he planned to make 145 staff redundant.

Last week it emerged that two of the Express and the Sunday Express's most senior business journalists, Patrick Hosking and Patrick Tooher, were in negotiations to leave the paper.

And the paper's deputy showbusiness editor, Neil Michael, is also taking voluntary redundancy.

Today it also emerged that the newsdesk has lost its secretary - the paper's new recruit, photographer Jason Fraser, seconded her for his own office.

webTitle: 'Labour cannot look to the past to solve today's NHS problems'

fields.headline: 'Labour cannot look to the past to solve today's NHS problems'
fields.standfirst: There is a danger that the government's 'modern matrons' will become just another tier in an already crowded NHS hierarchy, warns Ray Rowden
fields.trailText: There is a danger that the government's 'modern matrons' will become just another tier in an already crowded NHS hierarchy, warns Ray Rowden.
fields.body:
Is "modern matron" the saviour of the NHS or a sop to the tabloid readers of middle England? The answer is probably a bit of both.

We know that issues relating to hygiene and nutrition of patients in hospitals worry the public. The increases in hospital acquired infections and increased complaints of under-fed older people vividly show that the public and politicians have a right to be concerned.

Since the 1980s, many support services in the NHS - catering, cleaning, laundry and so on - have been put out to contract. The days when such jobs were done by NHS employees are long gone. As a result, ownership of problems in these services has become more diffuse. When the cleaner was a NHS employee and part of the NHS team, it was easier for the nurse in charge to set and maintain standards of cleanliness.

In today's NHS it is less clear as to who can call the contractor to account. Too often, the person with that clout is too far removed from patients. In that sense the idea behind the concept of "modern matron" is OK. The NHS plan suggests a nurse of sufficient experience and authority to actually manage the environment in which patients are cared for. The person who should have such authority is the senior nurse in charge of the ward. There may be some risk that the "modern matron" becomes another tier in an already crowded NHS hierarchy.

The downside of the debate lies in the chosen title of this new breed of senior nurse. The title matron will doubtless please Ann Widdecombe, but harks back to a mythical era in nursing history that never was.

A proper examination of the history suggests that most matrons were disempowered in hospital culture. They were almost always women; nursing was women's work, and therefore low in the pecking order. There were some notable exceptions, mainly in the big London and metropolitan teaching hospitals, but most were nowhere near as powerful as image would have us believe.

The title is also evocative of a demeaning role, with the woman at the pinnacle of nursing portrayed as a harridan or battleaxe, striking fear into her minions. This is certainly bad news as nursing seeks to recruit from a wider pool, including increased numbers of men, who will find this distinctively sexist title very negative.

For a so-called "modernising" party, it is curious that Labour has harked back to some loaded and questionable terminology to find solutions for the NHS of today.

 Ray Rowden is honorary visiting professor of nursing at University of York and a Labour Party member

webTitle: 'I was 15, and my dad was sent to prison'

fields.headline: 'I was 15, and my dad was sent to prison'
fields.trailText: Case study: Daniel had an excellent school record with good attendance before his father was sent to prison. Now his experiences have led him to the point where he is struggling to maintain his place in an alternative to exclusion facility.
fields.body:
Fifteen-year-old Daniel had an excellent school record with good attendance before his father was sent to prison. Now his experiences have led him to the point where he is struggling to maintain his place in an alternative to exclusion facility.

He said: "On the morning he was going to court, I asked him to wake me up at 6am before he went because I wanted to see him go. Dad didn't wake me up before he went. I felt sad and upset I couldn't say cheerio.

"My dad had explained before, what might happen. I didn't really understand, I was just like 'aye, nae bother'. The social worker asked daft questions and that didn't help. I happened to be at my IT worker's office when a call came through. He told me my dad got eight years.

"I cried for two hours and broke a window and two doors. I went to my mum's pal's house where my mum was and she said 'What are you crying for?' I had to tell her. I didn't really think about her - I was thinking about myself. The lawyer was supposed to get back in touch with us and let us know what was happening but he still hasn't to this day."

Daniel describes how he and his mum have been constantly arguing since his dad went to prison. Before all this happened, he would never have shouted at his mum or his dad.

"Some people at my school found out - people my own age - they would keep away from me. The teachers must have known but they didn't mention anything," he said.

"I'm never relaxed, always wary since my dad went to prison, always aware of what's going on around me. I've never talked to any of my pals at school about it ... scared to. Other kids might give me hassle. I've had enough hassle."

As for the times he went to visit his father, Daniel said: "There were cameras spinning about. Dad used to say 'don't look at them son'. I thought there was, like, a prison officer at the other end looking down the camera at you. It would be better if there were things to do, like videos, Gameboys, computers - you could pay for it - just something to do."

Daniel says he feels angry towards his dad because he wasn't there for his birthday. But he isn't able to speak to anyone about it. "I don't want to worry my mum with my worries. I do worry about my dad. He went into prison at 20 stone, now he's 12-and-a-half stone. He's got false teeth, disgusting, and he's been in and out of hospital.

"I'd want to turn back time. Never be bad at school, have a better life, better place to stay. I've adapted to it, you have to. I was 15, and my dad got sent to prison. You'd think someone would've sat down and said to me 'Is something wrong?' Mad isn't it?"

fields.headline: Liverpool prepare for biggest test
fields.standfirst: Dan Rookwood previews Liverpool's upcoming Uefa Cup semi-final against Barcelona
fields.trailText: Dan Rookwood previews Liverpool's upcoming Uefa Cup semi-final against Barcelona.
fields.body:
A resurgent Liverpool team take on Barcelona tomorrow night, knowing that this pilgrimage to one of the world's most famous sporting cathedrals is the real test of their progress this season.

Having seen off the boys from Old Trafford at the weekend, Liverpool now take to the Nou Camp, desperate to get a foot-hold in the first leg of the Uefa Cup semi-final.

And having deposed Roy Keane as midfield monarch at Anfield on Saturday, the microscope is firmly focused on Steven Gerrard. The 20-year-old, whose stunning strike crowned an imperious display, now has to match up to another of the world's best midfielders - Rivaldo.

But the local lad that Robbie Fowler this week tipped as a future England captain is growing in assurance as well as physique. And as long as he can shake off the ever-present back injury caused by his rapid growth spurt, Gerrard is confident he will acquit himself well. "If I'm playing against Rivaldo I won't worry about him or fear him I will respect him and try my best," he said.

Following all the recent high-profile plaudits, it is Gerrard rather than Michael Owen or Fowler who has created a stir in Spain. The 98,000 fans crammed into the Catalan Cauldron are expecting the young Scouser to cause all sorts of toil and trouble.

Barcelona's Michael Reiziger hinted that Gerrard would be singled-out. He said: "I think he is the one to stop, but in Pep Guardiola we have the man to do it."

All this serves to deflect attention away from Liverpool's other rising stars. Manager Gerard Houllier has been at pains to impress the team ethic at the club this season, underlined by his firm rebuke of the disillusioned Christian Ziege today. The German international is bemoaning his place on the sidelines.

"It is very important to keep true to the values of the country you are working in," said Houllier, who has no time for dissenters in the tight ranks.

The backbone of this revitalised Liverpool team - still competing for three cups - is English to the marrow. And with each goal in this season's successful European sorties scored by home-grown talent, this is a product which is very much made in England. "Perhaps in the semi-final I will allow one of my foreign players to score," quipped Houllier, following the victory against Porto in the last round.

"When I came here it only took six months for people to say I was flooding the place with foreigners. But look at us now. We have a British heart and that is what I have always wanted."

But recent British visitors have not fared well in Barca's back yard. The Catalans have played five English sides in European competition in the last four seasons - Newcastle United, Manchester United, Arsenal, Chelsea and Leeds United - and none of them have managed to win at the Nou Camp.

In fact, the only English team ever to win in Barcelona's stadium were Liverpool in their run to their second and last Uefa Cup triumph 25 years ago. Liverpool went through 2-1 on aggregate in the semi-finals of 1976.

But Barcelona will not take this game for granted. They are desperate to salvage some silverware from a relatively disappointing season, and will not let the opportunity of a Uefa Cup final pass them by. "Liverpool will arrive in very good shape after beating Manchester United," said Dutch midfielder Philip Cocu. "They'll be difficult rivals for us but we have a good chance as well. We have to watch their counter-attacks and try our best not to concede a goal."

Liverpool will know all about Barcelona too, with Jari Litmanen a provider of insider information. However, the Finn will himself miss out on an opportunity to show his old club how wrong they were to let him go.

The 30-year-old was snapped up out of Barcelona's bargain bucket earlier this season, and was proving to be one of the signings of the season. But a wrist break, sustained at Anfield while on international duty last month, looks to have ended his fractured season.

Liverpool will remember Marc Overmars' pace from his days at Arsenal. The flying Dutchman is at last showing the sort of form that prompted Barcelona to swoop for him and Emmanuel Petit in a £35 million double deal last summer.

But for all the talk of Rivaldo, Overmars, Luis Enrique and Patrick Kluivert, admittedly a formidable array of Barcelona talent, the Liverpool attack contains sufficient style and steel to strike fear in - and goals against - the best.

Michael Owen, fresh from his impressive goal-scoring travels with England is finally getting back to the sharpest, most vibrant form of his young career.

Robbie Fowler, having shaken off injuries and controversies, has emerged as an intelligent and resourceful left-sided provider, as well as a clinical penalty-box poacher.

And Emile Heskey's physical presence and target-man efficiency provides the perfect foil for the smaller men around him.

Despite a chronic case of fixture congestion, Houllier is confident that this forward line will score a crucial away goal. "I will be very surprised if the game finishes 0-0," he said. "They are one of the best offensive sides in Europe. They score goals, attack all the time and keep a lot of possession.

"But we've scored 96 goals in all competitions since the beginning of the season so it will be interesting."

It is indicative of the improvement in this Liverpool side that the likes of Gerrard and Owen can at last parade their skills on such a grand stage.

But despite all the cups, and the prospect of a first European final in 16 years, Liverpool have not forgotten what Shankley would call their bread and butter. Cups are all very well, but success in the Premier - and ultimately the Champions - League is what Anfield expects.

"This is the kind of game we want to be playing on a regular basis, which is why the most important thing is still the league," said Gerrard.

The British heart is strong in this one.

POSSIBLE TEAMS

Barcelona: 35-Jose Manuel Reina; 24-Carles Puyol, 17-Emmanuel Petit, 3-Frank de Boer, 12-Sergi; 4-Pep Guardiola, 8-Philip Cocu, 21-Luis Enrique, 11-Marc Overmars; 10-Rivaldo, 9-Patrick Kluivert

Liverpool: 1-Sander Westerveld; 6-Markus Babbel, 2-Stephane Henchoz, 12-Sami Hyppia, 23-Jamie Carragher; 17-Steven Gerrard, 16-Dietmar Hamann, 13-Danny Murphy, 15-Patrick Berger; 10-Michael Owen, 8-Emile Heskey

Referee: Helmut Krug (Germany)

fields.headline: Teenagers with imprisoned relatives being 'abandoned'
fields.trailText: Teenagers who have a family member in prison are often abandoned by the system and left to cope alone with feelings of anxiety, loss and isolation, a new study has revealed.
fields.body:
Teenagers who have a family member in prison are often abandoned by the system and left to cope alone with feelings of anxiety, loss and isolation, a new study has revealed.

The study, by the Scottish forum on prisons and families (SFPF), is the first of its kind to focus on teenagers affected by the imprisonment of a parent, sibling or other relative - a previously hard to reach and invisible group.

Next month a study by the Federation of Prisoners' Families Support Groups in England and Wales, which has also been funded by The Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Fund, is likely to show similar findings with teenagers feeling traumatised, isolated and lacking in support.

The Scottish study, which estimates some 11,000 children are affected, found that for many young people losing a relative through prison created multiple problems. Many had increased responsibilities within the family and were anxious not to burden the remaining parent with their own worries, leaving them isolated to cope with their own complex feelings.

Young people were particularly aware of the stigma associated with having a relative in prison, were often anxious to keep it secret, and lived in fear of the consequences of people finding out. These only served to cut them off further from much-needed support.

"The trauma of arrest, trial and subsequent imprisonment and loss of their relative leaves a distressing legacy," says the report.

"One of the most striking and alarming findings is the high number of young people who find themselves in circumstances which isolate them from service provision and from their peers and community. For them, the term social exclusion is a daily and potentially long-term experience."

The report calls for more awareness among professional agencies, as well as the public, about the experiences and needs of young people. "Statutory and voluntary sector agencies must act together to bring about an effective mobilisation of energy and resources which will ensure that young people do not find themselves punished, penalised or in any other way discriminated against because of their circumstances."

The report makes a host of recommendations to improve the situation. The Scottish prison service should make visits more child-friendly, arrange extra visits for young people and make access easier through cheaper telephone calls or by introducing email links.

Police should ensure that an officer is responsible for looking after children and young people at the time of arrest, ensure they are accompanied, and have all the information they need to help them understand what is happening.

Meanwhile, the SFPF itself should develop a schools information and training programme to raise awareness of the effects of the imprisonment of a relative on young people and their need for special support.

Kate Philbrick, vice-convenor of the SFPF, said: "We need to get social work, education and criminal justice agencies to look at their processes and the lack of support for teenagers in this vulnerable position. The early experiences, such as arrest and trial, can be as crucial as the imprisonment itself, and can have a life-changing effect."

Stewart Asquith, professor of social policy at Glasgow University, said there was a danger that teenagers might feel that they themselves were being punished in some way for the behaviour of their imprisoned parent or relative.

"Unless the needs of these young people are addressed ... they will continue to feel that they are being punished and they will carry with them a legacy into adulthood which puts them at further risk," he said.

"Help with coping with the effects of imprisonment of a parent or other key figure, and ensuring that they maintain contact with them when they are in prison, has to be provided to teenagers as of right, not as some form of charity."

Bernadette Monaghan, senior manager of criminal justice charity Safeguarding Communities and Reducing Offending (Sacro) in Scotland, said that people who were able to maintain relationships with their family while in prison were much less likely to reoffend.

"A lot of work has been done to improve visiting facilities, particularly in relation to young children, but up until now nothing has been done for teenagers. Maybe it is easier to look at young children and their needs. When it comes to teenagers there doesn't seem to be the support they can tap into," she said.

The Scottish prison service said it placed great importance on maintaining family links. "These are a key element in the rehabilitation process and the prison service has provided a number of initiatives, both itself and with external agencies, to foster greater links," said a spokeswoman.

webTitle: GPs 'charging care homes for nonexistent services'

fields.headline: GPs 'charging care homes for nonexistent services'
fields.trailText: Analysis: Family doctors are charging nursing and residential homes for free NHS care under the pretence of providing additional medical services to elderly residents, according to a leading geriatrician.
fields.body:
Family doctors are charging nursing and residential homes for free NHS care under the pretence of providing additional medical services to elderly residents, according to a leading geriatrician.

His comments come after a survey of 183 care establishments by three groups of charitable bodies found that one in three pay retainer fees of up to £10,000 a year for GP services. The charges come on top of the £45.05 that doctors receive from the NHS for each patient aged over 75 on their lists.

GPs are allowed to charge care providers fees for delivering healthcare services that go beyond their core NHS work, such as minor surgery, advice on nutrition and diet, occupational health and training staff.

However, Dr Clive Bowman, associate director of the International Institute on Health and Ageing at the University of Bristol said: "Some GPs are using the provision of additional medical services as a subterfuge to pay for delivering NHS care to care home residents. Health authorities have also been known to lean on homes to provide fees. That clearly isn't acceptable."

A GP who was involved in managing care homes for his health authority and does want to be named added: "It was clear colleagues were charging for core services."

Research by the Association of Charity Officers (ACO), the Occupational Benevolent Fund (OBFA) and Voluntary Organisations Involved in Caring in the Elderly Sector (VOICES) found confusing variations in payments for GP services. Twenty-seven per cent of GPs did not hold surgeries in care homes but charged fees while 10% delivered on-site consultations for free.

Graham Allen, chief executive of the Bakers' Benevolent Society, believes the charity is being "unreasonably charged" for medical services provided to its two sheltered housing schemes in Epping and Congleton.

"Although our contract with the GP practice includes 'extra' services, such as occupational health, infection control and advice on the storage and administration of drugs, these services have rarely been provided. We provide a room for consultations, we organise the appointment list and the duty warden keeps the residents' medical records. Yet the fee's gone up at our Epping site from £280 to £496 a month - nearly £6,000 a year."

A residential home in Rugby run by Ben - the Motor and Allied Trades Benevolent Fund pays more than £10,000 a year for GP services - or £100 per resident per year.

The charity's deputy chief executive David Prescott said: "Although the contract does include giving advice on flu or doing an occasional staff medical, I do believe we're paying for NHS care on the whole."

Cardiff GP Dr Andrew Dearden, chairman of the British Medical Association's community care committee, said it was fraudulent to charge for NHS services. But he said GPs did not have the resources to meet the growing and increasingly complex needs of care home residents for free.

"With the closure of long-stay geriatric hospitals over the past 10 years, residential homes have become geriatric community hospitals. Prescription costs for nursing home residents are two to three times those for elderly people in the community, but there has been no extra money from government for primary or community care," said Dr Dearden.

He contended that the charities' research was "flawed" as it failed to take regional funding variations into consideration. "Health authorities can set up local development schemes, paying GPs to provide extra healthcare services for free. But only one in 20 health authorities have done so."

However, Les Bright, deputy chief executive for charity Counsel and Care, which provides advocacy for older people and their families, said: "That's a technocratic answer. What this boils down to is that GPs are having to be bribed into taking on work that they provide for free in another setting."

fields.headline: Full text of Bush's statement
fields.standfirst:
The following statement was given by the US president, George Bush, at the White House on Tuesday, April 3 about the US EP-3 surveillance plane that made an emergency landing on a Chinese island on Sunday

Special report: China
fields.trailText: The following statement was given by the US president, George Bush, at the White House on Tuesday, April 3 about the US EP-3 surveillance plane that made an emergency landing on a Chinese island on Sunday.
fields.body:
Good afternoon. I want to report to the American people, and especially to the families involved, that I've just talked with Brigadier General Sealock, who, earlier today, met with our 24 men and women in China.

The General tells me they are in good health, they suffered no injuries, and they have not been mistreated. I know this is a relief to their loved ones, and to all Americans.

Our crew members expressed their faith in America, and we have faith in them. They send their love to their families. They said they're looking forward to coming home, and we are looking forward to bringing them home.

This is an unusual situation, in which an American military aircraft had to make an emergency landing on Chinese soil. Our approach has been to keep this accident from becoming an international incident. We have allowed the Chinese government time to do the right thing. But now it is time for our servicemen and women to return home. And it is time for the Chinese government to return our plane.

This accident has the potential of undermining our hopes for a fruitful and productive relationship between our two countries. To keep that from happening, our servicemen and women need to come home.

Thank you very much.

webTitle: Matrons to make a comeback on the wards

fields.headline: Matrons to make a comeback on the wards
fields.trailText: A £4m scheme to bring matrons back to NHS hospitals, 30 years after they were abolished for being too old-fashioned, has been announced by health secretary Alan Milburn.
fields.body:
A £4m scheme to bring matrons back to NHS hospitals, 30 years after they were abolished for being too old-fashioned, has been announced by health secretary Alan Milburn.

Mr Milburn said that bringing back matron was a way of driving up standards of care, nutrition and cleanliness on hospital wards and of putting more power into the hands of frontline clinical staff.

But the move, the latest in the government's plan to "modernize" the NHS, was immediately seized upon by the Conservatives as an attempt to steal their idea - "bring back matron" has been a Tory catchphrase for years.

Mr Milburn said that around 2,000 "modern matrons" would be on the wards by 2004, with 500 in place by April 2002. Every hospital will have matrons in charge of groups of wards.

Matrons will be paid up to £31,000 a year and will wear distinctive uniforms "to ensure they are visible to patients and their families".

Mr Milburn said: "Matrons on the wards will have the authority to put things right for patients. Matron will make sure the wards are clean, the food is good, the care is there."

The decision to bring back matron partly reflects a clamour from the public. A public consultation prior to the publication of the NHS plan in July 2000 revealed support for "a modern matron - someone to get things done, someone patient-focused".

Dr Liam Fox, the Tory health spokesman, said: "I sometimes wonder if an original thought has ever passed through Alan Milburn's head. The Conservative party has been calling for the return of real matrons in the NHS for a considerable time.

"What he proposes is inadequate. We can't wait until 2004 to clean up our dirty wards or to ensure that patients are fed properly. We need these posts immediately, with someone taking full control of standards of cleanliness and discipline."

The Royal College of Nursing welcomed the initiative. "Patients have been crying out for someone they know to be in charge on hospital wards," said RCN general secretary Christine Hancock.

"The idea of modern matrons recognises that strong nursing leadership leds to better patient care and that, when things do go wrong, there is someone with authority to put them right."

But there was some concern that the decision to resurrect the name "matron" for the post, which is essentially that of a clinical ward manager, was an attempt by ministers to appeal "Middle England" opinion.

Ray Rowden, a former nurse and now a visiting professor at York University said although there was a role for nurses in taking responsibility for quality on the wards, the name matron was clearly calculated "to play to Daily Mail and Sun readers".

The term was "sexist", he added, as it suggested the job was reserved for women nurses. Mr Rowden said the notion of the "good old days" when hospitals were ruled with a rod of iron by an all-powerful "Hattie Jacques-style" matron was a romantic myth.

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS confederation, welcomed the creation of a modern matron as "essentially an investment in management and leadership in the NHS".

webTitle: No end to spy plane stalemate

fields.headline: No end to spy plane stalemate
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, today said it was not "realistic" for the Chinese to expect an apology from the US over its spy plane.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, today said it was not "realistic" for the Chinese to expect an apology from the US over its spy plane.

Speaking before a trip to Belgrade, Mr Cook said China should return the aircraft and its 24-member crew to resolve the dispute as quickly as possible.

The US navy EP-3 surveillance plane was forced to make an emergency landing on Hainan Island, China, after a mid-air collision with the Chinese jet that was tracking it.

The Chinese fighter crashed into the sea and its pilot is missing.

"The sooner that is resolved, the easier it will be to tackle the questions that arise from this," Mr Cook said.

The Chinese president, Jiang Zemin, has, however, reiterated his calls for an apology from Washington. He believes the US is responsible for the incident and has called for an end to surveillance flights off China's coast.

"The United States should do something favourable to the smooth development of China-US relations, rather than make remarks that confuse right and wrong, and are harmful to the relations," he said.

The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, refused. "We did not do anything wrong," he said.

"Our aeroplane was in international airspace, an accident took place and the pilot, in order to save 24 lives, including his own, under circumstances we now have determined must have been hair raising, safely got that plane on the ground."

George Bush, the US president, said he wanted to give China time to respond to prevent the stalemate from escalating into a full blown crisis. But he said a grace period was quickly expiring.

The European Union added its voice to international demands for a quick end to the crisis. "There [is] a worrisome escalation process going on," said Goeran Persson, the Swedish prime minister. Sweden is the current holder of the EU presidency.

US diplomats were today allowed to see the crew again. They are planning a long stay on Hainan Island, a popular tourist destination, despite no indication that they will be able to make further visits.

A Chinese foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, said he did not know when the crew would be released. He said their fate would depend on an investigation.

State television has broadcast comments by ordinary people expressing their anger over the incident.

They stick closely to the official account blaming the American pilot but urge viewers to stick to their normal work and study routines - apparently to discourage mass protests such as those that followed America's accidental bombing of China's Belgrade embassy in the Kosovo conflict.

But certain to add to the strain, a US-based Chinese political scientist, Gao Zhan, whose detention caused a diplomatic uproar with Washington has been formally arrested on spying charges, a human rights group reported.

Security at US diplomatic missions has been stepped up since Sunday.

webTitle: Beattie joins Izzard for Amnesty campaign

fields.headline: Beattie joins Izzard for Amnesty campaign
fields.trailText:
4.15pm: The man behind the controversial FCUK adverts has turned his attention to Amnesty International, writes Julia Day.

Amnesty's 'We Know Where You Live' website
fields.body:
The man behind the controversial FCUK adverts has turned his attention to Amnesty International.

Trevor Beattie has created a new campaign for free with the help of comedian Eddie Izzard.

More used to ruffling the feathers of middle England, Beattie is turning his attentions to rattling governments with poor human rights records.

To celebrate its 40th birthday this year Amnesty is launching a campaign called "We know where you live".

The linchpin of the campaign will be a comedy benefit night at Wembley Arena on June 3 hosted by Izzard.

The event and campaign surrounding it will be branded "We know where you live", referring to Amnesty and its supporters knowing where to find the perpetrators of abuse.

Mr Beattie, who came up with the name of the campaign with Izzard, has created a newspaper, poster and postcard campaign that will break at the end of this week.

A giant-sized poster will be revealed in London and buses sporting the slogan and painted black are already in circulation.

The campaign has been created free of charge by Mr Beattie's advertising agency TBWA London. It is the first time the agency has worked for Amnesty.

TBWA London was approached by Mark Borkowski PR, which has been appointed by Amnesty to work on all of its 40th birthday celebration projects.

The campaign's website also kicks off Amnesty's move in to online campaigning, promoting six cases including comedians jailed in Myanmar, formerly Burma, and a transvestite murdered in Argentina.

webTitle: Building a library for your child

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child.
fields.body:
The Guardian/BOL short story competition: Ages 0-3, Ages 4-7, Ages 8-11, Ages 12+

The Guardian Parents page has joined the online entertainment and media retailer BOL to promote a competition, devised by Jacqueline Wilson, for children to write their own short stories. To enter, first go to www.bol.com to read a new story by Wilson and discover her tips for aspiring writers. Entrants must be under 15 at the competition's closing date (May 11), and the story should be a maximum of 750 words in length; all other details and conditions can be found at the BOL homepage. The winning story will be published not only in Guardian Parents and at BOL, but also in Jacqueline Wilson's next book of stories!

Rattletrap Car
Phyllis Root, illustrated by Jill Barton
Walker
£9.99
CultureShop price: £7.99

This book has got to be an instant classic. The illustrations are big, bright, expressive and have a wide-eyed appeal, and Phyllis Root's story combines ingenuity with repetition of the lumpety-bumpety, clinkety-clankety, bing-bang-pop variety that babies and toddlers adore.

It tells the story of a dad and three children who, one hot summer's day, set out for the lake in their boneshaker of a car. They take with them a beach ball, surfboard, wind-up paddle-wheel boat, a thermos of razzleberry dazzleberry snazzleberry fizz and some chocolate marshmallow fudge delight, which all come into their own as the car starts to fall apart. This is a book touched by exhilarating summer madness, but which also recognises that sometimes it is children, not adults, who have the answers.

Don't Make Me Laugh
James Stevenson
Red Fox
£4.99

This innovative picture book is a little miracle. It turned a cross, crying five-year-old into a bundle of giggles. It works like a game. There are just three rules: first, you must not laugh when reading this book; second, you must not even smile; finally, you mustn't do anything that you are told not to do. If you do break the rules - which you undoubtedly will - you must go back to the very front of the book again.

In charge of the book and its reader are Mr Frimdimpny, a very stern crocodile. Mr Frimdimpny tells stories that are guaranteed to make any five- or six-year-old laugh. In a clever twist he breaks his own rules and ends up being sent to the front of his own book. Provided that the adult joins in the spirit of the thing, this is a lot of really silly fun for all the family.

The Cat Mummy
Jacqueline Wilson
Doubleday
£10.99
CultureShop price: £7.99

Verity's mum is dead and her granny, granddad and dad never, ever mention her mother. Verity takes emotional refuge with her mum's old cat Mabel, who is now on her last legs. But then Mabel dies, and Verity, who is studying the Ancient Egyptians, has an idea. It's the kind of idea that grown-ups would find weird but which seems perfectly sensible when you are young, emotionally vulnerable and facing up to death in a family that can't deal openly with bereavement.

Wilson gives an extraordinarily truthful child's-eye view of the world. This slight novel, an accessible read for three-to-fives, raises a subject that most fiction for this age group still shies away from. An excellent book, but one you need to know that your child is reading so you can deal with the questions it raises openly.

True Believer
Virginia Euwer Wolff
Faber
£4.99

This follow-up to Make Lemonade is a rare thing: a compulsively good read but also a great piece of lyric writing. Don't be put off by the fact that it looks like freeform poetry - it is actually liberating. From the first line you are plunged up to your neck into the story of LaVaughn, whose babysitting saga featured in Make Lemonade, and who now, at 15, is facing greater dilemmas in her life as adulthood beckons.

The writing is diamond-sharp, so that a gritty social-realist story becomes touched with poetry. The characterisations are intricate and the emotions feel so raw and true that even as an adult it makes you remember what it was like to be 15 again and so full of expectation, hope and the torment of being let down by those things and people that you counted on.

Shh! Don't Tell Mr Wolf
Colin McNaughton
Collins
£5.99
CultureShop price: £3.99

Small children love familiarity, and McNaughton's comic series about the adventures of the ever-hungry and sneaky Mr Wolf and the lovable Preston Pig now boasts a number of titles.

This latest instalment is a lift-the-flap book that will appeal to the very young as Mr Wolf (not a wolf of great brain) stalks his dinner (Preston Pig) all over the house. Of course, dinner always escapes and, in the battle of wits, Mr Wolf fares rather badly - to such an extent that he ends up resembling a walking stretcher case.

This is like Tom and Jerry in book form: the pleasure comes not from knowing what will happen - Mr Wolf will always go hungry - but from how it comes about. The flaps are ingenious, although they may not stand up to repeated use, and the humour is always deliciously subversive.

The Man Who Wore All His Clothes
Allan Ahlberg
Walker
£9.99
CultureShop price: £7.99

The number of six- and seven-year-olds hooked on adult TV soaps is distressingly high, but now they have their own novelette-style soap opera in the shape of the Gaskitts, a very ordinary family who lead extraordinary lives, just as we all do.

The first in what will be a series, this picture-heavy book, with its bold, natty illustrations, chronicles the domestic life of the Gaskitts. It is a life that is a little bit off the wall - from the car radio that gets everything topsy-turvy, to the cat that goes round to his friends' place to watch weepy films in the afternoon, to the bank robber who hijacks Mrs Gaskitt's taxi.

Ahlberg builds up his story like a zany game of consequences, leading to an ending that quite logically explains why Mr Gaskitt wears all his clothes to work. A lovely book for new readers.

Caught on a Train
Carlo Gebler
Egmont
£4.99

This bewitching piece of storytelling is the kind of book that a confident 10- or 11-year-old could read but would return to when they were teenagers or adults. At its heart are three Irish folk tales: Soul Cages, Daniel O'Rourke and Bewitched Butter, which can also be found in WB Yeats's anthology of Irish tales. Gebler makes these tales seem new-minted, but it is the way that he frames them that is really thrilling as they become part of a storytelling contest between the sinister Mr Clink and two other men, the only first-class passengers on the express train from Dublin to Achill Island one day in 1899. Told through the eyes of Archie, the kitchen boy, Gebler builds up a detailed and atmospheric portrait of an everyday working life suddenly touched by an inexplicable evil. A compulsive read that clutches at your heart and makes you shiver until you remember that it is only a story.

The Damage Done
Linda Newbery
Scholastic
£5.99
CultureShop price: £4.99

Kirsty's mother has left home, so the teenager is living with her father, a writer absorbed in his work. Her elder brother has gone to America, leaving her both to look after Dad and to run the riding stable business. It is all too much responsibility for the girl who is part child, part woman, and the news that horses in the area are being attacked adds to the pressure. Then Kirsty meets the mysterious Dally. Is he responsible for the mutilated horses, or the friend Kirsty needs?

Newbery tells her story of a young woman's self-discovery with a quiet authority in a book that is always a page-turner but feels measured and adult as it grapples with Kirsty's insecurity. The story and issues - coming to terms with the fact that those you love can let you down, and the need to live your own life, not the one that parents or friends demand - are always entwined, never separate.

 Readers can call the Guardian book ordering service on 0800 3166 102, or send an order with a UK cheque, payable to The Guardian, to Off the Shelf Book Offers, FREEPOST Books, LON3590, London, W3 6BR. 1st Class p&p is £1.99 per order, not per book.

Don't Tell Mr Wolf Colin McNaughton Collins £5.99 CultureShop price: £3.99 Small children love familiarity, and McNaughton's comic series about the adventures of the ever-hungry and sneaky Mr Wolf and the lovable Preston Pig now boasts a number of titles. This latest instalment is a lift-the-flap book that will appeal to the very young as Mr Wolf (not a wolf of great brain) stalks his dinner (Preston Pig) all over the house. Of course, dinner always escapes and, in the battle of wits, Mr Wolf fares rather badly - to such an extent that he ends up resembling a walking stretcher case. This is like Tom and Jerry in book form: the pleasure comes not from knowing what will happen - Mr Wolf will always go hungry - but from how it comes about. The flaps are ingenious, although they may not stand up to repeated use, and the humour is always deliciously subversive. The Man Who Wore All His Clothes Allan Ahlberg Walker £9.99 CultureShop price: £7.99 The number of six- and seven-year-olds hooked on adult TV soaps is distressingly high, but now they have their own novelette-style soap opera in the shape of the Gaskitts, a very ordinary family who lead extraordinary lives, just as we all do. The first in what will be a series, this picture-heavy book, with its bold, natty illustrations, chronicles the domestic life of the Gaskitts. It is a life that is a little bit off the wall - from the car radio that gets everything topsy-turvy, to the cat that goes round to his friends' place to watch weepy films in the afternoon, to the bank robber who hijacks Mrs Gaskitt's taxi. Ahlberg builds up his story like a zany game of consequences, leading to an ending that quite logically explains why Mr Gaskitt wears all his clothes to work. A lovely book for new readers. Caught on a Train Carlo Gebler Egmont £4.99 This bewitching piece of storytelling is the kind of book that a confident 10- or 11-year-old could read but would return to when they were teenagers or adults. At its heart are three Irish folk tales: Soul Cages, Daniel O'Rourke and Bewitched Butter, which can also be found in WB Yeats's anthology of Irish tales. Gebler makes these tales seem new-minted, but it is the way that he frames them that is really thrilling as they become part of a storytelling contest between the sinister Mr Clink and two other men, the only first-class passengers on the express train from Dublin to Achill Island one day in 1899. Told through the eyes of Archie, the kitchen boy, Gebler builds up a detailed and atmospheric portrait of an everyday working life suddenly touched by an inexplicable evil. The Damage Done Linda Newbery Scholastic £5.99 CultureShop price: £4.99 Kirsty's mother has left home, so the teenager is living with her father, a writer absorbed in his work. Her elder brother has gone to America, leaving her both to look after Dad and to run the riding stable business. It is all too much responsibility for the girl who is part child, part woman, and the news that horses in the area are being attacked adds to the pressure. Then Kirsty meets the mysterious Dally. The story and issues - coming to terms with the fact that those you love can let you down, and the need to live your own life, not the one that parents or friends demand - are always entwined, never separate.  Readers can call the Guardian book ordering service on 0800 3166 102, or send an order with a UK cheque, payable to The Guardian, to Off the Shelf Book Offers, FREEPOST Books, LON3590, London, W3 6BR. 1st Class p&p is £1.99 per order, not per book.

fields.headline: 'Nothing could have prepared me for this'
fields.standfirst: Richard Davies describes his grief after his wife lost their unborn child
fields.trailText: Richard Davies describes his grief after his wife lost their unborn child.
fields.body:
Two weeks after her period was due, my wife Jane decided the time had come to take a pregnancy test. I remember idly thinking: were we ready for this? Moments later, Jane bounced out of the bathroom and presented the dark blue line in triumph. Ready or not, we were soon flicking through the dictionary of first names and, with two boys already, struggling to remain gender-neutral. It was a third child we wanted, we told ourselves, and besides, the matter was already out of our control.

Having previously suffered an early miscarriage, we knew it was sensible to delay the announcement. But we were expecting a family visit and they would surely guess why Jane had gone teetotal. So we began to tell the world with Jane barely eight weeks pregnant.

Parents of more than one child will recognise the syndrome. With the first child, you sit down and work your way through your address book. This time, we casually mentioned it, often halfway through a social occasion: "Oh, did I tell you that Jane is pregnant again?"

The following week I was away on business. I was shocked when I phoned home to find Jane in tears. Carrying our four-year-old up to bed, she had tripped on a toy and fallen badly. It was an awful moment for both of us: me feeling guilty for being away; Jane upset because she did not want me to think she could not cope on her own. Two weeks later, Jane started to bleed. Without panicking, we consulted our library of parenting books. Bleeding was a common experience, we discovered. We tried to avoid thinking the worst.

When the bleeding did not stop a day later and clots started to appear, Jane called our GP. It was the weekend and she was advised to attend the A&E department. We both knew what this meant. While I looked after the kids, Jane spent four hours waiting to be seen. A junior doctor examined her to see whether the mouth of her womb was open, but couldn't tell. Jane was booked in for an ultrasonic scan the following week.

We agreed that I would take the day off work to accompany her to the clinic. If it was bad news, they might want her to have a scrape, we thought. Jane would need me to drive her, pick up the kids and generally "take over" while she recovered.

In truth, it was not a good time for me to be off work. But at the back of my mind was a memory of how, when Jane had her first miscarriage, I had failed to support her. Like the average guy, an early miscarriage had seemed to me little more serious than a late period. That was until Jane came back from the hospital, accused me of not giving a damn and cried for a week. This time I wanted to be there for her.

Leaving the hospital, we decided on a bit of retail therapy to lift our depression. Later, with a car full of unplanned purchases, I asked Jane if she would mind my going to the office. She stared at me, incredulous. Yes, she did mind. We had both been to the same clinic and heard the same advice. Somehow, I came out thinking there was still a chance of life; Jane came out convinced that she was carrying a dead baby. I realised Jane was right. I finally put work out of my mind. That night, Jane enjoyed her first drink in a month.

Jane's bleeding became heavier and the clots larger. But she was back to her usual self. Together we faced the task of explaining our situation to friends. Who had we told? What should we say? Did I tell you Jane was pregnant? No? Well now she isn't.

Later that week, I came home from work and Jane warned me not to go into the bathroom. Usually this would mean the boys had destroyed one of my DIY efforts. I stepped into the room. Nothing could have prepared me for what I found. A tiny foetus, no bigger than my thumb, lay on a bloodied sanitary towel. I held it up and examined it closely, unable to believe that its features could be so distinct.

Suddenly, I was choked with tears. It was so unspeakably sad, that this little person had barely lived before it was dead. Jane was amazed by my reaction. She had done her grieving on the day of the scan. It took for me to see what I had lost.

The problem then became a practical one: what to do with the remains of our child. It was like being in a Joe Orton play. The idea of flushing it down the lavatory was unthinkable. Jane favoured a burial in the garden, but I objected on the grounds that either I or some future owner would disturb its resting place. So we decided upon cremation.

With our boys tucked up in bed, on a cold winter's night, we put the tiny body on a bed of tissue in a cardboard cufflinks box, doused it with white spirit and set it alight on the upturned lid of a metal dustbin. It burned for a very long time. We sat and watched, swigging from a flask of brandy, and wept our final tears. Then we scattered the ashes in our flowerbed.

In the weeks that followed, we tried to talk about our experience with friends. I was not surprised to find that male friends were generally uncomprehending, even those who were parents. For many men, the idea of miscarriage is permanently associated with "lucky escapes". But some female friends found it equally difficult to offer sympathy. Just when Jane thought she was starting to put the experience behind her, one of her girlfriends asked whether she thought it possible that she "only miscarried the girl babies".

Miscarriage is one of society's taboos, we discovered. Only those who have been through it understand. When someone asks Jane whether her second pregnancy was easier than her first, I can't always predict how she will answer.

fields.headline: An unspeakable sorrow
fields.standfirst: As news of Nicole Kidman's miscarriage proves, not even celebrities are safe from this indiscriminate tragedy, says Sally Weale
fields.trailText: As news of Nicole Kidman's miscarriage proves, not even celebrities are safe from this indiscriminate tragedy, says Sally Weale.
fields.body:
If anyone asks Laura Gliddon how many children she has, she tells them seven - but that she has lost five. If anyone inquires further, she explains that five of her pregnancies ended in miscarriage but, as far as she is concerned, they were all her children.

She has given them names - the dead, just as the living. Jade is now six, Ellie is three, but Laura also had Jay, Christopher, Alex, Danny and Elliott, all of whom she lost between nine and 20 weeks into her pregnancies. It makes no difference at what stage she lost them - she grieves for them all just the same. She doesn't know for sure that they were all boys - it's just a feeling.

Up to one in four pregnancies end in miscarriage. There are an estimated 250,000 miscarriages every year in Britain, and one in four women will lose a baby before birth at some time in their lives. Celebrities have miscarriages just like the rest of us; last month it was Nicole Kidman, but there were Lauren Booth, Martine McCutcheon, Gillian Taylforth and Caroline Quentin before her.

Ask your friends and you'll find that many of them have had at least one miscarriage. There are no rules. Because it is so commonplace, the assumption is that it is something you should get over quickly and not make too much of a fuss about. But for many women - even those who go on to have children - it isn't that easy.

"I've felt so totally lost after all of mine and just so alone," says Laura. "I didn't know what to do with all of these feelings. Miscarriage is so anonymous. It's hard to grieve for someone you've never met or known.

"You don't have a grave to go to. You don't have any physical reminders that there was a baby there at all. It's the lack of acknowledgment. The baby doesn't even have a legal identity. There's no birth or death certificate."

And how long are you allowed to feel sad? If the miscarriage happens in the early weeks of pregnancy, not long. It was just a late period, really - social convention dictates that you can't get too upset about that. If it happens past the 12-week watershed, the point at which most people tell friends and family about a pregnancy, you're allowed to grieve a little longer, but your loss is soon forgotten by others.

A recent report in the British Journal of Medical Psychology concluded that the grief for both partners following a miscarriage is often underestimated - particularly as far as men are concerned, since it is felt that the father has had little opportunity to "bond" with the unborn child. This chimes with the findings of an Australian survey on the effect of miscarriage. Kim Conway, who carried out the study with Professor Graeme Russell at Macquairie University, Sydney, said: "The prevailing view both in the health and lay communities has been that the trauma of miscarriage is not great. It entails a short visit to hospital, full recovery and the expectation of a successful pregnancy afterwards."

Laura Gliddon went on to have two successful pregnancies, but it did not lessen her grief for the ones she had lost. Her marriage broke down. "My friends were all there for me at the time, but they don't mention it now," she says. 'They just don't acknowledge it. But for me it goes on. I don't think it's something you get over. I think it's something you get through."

At the remembrance services Laura Gliddon attends for the children she feels she lost, there is often standing room only. There are some men there, but it's mainly women - including one elderly lady who lost her baby back in the 1930s. She still remembers 70 years on.

Likewise Sarah Williams, who had a miscarriage after three years of trying to get pregnant. She and her husband had not told anyone about the pregnancy. After so much disappointment, she wanted to be as sure as she could that all was well; they planned to tell everyone after 12 weeks. Then, at about 10 weeks, she miscarried.

The baby had not existed for anyone but her and her husband. They subsequently told their families what had happened, but somehow because no one had known she was pregnant in the first place, she never felt that anyone really appreciated the loss. And everyone assumed she would get pregnant again. She hasn't yet.

Years after the miscarriage, she remembered a fortune teller she had consulted long ago. The palmist told her she would have one son. That was him, she feels. That 10-week flutter of life. Brief but never, ever forgotten.
