webTitle: The panel: is the risk posed by amniocentesis acceptable?

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The question: A study of amniocentesis has found that, for every positive result of Down's syndrome, the test causes four healthy foetuses to abort. Is this an acceptable risk? Interviews by Diane Taylor
fields.trailText: The question: A study of amniocentesis has found that, for every positive result of Down's syndrome, the test causes four healthy foetuses to abort. Is this an acceptable risk? Interviews by Diane Taylor.
fields.body:
Richard Nicholson: Editor, Bulletin of Medical Ethics

For me, it's not a question of what the statistics show; I have never been a supporter of antenatal testing. I believe that the pressure put on most women to have this testing is based on the myth of how severe a handicap Down's syndrome is. In fact, a large proportion of people with Down's not only have fulfilled and rewarding lives themselves, but contribute to other people's lives. This pressure to try to eradicate Down's is eugenic, and rather nastily so. People ought to realise that having a Down's baby is not a disaster but often a blessing.
Verdict: No

Barbara Lisicki: Disabled rights campaigner

If a test in the womb is to screen for a life-threatening genetic disorder, it needs considering very carefully. But many people have irrational fears about having a child with an impairment. Support that gives people useful rather than scary information needs to be looked at more closely; then, the implications of having a disabled child wouldn't be so problematic. A better attitude is to think that having a child with a disability will be a different kind of experience, that a lot can be learned from him or her and that the child is going to be loved and valued.
Verdict: No

Carol Boys: Chief executive, Down's Syndrome Association

What is missing from antenatal screening for Down's at the moment is good support and information. We get thousands of calls each year from people who don't know how to cope with test results. We accept that testing is now a routine part of antenatal care, but we strongly believe that any such programme should be accompanied by non-directive counselling. Individuals can then make a decision based on full and accurate information. Appropriate support must be provided regardless of the choices made.
Verdict: Yes

Cathie Louis: PR manager and mother

I had my first child in my late 30s and there was a message from the medical profession that, at my age, I shouldn't be taking unnecessary risks. I was offered the Down's test, but I was also told that there was an increased risk of miscarriage - although I had no idea of the ratio. My partner and I decided we were prepared for the possibility of having a Down's child. We were both mature, and both working. Once we had decided not to take the test, I was more concerned with staying healthy through my pregnancy than with the possibility of having a Down's baby.
Verdict: No

Monique Tomlinson: Charity manager and mother-to-be

I'm 40 and pregnant with my first child. I was told that the risk of having a child with Down's at my age could be one in 60. After I was screened, I was told the risk was actually one in 509, but went ahead and had amniocentesis. When I was told that the risk of a miscarriage as a result of the test was one in 100, my anxiety levels zoomed up, but by then I felt I had to know. Someone has to be that one in 509 - if it was going to be me, I wanted to know so that I could plan what to do next. I got the results back and everything was OK. I'm glad I took the test.
Verdict: Yes

Mary Newburn: Spokesperson, National Childbirth Trust

Women have the absolute right to choose whether or not to have ante-natal tests, but what's worrying is that many women have reported feeling "swept along" into consenting to tests without being fully in possession of the facts. For parents to make informed choices about such tests, they need to know the relative risks, benefits and consequences of all alternatives - including their right not to have tests. Health professionals should never presume what decisions parents will make, but give them the time and the information to decide for themselves.
Verdict: Yes

fields.headline: Laissez-faire childcare
fields.standfirst: When Nicholas Lezard was left in charge of the kids for a week, the hands-off approach worked a treat
fields.trailText: When Nicholas Lezard was left in charge of the kids for a week, the hands-off approach worked a treat.
fields.body:
It is the premise of this occasional and seemingly randomly generated column that the overattentive father, or, let's be honest about this, the attentive father, can generate problems for himself that a more laissez-faire approach would avoid. Such criticism as has been directed against me - and believe it or not, there has been some, from busybody children's charities and the like - tends towards the suspicion that the motives behind being a Slack Dad are reprehensibly self-centred. This is absolute rot, and I can prove it.

Last week, the wife went skiing. (Two points before we proceed: 1. I apologise for the intrusion of the personal in this column. It would have been preferable to draw my conclusions, as I generally do, from examples in the work of middle-period Racine, early Bob Dylan, and the Eighteenth Brumaire of Louis Napoleon, but sometimes only that homely, personal touch will do. 2. I do not apologise for that fantastically unreconstructed term, "the wife". As this text will reveal, I let the woman I married go skiing for a week while I stayed home and looked after the kids. This means I can call her "the wife". All right?)

Anyway, as I was saying - and I don't wish to harp on about it or anything - last week, the wife went skiing. And I, for reasons principally connected with loathing of skiing and skiers, did not. Which left me with three children, aged six, three and nought, to look after - a scenario that Slack Dad was looking forward to about as much as a week-long trip to the dentist.

While I am well aware that the contemporary Glad Dad, the emasculated and contemptible fool, his heart brimming with noble intentions and his brain bursting with good ideas about improving places to take the kids on their pre-school jog, Slack Dad, armed only with a limited stock of funny faces and a medium-sized au pair, looks around frantically with a mixture of cunning and panic and wonders how the hell he is going to get through the week with the same number of children and adults in the house as he started out with.

The thing is, it was astonishingly easy. The trick, it turns out, had already been mastered in the months prior to the wife's departure, and that trick involves a total, candid honesty about Slack Dad's own abilities. He does not dissemble or give the impression that his child-rearing talents are any greater than they are. Remember that medium-sized au pair I mentioned last paragraph? Well, she did a lot. She's leaving now - her departure entirely unconnected, I assure you, with the events of last week - but she did a hell of a lot. A fundamental respect for human life, even the kids', ensured that I didn't have to do too much.

But I still did my bit. "Time to grow up, fast," I told the two elder children. And they heard me. The greatest breakthrough was the morning routine. Now, if you're reading these pages, you know what the morning routine is like. It's a blur of threat and defiance, a tornado of anxiety and near-violence, the clock ticking away while Coco Pops are still being leisurely chomped, teeth remain nonchalantly unbrushed, the only serviceable shoes remain scattered to the four winds, and the PE kit - the what? No one told me about a PE kit. Has the school suddenly gone private or something?

So explain to me how it happened that when I was in loco parentis, we found ourselves all packed and ready to go (tip: pack everything you can find into the school bag, every day. There may be a considerable number of redundant items in there, but at least you won't have forgotten anything) at half past eight, our legs swinging from the table, the calm broken only by my saying, "Well, we could leave for school now, but we'd be 20 minutes early. Why don't you read a book for a while?"

And explain to me how, one morning, as the kids sat on my head at half past six, again - Slack Dad, remember, hates and fears the dawn as much as any vampire, even if he went to bed sober the night before - I said, "Look, get yourselves dressed and I shall give you an unspecified treat in the future," and they did. And how they got themselves dressed, what is more, with a degree of colour coordination that Slack Dad himself is incapable of managing.

Unslack Mum came back, refreshed from her one week off in the year, and tried to get them to do the same thing. "No," came the reply, firmly. "Mummy do it."

What's that all about, then?

webTitle: The rise of families with three children

fields.headline: Crowded houses
fields.standfirst: As the national birth rate shrinks ever faster, one demographic is on the up - the number of families with three children.  Sarah Ebner reports
fields.trailText: As the national birth rate shrinks ever faster, one demographic is on the up - the number of families with three children. Sarah Ebner reports.
fields.body:
Just a couple of generations ago, big families meant one thing: poverty. Lack of birth control may have been a factor, infant mortality another, but by and large, poor working people had lots of children for economic reasons. For, in the days before the welfare state, who was going to support you in old age, if not your sons and daughters?

The demographics of postwar affluence led to a decline in large families, and we have all come to accept the received wisdom that prosperity means either small families or no kids at all. But while everyone knows the birth rate is falling (the average woman now has just 1.7 offspring) and the number of lone parents increasing, there are some other interesting trends concealed within our national statistics.

The latest figures from the Office of National Statistics show that women in England and Wales now give birth to fewer children than at any time since 1977. But it emerges that from 1989 to 1999, proportionately more of the children being born each year were the third in their family. In other words, while the overall birth rate is down, many of those who do give birth are choosing to have larger families.

Wendy Holden is one of those women. When she became pregnant, she was not alone. In her village of Staverton, Northants, population only 500 people, she can name 10 neighbours who also gave birth last year. And for four of those families, like Holden's, it was child number three. "It's quite a phenomenon," she says. "There seem to be so many people having bigger families here."

But it's not just happening in Staverton. From 1989 to 1999, while total births fell by 10%, the number of third children born increased, from 16% of all births to 18%. It was the only category to show a significant rise; the number of second babies, for instance, fell by just over 1%.

"What this research suggests is that there is a polarisation between women having no baby or just one and larger families," says Maria Iacovou of the Institute for Social and Economic Research. "Given the cost of childcare, it's likely that women having more children are from affluent families."

A closer look at the figures reveals clear social differences. Essentially, women in social classes IIIM, IV and V (manual skilled, partly skilled and unskilled) are having smaller families. There has been a dramatic fall - 43% - in the number of children with at least one older sibling being born to the manually skilled. The relative numbers of second children and upwards born to the top social classes have fallen too, though the drop has not been as remarkable (9% over the past 10 years). What is significant is that just one category has shown a substantial increase - women in their 30s in social classes I and II. In the last 10 years, the number of these women having a third child has gone up 8%.

There are some caveats - the figures above are for married women only, for example - but the new trends come as no surprise to Iacovou. "People of modest means would tend to stop at two children," she says.

Holden is a perfect example of the statistics. Aged 37, she is university-educated and worked in senior middle management until her second son, Timothy, now three, was born. Her oldest, Matthew, is five, while Zoë was born last October. "I know a lot of people who aren't having children and a lot who are single, so we're keeping up the average," says her husband, Peter Williams, a manufacturing manager. "We're lucky because we could afford to have a third. Our situation is probably representative of the village; all these third children reflect the economics of Staverton."

David Coleman, reader in demography at Oxford University, agrees. "The better-off are able to afford larger families while they continue with their careers. They're less affected by the costs of having children."

Holden and Williams did not plan on three. "I've spoken to many people who had babies later in life, and like them, I've been surprised at how lovely it is to raise a family," says Holden.

Williams, who has a brother seven years his junior, says he was keen for his children to have siblings they could play with. Holden, the oldest of three, admits that her experience may have encouraged her desire to have a third. Three, she says, is a "family unit".

It seems to be a widespread belief. "In due course," says Coleman, "having three children may become even more common, if prosperity increases and is evenly distributed."

Peter and Julia Barron are both the youngest of three. "Although we never really discussed it, we knew that once we had two, we wanted a third," says Peter, father of baby Luke, Martha, two, and George, three. "Deep down, that's probably because of our own experiences. It wasn't planned, but we're very happy with three."

Like Holden and Williams, Peter, 38, from London, says finances were not particularly a consideration in the decision to have a bigger family. "Space is more important. We didn't think of the expense of having three, and now we've gone and done it."

He knows a number of people with larger families. "I've got two colleagues with four and various others with three," he says. "I suppose it's to do with affluence. Anyway, the number of people carriers around suggests that people are having more children."

But his wife's experience is the opposite. "Most women I know are still working," says Julia, 36. "That makes three pretty much impossible. You have one, maybe two, but your career is totally broken by three."

"I decided to take a few years out from working after Martha," she adds. "I went back quickly after George and it was great, but I wasn't spending that much time with him. It's harder to do that with two and, as I'm no good at juggling, I decided to take time off. Having three children and going back to work would require a phenomenal amount of childcare."

To some extent, Barron's experience epitomises the reality of childbearing today. Many women have no children, while others have three. "In the past there has been a negative association between higher educational status and family size," says Coleman. "Childlessness has been associated with these [more educated] women."

Both Wendy Holden and Julia Barron say their families are now complete (although both husbands are less definite). "I'm not going to have another one," says Wendy with determination.

Barron agrees. "After two, I felt I had one more in me," she says. "But the last pregnancy was so knackering, that's it."

fields.headline: Autism on the increase
fields.standfirst: SocietyGuardian health
fields.trailText: The number of cases of autism diagnosed in the UK has increased tenfold over the past decade, according to a study published today.
fields.body:
The number of cases of autism diagnosed in the UK has increased tenfold over the past decade, according to a study published today.

Researcher Dr Paul Shattock called for urgent action to determine the cause of the alarming increase, which he believes must be caused by a change in environmental influences.

Dr Shattock, director of the Autism Research Unit at the University of Sunderland, said that there was no proof that the controversial MMR vaccine for measles, mumps and rubella was responsible.

However, he insisted that research into MMR's possible role in causing autism had so far been inadequate and that a study planned by the Medical Research Council would not settle the issue.

Many parents blame MMR for their child's autism, but the government and the vast majority of doctors believe the vaccination is safe.

Today's study, an interim announcement of a full report to be published later this year, is the result of the analysis of 6,000 people on the Autism Research Unit's database.

Dr Shattock said that there were many possible reasons for the increase in autism cases, which was unlikely to be caused simply by changes in diagnostic practice.

"Clearly there is increased awareness and understanding of autism and diagnostic criteria have changed slightly," he said.

"But even allowing for this, all over the world there seems to be a big increase in incidence, and we have to look at all the things that have happened in the meantime to see what is likely to be relevant.

"There are many possible reasons. Clearly, if there is an increase in numbers, there must be environmental factors involved and there are many possibilities, all of which need to be explored," he told BBC Radio 4's Today programme.

"Our theories include everything that has changed - pesticides, infectious disease patterns, vaccinations, plastics in bottles, the fact that we are eating different foods to what we were eating before, different bacteria in our intestines, heavy metals, pollution, anything really."

Asked if MMR could be to blame, he said: "The link has not been proven."

But he added: "There is a huge amount of anecdotal evidence from thousands of parents in the UK and tens of thousands of parents around the world who all believe that this is a factor. And it has not been explored properly, that is why there is no proof one way or the other."

The planned Medical Research Council study would not settle the issue because it would not look at individual autistic children to see if the measles infection had persisted in their digestive systems following MMR vaccination.

fields.headline: Japanese buy final Morse episode
fields.trailText:
3.30pm: The last Inspector Morse drama, the Remorseful Day, has been sold to a Japanese broadcaster at MipTV, reports Jason Deans.
Apr 4: Broadcasters bid for South Park creators' new show
fields.body:
The last Inspector Morse drama, the Remorseful Day, has been sold to a Japanese broadcaster at the MipTV programming market in Cannes.

The two-hour episode, in which John Thaw and Kevin Whately starred as Morse and Lewis for the last time, went out on ITV before Christmas.

Now it has been sold to Japanese broadcaster NHK at MipTV by distributor Carlton International, along with 60-minute documentary the Last Morse, which examines the Morse phenomenon.

Carlton is also doing good business with the Gerry Anderson library of cult "supermarionation" puppet shows.

The latest Anderson show to make a comeback is Stingray, which has been sold to New Zealand broadcaster Prime TV.

A much newer Carlton children's show, STARStreet, has also proved popular in Cannes, selling to broadcasters in France and Singapore.

The 13-part series, which goes out in the UK as part of ITV Saturday morning show SM:TV Live, follows the adventures of pop band allSTARS.

Meanwhile, Granada has sealed two production deals with overseas companies.

Granada Kids has hooked up with the US children's programming producer JP Kids to co-develop up to four shows a year.

Granada and JP Kids will develop children's live-action and animated shows, as well as TV movies aimed at a family audience.

Also in Cannes, Granada International has signed a deal with US/Israeli producer AT Media to co-produce a minimum of 30 hours of factual programming a year.

The partners have agreed to work on projects such as an historical documentary series called In the Footsteps of Moses and a show based on the real-life heroine who inspired Patricia Cornwall's best-selling crime thrillers.

Related story
Apr 4: Broadcasters bid for South Park creators' new show

fields.headline: BBC2 documentary strand goes digital
fields.trailText: 3.30pm: BBC2 documentary strand Storyville will be moved to a weekly slot on digital channel BBC4, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC2 documentary strand Storyville is to move to new high-brow digital channel BBC4 and become a weekly feature of the service.

Storyville editor Nick Fraser is at the MipTV programming market in Cannes this week looking for foreign material to fill the extra slots.

From next year, the number of Storyville slots will go up from around 10 documentaries shown annually on BBC2 to 52, some on the same channel but most on BBC4, according to Mr Fraser.

Storyville has showcased some of the best international documentaries around in recent years, including last year's documentary Oscar winner One Day in September.

"I always wanted to have enough space to show a huge variety of the best non-fiction programming," said Mr Fraser.

"I've been looking through the archives for some golden oldies, but there will also be a lot of new stuff, including co-productions and pre-purchased documentaries from overseas."

fields.headline: Tories threaten to delay poll
fields.trailText: The Conservative party is threatening to upset the prime minister's plan to hold local elections on June 7 by voting against essential legislation to allow the delay in the House of Lords tomorrow.
fields.body:
The Conservative party is threatening to upset the prime minister's plan to hold local elections on June 7 by voting against essential legislation to allow the delay in the House of Lords tomorrow.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, plans to introduce an emergency bill in the House of Commons today, with the aim of postponing local elections in 34 county and 11 unitary councils which were scheduled for May 3.

In a rare move, the legislation is expected to pass through all its necessary stages in the Commons chamber today, before being sent to the Lords. However senior Tories are unhappy with the government's plans to set a new date, June 7. They want the bill to postpone elections indefinitely in the face of the foot and mouth epidemic.

The Conservative party is the largest party in the Lords and could delay the bill, preventing it gaining royal assent.

Today a spokesman for the party said it was "up in the air" as to whether they would co-operate with the government.

A spokeswoman said: "We have four amendments which we have added to the bill which we want to see acted upon. Until that is done there is no guarantee we won't vote against this in the Lords."

The Conservatives want to see a pledge that no elections - general or local - will be held until the several conditions are met. These are that all suspected animals are slaughtered within 24 hours of being identified, the geographical spread of the disease is reversed, restrictions on movements at most farms are lifted, and the trend of new infections shows a significant decrease.

However, the prime minister, Tony Blair, was unequivocal this week when he announced that the delay would not be "an indefinite postponement." The postponement is the first to any elections in the UK since the second world war.

In a rare move, the legislation is expected to pass through all its necessary stages in the Commons chamber today, before being sent to the Lords. However senior Tories are unhappy with the government's plans to set a new date, June 7. They want the bill to postpone elections indefinitely in the face of the foot and mouth epidemic. The Conservative party is the largest party in the Lords and could delay the bill, preventing it gaining royal assent. Today a spokesman for the party said it was "up in the air" as to whether they would co-operate with the government. A spokeswoman said: "We have four amendments which we have added to the bill which we want to see acted upon. Until that is done there is no guarantee we won't vote against this in the Lords." The Conservatives want to see a pledge that no elections - general or local - will be held until the several conditions are met. These are that all suspected animals are slaughtered within 24 hours of being identified, the geographical spread of the disease is reversed, restrictions on movements at most farms are lifted, and the trend of new infections shows a significant decrease. However, the prime minister, Tony Blair, was unequivocal this week when he announced that the delay would not be "an indefinite postponement." The postponement is the first to any elections in the UK since the second world war.

webTitle: Cook urges Hague trial for Milosevic

fields.headline: Cook urges Hague trial for Milosevic
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, flew in to the Yugoslav capital Belgrade today to urge the Serbian government to turn over the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, to an international court to be tried for war crimes.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, flew in to the Yugoslav capital Belgrade today to urge the Serbian government to turn over the former president, Slobodan Milosevic, to an international court to be tried for war crimes.

Mr Cook stressed that he would not be "laying down the law" or delivering an ultimatum to the Serbs that international cooperation would be withdrawn unless their former president was delivered to the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

But he said: "There has to be two parallel tracks, in which the international community helps Serbia and Serbia helps the international community."

Mr Cook's visit comes just days after Mr Milosevic was arrested. He is now awaiting trial on charges of misuse of power, corruption and murder - which carries the death penalty.

Mr Cook said that he understood that the Serbian people needed to try Mr Milosevic within the country before turning him over to the Hague tribunal.

He said: "It's very important the Serb people should go through an education about the Milosevic years and the extent to which he was as big a menace to them as he was to the other people of Yugoslavia. I don't go as somebody who is going there to lay down the law and demand that I get Milosevic to take back on a plane.

"I want to be quite firm that he has to end up in the Hague. But I won't be putting that in the context of, if you don't do that, then this won't happen," Mr Cook added.

After landing in Belgrade this morning, the foreign secretary went into talks with the Yugoslav president, Vojislav Kostunica. He was also due to meet the Yugoslav foreign minister, Goran Svilanovica, and the Serbian justice minister, Vladan Batic.

Tonight, Mr Cook will host a reception for aid organisations and local representatives at the British embassy in Belgrade.

As well as pressing the case for Mr Milosevic to be sent to stand trial for war crimes, Mr Cook was to discuss further international aid for Serbia and the prospect for cancelling some of its crippling debt burden to help rebuild the country's shattered economy.

After years of corruption and conflict, inflation is running at 48% and there is widespread poverty. Yugoslavia, made up of Serbia and Montenegro, already qualifies for about £265m in EU aid. The US government this week released $50m in new aid for Yugoslavia.

Mr Cook's talks will also focus on returning stability across the Balkans, urging progress in completing the Bosnian peace process.

Tomorrow he will visit the Macedonian capital, Skopje. Macedonia has been plagued by insurgent Albanian guerrillas along its border with Kosovo. Britain and Scandinavian countries recently sent 400 troops to reinforce border security.

webTitle: Bruce named as new Wigan manager

fields.headline: Bruce named as new Wigan manager
fields.trailText: Steve Bruce has been appointed the new manager of Wigan.
fields.body:
Steve Bruce has been appointed the new manager of Wigan.

Bruce, who has been out of work since being sacked by Huddersfield in October, will work alongside Colin Greenall and Brendan O'Connell, while director of football John Benson will take charge of youth development.

"I'm looking forward to the challenge," said Bruce. "We want to cement our play-off position and I'm looking forward to achieving Wigan's aim of First Division status."

fields.headline: Nokia recovers from market jitters
fields.trailText: 1.45pm: Nokia shares have recovered following initial market doubts over its £1.25bn deal with Orange, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Shares in mobile phone maker Nokia have recovered following initial market doubts over its £1.25bn "vendor finance" deal with wireless giant Orange.

Investors' eyebrows had been raised at the size of the deal, which will see Nokia loaning the cash Orange needs to build its 3G mobile phone networks in France, Germany and the UK.

In effect, Nokia is giving Orange money to buy its products.

Nokia's shares, however, recovered from a 7% loss yesterday to settle at E25.20 on the Helsinki exchange in Finland this morning - just 0.2% down.

Analysts spoke up for the Orange deal, arguing that Nokia will be boosted by equipment orders for the 3G networks, which will provide always-on internet connections, faster transmission speeds and video services to 10m Orange customers.

"Orange is a huge player in Europe. Nokia has a very healthy balance sheet and it is best for it to cement these relationships by providing a bit of vendor finance," said Susan Anthony, telecoms equipment analyst at Credit Lyonnais.

Ms Anthony added that Nokia will also be well placed to benefit from further expansion of the networks, which should happen as soon as traffic increases.

Nokia has also agreed to provide £315m-worth of 3G network equipment to Hutchison 3G, a new player in the UK mobile phone market.

It caused jitters in the markets earlier this week when it announced a similar deal with Mobilcom of Germany, which is part-owned by Orange and has suffered from the negative sentiment sweeping the telecoms sector.

But vendor financing is seen as the best way for mobile phone equipment makers to reach their revenue targets and for cash-strapped mobile phone companies to pay for 3G networks.

The telecoms sector is awash with debt after European players spent a staggering £97m last year - most of which was borrowed from banks and spent on hugely expensive 3G mobile phone licences.

The biggest victims are BT, which owes £30bn, France Telecom, which owes £40bn and Deutsche Telekom, which owes £36bn.

Some analysts fear a stream of defaults on loans taken out to pay for these licences, which has sent telecoms operators scurrying to the likes of Nokia for more cash.

It is estimated a further £100bn will have to be spent on 3G networks over the next four years. Nokia, Ericsson and Motorola have a total £90bn available in shareholders' funds.

fields.headline: Fresh hope as tally passes 1,000
fields.standfirst:
 Growth of cases slowing down
 Government scientist briefs Blair
 Lib Dems outline foot and mouth proposals

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Evidence that the foot and mouth crisis could be turning a corner is expected today despite the number of cases passing the 1,000 mark.
fields.body:
Evidence that the foot and mouth crisis could be turning a corner is expected today despite the number of cases passing the 1,000 mark.

Amid signs that the steps taken to combat the outbreak were beginning to gain ground, the government's chief scientist, Professor David King, was at Downing Street this morning to brief the prime minister on the latest projections on the spread of the disease.

Studies that recently forecast that 4,400 cases would emerge by June are now expected to offer a lower estimate. But, with the number of confirmed cases now standing at 1004, Professor King was also likely to be warning that the outbreak was not yet under control.

Ian Gardiner, deputy director general of the National Farmers' Union, agreed that the "end game" was now in sight.

While Professor King was expected to endorse the government's strategy of cutting the report-to-slaughter time to 24 hours, he will also underline the fact that they still face a long haul to get the disease under control.

In Northern Ireland, where there has been just one case, there was a glimmer of hope in the battle to get on top of the disease with today's lifting of restrictions on the movement of meat and milk.

The government is hoping that the opening of another landfill site at Turnhill in Shropshire will help to speed up the process of disposing of the carcasses of thousands of animals slaughtered in the mass cull.

There are now 1,458 vets, 315 slaughter workers and 1,750 troops involved in the effort to get the disease under control.

Meanwhile, the Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, today outlined a package of proposals for helping the farming and tourist industries to recover from the impact of the crisis.

The proposals include the immediate allocation of £100m from the Treasury's contingency reserve to fund a compensation scheme for farmers, and allocating an additional £100m from the reserve to fund an interest-free loan scheme to be administered by the banks.

Mr Kennedy was also pushing for a £50m subsidy for tourism promotion agencies to finance a campaign stressing that much of the country remains accessible.

fields.headline: Marketing
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 5
fields.trailText: April 5: Three tobacco giants are joining forces to launch a global anti-youth-smoking campaign.
fields.body:
Philip Morris, British American Tobacco and Japan Tobacco International are joining forces to launch a global anti-youth-smoking campaign.

The British Tourist Authority is to hire an advertising agency and PR firm to combat the steep drop in tourism caused by the foot and mouth crisis.

The BBC is to create a range of Masterchef-branded products, including food, cookware and brown goods.

Bass has called a review of the Worthington creative advertising account, worth £4m.

Granada Enterprises has set a price tag of £18m over three years for an integrated sponsorship package covering ITV's Premier League programming.

The Times and Sunday Times have lost their second marketing director in two years with the resignation of Patrick Sherriff.

Levi's has launched a blistering attack on Tesco, accusing the retailer of building its brand "illegitimately" as the companies prepare for the latest round in a long-running legal battle.

One2One has recruited Clent Richardson from Apple Computers to be its chief sales and marketing officer.

fields.headline: Marketing Week
fields.standfirst: Publication date: April 5
fields.trailText: April 5: The Lords are calling for major exemptions to the proposed ban on tobacco advertising.
fields.body:
Members of the House of Lords are calling for major exemptions to the proposed ban on tobacco advertising to allow the direct marketing of tobacco to continue.

Internet bank Smile has appointed Mike Phillipson, former marketing director at Time Group, as its first director of marketing.

Ipswich Town Football Club, which is on course for a lucrative Uefa Champions League spot, is understood to be looking for a sponsor to reflect its European ambitions.

HSBC has appointed Lowe Lintas to handle its £15m UK creative account, in place of incumbent St Luke's, following a head-on pitch last month.

Patrick Sherriff, marketing director of Tte Times and Sunday Times, has left the newspaper group without a job to go to.

Publicis has won the £15m Post Office account. The appointment is part of a change in strategy for the Post Office, which involves shifting its focus to above-the-line advertising.

fields.headline: Graf steps into Labour favours row
fields.trailText:
11pm: Philip Graf has warned that the Sun enjoys too close a relationship with New Labour's publicity machine. By Jessica Hodgson.
April 2: The Sun's election leader
April 2: Sun election scoop enrages rivals
March 19: Interview with Philip Graf
fields.body:
The chief executive of Trinity Mirror, Philip Graf, has warned that the relationship between New Labour's media relations machine and the Sun newspaper is too close for comfort.

He said the relationship "does not seem a very satisfactory way to do business".

Mr Graf said he had "a great professional admiration for the Sun", the top-selling tabloid newspaper owned by his rival, News International.

But he said it was extraordinary to see how the Labour party had ignored the cabinet, the parliamentary party and due democratic processes and announced the general election date through a newspaper and the BBC.

His reference to the Sun's revelation that the government would be delaying the date of the general election suggested Mr Graf felt the Mirror was not enjoying the same privileges.

Rival newspapers claimed this week that the Sun's political editor Trevor Kavanagh had been briefed on the decision to delay the election ahead of the rest of the press and members of Tony Blair's own cabinet.

But in the course of a wide-ranging speech about the relationship between the government and the press, Mr Graf dwelled on the relationships between lobby journalists and spin doctors, and newspaper publishers and government.

"It would be hard to deny that Rupert Murdoch's takeover of the Times and the Sunday Times was not helped by his support of the then government," Mr Graf said.

He added that Neil Kinnock was persuaded to refrain from making a statement condemning Robert Maxwell's planned takeover of Mirror Group in 1984.

Mr Graf also praised Mr Blair's chief spin doctor Alastair Campbell for introducing more openness into the lobby system.

And he spoke of the new European Human Rights Act, warning that privacy cases brought by celebrities threatened to undermine press freedom by introducing a backdoor privacy law.

"There is already evidence to indicate that the Human Rights Act is being used by courts to restrict what can be reported in criminal proceedings and, at least initially, the courts have been more inclined to restrict press freedom rather than be robust in defence of it," he said.

Mr Graf also praised Mr Blair's chief spin doctor Alastair Campbell for introducing more openness into the lobby system. And he spoke of the new European Human Rights Act, warning that privacy cases brought by celebrities threatened to undermine press freedom by introducing a backdoor privacy law. "There is already evidence to indicate that the Human Rights Act is being used by courts to restrict what can be reported in criminal proceedings and, at least initially, the courts have been more inclined to restrict press freedom rather than be robust in defence of it," he said. fields.headline: Corley takes reins at GMTV
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: Paul Corley is to make a dramatic comeback to mainstream TV after being appointed managing director of GMTV, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
The former boss of factual programming at ITV is to make a dramatic comeback to mainstream television after being appointed managing director of GMTV.

Three years after quitting the ITV job in the wake of a "restructuring", Paul Corley has beaten off the competition to get one of the top executive posts in commercial television.

He will be the second boss in the breakfast station's history and will succeed Christopher Stoddart, who is leaving to head up the new horseracing and gambling consortium Go Racing.

Mr Corley beat off at least three other candidates for the job - former ITV director of planning David Bergg, GMTV marketing director Clive Crouch and Carlton Central managing director Ian Squires.

After leaving ITV's network centre, Mr Corley spent two-and-a-half years as chief executive of Border TV.

fields.headline: Inmates denied the vote
fields.trailText: None of the UK's 64,000 prisoners will be permitted to vote in the forthcoming general election, the high court ruled today.
fields.body:
None of the UK's 64,000 prisoners will be permitted to vote in the forthcoming general election, the high court ruled today.

Three prisoners had appealed that denying inmates the vote was in contravention of the Human Rights Act, which the Labour government introduced in 1998.

But today two senior judges threw out their claim, agreeing with the 1983 Representation of the People Act that bars convicted prisoners from the electoral roll while they are in prison.

Lord Justice Kennedy said the voting franchise was a matter for parliament and "parliament has taken the view that for the period during which they are in custody convicted prisoners have forfeited their right to have a say in the way the country is governed."

Lord Justice Kennedy and Mr Justice Garland were unanimous in rejecting the challenge from the three men - Anthony Pearson, serving 10 years for importing drugs; Richard Martinez, serving life after being convicted in 1996 of arson with intent to endanger life; and John Hirst, serving life at Nottingham prison for manslaughter.

The judges added that there was a "broad spectrum" among democratic societies over whether or not prisoners should have the vote, and the UK "falls into the middle of the spectrum".

They also rejected a bid from the Edward Fitzgerald QC, who represented two of the inmates, to allow an appeal to the court of appeal.

Mr Fitzgerald said: "It is illegitimate to use disqualification from the vote as punishment."

He told the judges that even if it were legitimate, the present legislation was arbitrary "because it punishes imprisonment, rather than offences on any graded scheme".

A spokesman for the Prison Reform Trust, Joe Levenson, which supported today's application, expressed disappointment with the court's ruling, but added: "This case should mark the start - not the end - of the political and public debate about how our society encourages prisoners to take responsibility.

"Banning prisoners from voting serves no purpose and is a hangover from the 19th century. Parliament should look at this matter again as a matter of urgency."

Remand prisoners are unaffected by the ruling, as they retain their right to vote until sentencing. Prisoners regain their place on the electoral roll after leaving jail.

Under the Representation of the People Act 2000, homeless people were enfranchised for the first time, so long as they could name a local day centre, or even a park bench, as their place of "local connection".

Mental patients are another group who can vote - provided they are not in a prison hospital. People who live on barges and house boats are eligible too, provided they give a lock keepers house or pub address as a local connection.

webTitle: Teacher says TB spread at home

fields.headline: Teacher says TB spread at home
fields.standfirst:
A guide to infectious diseases
Guardian Unlimited Education - schools
SocietyGuardian health
fields.trailText: The headteacher of a school hit by seven cases of tuberculosis - believed to be Britain's worst outbreak in recent years - said today he believed the disease was spread at home rather than in the classroom.
fields.body:
The headteacher of a school hit by seven cases of tuberculosis - believed to be Britain's worst outbreak in recent years - said today he believed the disease was spread at home rather than in the classroom.

Headteacher Gary Coleby refused to speculate on whether the fact that 93% of pupils were from families originally from the Asian subcontinent was a factor in the outbreak of the potentially fatal disease.

"It would be premature for me, who is not a medical person, to say that," he said. "Once the screening is done it will be interesting to follow that up."

Mr Coleby said he was keeping an open mind about the origin of the outbreak until a full investigation had been carried out.

He said: "It is very hard to catch it in a school setting, I have been told, and it is far more likely to be an issue through domestic circumstances than at school. We live in a busy, bustling city and there will be many areas that will need to be investigated."

Public health officials, who were too busy to comment, were due to announce later today whether the number of pupils with the disease, which relentlessly attacks the lungs, had risen after final tests were carried out.

A mass screening programme was started when three youngsters at the Crown Hills community college, in Leicester, were found to have the disease.

Results yesterday showed a further four pupils at the school had developed a non-infectious form of TB. There are also fears a teacher at the school who has been off sick may have the disease.

Tuberculosis (TB) had been on the wane since the Victorian period, when it was rife, but there have been claims it is becoming an increasing threat once again.

The news of the outbreak comes after it was announced this month that the routine immunisation programme for children against tuberculosis was to restart in schools.

The BCG programme was suspended 18 months ago because of lack of vaccine. A catch-up programme will also be introduced to immunise all children who have missed out on the jabs.

Tuberculosis was declared a global emergency in 1993 by the World Health Organisation after a slowing down in the decline of the disease was noticed in many industrialised countries. Last year about 7,000 people in Britain contracted TB.

However, epidemiologist Dr John Watson, of the public health laboratory service, said the rash of TB cases did not imply that an epidemic was under way.

"I don't think it is a cause for alarm. TB is something we need to be watching very carefully and taking additional steps with, but it is a problem that needs to be kept in context," he said.

"If we go back 50 years, we have in the order of 50,000 cases of TB each year in this country."

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst: He is an expert on advertising in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the past 10 years. Every Wednesday morning, Stefano Hatfield, now based in New York heading Ad Age Global, will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue. This week he asks why it's all gone pear-shaped in adland
fields.trailText: April 4: Stefano Hatfield asks why it's all gone pear-shaped in America's adland.
fields.body:
An email news alert pings across my screen detailing the latest job losses in the US advertising industry. This time the internet company Organic announced it was to lay off 300 staff and was exploring merger opportunities with its sister Omnicom subsidiary, BBDO.

A couple of days later, I had learnt that Leo Burnett's Giant Step had laid off 52 of its 227 employees (Burnett itself had already axed over 200), the direct marketer Rapp Collins had closed down its Minneapolis office, Ogilvy & Mather had shut down in Atlanta, and the online advertising sales company Phase2Media was losing 30% of its staff (including closing its London operation).

Meanwhile, Oxygen was laying off 35 more staff, and MarchFirst, the ailing web design and consulting company, was on the brink of selling itself in deals which hoped to save half of its 7,000 staff. It is hard to recall that when we arrived in New York in far-off September, many of the above names were the shining lights of the new economy.

Since then we have been asked constantly by non-Americans: "Is it really that bad?" And, if it is not that bad, why are the cuts so apparently drastic?

The answers depend on an understanding of what makes America different from every other market in the world - no, it's not the World Series where only Canada is invited to compete, but scale. It is difficult to overstate the difference the vastly increased scale makes to everyday business life.

Among the legion of astonishing numbers that surround American advertising there is last year's staggering US Bureau of Statistics total of 199,100 people working in the industry - a record. To put this in perspective, this is 14 or 15 times the total working in IPA member agencies in the UK.

It's the legacy of so much business pouring in over the last three years or more. When American agencies win a significant account, the numbers involved are far removed from those with which other markets work with. Accounts of $100m regularly move here, and agencies staff up accordingly. Some agencies have over 50 creatives working on their Super Bowl spots alone. And in the last few years these numbers were ridiculously inflated by the hundreds of millions of dollars of dot.com advertiser money swelling fat agency coffers.

This has all now gone pear-shaped. The hope had been that old-economy advertisers would step into the dot.coms' shoes. Sadly, there appear to be only a few brave and clever marketers like IBM that seem determined to capitalise on challenger brands slashing advertising spend by increasing their own budgets.

A more common tale is that of GM, which stunned the television networks over Christmas by cutting over $200m from its "upfront" commitments (the amount it pledged to spend this year). It has followed that up in 2001 by cutting entire schedules from well-known publishing houses like Conde Nast and Ziff Davis, as well as a host of individual magazines.

Although adland long maintained a surreal air of optimism regarding the rest of the year, this has belatedly dissipated. The year looks bleak, and most big companies in the agency and media sectors are publicly held.

Where did all that money everyone was making until October last year go? The shareholders, stupid. And shareholders don't take kindly to CEOs failing to deliver their profit forecasts. Hence, drastic budget cuts result in dramatic numbers of redundancies immediately impacting the bottom line. Sadly, it feels like the depressing cycle has only just begun.

 Stefano Hatfield is managing director and editorial director of Ad Age Global.

webTitle: Why Europe and America are worlds apart

fields.headline: The great divide
fields.standfirst:
George Bush's decision to rip up the Kyoto agreement left many of us staring across the Atlantic in disbelief. But Henry Porter is not surprised - as London editor of Vanity Fair he has found that America's view of the world is profoundly different to Europe's

Talk: what do you think of Bush?
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: George Bush's decision to rip up the Kyoto agreement left many of us staring across the Atlantic in disbelief. But  Henry Porter is not surprised - as London editor of Vanity Fair he has found that America's view of the world is profoundly different to Europe's.
fields.body:
The United States' decision to abandon the Kyoto agreement and put its own energy requirements above the planet's health has supplied Europe with an unusually rapid means of deciding the worth of George Bush - if indeed we needed one. At any rate, in little less than a week Europeans have concluded that the US government has been captured by an exceptionally irresponsible and foolish man. Bush seems too bad to be true.

While we all blinked at his dismissal of Kyoto and the forging ahead with plans for oil exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, Bush attended a dinner in Washington where he sought to relax the White House press corps with a line about water purity. "As you know, we're studying safe levels for arsenic in drinking water," he said. "To base our decision on sound science, the scientists told us we needed to test the water glasses of about 3,000 people. Thank you for participating."

What we appear to have in the White House, then, is the American equivalent of Jim Davidson: an unabashed conservative with a historic drink problem and an alluringly toxic sense of humour. But not even Jim would have confused capital punishment with death duties as Bush did a few weeks ago when he declared: "We understand how unfair the death penalty is."

We in Europe gape at such faux pas and conclude - unjustly, as it happens - that George Bush is some kind of essential distillation of all US culture and that, therefore, all America is to blame for his presence in the White House. We note that the US constitutes 5% of the world's population but is responsible for a quarter of all mankind's emissions of carbon dioxide. With only the slightest hesitation, it seems, this same nation voted in Bush Mark II, who promised to out-Reagan Reagan and to dismiss world opinion on issues which, in our innocence, we had decided were pretty much orthodoxies for the new century.

And then something fascinating happened, something which had long been waiting to happen. All the resentments about American national life - the continued use of the death penalty, the refusal to address guns, the overbearing nature of its entertainment industry, the disinclination to wholeheartedly ratify treaties on landmines, and the International Criminal Court - coalesced into a single charge sheet which damned American society as being arrogant and out of touch with global concerns.

The mood has been building for a long time, but the decision to abandon Kyoto crystalised the issue in people's minds. Suddenly Europe is tired of the American dominance in practically every area of life, which is how the French have found themselves a hero in the McDonald's wrecker, Jose Bove.

Americans are amazed by the swiftness and unjustness of it all. They really do like to be loved and they feel that Europe gives them scant credit for the era of peace which has been guaranteed by successive American governments since the last war.

I have a lot of close American friends, having worked for a US corporation for a good part of the last decade. With one of them I have only to mention the number of teenagers being executed in the US and he shoots back: "Hey, if it wasn't for us, you'd all be speaking German." Then he usually takes another sip of wine and adds: "Or Russian." Less than 50% of this is an ironic evocation of Archie Bunker.

Last summer I went out with another friend who edits one of the big news magazines in the US, a very charming anglophiliac Wasp. Unwisely I began to explain the European suspicion of America, listing the usual grievances that now form the charge sheet. He took it for a while then deliberately set down his glass and gazed at its stem, evidently struggling to hold on to his temper. "The trouble with Europe is that every time you get into trouble you yell across the Atlantic for help. But, when things are good you expect us to listen to your horseshit lectures about the way we run things in the US." The point is well made, and indeed Europe's need to carry its own big stick and to sort out its own problems in the Balkans is one of the driving instincts behind the European Defence Force.

Americans see Europe as ungrateful but also congenitally inclined to political chaos. This suspicion of Europe stretches back to the hot summer of 1787 when, among others, Benjamin Franklin and George Washington sat down to write the constitution for the 13 states of America. In every sentence, they strove to distinguish the new republic from the oppression and abuse in the old world. That self-conscious creation of a political antithesis was strengthened over the 19th century and into the 20th by the fact that great numbers of people fled Europe's famines, pestilence and persecution for America. Thus the ancestral memory of Europe, albeit hazy, is as a place to escape from. American jokes about Europe dwell on its dodgy, screwed-up, murderous past.

Americans may feel cut off from the civilising presence of European culture and dimly hanker after their ethnic roots, especially those who claim Scottish, Irish, Greek and Italian ancestry. But there is also the feeling among many that their not-so-bright kin were the ones left behind to tend the goats. The European cousins may look up and see the Parthenon, the ancient temples of Sicily or the walls of Dubrovnik in their everyday life, but it doesn't substantially change the fact that they are still goatherds. Meanwhile, the American relation boasts a used car lot bigger than the Forum. So what earthly reason can there be to take notice of the European's views about landmines and genetically modified food?

Something less than 25% of all Americans have passports and it follows that the American experience of the outside world is extremely limited. While Europeans are exposed to a constant flow of fascinating information about American life, there's no reciprocal interest in the US about Europe, except when we have floods and foot and mouth and atrocities in the Balkans. Then the US takes notice, but this only serves to underscore the impression that life outside the great republic is far from comfortable.

William Pfaff, writing in the Los Angeles Times the other day, noted a mistake made by the new secretary of the treasury, Paul O'Neill, who had commented that something had to be done to help the Japanese achieve a higher standard of living. As Pfaff writes: "In fact, Japan's problem is that its living standards are so high - much higher on average than in the United States - that Japanese consumers can't think of much they want to spend more money on."

Among my friends in the United States I find a similar frustration with our misapprehensions - the idea, for instance, that every schoolyard is being raked by a 12-year-old with an assault rifle, or that you are quite likely to see a car chase through the streets of Manhattan. In fact, Americans drive much more slowly than Europeans and for the most part lead lives of dull plenty in the suburbs. Except in the big cities, America is astonishingly slow and conservative. HL Mencken, the great journalist of the first half of the century, certainly understood this when he attacked the way Americans refuse to discuss religion: "The result is that all religions are equally safeguarded against criticism, and that all of them lose vitality. We protect the status quo and so make steady war upon revision and improvement. That is a profoundly clever observation about the US, which is so often mistaken for the jittery crucible of invention. In areas other than commercial enterprise, it has been remarkably slow to challenge the status quo - segregation and gun law - mostly from fear of offending the Bill of Rights and Constitution.

While America has a clear narrative to its political history which unrolls with fascinating drama but always with a consistent set of interests and procedures, Europe is evidently prey to more mobile and fitful political passions. In 1925 Mencken saw how the two cultures rubbed each other up the wrong way. Europeans, he wrote, despaired of "our growing impatience with the free play of ideas, our increasing tendency to reduce all virtues to the single one of conformity, our relentless and all pervading standardisation."

That still encapsulates the European doubt about the United States of America, and if you add the big issues listed on the charge sheet, you pretty much have it all. George Bush is a product of that deeply conservative strain in America that wars against revision and improvement. In Europe we are brave enough or foolish enough to think that we can revise and improve, which is why the clash occurs. To my mind the division appears deeper than it actually is, and in fact I'd bet my last dollar that we won't throw in our lot with Europe, which many suggest is the logical outcome of the current frustrations with American conservatism. There is one point that everyone is forgetting in the heated debate about Kyoto. America invented environmentalism and still has a high proportion of people who give to environmental charities and believe that taxes should be raised to fight pollution.

Continental drift: how the US and Europe see the world

Cuba

The European view: Hip holiday destination du jour, presided over by everyone's favourite Manics-loving uncle; home of record-breaking athletes, lyrical love poetry, and salsa

The US view: Depraved, child-snatching, tyrannical dictatorship hell bent on - and, frankly, fairly close to achieving - world domination; home of massive narcotics industry, cigars, and (a particularly clever form of cultural warfare, this) salsa

Guns

The European view: Lethal weaponry enabling alienated American high-school internet enthusiasts to massacre their unsuspecting classmates

The US view: Constitutionally enshrined form of protection enabling high-school students to defend themselves against attempted massacres by their alienated classmates

Litigation

The European view: Expensive, time-consuming, intimidating system allowing rich people to stop everyone else from saying nasty things about them

The US view: Popular recreational sport, like baseball, allowing Americans to generate a useful second income from spilling coffee on themselves

Foot and mouth

The European view: Hugely problematic catastrophe that threatens the global importance of Britain's agricultural industry

The US view: Yet another reason to steer clear of London, like BSE, pickpockets, and the aftermath of war in nearby Bosnia

Sierra Leone

The European view: Worryingly unstable West African country benefiting from a spot of good old-fashioned British army training.

The US view: Where?


Oliver Burkeman

All the resentments about American national life - the continued use of the death penalty, the refusal to address guns, the overbearing nature of its entertainment industry, the disinclination to wholeheartedly ratify treaties on landmines, and the International Criminal Court - coalesced into a single charge sheet which damned American society as being arrogant and out of touch with global concerns. The mood has been building for a long time, but the decision to abandon Kyoto crystalised the issue in people's minds. Suddenly Europe is tired of the American dominance in practically every area of life, which is how the French have found themselves a hero in the McDonald's wrecker, Jose Bove. Americans are amazed by the swiftness and unjustness of it all. They really do like to be loved and they feel that Europe gives them scant credit for the era of peace which has been guaranteed by successive American governments since the last war. I have a lot of close American friends, having worked for a US corporation for a good part of the last decade. With one of them I have only to mention the number of teenagers being executed in the US and he shoots back: "Hey, if it wasn't for us, you'd all be speaking German." Then he usually takes another sip of wine and adds: "Or Russian." Less than 50% of this is an ironic evocation of Archie Bunker. Last summer I went out with another friend who edits one of the big news magazines in the US, a very charming anglophiliac Wasp. Unwisely I began to explain the European suspicion of America, listing the usual grievances that now form the charge sheet. He took it for a while then deliberately set down his glass and gazed at its stem, evidently struggling to hold on to his temper. "The trouble with Europe is that every time you get into trouble you yell across the Atlantic for help. But, when things are good you expect us to listen to your horseshit lectures about the way we run things in the US." The point is well made, and indeed Europe's need to carry its own big stick and to sort out its own problems in the Balkans is one of the driving instincts behind the European Defence Force. Americans see Europe as ungrateful but also congenitally inclined to political chaos. This suspicion of Europe stretches back to the hot summer of 1787 when, among others, Benjamin Franklin and George Washington sat down to write the constitution for the 13 states of America. In every sentence, they strove to distinguish the new republic from the oppression and abuse in the old world. That self-conscious creation of a political antithesis was strengthened over the 19th century and into the 20th by the fact that great numbers of people fled Europe's famines, pestilence and persecution for America. Thus the ancestral memory of Europe, albeit hazy, is as a place to escape from. American jokes about Europe dwell on its dodgy, screwed-up, murderous past. Americans may feel cut off from the civilising presence of European culture and dimly hanker after their ethnic roots, especially those who claim Scottish, Irish, Greek and Italian ancestry. But there is also the feeling among many that their not-so-bright kin were the ones left behind to tend the goats. The European cousins may look up and see the Parthenon, the ancient temples of Sicily or the walls of Dubrovnik in their everyday life, but it doesn't substantially change the fact that they are still goatherds. Meanwhile, the American relation boasts a used car lot bigger than the Forum. So what earthly reason can there be to take notice of the European's views about landmines and genetically modified food? Something less than 25% of all Americans have passports and it follows that the American experience of the outside world is extremely limited. While Europeans are exposed to a constant flow of fascinating information about American life, there's no reciprocal interest in the US about Europe, except when we have floods and foot and mouth and atrocities in the Balkans. Then the US takes notice, but this only serves to underscore the impression that life outside the great republic is far from comfortable. William Pfaff, writing in the Los Angeles Times the other day, noted a mistake made by the new secretary of the treasury, Paul O'Neill, who had commented that something had to be done to help the Japanese achieve a higher standard of living. As Pfaff writes: "In fact, Japan's problem is that its living standards are so high - much higher on average than in the United States - that Japanese consumers can't think of much they want to spend more money on." Among my friends in the United States I find a similar frustration with our misapprehensions - the idea, for instance, that every schoolyard is being raked by a 12-year-old with an assault rifle, or that you are quite likely to see a car chase through the streets of Manhattan. In fact, Americans drive much more slowly than Europeans and for the most part lead lives of dull plenty in the suburbs. Except in the big cities, America is astonishingly slow and conservative. HL Mencken, the great journalist of the first half of the century, certainly understood this when he attacked the way Americans refuse to discuss religion: "The result is that all religions are equally safeguarded against criticism, and that all of them lose vitality. We protect the status quo and so make steady war upon revision and improvement. That is a profoundly clever observation about the US, which is so often mistaken for the jittery crucible of invention. In areas other than commercial enterprise, it has been remarkably slow to challenge the status quo - segregation and gun law - mostly from fear of offending the Bill of Rights and Constitution. While America has a clear narrative to its political history which unrolls with fascinating drama but always with a consistent set of interests and procedures, Europe is evidently prey to more mobile and fitful political passions. In 1925 Mencken saw how the two cultures rubbed each other up the wrong way. Europeans, he wrote, despaired of "our growing impatience with the free play of ideas, our increasing tendency to reduce all virtues to the single one of conformity, our relentless and all pervading standardisation." That still encapsulates the European doubt about the United States of America, and if you add the big issues listed on the charge sheet, you pretty much have it all. George Bush is a product of that deeply conservative strain in America that wars against revision and improvement. In Europe we are brave enough or foolish enough to think that we can revise and improve, which is why the clash occurs. To my mind the division appears deeper than it actually is, and in fact I'd bet my last dollar that we won't throw in our lot with Europe, which many suggest is the logical outcome of the current frustrations with American conservatism. There is one point that everyone is forgetting in the heated debate about Kyoto. America invented environmentalism and still has a high proportion of people who give to environmental charities and believe that taxes should be raised to fight pollution. Continental drift: how the US and Europe see the world Cuba The European view: Hip holiday destination du jour, presided over by everyone's favourite Manics-loving uncle; home of record-breaking athletes, lyrical love poetry, and salsa The US view: Depraved, child-snatching, tyrannical dictatorship hell bent on - and, frankly, fairly close to achieving - world domination; home of massive narcotics industry, cigars, and (a particularly clever form of cultural warfare, this) salsa Guns The European view: Lethal weaponry enabling alienated American high-school internet enthusiasts to massacre their unsuspecting classmates The US view: Constitutionally enshrined form of protection enabling high-school students to defend themselves against attempted massacres by their alienated classmates Litigation The European view: Expensive, time-consuming, intimidating system allowing rich people to stop everyone else from saying nasty things about them The US view: Popular recreational sport, like baseball, allowing Americans to generate a useful second income from spilling coffee on themselves Foot and mouth The European view: Hugely problematic catastrophe that threatens the global importance of Britain's agricultural industry The US view: Yet another reason to steer clear of London, like BSE, pickpockets, and the aftermath of war in nearby Bosnia Sierra Leone The European view: Worryingly unstable West African country benefiting from a spot of good old-fashioned British army training. The US view: Where? Oliver Burkeman <>BRelated special report Special report: global warming Useful links Do you know your Bushisms? Spoof: GWBush.com The White House Capitol Steps political satire

webTitle: Give minister of sport more clout say MPs

fields.headline: Give minister of sport more clout say MPs
fields.trailText: Sport and its minister should be split off from the department of culture, media and sport and given a raised profile, according to a Commons select committee report that also criticises the government's decision to take athletics out of the plans for the new Wembley stadium.
fields.body:
Sport and its minister should be split off from the department of culture, media and sport and given a raised profile, according to a Commons select committee report that also criticises the government's decision to take athletics out of the plans for the new Wembley stadium.

The report, by the culture, media and sport select committee, says: "There is no doubt that the minister for sport should be a more important role and maybe it will give fresh life to the people who hold the job. What we do advocate is that it should be a senior ministerial role within the Cabinet Office.

"That means it would give direct access to the prime minister and it is inevitable that more influence would come with that. Ian McCartney's role as minister for the Commonwealth Games is within the Cabinet Office and he has been enormously effective."

The committee found sport was badly run by the government, leading to problems with major projects such as international events and the construction of new stadiums.

The report claims that the government has failed to keep up with the changing nature of sport and that a proliferation of organisations has led to confusion in the way sport is run. It calls for a more streamlined system, including a new organisation to coordinate bids for major events and that it should be led by a minister for events who would have the final say over important decisions, such as whether or not Britain should bid for the Olympics or the World Cup.

The committee identifies "many problems of overlapping responsibilities" and claims that "too many issues that fall into the gaps between bodies".

"There is an overwhelming need for institutional reform and simplification. We recommend that the major events steering group of UK Sport and the Government and Agencies Committee within government be abolished and both be replaced by a single decision-making body chaired by the minister for events."

Regarding Wembley, the report criticises the government for its lack of control over the project and failure to communicate with the different bodies involved in the construction of a new stadium.

"There has been great confusion and feeling that there has been a lack of coming together within the governance of sport," said committee member David Faber in the report.

"There are four sports ministers as a result of devolution and that has to be taken into account but there are also different lottery-funding bodies and there seems to be a lack of cohesion between the government and these bodies."

The report is also critical of the deal done between Chris Smith, secretary of state for culture, media and sport, and the Football Association over the return of £20m of lottery money to Sport England after it was decided that athletics would not feature at Wembley.

Faber described the deal as "mysterious" and claimed that there were question marks over its legality.

Organisers of the Commonwealth Games in Manchester next year are also warned that unless they raise the event's profile, it could be a flop.

MPs visited the games site last month. The report claims that merchandising is "almost invisible" and that work needs to begin immediately on raising public awareness.

fields.headline: Italian steak now extra rare
fields.standfirst: The famed Florentine T-bone is the latest casualty in the country's beleaguered food industry, says Rory Carroll
fields.trailText: The famed Florentine T-bone is the latest casualty in the country's beleaguered food industry, says Rory Carroll in Rome.
fields.body:
For tourists, the only evidence of turmoil might be a line crossing out a dish on a restaurant menu and a waiter's sigh. But Italy's food industry is in trouble, and the impact is rippling from farms into the cities.

The famed Florentine T-bone steak this week become the latest casualty of the mad cow scare. Banned as dangerous, a funeral was held in Tuscany with a coffin, hearse and laments.

Italy's eleventh case of mad cow disease, or BSE, has just been reported. Before January there was only the case of two cows imported from Britain.

Italy's homegrown cows were safe, the product of superior farming techniques, respect for nature and government controls. So it was said.

Since testing began in earnest, scientists have discovered otherwise. Most of the cases have been on northern farms, where the bulk of Italy's 7m cows are reared. Between 800 and 1,000 are tested daily and the number of confirmed cases rises each week.

A British-scale catastrophe is not expected but thousands of farmers say they face ruin. Demonstrations in front of parliament have turned nasty.

A spate of food industry scandals and revelations have shaken consumer confidence as never before. For a country which cares so much about what it eats, that hurts.

The mafia has branched out into setting up illegal slaughterhouses from which it sells infected meat, according to the anti-vivisection league.

Cattle rustling has increased by a fifth and 1,800 of 2,000 slaughterhouses were breaking European Union regulations, it said.

Mobsters are also said to have infiltrated the disposal of carcasses, in some cases using incinerators used for human corpses.

This week the agriculture minister, Alfonso Pecoraro Scanio, accused the biotechnelogy firm Monsanto of distributing banned genetically modified seeds to growers. Monsanto rejected the claim but suspected environmental militants broke into their depot near Milan and set fire to a granary.

One of Umbria's biggest truffle vendors, Urbani Tartufi, a respected family firm in the Valnerina valley, has been accused of tax evasion and fraud.

Two years ago tons of Chinese truffles were found in a company warehouse but allegations that they were to be passed off as Umbrian were never proven.

In the four days that Florentine T-bones have been banned rumours have circulated of an underground trade. Tuscan butchers in particular are convinced the steaks are safe and boast, anonymously, of supplying a black market.

Restaurants, however, are striking off other beef dishes such as calf's intestine glistening in tomato sauce and tail simmered in red wine.

In their place are offered extra fish and vegetable dishes, plus less familiar meats such as kangaroo, ostrich, buffalo, horse and reindeer. Diced, sliced, stewed, fried or grilled, chefs and diners are exploring the best ways.

Despite its anxieties, Italy's food industry has more public confidence, at least for now, than Britain's. Two suspected cases of foot and mouth turned out to be negative, leaving Italy free of the disease.

The government is taking no chances. On Tuesday this week, a ban on imports of livestock and livestock products from Britain and parts of France, the Netherlands and Ireland, was extended until April 19.

fields.headline: Channel 4 to make Egyptian epic
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: Channel 4 has ordered a £6m documentary series on ancient Egypt with special effects from the team who worked on Gladiator. By Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has ordered a £6m documentary series on ancient Egypt with special effects from the Oscar-winning outfit behind the computer graphics for movie smash hit Gladiator.

Ancient Egyptians is already being talked about as the next Walking with Dinosaurs, with special effects that will recreate the pyramids and other features of early Egyptian civilisation.

The documentary will combine live action and computer-generated special effects, with each of the six half-hour episodes telling a key story from Egyptian history.

"The series will be an extraordinary journey through Egyptian history from the construction of the first pyramids to the last decadent days of Alexandria," said series producer Ben Goold.

Producer Wall to Wall Television, the company behind The 1900 House and Neanderthal, will be drawing on evidence from primary sources including old documents, court records and inscriptions to reconstruct life in ancient Egypt.

The special effects will be supplied by The Mill, which recently picked up an Oscar for its work on Roman epic Gladiator.

Ancient Egyptians is due to go into production this summer and will be delivered to Channel 4 in mid-2003.

The series is also backed by US cable channel TLC and is being distributed internationally by Granada International. It has already been sold to Germany.

Ancient Egypt will be a multi media property featuring a tie-in book, video, DVD and interactive and enhanced versions of the series.
