fields.headline: French Connection may rethink advertising
fields.trailText:
10.45am: French Connection's new marketing chief is set to review the company's controversial advertising strategy, reports Julia Day.
Apr 3: Watchdog reins in French Connection
fields.body:
French Connection's new marketing director is set to review the company's controversial advertising strategy.

The appointment of L'Oreal senior product manager Matthew Griffiths coincides with the Advertising Standards Authority ruling that French Connection's outdoor advertising must be pre-vetted for the next two years.

The sanction was imposed after the ASA upheld 132 complaints that French Connection's "fcukinkybugger" poster campaign was offensive and irresponsible.

Mr Griffiths has been hired to replace marketing director Claire Dobbie, who left last month to join marketing consultancy Branded.

He previously held marketing positions at Habitat and haircare company Charles Worthington.

In his new role Mr Griffiths will report to French Connection chief executive Stephen Marks.

"Matthew will definitely look at reviewing the advertising and marketing strategy," said a spokeswoman for French Connection.

"We will take what the ASA has said on board but we have no definite plans yet as it only happened this week."

The company is unlikely to part with its advertising agency TBWA London and its creative director Trevor Beattie, who masterminded the "fcuk" strapline.

fields.headline: 13m tune in to EastEnders cliffhanger
fields.trailText: 6.30pm TV overnights: Almost 13m viewers tuned in hoping to see Phil Mitchell confront his assailant, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Almost 13m viewers, 59% of audience share, tuned in hoping to see Phil Mitchell confront his assailant in EastEnders last night.

The tension mounted as Phil left hospital, returned to Albert Square for the cliffhanger ending when he knocked on mystery attacker's door.

Viewers will have to wait until tomorrow to see the whodunnit ending when more than 15m are expected tune in.

Over on ITV at 7.30pm, Star Treatment attracted 4.3m viewers, a 20% share.

But 6.5m viewers tuned in for the Bill at 8pm.

On BBC1 the audience fell from the EastEnders evening high to 7.4m for hospital drama Holby City.

webTitle: American Atheists fight for founder's remains

fields.headline: American Atheists fight for founder's remains
fields.standfirst: The born-again son of the group's murdered leader has given her a Christian burial, says Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: The born-again son of the group's murdered leader has given her a Christian burial, says Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles.
fields.body:
Conservative Christians in the United States had absolutely no doubt where Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the founder of American Atheists, would go when she died, and it was not a place where angels sang and Saint Peter operated the door policy.

But now an angry dispute is under way over just what should happen to the remains of the woman once described by Life magazine as the "most hated woman in America", who disappeared in 1995 and whose murdered remains have only just been recovered.

The row helps to spotlight just how hard it is to be an atheist in the United States where every politician has to profess sincere beliefs and every other award winner feels obliged to thank God for their good fortune.

One of O'Hair's children, who has become a born-again Christian, has spirited her remains away to a hidden grave with a preacher in attendance. He said that he believed his mother may well have had a change of heart and "turned to Jesus" in the hours where she was waiting, bound and gagged, to be killed.

Now the American Atheists are considering a legal battle to have the remains of their founder given to them on the grounds that the last thing she would have wanted would be a Christian burial. They claim she abhorred such ceremonies and wanted to be cremated and have her ashes scattered to the winds.

O'Hair was a larger than life character who took on the Christian establishment in the US and campaigned to have compulsory prayers removed from the school system, after objecting to the fact that her son, William, had to take part in them.

But he speculated that his mother may have undergone a last-minute conversion after she had been tied up by her murderers. "That last day they were bound and gagged with duct tape, maybe unable to speak, able only to think. In those hours, did they have a change of heart and turn to Jesus? The dispute helps to highlight some remarkable statistics about belief. A survey carried out by the International Social Survey Programme found that only 3.2% of Americans say that they do not believe in God, while throughout Europe around six times as many would profess atheism.

In the US, 86% of the population believes in heaven, twice the figure for the UK, and 76% believe in hell.

While social attitudes have changed dramatically in the last 20 years in the US, to the extent that 92% would now elect a woman for president (up from 76% in 1978) and 95% would be happy with a black president (up from 73%) less than half the country would even now consider voting for a professed atheist. fields.headline: Messier sues for defamation
fields.trailText:
11.45am: The Vivendi Universal chief is taking legal action against a German telecoms executive, reports Dan Milmo.
Apr 3: Messier fuels rumours of Yahoo! alliance
fields.body:
Jean-Marie Messier, the chief executive of French media giant Vivendi Universal, is suing a German telecoms executive for defamation.

Mr Messier was incensed by comments made by Klaus Esser, former chief executive of Mannesmann, in this morning's Financial Times.

"Following Mr Esser's declarations, Mr Messier has decided to take legal action for defamation against Mr Esser," Vivendi said in a brief statement.

Mr Esser claimed Mannesmann was forced to accept a takeover bid from UK rival Vodafone in January last year after Mr Messier abruptly abandoned a merger with the German company.

Mannesmann, which was desperate to avoid a Vodafone takeover, was clinging to the hope of a Vivendi rescue bid.

The German executive described Mr Messier's behaviour as "indecent" and "dishonourable" and accused the Frenchman of negotiating with Vodafone while engaged in delicate negotiations with Mannesmann.

"I had been discussing things with Mr Messier that could only be discussed in a climate of absolute trust," said Mr Esser.

Instead of tying up the Mannesmann deal, Mr Messier shocked the mobile phone company by announcing it had established the Vizzavi internet joint venture with Vodafone.

Mr Esser claims the Vizzavi deal and Vivendi's subsequent abandonment of merger talks forced him to recommend the Vodafone takeover bid to a reluctant Mannesmann board.

Mr Esser also hit out at rumours he accepted the £109bn bid in exchange for the promise of a £19m redundancy package.

The payment is now being investigated by public prosecutors in Germany.

"The whole story is driven by envy and is nothing but a slanderous media coup," he said.

However, the Vivendi chief executive has hit back at allegations of his duplicity, saying Mr Esser knew he was talking to Vodafone counterpart Chris Gent.

"In an industrial war, as in any war, discussing with both camps is always a delicate exercise.

"Of course Chris Gent and Klaus Esser knew we were talking to both of them," said Mr Messier.

Vivendi Universal was unavailable for further comment.

fields.headline: 'No special favours for Sophie' insists PCC chief
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Lord Wakeham today denied he was responsible for negotiating 'special favours' for Sophie Rhys Jones. By Jessica Hodgson.

Apr 2: The Countess and the tabloid sting

Apr 2: Sheikh rattles and rolls out star victims
fields.body:
A rift opended between Buckingham Palace and the Press Complaints Commission today after the chairman of the watchdog took the unprecedented step of denying he was responsible for negotiating "special favours" for Sophie Rhys Jones.

Three days after the Countess of Wessex debacle broke, Lord Wakeham has declared the royals were treated just like any other member of the public.

In a letter to the Daily Telegraph today, he said: "The Palace asked for no special favours and would have received none."

He was stirred into action following Buckingham Palace claims that the News of the World interview with the countess in which she talked about Prince Edward not being gay was arranged "in conjunction" with the PCC.

Lord Wakeham confirmed the Palace had approached by the PCC two weeks ago when it first emerged that secret recordings had been made by the News of the World.

"I gave them exactly the same advice that the PCC gives countless members of the public - and public figures alike - who approach us every week for help before an article is published," Lord Wakeham said.

"I told them there were two courses of action open to them. Either they could wait until the Sunday newspaper in question had published transcripts and complain to us if they thought it breached the newspaper industry code.

"Or they could approach the newspaper direct, in advance of publication, to argue their case and see if some accommodation could be reached."

He added: "After that discussion, the decision on the course of action was the Palace's alone." The PCC had no "further role in the marker".

Lord Wakeham's tersely worded letter will be seen as a direct rebuke of the Queen's press secretary Simon Lewis, who reportedly told friends he was advised by the PCC to sanction Sophie Wessex's interview with the News of the World.

The interview spectacularly backfired on the newspaper, which is now being seen as the Palace's puppet.

Editor Rebekah Wade agreed not to publish the dynamite material obtained by her undercover reporter Mazher Mahmood, who duped the Countess by posing as a sheikh seeking business with her PR firm.

She is alleged to have called the wife of the prime minister, Cherie Booth, "horrid, horrid, horrid", and described the Queen as "the old dear".

The damage limitation strategy mounted by Buckingham Palace also backfired after the Mail on Sunday was tipped off about the taped interview.

Today the Palace is bracing itself for even more embarrassing revelations. It is claimed a second set of tapes exists about the countess's PR firm, Rhys-Jones Harkin.

fields.headline: Labour's Independence Day broadcast
fields.trailText: The Labour party has prepared an election broadcast themed after the film Independence Day, showing the City of London under threat from a Tory spaceship representing boom and bust. By Matthew Tempest.
fields.body:
The Labour party has prepared an election broadcast themed after the film Independence Day, showing the City of London under threat from a Tory spaceship representing boom and bust.

The mini-movie, which has already been shot, features businessmen and women in suits looking up as a huge shadow falls over the skyscrapers of London's financial centre.

The Hollywood blockbuster-inspired broadcast mirrors current Labour adverts on billboards across the country, showing the shadow chancellor Michael Portillo alongside William Hague with the slogan "Economic Disaster II".

That poster show an explosion engulfing the two men. The new five-minute election broadcast mimics the 1996 smash hit film, which showed a shadow falling across landmark sites in New York and the White House, before an alien spaceship destroyed them in a ball of fire.

"They've clearly been watching too many movies - it's all a pathetic fantasy," said a Tory party insider.

"What they know full well is that they inherited the strongest economic position of modern times and no lying will get around the fact they've been reduced to negative campaigning rather than running on their own record."

A spokesman for shadow chancellor Michael Portillo said "There is nothing in Conservative plans which can possibly substantiate this claim of boom and bust".

Each of the main three parties is allowed five party election broadcasts during the campaign proper, now expected to run from early May to June 7.

Last week Guardian Unlimited revealed how the Conservative party planned to shoot a commercial showing illegal immigrants trying to enter Britain - the ad was later dropped after widespread outcry.

A spokesman for the Labour party today refused to comment on the broadcast, saying only that "the content of Labour's election broadcasts has not yet been decided."

"There is no reason why Labour should not campaign on the Tory record of boom and bust," he went on. "You only have to look at our economic meltdown poster campaign to see that."

Asked if any more election broadcasts had been shot, the spokesman added "We do not reveal Labour's election strategy ahead of time."

fields.headline: Infectious diseases
fields.standfirst: The foot and mouth outbreak has show how quickly a contagious disease can spiral out of control. With the return of TB, Simon Jeffery examines some potential epidemics
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth outbreak has show how quickly a contagious disease can spiral out of control. With the return of TB, Simon Jeffery examines some potential epidemics.
fields.body:
Tuberculosis
Nearly 2bn people, just under a third of the world's population, are infected with TB. Infection is estimated to occur at 20 times the rate of mortality but TB is still the leading cause of death from a single organism in the world today. It kills more adults each year than Aids and malaria combined.

The bacteria that causes the disease can survive for months if dry and is resistant to mild disinfectants. Historically, TB became an epidemic in the west during the industrial revolution when cramped living conditions in poorly sanitised cities aided its transmission. It was the leading cause of death in the industrialised nations until early last century.

TB's grip today is intensified by the emergence of strains that are increasingly drug resistant - and these can result in an incurable form of the disease that in most cases prove fatal. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that more than 50m people worldwide may be infected with such a strain.

The bacteria is spread when an infected person coughs or sneezes, or even talks, and the discharge is inhaled by a healthy person. TB begins with weight loss, lack of energy and coughing. As the disease progresses the cough gets worse and may start to bring up blood from a lesion in the lung, although any organ can be affected. When TB kills it is usually because damaged lung tissue prevents the sufferer from adequately breathing.

Since the 1980s, the spread of HIV has contributed to an increase in TB infections. It is a significant cause of death in developing countries.

Foot and mouth
Foot and mouth is probably more infectious than any other disease affecting animals - it spreads rapidly if uncontrolled. Sheep, pigs and cattle are susceptible but also hedgehogs, elephants and rats.

There are millions of ways in which the virus can be carried. A sandwich brought over on an aeroplane from an infected country, for example, would be capable of carrying the disease.

The 1967 outbreak, which led to the slaughter of 400,000 animals, was traced back to an infected leg of lamb from Argentina. A farmer cooked the lamb and fed the bone to his dog, which left it near some pigs. However, it can also be spread by the wind - a factor that is thought to be spreading the disease today.

Foot and mouth is an acute infectious viral disease causing fever, followed by the development of blisters chiefly in the mouth and on the feet. Type O - the strain in Britain - started in 1991 in south Asia and spread through Arabia to first reach Europe in 1996. The UN warns that animals, animal products and humans crossing the world as either tourists or migrants could carry the virus.

Ebola
Named after a river in Zaire - its first site of discovery in 1976 - the Ebola virus affects monkeys, apes and humans. It is usually fatal. Early symptoms include fever, severe headaches and loss of appetite. In the later stages vomiting, bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain, sore throat, and chest pain can occur. In these cases, the virus is liquefying the internal body as it destroys the cells in the liver and the lining of all other organs. Uncontrollable internal and external bleeding is often followed by death.

There are two principal strains: Ebola Zaire is fatal in approximately 90% of cases and Ebola Sudan in around 60%. Outbreaks have occurred predominately in Africa but there has been one in the United States. The most recent major fatalities were in 1996 in a village in Gabon, west Africa, where 70 people died after, it is believed, children found and ate an infected chimpanzee.

The virus is spread through close contact and carries easily, though it must come from a person or primate who is already very ill with the disease. Re-using needles and caring for sufferers without adequate protection, especially if this involves coming into contact with their bodily fluids, will soon spread Ebola. The virus may also be present for a brief period in people who have made a full recovery.

No evidence exists as yet that the Zaire and Sudan strains are airborne. The American strain, Ebola Reston, appears to have been transmitted through the air to humans from Filipino monkeys imported to a laboratory in Virginia. Four humans developed antibodies but did not become ill.

There is no cure for Ebola and little is known about its source. Extensive ecological studies are currently underway in Cote d'Ivoire to identify the host. One theory is that the virus may be transmitted by bats who are shown to have an immunity to Ebola in tests

Influenza
There are three broad varieties of influenza - types A, B and C. The virus tends to spread across the world in wave-like epidemics on regular cycles. Type A reappears every two to three years and type B every four to five.

The 1919 epidemic killed 40m people worldwide. It is the most serious to date, though pandemics in 1957 ("Asian flu") and 1968 ("Hong Kong flu") both killed millions around the world. Influenza was first described by Hippocrates in 412 BC and the first well-described pandemic of influenza-like disease occurred in 1580.

The infection is spread by coughing and sneezing. As the virus enters the body they attack the cells that line the upper respiratory tract. Symptoms include chills, fevers and muscular aches. Death - when it occurs - is frequently from complications such as pneumonia and bronchitis.

Mortality is low among the young but older people are especially vunerable. A 1999 outbreak in Britain left 20,000 people dead from related illnesses. Its ability to kill stems from the fact that the virus can mutate quickly, often producing new strains against which human beings have no immunity.

There is evidence that new strains come from animals. The 1919 epidemic is traced back to pigs and the later pandemics from birds. A 1997 outbreak of a new strain of avian (bird) flu in Hong Kong led to the slaughter of 2000 chickens. No cure exists for influenza and the most commonly followed course of action is to develop a vaccination for the next anticipated strain.

Dengue fever
The WHO estimates that there are more than 50m cases of this flu-like fever each year. This mosquito-borne infection is endemic in more than a hundred countries worldwide. Before 1970 only nine countries had experienced an epidemic.

Dengue is the leading cause of childhood mortality in several Asian countries. In adults it can lead to a temporary incapacitation but rarely death. With intensive treatment fatality rates are around 1%, but left alone they can exceed 20%.

Besides fever, the disease is characterised by extreme pain and stiffness in the joints. There is no specific treatment and immunisation is difficult since the virus has four principal strains. Protection against only one or two of them could increase the risk of more serious disease. The most successful prevention is to destroy mosquitoes and their breeding grounds.

In adults it can lead to a temporary incapacitation but rarely death. With intensive treatment fatality rates are around 1%, but left alone they can exceed 20%. Besides fever, the disease is characterised by extreme pain and stiffness in the joints. There is no specific treatment and immunisation is difficult since the virus has four principal strains. Protection against only one or two of them could increase the risk of more serious disease. The most successful prevention is to destroy mosquitoes and their breeding grounds.

webTitle: Barbra Streisand hits out at Bush

fields.headline: Barbra Streisand hits out at Bush
fields.standfirst:
Star voices Hollywood's frustration with Democrats' passivity as new policies swing US to the right

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The singer Barbra Streisand has fired off a blistering letter to leading Democrats in Washington calling on them to start fighting the "destructive" Bush administration.
fields.body:
The singer Barbra Streisand has fired off a blistering letter to leading Democrats in Washington calling on them to start fighting the "destructive" Bush administration.

The letter crystallises the feelings of many Democrat backers from the entertainment world who are puzzled that President Bush appears to have encountered so little opposition to his aggressively rightwing agenda.

The letter to senior Democrats is entitled "Nice Guys Finish Last or Where Do We Go From Here: A Case for the Democrats." It chides the Democrats for not doing enough to attack Mr Bush and his policies.

"What has happened to the Democrats since the November election? Some of you seem paralysed, demoralised and depressed," writes the 58-year-old Oscar-winning singer, actor and director, who has been one of the Democrats' key fundraisers in Hollywood.

She also attacks Mr Bush for reneging on electoral commitments to end partisan politics. "Look at his ratings - how could such a destructive man be so popular with the American people? Not only is he poisoning our air and water by withdrawing his promise to enforce emissions standards and arsenic regulations, but he's poisoning our political system as well. Bipartisanship only works if you can trust the other side. As we have learned in the past weeks, we cannot trust George W Bush."

The star of Funny Girl and A Star is Born writes: "We have a president who stole the presidency through family ties, arrogance and intimidation. We have a Congress passing laws that benefit corporations and the privileged few at the expense of the working men and women of this country."

Many politically active members from the entertainment world share Streisand's dismay that Mr Bush has moved the country to the right, in policy changes on the environment and abortion rights - with little obvious opposition.

webTitle: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
Movable removals

Our recent items on dodgy or incompetent removals firms appear to have roused many of you to put pen to paper and enlighten us as to your delivery woes. Leonard Fearenside of Walsall paid a company called UK Worldwide Movers to ship some packages to Adelaide in Australia last October. Three months later, a handling agent in Sydney demanded a hefty fee from the recipient before dispatching the goods to their final destination. According to the Australian firm, UK Worldwide Movers had failed to make arrangements for forwarding the packages to Adelaide. The goods are still stranded on a wharf in Sydney and three letters to UK Worldwide Movers from Fearenside, including two sent recorded delivery, have not been replied to. "I've also made over 11 phone calls and on only two occasions have I been able to speak to the person I was told was dealing with the matter," says Fearenside. "I understand that the Sydney agent has given up hope of hearing from them."

Consumer gets through to a kindly sounding gentleman called Steve Banks who tells us that UK Worldwide Movers ceased trading on March 1 and that he's there to oversee unfinished business. The traditionally quiet winter season took its toll, he laments. It turns out that he's too modest to admit that he is the company secretary, but more of that later. By cosy coincidence, UK Worldwide Movers had adopted the telephone number of the defunct removals firm Cargo Forwarding, whose antics we reported last month. "We thought it would get us good business but it's been a nightmare," he says. Banks blames the Australian agent for double-charging Fearenside and promises to send him a cheque to cover his extra outlay. He's as good as his word and Fearenside is now contented, but, meanwhile, an interesting picture emerges from Essex Trading Standards.

Like Cargo Forwarding, the company is phoenix-like in its regeneration. It began as Overseas Moving Services in 1993 and changed its name to Global Moving Services then Red Gulf Transport. A compulsory liquidation order was imposed in 1997 after an investigation by the Office of Fair Trading. Another company, Goodline Management, was set up in its place under the same director and that too was ordered to wind up. Next it became Goldvale Associates, still with the same director, until it was served a compulsory liquidation order last August. UK Worldwide Movers, registered at the same address in 1999, was already poised to leap into the breach and has now ceased trading under its own volition. Trading Standards says it has dealt with all the previous incarnations of the firm and that the common link is none other than Mr Steve Banks. "He's been involved all the way along," says a spokesman. "We've had complaints about goods not being delivered on time or not at all and of agents or shipping companies who've not been paid and so charge the customer. By the time some people have located their goods, they've run up big storage fees." Back to Banks who admits he was "deeply involved" as export manager of the previous companies, but denies that goods have been mislaid or agents not paid. "The Trading Standards' information isn't wrong, just misconstrued," he says. He is currently considering whether or not to set up a new firm. Trading Standards is powerless to stop the company reinventing itself because its investigations show that it has breached civil, not criminal, law.

Cargo capers

In the meantime we've heard from Susan Doyle in Australia and Makaiki Chithambo from South Africa, both of whom are victims of Cargo Forwarding. Doyle, who eventually traced her goods to Asia, is being asked to pay a delivery fee to a Melbourne agent who claims it has received nothing from Cargo. Chithambo was expecting £25,000 of research equipment, which has vanished, last heard of in Taiwan. Alas, as we wrote before, there's nothing Consumer can do because the company is in liquidation, although future emigres should beware of its new incarnation, CFI, based in Milton Keynes. The only good news is that a new Insolvency Act, due to be implemented this year, will speed up the disqualification of unfit company directors, although rogue entrepreneurs can get round this by appointing stooges. The new law will also enable Trading Standards authorities to issue Stop Now orders to arrest rogue traders in their tracks.

fields.headline: Giggs agrees new United deal
fields.trailText: Ryan Giggs has agreed a new five-year contract with Manchester United. Giggs, who will put pen to paper at the end of the season, has followed Andy Cole and Jaap Stam in committing his future to United.
fields.body:
Ryan Giggs has agreed a new five-year contract with Manchester United. Giggs, who will put pen to paper at the end of the season, has followed Andy Cole and Jaap Stam in committing his future to United.

"I'm really pleased to have agreed a new deal," the 27-year-old said. "I've had a fantastic time at United and I hope to enjoy as much success with the lads in the future as I have in the past 10 years."

United manager Sir Alex Ferguson was equally pleased with the news. "I'm delighted that Ryan has agreed a new contract," he said. "His performances over the years have thrilled the fans and he has played a big part in helping the club achieve consistent success."

Giggs has won 11 major honours with United since making his debut as a 17-year-old against Everton in March 1991 and has scored 86 goals in 435 appearances.

The Welshman cannot officially sign his new contract until July 1 because the transfer deadline passed in March. United will now turn their attentions to unresolved negotiations with players such as David Beckham, Gary Neville and Paul Scholes.

webTitle: Foot and mouth in the media

fields.headline: Day 44: foot and mouth in the media
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk keeps you informed with a daily briefing on the press coverage of foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
Day 44: Several papers lead with the news 900 carcasses are to be dug up because they were buried in the wrong place.
Special report: foot and mouth in the media
fields.body:
The Independent
Two pages of coverage of foot and mouth are headed by a photograph of Tony Blair striding purposefully to a press conference under the headline: "Blair urges council leaders to reopen footpaths". And the Review section carries a personal account of Independent journalist John Walsh's efforts to go vegetarian.

The Guardian
Foot and mouth is back on the front page. A list of errors and misjudgments in the handling of the crisis appears under the headline: "What a shambles". Environment minister Michael Meacher caused embarrassment for Mr Blair when he jumped the gun by announcing there would be a government enquiry when the crisis is over.

The Mirror
The Mirror is one of several papers to lead its coverage with the news the carcasses of almost 900 animals are to be dug up because they were buried in the wrong place. The Environment Agency said it had warned the Ministry of Agriculture they could pollute a spring used by farms.

The Sun
Canada turned away a British ship supplying troops because of fears mud left on Land Rovers would spread foot and mouth disease. And William Hague's call for the military to take over the cull and disposal of condemned animals was shot down by the army.

Daily Express
The paper splashes on the news a farmer has committed suicide after foot and mouth hit the farm next door to his. Extensive coverage of the crisis continues on pages eight, nine and 10. And the paper's leader accuses the Environment Agency of incompetence over its role in the decision to bury carcasses on land that was likely to leach water and pollute other areas.

fields.headline: Labour's Independence Day broadcast
fields.standfirst: View our classic poster archive
fields.trailText: The Labour party has prepared an election broadcast themed after the film Independence Day, showing the City of London under threat from a Tory spaceship representing boom and bust. By Matthew Tempest.
fields.body:
The Labour party has prepared an election broadcast themed after the film Independence Day, showing the City of London under threat from a Tory spaceship representing boom and bust.

The mini-movie, which has already been shot, features businessmen and women in suits looking up as a huge shadow falls over the skyscrapers of London's financial centre.

The Hollywood blockbuster-inspired broadcast mirrors current Labour adverts on billboards across the country, showing the shadow chancellor Michael Portillo alongside William Hague with the slogan "Economic Disaster II".

That poster show an explosion engulfing the two men. The new five-minute election broadcast mimics the 1996 smash hit film, which showed a shadow falling across landmark sites in New York and the White House, before an alien spaceship destroyed them in a ball of fire.

"They've clearly been watching too many movies - it's all a pathetic fantasy," said a Tory party insider.

"What they know full well is that they inherited the strongest economic position of modern times and no lying will get around the fact they've been reduced to negative campaigning rather than running on their own record."

A spokesman for shadow chancellor Michael Portillo said "There is nothing in Conservative plans which can possibly substantiate this claim of boom and bust".

Each of the main three parties is allowed five party election broadcasts during the campaign proper, now expected to run from early May to June 7.

Last week Guardian Unlimited revealed how the Conservative party planned to shoot a commercial showing illegal immigrants trying to enter Britain - the ad was later dropped after widespread outcry.

A spokesman for the Labour party today refused to comment on the broadcast, saying only that "the content of Labour's election broadcasts has not yet been decided."

"There is no reason why Labour should not campaign on the Tory record of boom and bust," he went on. "You only have to look at our economic meltdown poster campaign to see that."

Asked if any more election broadcasts had been shot, the spokesman added "We do not reveal Labour's election strategy ahead of time."

fields.headline: Reuters' online float under fire
fields.standfirst: Sector analysts baffled by timing of $3bn broker offering
fields.trailText: Reuters came under fire from media analysts for a 'baffling' decision to press ahead with a $3bn (£2.1bn) float of its electronic broking business Instinet, writes Andrew Clark.
fields.body:
Reuters came under fire from media analysts for a "baffling" decision to press ahead with a $3bn (£2.1bn) float of its electronic broking business Instinet, braving plunging stock markets around the world.

In a filing to the US securities and exchange commission, Reuters yesterday revealed that Instinet's shares would be priced at $11 to $14 on the hi-tech US Nasdaq. This values the business at $2.6bn to $3.3bn - well below initial expectations of $4bn.

One industry analyst said: "The timing is a mystery - I find it baffling. Maybe they think the markets are going to get worse if they delay it."

Instinet provides online share dealing services to financial institutions. Reuters shares plunged 79p to 775p on concerns that the offering would be a failure.

A Reuters spokesman said: "We're doing this for strategic reasons, not as a device to raise money. The current market conditions won't deflect us."

Reuters is offering 14% of Instinet to investors, keeping the rest of the shares itself. The spokesman said: "There comes a time when some of the group's operations are better off with a degree of autonomy in management."

Supporters of the flotation point out that it will generate money for Reuters to reinvest in the business, helping Instinet diversify from trading in equities to fixed-income investments. Paul Richards of WestLB Panmure said: "This isn't just financial engineering - it's to raise cash to develop the business."

Critics say Instinet operates in a high risk, price sensitive environment. One analyst said: "There must be a broader agenda here. There's a lot of uncertainty about trading in Europe, and about the future of stock markets. Maybe they're planning a bid for the [London] Stock Exchange."

webTitle: The cost to local councils of failing to complete census forms

fields.headline: True to forms
fields.standfirst: You face a £1,000 fine if you don't fill in a census form, but it could cost your local council far more.
fields.trailText: You face a £1,000 fine if you don't fill in a census form, but it could cost your local council far more.
fields.body:
Later this month, 24m households will take part in the biggest peacetime activity in Britain. Across the country, people will answer questions on everything from the size of their home to their health, jobs and ethnicity. The census is a unique snapshot of the nation - the only source of reliable, nationally comparable statistics for different areas.

Setting aside its importance to the archives and statisticians, there is a more pressing reason why the census is vital to local authorities: money.

On Sunday, April 29, each person who completes a census form will be worth approximately £1,000 a year to their local council, because public spending - under the standard spending assessment for local government - is directly informed by the census. Over the 10-year life of the census, each person is worth some £10,000 to their local authority.

Nationally, the data will be used to help decide an annual £50bn of public spending. Regionally, the census will inform £1.4bn of public spending in Liverpool and Merseyside, £2.3bn in Greater Manchester and £9bn in London. The data gleaned from the census also provides the base for competitive funding such as single regeneration bids and other government grants.

If people fail to complete and return census forms, they are not counted. As funding is based on the size and needs of a population, a low count means low funding. One "missing" person means a potential loss of £10,000 in funding over the next 10 years - funding which could be spent on extra teachers, policemen, schools or day centres.

In 1991, 1m people went missing. That was discovered only when returns from individuals were compared with projections and estimates from the 1981 count. Each of them could have "earned" money for their local authority. There are no accurate figures to show exactly how much money was lost as a result of the census's missing respondents, but today, if the same thing happened, councils across the country would suffer a potential loss of billions of pounds in grants.

One of the areas worst affected by the apathy in 1991 was Brent, north London. It was discovered, after comparing projections with returns, that some 20,000 people in the borough went missing. With each person worth a potential £1,000 a year to the council, it is estimated Brent has since lost - or, rather, failed to atttract - a potential £200m in funding.

The money, says Brent council, could have paid for 500 nurses, 286 police officers or 323 teachers. "If people are invisible, we simply don't get the money," says council leader Ann John. "If we get a low count, we don't get funding for services. We need people to be counted."

To ensure residents participate this time, Brent is encouraging community leaders to be "census champions" - to spread the word about the importance of filling out the forms. Two half-day seminars have been held at the town hall for this purpose.

Among the groups likely to ignore the forms, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), which runs the census, are men aged 20-29 in inner-city areas. They are rarely in to receive or hand back forms, so this year's post-back census form is designed to combat this problem. Parents often forget to enter babies on the forms - sometimes because they are in hospital or are newborn - and elderly women over age 85 tend to be reluctant to answer the door or complete forms. Ethnic minority residents harbour a similar suspicion - and face the added disadvantage of language barriers. Other reasons for apathy include the fact that people do not understand what the census is for, or the form is seen as long and dull.

However, a main reason for the low returns in 1991 was the notion that a big brother-style government was "spying" on its citizens. The fact that the last census came at the time of furore about poll tax exacerbated the public's suspicion of authority. Derek Emmot, an ONS census area manager for Leeds, who was an enumerator in the 1991 count, recalls: "Last time, the reluctance to complete the forms was the fall-out from the poll tax: people did not want to be registered by anyone. The climate at the time was not good."

This year, ONS census literature emphasises that it is illegal for the census office to pass information on to any government department or any individual. It is illegal for any data to be published for 100 years.

To ensure that as few people as possible are invisible, the country has been divided into 115,000 enumeration districts, each containing about 200 households or 500 people. The ONS is employing 69,000 enumerators, or census takers, to distribute forms from next Monday. Forms have to be posted back after census day in pre-paid envelopes.

The ONS is also stressing in all its literature that failure to complete and return forms can lead to prosecution and a fine of up to £1,000. In 1991, however, only 342 people were prosecuted - a drop in the ocean of the missing million.

Roger Sykes, head of research at the Local Government Association, says it is essential for councils that people do take part in the census. "The census provides the essential building block - it is key data," he says. "If people go missing, there is a cost. The figures are significant. As many people as possible must complete a census form."

Across the country, people will answer questions on everything from the size of their home to their health, jobs and ethnicity. The census is a unique snapshot of the nation - the only source of reliable, nationally comparable statistics for different areas. Setting aside its importance to the archives and statisticians, there is a more pressing reason why the census is vital to local authorities: money. On Sunday, April 29, each person who completes a census form will be worth approximately £1,000 a year to their local council, because public spending - under the standard spending assessment for local government - is directly informed by the census. Over the 10-year life of the census, each person is worth some £10,000 to their local authority. Nationally, the data will be used to help decide an annual £50bn of public spending. Regionally, the census will inform £1.4bn of public spending in Liverpool and Merseyside, £2.3bn in Greater Manchester and £9bn in London. The data gleaned from the census also provides the base for competitive funding such as single regeneration bids and other government grants. If people fail to complete and return census forms, they are not counted. As funding is based on the size and needs of a population, a low count means low funding. One "missing" person means a potential loss of £10,000 in funding over the next 10 years - funding which could be spent on extra teachers, policemen, schools or day centres. In 1991, 1m people went missing. That was discovered only when returns from individuals were compared with projections and estimates from the 1981 count. Each of them could have "earned" money for their local authority. There are no accurate figures to show exactly how much money was lost as a result of the census's missing respondents, but today, if the same thing happened, councils across the country would suffer a potential loss of billions of pounds in grants. One of the areas worst affected by the apathy in 1991 was Brent, north London. It was discovered, after comparing projections with returns, that some 20,000 people in the borough went missing. With each person worth a potential £1,000 a year to the council, it is estimated Brent has since lost - or, rather, failed to atttract - a potential £200m in funding. The money, says Brent council, could have paid for 500 nurses, 286 police officers or 323 teachers. "If people are invisible, we simply don't get the money," says council leader Ann John. "If we get a low count, we don't get funding for services. We need people to be counted." To ensure residents participate this time, Brent is encouraging community leaders to be "census champions" - to spread the word about the importance of filling out the forms. Two half-day seminars have been held at the town hall for this purpose. Among the groups likely to ignore the forms, according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), which runs the census, are men aged 20-29 in inner-city areas. They are rarely in to receive or hand back forms, so this year's post-back census form is designed to combat this problem. Parents often forget to enter babies on the forms - sometimes because they are in hospital or are newborn - and elderly women over age 85 tend to be reluctant to answer the door or complete forms. Ethnic minority residents harbour a similar suspicion - and face the added disadvantage of language barriers. Other reasons for apathy include the fact that people do not understand what the census is for, or the form is seen as long and dull. However, a main reason for the low returns in 1991 was the notion that a big brother-style government was "spying" on its citizens. The fact that the last census came at the time of furore about poll tax exacerbated the public's suspicion of authority. Derek Emmot, an ONS census area manager for Leeds, who was an enumerator in the 1991 count, recalls: "Last time, the reluctance to complete the forms was the fall-out from the poll tax: people did not want to be registered by anyone. The climate at the time was not good." This year, ONS census literature emphasises that it is illegal for the census office to pass information on to any government department or any individual. It is illegal for any data to be published for 100 years. To ensure that as few people as possible are invisible, the country has been divided into 115,000 enumeration districts, each containing about 200 households or 500 people. The ONS is employing 69,000 enumerators, or census takers, to distribute forms from next Monday. Forms have to be posted back after census day in pre-paid envelopes. The ONS is also stressing in all its literature that failure to complete and return forms can lead to prosecution and a fine of up to £1,000. In 1991, however, only 342 people were prosecuted - a drop in the ocean of the missing million. Roger Sykes, head of research at the Local Government Association, says it is essential for councils that people do take part in the census. "The census provides the essential building block - it is key data," he says. "If people go missing, there is a cost. The figures are significant. As many people as possible must complete a census form."

webTitle: X-Men ahead in race for sci-fi Oscars

fields.headline: X-Men ahead in race for sci-fi Oscars
fields.trailText: Bryan Singer's movie adaptation of the famous comic strip has been nominated for ten awards at the Saturn Awards, which honour the best science fiction, fantasy and horror films
fields.body:
For the majority of movie watchers, the awards season finally wrapped up with last week's Academy Awards. But for the geek elite of the sci-fi, fantasy and horror genres, the Oscars are just a distracting precursor to the main event on the film calendar - the 27th annual Saturn Awards.

Organised by the Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror Films, the Saturns will be presented on June 12 at a black tie event at the Park Hyatt Hotel in Century City (the Spock ears, presumably, are optional). Last night's announcement of the nominees confirmed Bryan Singer's X-Men as this year's hot favourite. The acclaimed saga of misunderstood mutants with super powers claimed ten nominations, including Best Science Fiction Film, Best Actor (for Hugh Jackman), Best Supporting Actor (Patrick Stewart), Best Supporting Actress (Rebecca Romijn-Stamos) and Best Director (Singer).

In joint second place with eight nominations apiece lie two very different films, Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Ron Howard's saccharine Christmas treat The Grinch. Gladiator, the overall victor in last week's Oscar showdown, lags in fourth place with seven nominations.

webTitle: Spy plane crisis: 'They must come home'

fields.headline: 'They must come home'
fields.standfirst:
Bush demands that China returns US aircrew or relations will suffer

Special report: China
fields.trailText: The confrontation between the United States and China over the detained American spy plane entered a delicate new phase last night when President Bush demanded the return of the 24-strong crew only hours after China threatened to keep them in detention and subject them to Chinese law.
fields.byline: John Gittings in Shanghai and Martin Kettle in Washington
fields.body:
The confrontation between the United States and China over the detained American spy plane entered a delicate new phase last night when President Bush demanded the return of the 24-strong crew only hours after China threatened to keep them in detention and subject them to Chinese law.

In a statement in the White House garden, Mr Bush said the servicemen were in good health, had suffered no injuries and had not been mistreated. "They said they were looking forward to coming home and we are looking forward to bringing them home."

He said the administration's approach had been to "keep this accident from becoming an international incident."

But he continued: "Now it is time for our servicemen and women to come home and for the Chinese goverment to return our plane.

"This accident has the potential for undermining our hopes for a fruitful and productive relationship between our two countries. To keep that from happening our servicemen need to come home."

Earlier, Beijing had issued a dramatic midnight statement which appeared to sink any chance of a quick resolution to the diplomatic crisis. A foreign ministry spokesman said China would "deal appropriately with the crew and plane according to law" once investigations had been completed.

At its worst, the statement could be interpreted as a threat of a trial of the crewmen, which would plunge US-China relations to a new low.

The potential for the dispute to become more confrontational was underscored when the Pentagon spokesman, Admiral Craig Quigley, was asked whether the crew should be seen as prisoners or hostages. "I think the term is ambiguous at this point," he replied. "I don't have a good answer."

Washington drew comfort from the fact that China finally fulfilled its pledge to allow US diplomats to meet the crew - 22 from the navy, one marine and one air force member - late last night. A team of three officials spent more than 40 minutes with the crew on Hainan island. General Neal Sealock, the US embassy defence attache, confirmed they were all in good health.

Meanwhile, the Pentagon said it had received intelligence reports that Chinese officials had begun removing equipment from the grounded spy plane in defiance of Monday's hands-off warning from President Bush. "We have every reason to think the Chinese have been all over the airplane," the US ambassador in Beijing, Joseph Prueher, said in a television interview.

Beijing maintained its demands for an apology from Washington over Sunday's mid-air clash 70 miles south of Hainan, when two Chinese F- 8 fighters challenged the EP-3 over an area of the South China sea claimed by Beijing, which concedes, however, that the site of the incident was not formally Chinese airspace. A series of cat-and-mouse manoeuvres caused one Chinese plane to crash and the US plane to make its emergency landing in China.

"The United States should face reality, take responsibility and apologise to China," assistant foreign minister Zhou Wenzhong said.

President Jiang Zemin called on the US to promise an end to surveillance flights over the area. The US and others say it is international airspace.

Mr Bush's statement last night contained no hint of an apology.

The White House said the planes had been involved in an accidental clash during an "overt, routine" flight. The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, speaking in Florida, said of the meeting between officials and the crew: "I hope this starts us on a road to a full and complete resolution of this matter."

fields.headline: The US-China spy plane row
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown unravels the full-blown international crisis which followed a US surveillance jet's emergency landing on Hainan island

Special report: China

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Derek Brown unravels the full-blown international crisis which followed a US surveillance jet's emergency landing on Hainan island.
fields.body:
What was the American plane doing?
It was flying over the South China sea on what military spokesman say was a "routine surveillance mission". It was monitoring radar signals and radio traffic and the activities of Chinese shore-based units, ships and aircraft. In short, it was spying.

Was the US plane where it shouldn't have been?
That's the crux of the dispute. The Americans insist that it was flying over international waters, where it had every right to be. The Chinese claim territorial rights over the western half of the sea; a vast expanse of water roughly bounded by Taiwan, the Philippines, Vietnam and China itself. China's claim is disputed by its neighbours.

How did the collision happen?
It seems that a flight of two Chinese F8 fighters were dispatched to intercept the slow-flying EP-3 aircraft. There is no confirmed account of what exactly happened, though it seems that the Chinese jets "hemmed in" the much bigger American plane, in an apparent manoeuvre to make it change course.

According to the Chinese foreign ministry, the US plane suddenly veered to the left, hitting one of the single seater jets on its tail. The Chinese machine crashed into the sea and the pilot is missing, presumed dead.

Why didn't the American plane try to escape?
It was too badly damaged. One account says that it plunged several thousand feet before the pilots recovered control and set an emergency course for the nearest available landing strip: a naval airbase on Hainan island. There it remains.

How is the spy plane equipped?
Every manner of sophisticated eavesdropping device, decrypting and recording machines. The crew will have orders to destroy or damage what they could during the short flight to Hainan, to prevent it falling into Chinese hands. But the larger items of equipment, including exterior antennae, sensors and radomes, are probably intact, and under intense scrutiny by Chinese experts.

Where is the crew?
The Chinese say they are under "protective custody" and have hinted that they could be put on trial on spy charges. American diplomats were allowed to see the 24-strong crew - believed to include three women - only after putting intense pressure on the Chinese. They reported that the US service personnel were in good shape and being treated properly.

What are the Americans saying now?
That they want their plane back, and its crew. President George Bush has said that the incident could severely damage Sino-American relations.

And the Chinese?
They are insisting on an apology for the intrusion, and for the death of their fighter pilot. The Americans are not obliging.

How alarming is the confrontation?
It's very, very serious - easily the deepest crisis between the two Pacific superpowers for a decade or more. The Bush administration has already re-graded China as a "competitor" nation, and is deeply suspicious of Beijing's growing economic and military power.

The Chinese, for their part, strongly resent America's assumption of moral and military superiority, and its continuing support for Taiwan. On the other hand, neither side wants the confrontation, already causing wobbles on global stock markets, to degenerate into conflict.

Are there any precedents?
In 1981, Sweden held for 10 days a Soviet submarine which ran aground in its territorial waters. The Swedes suspected it of spying but the Russians said it had merely made a navigational mistake. In 1991, during Operation Desert Storm, the Iraqis sent hundreds of warplanes to neighbouring Iran to protect them from US bombing. Iran hung on to them.

An intriguing precedent, in US law at least, is that of the Exchange, an American schooner seized by the French navy and converted into a warship.

When the ship later took shelter from bad weather in Philadelphia harbour, the original owners staked a claim. But the US supreme court ruled that the ship enjoyed immunity from US jurisdiction. That was, however, in 1812.

webTitle: University jobs figures reveal racial bias

fields.headline: University jobs figures reveal racial bias
fields.trailText: Most students find work quickly after leaving university regardless of where they study, but black and Asian graduates still face discrimination from employers, according to an official report out today.
fields.body:
Most students find work quickly after leaving university regardless of where they study, but black and Asian graduates still face discrimination from employers, according to an official report out today.

Of last year's graduates, 94.1% were in work or further training or study by January 3 this year, the higher education funding council for England records.

But for black African graduates the figure was 87%, for black Caribbean graduates 90.7%, and for Bangladeshi and Pakistani graduates 88.4% and 89% respectively. Employment or study rates among whites were higher than average, 94.6%. Women were more likely to be employed than men (95.3% compared with 92.6%).

Lady Blackstone, the higher education minister, said: "Graduates from ethnic minorities have significantly lower employment rates than white graduates. This is an unacceptable situation in respect of equality and because it is a waste of the nation's talent."

She urged universities to offer more careers advice to individual students.

Chris Myant, spokesman for the commission for racial equality, said: "The old argument that black and Asian people don't get jobs because they don't have skills is masking a degree of discrimination in the area of skilled work which is particularly pernicious."

Some new universities out perform traditional colleagues. Luton, which is having to make academic staff redundant this year, boasts a 100% employment rate. Natfhe, the lecturers' union, said the figures were a vindication of the former polytechnics. Some 68.4% of 2000 graduates were in paid work.

"New university lecturers receive only two-thirds of the teaching income of their old university counterparts but still manage to turn out highly employable, capable graduates," said its general secretary, Paul Mackney. Oxford University has a 95% employment and study rate and Cambridge 98%.

HEFCE has produced "benchmark" figures for comparison - the proportion of graduates it would have expected each institution to have in work or further study, based on entry, social background, degree classification and other factors. Brunel, Hull, Kent, Loughborough, Luton, Nottingham Trent, Aberdeen, and Napier in Edinburgh do better than their benchmark.

But Cumbria College of Art and Design, Falmouth College of Arts, and the universities of East London, Harper Adams in Shropshire, Leeds Metropolitan, Liverpool John Moores, London Guildhall, Salford, South Bank, Sussex, Paisley, Swansea and Aberystwyth do worse.

Of the 207,234 British-based graduates last year, 81% took part in the study, although response rates did vary widely. Critically, the study did not show the type or income of jobs the graduates went into.

A spokesman for the University of Warwick said: "Warwick worked hard to produce a 93% response rate for this exercise - the third highest response rate across all the institutions measured. We need not have bothered to work so hard - if there had have been a national lottery style lucky dip box to tick instead we could all have done that and achieved an equally meaningful result which wasted a lot less of everyone's time."

There is also some variation between subject areas. Some 99.5% of medicine, dentistry and veterinary science graduates are employed or in further study; so too are 94.2% of maths graduates. Music and drama graduates are above the national average at 94.3%.

But computer science (91.8%) and engineering and technology (92.8%) graduates are all surprisingly below the average.

fields.headline: Temptation Island comes to UK
fields.trailText: 6.45pm Tuesday: C4 and Sky One are making a British version of the controversial reality TV show. By Dan Milmo and Jason Deans.
fields.body:
A British version of the controversial reality TV show Temptation Island, which was branded "immoral, sadistic and cynical" when screened in the US, is to be made.

The programme will be made in an unusual joint deal by Sky One and Channel 4.

Channel 4 in particular is sure to face a critical backlash over the decision to buy a programme which tempts committed, but unmarried couples, into being unfaithful.

In America the show has been criticised as a cynical bid to cash in others' emotional trauma in a bid to boost flagging ratings.

It sparked protests from religious groups and advertisers across the Atlantic, who objected to a programme which flies couples to a tropical island and tempts them into indiscretions with attractive single people.

Last week it emerged that a Los Angeles couple booted off the TV series because they have a two-year-old child are suing the producers for defamation of character.

"Temptation Island follows in the tradition of the entertainment formats which have been such a success and is great fun for a late-night slot," said a Channel 4 spokesman.

It is believed Sky One will screen the show before Channel 4, which will show the repeat.

Channel 5 pulled out of early negotiations partly because of US broadcaster Fox TV wanted to retain editorial control of the series.

It wanted to continue to use the Belize island and produce the show and simply fly in a British production team to oversea the making of the series.

Although no price was revealed for the deal, it is also understood Fox TV was demanding a staggering £400,000 per hour to film the series on its island location.

The plot will see four committed - and highly attractive - couples marooned on a tropical island with 26 equally gorgeous beachwear-clad singletons who have been specially selected to appeal to the couples.

The six-week series gained an average of 17m viewers per episode in the US.

The American series was broadcast in the UK on Sky One, ending last month with viewing figures of 750,000 - impressive for a satellite channel.

The show gained not only high viewing figures but notoriety in the US after family values campaigners criticised it for encouraging infidelity and treating the singles on the island as prostitutes.

webTitle: Front line for Beijing's claims to sea

fields.headline: Front line for Beijing's claims to sea
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: Hainan island, where the US crew members and their reconnaissance plane are detained, provides harbours and runways for the naval and air forces China uses to try to enforce its disputed claim to a swath of the South China sea.
fields.body:
Hainan island, where the US crew members and their reconnaissance plane are detained, provides harbours and runways for the naval and air forces China uses to try to enforce its disputed claim to a swath of the South China sea.

The indigenous Li and other minorities have been reduced to tourist attractions. Visa-free travel has recently been introduced for foreign tourist groups, and new motorways and hotels have proliferated.

During the Vietnam war (1965-73) US spy planes regularly flew over Hainan, a base for China's supply of military equipment to North Vietnam.

Until 20 years ago, the island was a closed military zone, almost shut off from the outside world ever since the communists seized power in China in the 1950s.

But during the 1980s Hainan got a reputation as a wild frontier place where almost anything went.

During that decade, the capital of Haikou became notorious for building scams and open prostitution, before these appeared widely elsewhere in China as economic liberalisation crept in.

The city of Sanya, close to where Beijing says the US spy plane was operating, used to be a holiday resort for select government and military officials.

fields.headline: Missing Chinese pilot is named
fields.standfirst: Special report: China
fields.trailText: The missing fighter pilot was flying one of China's most advanced jets but probably had less experience than his Western counterparts, according to military analysts.
fields.body:
The missing fighter pilot was flying one of China's most advanced jets but probably had less experience than his Western counterparts, according to military analysts.

China yesterday named the pilot as Wang Wei and said he parachuted out of his F-8 jet after the collision.

Chinese fighter pilots spend about 105 hours flying a year - half the time put in by US fighter pilots, military analysts said.

China's training simulators are generations behind those of other air forces and training is tightly regimented, harming pilots' ability to react spontaneously in combat situations.

"In general terms, Chinese pilots are thought to not spend anywhere near as much time as Western pilots in flight training and are much more conservative in handling their aircraft," said Robert Karniol, Asia Pacific editor of Jane's Defence Weekly.

The commander of the American plane's squadron said a jet flying slowly and close to a propeller-driven plane such as an EP-3 risks becoming unstable. Turbulence from the propellers could toss the jet around, said US navy commander Bernard Lessard, of Whidbey Island naval air station in Washington state.

"A high-performance jet is more unstable - especially if it's flying slowly," Commander Lessard told the Seattle Post-Intelligencer.

China yesterday said an air and sea search had failed to find the missing pilot but their efforts were continuing.

webTitle: Spy crew under orders to destroy key equipment

fields.headline: Spy crew under orders to destroy key equipment
fields.standfirst:
Packed with state-of-art electronics

Special report: China
fields.trailText: US aircraft packed with state-of-art electronics
fields.body:
From afar, the US navy spy plane that landed on Hainan island after colliding with a Chinese jet looks like an ageing medium-sized commercial airliner.

But up close, the radomes and aerials give away the mission of the EP-3E Aries II (or, airborne reconnaissance integrated electronics system). The lumbering four-engine turboprop is packed with state-of-the art electronics to eavesdrop on military communications and radar signals.

After it picks up an opponent's signal communications it can relay them so fast that commanders at base get those signals almost in real-time.

The unarmed spy plane - which can fly missions of more than 12 hours covering more than 3,000 nautical miles - can also send and receive messages to and from satellites. Infra-red equipment enables it to spot aircraft and shipping at night.

US military spokesmen say the aircraft, based on the Japanese island of Okinawa, was on a "routine surveillance mission" over the South China sea, an area claimed by China but regarded by the US as international waters.

However, the US navy reconnaissance plane was almost certainly flying as close as the crew considered safe to the Chinese coast to trigger the country's air defences and then monitor them, intelligence sources say.

Since the days of the cold war, spy plane crews - British as well as American - have been instructed to dump or destroy as much of their sensitive equipment as possible if capture seems likely. They do this under an emergency "classified destruction plan".

The crew should have been able to destroy or wipe hard disks as well as disable lighter equipment during the 30-60 minutes it is estimated to have taken the plane to fly to Hainan island after the collision with an F-8 Chinese jet.

This should prevent the Chinese from finding out what the US aircraft picked up, and how the information was interpreted by its crew. But they might be able to discover the general capabilities of the eavesdropping equipment, including the exterior antennae, aerials, sensors, scanners and radomes.

The aircraft's crew consists of 22 navy personnel, one air force officer and one marine. Reports say three of those on board were women.

The incident is a political test for the new Bush administration, which describes China as a "strategic competitor".

China has been threatening unspecified consequences if Washington sells Taiwan the advanced ship-based Aegis radar system which, with the Patriot missile system, would provide Taiwan with an anti-missile shield.

webTitle: Spy plane crisis: US looks for diplomatic solution

fields.headline: US looks for diplomatic solution
fields.standfirst:
Bush goes for cool approach realising China has the initiative

Special report: China
fields.trailText: Bush goes for cool approach realising China has the initiative.
fields.body:
When George Bush and his national security team gathered in the White House situation room on Sunday to weigh their response to the US spy plane's emergency landing in China, the fiercest debate around the table focused on two key issues.

First, should Mr Bush immediately telephone his Chinese opposite number, Jiang Zemin, in Beijing to demand the return of the plane and its crew? And second, should Mr Bush go on American television to address the nation about the incident?

The discussion went back and forth, but in the end, in both cases, the answer to the questions was No.

Like the dog in the Sherlock Holmes story that did not bark in the night, the phone call that was never placed and the broadcast that was never made could hold the key to understanding the way the Bush administration has approached its first international crisis.

In those key early encounters Mr Bush and his team took the decision to play the embryonic crisis tough but cool. They would make clear how they expected China to respond, but they would do it through traditional diplomacy, not through the television studios.

"We really want to work this out through diplomatic channels," the US ambassador to Beijing, Joseph Prueher, said yesterday. "The lead will stay with the state department," a Pentagon spokesman confirmed.

Whether that determination can withstand an escalation of the crisis or a failure to find a quick solution is another matter, however. The White House described last night's meeting between US diplomats and the 24 members of the spy plane's crew as a "positive development" but there was no sign that Washington was prepared to issue the public apology that was being demanded in Beijing.

The Bush administration nevertheless put on a show of business as usual yesterday as the crisis developed but the tactics appeared to change. At 9pm last night as Mr Bush made a statement on the developing crisis as he returned to Washington from a brief trip to Delaware.

He had been there to promote his education reform package.

Vice-president Dick Cheney had also played it low key, travelling alongside Mr Bush but making no public pronouncements. The White House's national security team, led by Condoleezza Rice, kept in the background too, as they have done throughout the crisis.

With both the White House and the state department cancelling their daily on-the-record press briefings, it was clear that the administration was seeking to exert maximum control over its message, ensuring that Beijing would receive only the signals that Washington had authorised. The situation was "very delicate, very difficult", a White House official said.

Only the Pentagon press spokesman, Admiral Craig Quigley, carried out a regular press briefing session yesterday before Mr Bush made his statement. Defence secretary Donald Rumsfeld also stayed out of sight.

The only high profile member of the administration to make a public statement in the first part of the day was secretary of state Colin Powell. Mr Powell had travelled to Key West, Florida, in another show of normality, to attend US-sponsored talks between Armenia and Azerbaijan over the future of the disputed enclave of Nagorno-Karabakh, where he gave a brief but generally conciliatory and low-key reading of the latest developments to journalists in a short press appearance.

The line in Washington throughout the stand-off so far has been that the administration is anxious "to give the Chinese time to get to the right decision", as one official put it yesterday.

Washington remains anxious that the spy plane incident should not spiral into a major confrontation with China, even though it comes at a time when US-China relations are poised for a stormy phase over the issue of Taiwan arms sales.

Officials continue to treat the emergency landing of the EP-3 plane on Hainan as "an accident not an incident".

As if to underline the effort to ensure that the Hainan island stand-off is not being allowed to become the sole focus of US-China relations, the state department ensured that yesterday's introduction of a regular daily UPS parcels delivery flight from the US to Shanghai went ahead as planned.

Even conservative Republican politicians who can normally be counted on to rattle their sabres were sticking to official party discipline over the incident.

Senator Jesse Helms, the influential Republican chairman of the senate foreign relations committee, said yesterday that he had "very strong opinions" on the stand-off, but said that he "did not want to aggravate the debate by giving those opinions".

The reality is that China, not the US, has most of the important cards in its hands.

Washington's initial stance of making firm demands to Beijing for the return of the crew and the plane, was giving way yesterday to a private recognition that China had the initiative.

fields.headline: Refugee politics
fields.standfirst: Do not expect reforms before the election
fields.trailText: There will be no reform of the voucher scheme for asylum seekers this side of the election.
fields.body:
There will be no reform of the voucher scheme for asylum seekers this side of the election. This is unfortunate, but given the level to which both major parties are ready to descend to demonstrate their "toughness", this is probably a relief.

It is now six months since ministers headed off a platform defeat at the last Labour conference by agreeing a review of its egregious voucher scheme. Six months on, our home affairs editor reports today that, although the review was due to report in January, it is still far from complete on the first anniversary of the scheme.

Reformers have every reason to be angry. It is not just the way vouchers demean asylum seekers (including the rule preventing stores from providing change), nor even the unacceptably low level: 30% below social security. It is the bogus nature of the entire cumbersome edifice. Set up to deter refugees, it has patently failed: numbers have increased by 10%.

All of which adds spice to yesterday's report from the Council of Europe, rightly criticising the rightwing media's "inflammatory attacks" on asylum seekers and the failure of politicians to tackle this public bigotry head on. Labour is wary of the Tory party, not least with Andrew Lansley MP, former Tory research director on the election strategy team, because of his notorious admission to the Observer that immigration "played particularly well in the tabloids" in the 1992 election "and has more potential to hurt".

The UK is not the most racist European state on refugees. Of the five reports issued by the council yesterday, the other four (on Denmark, Austria, Macedonia and Albania) were causing more concern. But there is still much to be done in Britain, beginning with vouchers. They contradict the government's first principle, enunciated by Barbara Roche, immigration minister, yesterday: the duty to treat all applicants "properly and well".

Once the election is over, the prime minister should discard his fears of looking "soft", scrap vouchers and seek to achieve a common European approach, based on the European convention on human rights, rather than the lowest common denominator. Then he should seek to lead, rather than follow British public attitudes. One role of a politician is to articulate public fears, but when the fears are based on unfounded bigotry and prejudice, such attitudes have to be confronted. Just another reason why the sooner the election is over, the better.
