fields.headline: Sick men of Europe
fields.standfirst: Britons have been sneering at foreigners. But now it's we who are being patronised by Europeans
fields.trailText: Britons have been sneering at foreigners. But now it's we who are being patronised by Europeans.
fields.body:
It's a bit rich, isn't it? Europe, home to Jörg Haider and Jean-Marie Le Pen, scolding us for being the most racist nation of the bunch. Who are the Germans - longtime deniers of citizenship to Turkish gastarbeiten, even those born in the country - to declare our attitude to refugees and asylum seekers the worst in Europe? Where do the French, whose casual harassment of non-whites is noticed by every black traveller across the Channel, get off scolding us? Who made the Danes, with a scarily energetic rightwing of their own, the PC-police of the continent?

That would be one way of dealing with the latest European assault on Britain, yesterday's report from the Council of Europe diagnosing a "particularly acute" form of racism here. We could protest that we're no worse than everyone else. Or we might slay the messenger, noting that the council is a glorified talking shop unrelated to the European Union, whose reports are usually consigned to the filing cabinet of history. We might tease the council's investigators, who came here nearly a year ago for a grand total of four days.

All those lines of attack are open, and every one of them was taken by politician and pundit alike yesterday. But there is another, less predictable response: we can listen. We can pause for a second and see ourselves the way our neighbours see us. We may be in for an unpleasant surprise.

So we might listen to the council's claim that we tend to think of economic migrants not as people seeking a better life - which is admirable - but as parasites and "criminals trying to sneak into our country". We might consider, and not dismiss, the EU's racism and xenophobia monitoring unit in Vienna, which last month ranked Britain, of all the 15 member states, as the nation most hostile to political refugees.

We might decide that, judging by our present form, the Europeans have got us about right. Just last week we had outgoing Tory MPs John Townend and Christopher Gill offer up a double-act of Powellite xenophobia and stale, halitotic bigotry. No sooner had Townend sung the praises of old Enoch, lamenting that "Commonwealth immigration" had undermined our "homogenous Anglo-Saxon society," than Gill was backing him up. Rising numbers of asylum seekers were causing a "rats in a bucket syndrome", diluting our national character. "If you pour enough water on a double scotch," he said, "it ceases to taste like whisky."

Since neither of these men were denied the Conservative whip in the Commons, we can fairly conclude that William Hague sees no great contradiction between their views and parliamentary service for his party. And why should he? Did not Hague authorise a leaflet for last year's local elections warning of "bogus asylum seekers... flooding" our shores? Did he not raise the alarm recently about Britain becoming a "foreign land"?

So maybe the Euro-inspectors were not so wrong about us after all. But there is a juicier irony here, juicier even than the notion of a continent which houses the Freedom party and the Front Nationale ordering us to clean up our act. It is that, after years of putting up with British Euroscepticism, Europe is finally getting its own back.

Call it Britoscepticism. From the European heads of government furious with a British agriculture which has, once again, infected the continent with disease, to a foreign press that has branded our country Plague Island, our neighbours seem set to make Eurosceptic dreams come true. The British right-wing always longed for Britain to break from the continent; now, apparently, the continent wants shot of us.

It's not just the headlines announcing the Katastrophe of the Animalisches Inferno - though medieval images of pyres and burning flesh have fattened up foreign news bulletins for a month and half now. Our neighbours have connected our latest crisis, over foot and mouth, with a deeper malaise.

We are, they say, the "sick man of Europe," the "septic isle". For them, foot and mouth is not an isolated, freakish episode but part of a continuum - with BSE the defining event. It is because of mad cow disease, which did have lethal implications for humans, that foreigners have assumed the worst about F&M - even thought the worst damage F&M might inflict on a person would be a cold sore. It's no wonder that NBC News warns Americans of "the killer disease now stalking Britain - and how we can stop it coming here". When it comes to food safety, we are not trusted: we have previous.

But the problem is deeper still. Foreign observers are linking foot and mouth not only with our agricultural plight, but with the very way we function as a society. Italy's L'Espresso cited our stubborn rates of poverty, the Hatfield rail disaster and the Real IRA's ongoing campaign of bombing, as well as the animal epidemics, as proof that Britain was a nation under a "curse". Doubtless they will now be adding the return of tuberculosis, disclosed yesterday, to their list.

Thomas Keilinger of Germany's Die Welt writes of the parlous state of our public services, particularly the hospitals and railways. One despatch announced that Britain is "slowly disappearing in the mire of the real-existing chaos".

Keilinger has told his readers of our lack of patriotism, the vacuity of the dome, the winter floods and our appalling weather. Germans are Anglophiles, he says, but they need to temper their fondness with the truth about this country.

"I think we felt that, after Thatcherism, Britain was a shining example of America-style, go-getting entrepreneurial savvy. Now we realise there is so much that is still creaky... the Thatcher revolution left whole swaths of society destitute, struggling to survive." He has said that, after the Russians, the British may be the longest-suffering populace in the world - prepared to put up with sub-standard services when others would have revolted against them decades ago.

Of course, there is some journalistic hyperbole here, as there would be if the roles were reversed. But it's hard not to see a warning. For years, we were like the old wartime headline-writer who decided that, since the Channel was fog-bound, the continent was cut off - not us. For years, we assumed that Britain was the great catch, with Europe the pushy suitor desperate for our hand. The Eurosceptic case rested on a British arrogance which saw our participation in the EU as a kind of favour to those grasping, desperate continentals.

Now we can see that the true situation may be the other way around. Having heard our press and politicians pour scorn and disdain on them for generations, the Europeans are exacting their revenge. They are seeing Britain as Europe's sick man, a charity case which needs their help. When the time finally comes for Tony Blair to make good his promise to be "at the heart of Europe," he may find the dynamic has changed. Far from welcoming him in as a young, energetic saviour, the neighbours might offer him a look of pity and a cup of sweetened tea - but only after he's wiped his feet in a trough of disinfectant.

fields.headline: Frankly, I've got nothing to joke about
fields.standfirst: And anyway, there’s already too much humour in the news media
fields.trailText: Some of you will be relieved to know that this is the last column I shall be writing for the Guardian. Others may be sorry, and I thank you for that.
fields.body:
Some of you will be relieved to know that this is the last column I shall be writing for the Guardian. Others may be sorry, and I thank you for that. I have been told that my column has run its course, which is a self-fulfilling accusation, and also that it doesn’t have enough jokes. Since my background is in humour, it was expected that I would contribute more eagerly to the gag count in the paper.

My own feeling, however, is that the increasingly humorous tone of the news media is not an illuminating, penetrating, invigorating or even uplifting trend, but a whimsical levity calculated to reassure us that nothing really matters any more. A little chuckle and everything’s alright again in our postmodern consensual culture. In fact, much of satire, and even much of investigative journalism, has become part of a self-cleaning establishment, a purgative tonic for the belly of the beast.

Frankly, I do not see my job as keeping our rulers on their toes; I’d rather see them hanging by their feet. Perhaps I should have been more ironic, but then you might have thought I didn’t mean it, and I did. I certainly believe that a sense of humour is essential, but as a way of looking at the world, not as a way of packaging it for public consumption.

In any event, I was given the option of staying on until the election but also told that I shouldn’t use the column as a platform for the Socialist Alliance. Since the fact of the Socialist Alliance and the Scottish Socialist party putting up candidates is the only interesting thing about the election, that struck me as a bit of a limitation; and since I’m away for Easter, I may as well sign off now.

I won’t suggest that you vote for the Socialist Alliance; I’ll just tell you that I’m voting for it, for some skittish reason of my own. You vote in whatever way seems right. I can’t for the life of me recommend that you vote Labour, unless your Labour candidate is one of a very honourable handful, in which case the alliance will not be contesting the seat anyway. Anyway, I don’t suppose you’ll be short of people trying to get you to vote Labour. Whichever way you vote, most of the exciting developments in politics are happening outside the electoral orb.

Those who are enjoying power accuse us malcontents of being compulsively oppositional. “Why are you people always so angry?” they ask. We should reply: “Because there is so much to be angry about and the Body Snatchers haven’t got us yet”, but I’m afraid that they would counter with: “Our time has arrived, it is pointless to resist.” I don’t know what is more distressing, the triumphalism of those who crow that they’ve won, or the fact that so many of them would never have settled for such a victory a few short years ago. At least half of the government’s media supplicants would have railed in fury if the last government had done the things they tolerate from Labour.

The Tories are not going to get back in. The people who say they might are mostly Labour loyalists, who are perhaps waiting to surprise us with some newly emerging piece of venality. Perhaps Robert Maxwell is alive. But the Tories won’t win. Labour will not even be forced into a coalition with the Liberal Democrats, which in any case wouldn’t drag the government further to the right. Liberals and even Greens undergo some strange conversions when in power, it’s true; and Lib Dem councils have a pretty bad track record. But a Lib-Lab coalition government is unlikely, and I very much doubt whether it would be more corporate-friendly, racist and authoritarian than this one.

For me to write this will appal those socialists who still hold the line that “Labour is the party of the organised working class”, but I think it’s time to replace the word “working” with “capitalist”, and try the sentence again. Trade unionists put tremendous effort into the relationship but it’s an abusive one. I’m sure union leaders will say, “But Tony’s not like that when he’s with me”, but they’re just throwing money at the problem.

Anyway, I’m off now. One of the failings I freely acknowledge is that I haven’t given due credit to all the people who’ve given me information and inspiration for the column. So here are a few: Rosemary Nelson, Inquest, the National Coalition of Anti-Deportation Campaigns, the Campaign Against the Arms Trade, Voices in the Wilderness, the Pat Finucane Centre, Sukhdev Reel, the Monitoring Group, Lambeth NUT, the Crossroads Women’s Centre, the Refugee Council, the Garvaghy Road Residents’ Coalition, the Close Campsfield Campaign, the Lower Ormeau Concerned Community, Asylum Aid. Thanks also to the rest. And thanks to all the readers who’ve written to me - well, most of you.

fields.headline: Refugee politics
fields.standfirst:
Do not expect reforms before the election

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: There will be no reform of the voucher scheme for asylum seekers this side of the election.
fields.body:
There will be no reform of the voucher scheme for asylum seekers this side of the election. This is unfortunate, but given the level to which both major parties are ready to descend to demonstrate their "toughness", this is probably a relief.

It is now six months since ministers headed off a platform defeat at the last Labour conference by agreeing a review of its egregious voucher scheme. Six months on, our home affairs editor reports today that, although the review was due to report in January, it is still far from complete on the first anniversary of the scheme.

Reformers have every reason to be angry. It is not just the way vouchers demean asylum seekers (including the rule preventing stores from providing change), nor even the unacceptably low level: 30% below social security. It is the bogus nature of the entire cumbersome edifice. Set up to deter refugees, it has patently failed: numbers have increased by 10%.

All of which adds spice to yesterday's report from the Council of Europe, rightly criticising the rightwing media's "inflammatory attacks" on asylum seekers and the failure of politicians to tackle this public bigotry head on. Labour is wary of the Tory party, not least with Andrew Lansley MP, former Tory research director on the election strategy team, because of his notorious admission to the Observer that immigration "played particularly well in the tabloids" in the 1992 election "and has more potential to hurt".

The UK is not the most racist European state on refugees. Of the five reports issued by the council yesterday, the other four (on Denmark, Austria, Macedonia and Albania) were causing more concern. But there is still much to be done in Britain, beginning with vouchers. They contradict the government's first principle, enunciated by Barbara Roche, immigration minister, yesterday: the duty to treat all applicants "properly and well".

Once the election is over, the prime minister should discard his fears of looking "soft", scrap vouchers and seek to achieve a common European approach, based on the European convention on human rights, rather than the lowest common denominator. Then he should seek to lead, rather than follow British public attitudes. One role of a politician is to articulate public fears, but when the fears are based on unfounded bigotry and prejudice, such attitudes have to be confronted. Just another reason why the sooner the election is over, the better.

webTitle: Vaz caught up in fresh row

fields.headline: Vaz caught up in fresh row over conduct
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the Foreign Office minister, withheld information from MPs about advice he gave on human rights and the Ilisu Dam project in Turkey which should have been published in the public interest, according to the parliamentary ombudsman.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the Foreign Office minister, withheld information from MPs about advice he gave on human rights and the Ilisu Dam project in Turkey which should have been published in the public interest, according to the parliamentary ombudsman.

A committee of MPs complained to the ombudsman, Michael Buckley, about Mr Vaz's conduct after he refused to show them correspondence about the dam.

The international development committee wanted to see the letters because it said the government's evidence had been "starkly contradictory" and the Foreign Office's "subsequent attempts at explanation [were] vague, unconvincing and on occasion desperate".

This latest blow to the European affairs minister is part of an investigation by MPs into a £200m government credit backing for Balfour Beatty to construct the dam in Turkey which will drown 46 Kurdish towns and villages and threaten the water supply of Syria and Iraq.

Richard Caborn, trade minister, and Vivian Brown, chief executive of the export credit guarantee department, told the committee Mr Vaz had not given advice on the human rights and security implications of backing the project before they decided in principle to go ahead.

The MPs subsequently published a report saying the Foreign Office had abdicated its duty on human rights. In an angry letter to the committee, Mr Vaz told them they were wrong and denied he had failed to brief his fellow ministers.

The MPs challenged him to provide correspondence to back up his denial, but he refused, citing the code of practice on access to government information. This has an ex emption on internal discussion and advice between ministers when "information disclosure would harm the frankness and candour of internal discussions".

The ombudsman found that the actual letters between ministers should not be published but "there was a valid public interest in a clear answer... the public interest outweighs any harm that might be caused by disclosure of that information". He published a summary of the correspondence which showed the Foreign Office had given advice on Kurdish resettlement and human rights abuses in south-east Turkey. There was no mention of security questions over water supply to Syria and Iraq.

Bowen Wells, the committee chairman, yesterday said: "Mr Vaz tried to stop us seeing information which would have exposed the fact that he did not give the Department of Trade and Industry proper advice before they backed the Ilisu Dam project.

"We wanted to know whether DTI ministers had been advised about the Kurds' human rights, and the likely effect on the prospects of renewing conflict with the Kurds and near neighbours Syria and Iraq. No such overall assessment had been given. It is a grave hole in ethical foreign policy not to consider these issues and Mr Vaz basically tried to stop us seeing that this had happened.

"Instead he sent us an extremely rude and crude letter saying we had got our facts wrong. We challenged him and he refused to let us see the evidence hiding behind confidentiality.

"This is a less than frank minister who is insensitive and discourteous."

The Foreign Office last night said:"We take issue with the committee's version of events and will be forcibly taking this up with them."

The MPs subsequently published a report saying the Foreign Office had abdicated its duty on human rights. In an angry letter to the committee, Mr Vaz told them they were wrong and denied he had failed to brief his fellow ministers. The MPs challenged him to provide correspondence to back up his denial, but he refused, citing the code of practice on access to government information. This has an ex emption on internal discussion and advice between ministers when "information disclosure would harm the frankness and candour of internal discussions". The ombudsman found that the actual letters between ministers should not be published but "there was a valid public interest in a clear answer... the public interest outweighs any harm that might be caused by disclosure of that information". He published a summary of the correspondence which showed the Foreign Office had given advice on Kurdish resettlement and human rights abuses in south-east Turkey. There was no mention of security questions over water supply to Syria and Iraq. Bowen Wells, the committee chairman, yesterday said: "Mr Vaz tried to stop us seeing information which would have exposed the fact that he did not give the Department of Trade and Industry proper advice before they backed the Ilisu Dam project. "We wanted to know whether DTI ministers had been advised about the Kurds' human rights, and the likely effect on the prospects of renewing conflict with the Kurds and near neighbours Syria and Iraq. No such overall assessment had been given. It is a grave hole in ethical foreign policy not to consider these issues and Mr Vaz basically tried to stop us seeing that this had happened. "Instead he sent us an extremely rude and crude letter saying we had got our facts wrong. We challenged him and he refused to let us see the evidence hiding behind confidentiality. "This is a less than frank minister who is insensitive and discourteous." The Foreign Office last night said:"We take issue with the committee's version of events and will be forcibly taking this up with them."

fields.headline: Bid to defuse Mowlam 'terrorist' outburst
fields.standfirst:
Minister 'not expressing her own view on McGuinness' explain

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Mo Mowlam yesterday described Martin McGuinness, the Northern Ireland education minister, as "a murderer and a terrorist".
fields.body:
Mo Mowlam yesterday described Martin McGuinness, the Northern Ireland education minister, as "a murderer and a terrorist".

Her aides insisted she was using "a shorthand" and trying to reflect the opinions of some sections of the community, but was not expressing her own views.

Ms Mowlam, the Cabinet Office minister, made the remark during a free-wheeling address to a regional newspaper lunch at the Hilton hotel in London.

Discussing the future of integrated education in Northern Ireland, she referred to a recent telephone discussion she had with Mr McGuinness in his role as education minister. She told the lunch: "Bugger me, I thought, this is a murderer and terrorist talking about spending more on integrated education."

Mr McGuinness has been widely accused of being a member of the IRA, but it is highly unusual for a cabinet minister to make the suggestion.

In 1972 he was arrested on suspicion of IRA membership and subsequently jailed.

Ms Mowlam's aides insisted she was not trying to cause offence or make any defamatory remark, and if necessary she would ring Mr McGuinness to explain the context of her remarks.

In an informal question and answer session, she admitted that cabinet ministers had been told the date of the general election at the weekend, even though Downing Street has insisted this was not the case.

She also defended her call for the royal family to modernise or face extinction.

Ms Mowlam said of her proposal in a Saga magazine interview a year ago for the monarchy to quit Buckingham palace: "It is not, if you go back and consult the article, a negative argument against the royals. [It was] basically saying if you want to stay and move into the 20th, 21st centuries you have to change too."

"There was a slight piss-take in there, because I said you might need a more modern palace and what about Ikea furniture, so there was an element of jokiness."

But the point she was making was a serious one, she said: the need for change. "I think Prince Charles knows that and is changing his role, how he is perceived and the kind of things he does."

She began the address by saying that she had torn up her prepared speech since it was "completely irrelevant really in view of what happened yesterday".

Ms Mowlam revealed that she spent yesterday dashing to Greece and back to sign an international agreement that had to be completed before a general election could take place. "When we heard at the weekend there was not an election, it was too late to change it."

She had backed May 3 as the election date but had now changed her mind. "When I talked to Tony [Blair] at the weekend and when I thought about it a bit more, I thought it would be the right decision."

Like most decisions in politics it had been a risk judgment, she said.

Ms Mowlam also denied that there was any such thing as organic food. Referring to her role as minister with responsibility for government co-ordination on the genetically modified food issue, she said: "I get really frustrated when people say this is 100% organic or 100% GM-free. You can say neither. The scientific evidence is not at the moment where 100% organic means anything."

Turning to the decision of the Corus steel company to axe thousands of jobs, which will hit her Teesside constituency, she said: "Corus behaved appallingly, and there is no nicer way to put it than that."

Executives had shown "a simple lack of common courtesy" by refusing to discuss their decision with ministers or unions.

"It is appalling just to announce in the paper that [workers] are losing their jobs. I think it is inhuman."

She said her plans after her departure from Westminister included raising cash in the US for integrated schools in Northern Ireland, and she would sit on an international conflict resolution committee.

She promised that her planned autobiography would not be "bitchy" but would try to explain to readers the sources of the conflict in Northern Ireland.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: If this one doesn't clinch that long dreamed of appearance before Lord Wakeham's preposterous press complaints commission, nothing will.
fields.body:
If this one doesn't clinch that long dreamed of appearance before Lord Wakeham's preposterous press complaints commission, nothing will. It revolves around concerns for Keith Vaz following his collapse in his office last week. So far, there have been heavy hints about cardiac problems, Robin Cook has declared him to be seriously ill and he has been "ordered by his doctors" to take eight weeks off - a hugely convenient period which takes us to the election ... after which, the plan presumably goes, he can slide unobtrusively out of government on vague health grounds without embarrassing Mr Tony Blair in any way. How cute.

And yet no actual doctor, let alone Mr Vaz, has said anything about a dicky heart. So my colleague Marina Hyde calls his Leicester East constituency office and speaks to his assistant, Alison Acton. "I'm calling from Matthew Norman's office," she explains (and here, alas, comes the little white lie for Lord W to ponder). "Matthew has a game of squash arranged with Keith for Sunday, and was wondering if he might move it back?" "Right," says Alison, "I'll have to talk to Keith about that. So it's squash this Sunday, and you want to postpone it. Till when?" "Next Sunday. If Keith could manage it?" "Next Sunday, then. I'll get a message to him." Mm.

 If Mr Vaz does die of a heart attack today - and with my luck you wouldn't bet against it - it's been fun writing the Diary these past six years, and goodbye to you all.

 Anyone desperate for some light relief might do worse than visit www.cryptome.org, the favourite website of spook-watchers and conspiracy theorists everywhere. Special attention should be paid to the file mi6-restored.htm, which claims to restore censored information to MI6 reports. For glaringly obvious legal reasons I cannot be remotely specific about the contents, but suffice it to say that several friends are mentioned and all the juicy bits (probably cobblers, but amusing for all that) are printed in red.

 Queeny spat time at Radio 2, where callow newcomer Steve Wright, who can't be much over 50, has been stepping on the toes of Jimmy Young, who must be 110. Since shortly after the launch of the Ark, Jimmy has had a monopoly on pre-election political interviews (long before Mr T discovered the joy of Des O'Connor, Mrs T was a regular on the his much loved Prog). You will imagine his wrath, then, on discovering that Mr Wright had bid successfully for the prime minister. What our source describes as "a huge barney" ensued, and inevitably Jimmy Young emerged the winner. Or, as Sarah Ward from Radio 2 publicity puts it: "the Steve Wright Show were thinking about having Tony Blair, but ... decided not to, as Jimmy Young normally interviews the PM and the leaders of all the main parties around election time."

 The guest list at Colin Cowdrey's memorial in Westminster Abbey last week comprised what certain so-called rivals would doubtless describe as a veritable who's who of cricketing greats, and a procession that included Sir Gary Sobers and other greats was led by Cowdrey's 1970 county championship winning Kent side. When the chaps sat down in the front row, the enormous figure of Norman Graham was heard noticing that he was seated directly behind a grand piano (in fact there for an extract from the Mikado). "Fuck me," said Mr Graham to his onetime Kent teammate Brian Luckhurst, "they've booked that Elton John again."

 Would tank top-wearing Times managing editor George Brock contact the Diary forthwith. We hear George recently moved into some Kensington Palace apartments, his wife being assistant private secretary to the Queen, and wish to confirm this before deciding whether to grass him up to that fervent republican Rupert Murdoch.

fields.headline: Ban demanded on overseas bribes
fields.trailText: Britain's failure to introduce clear legislation to outlaw bribery and corruption in international business was castigated yesterday by a committee of MPs as a "shameful situation" that damaged the reputation of the City of London and the country abroad.
fields.body:
Britain's failure to introduce clear legislation to outlaw bribery and corruption in international business was castigated yesterday by a committee of MPs as a "shameful situation" that damaged the reputation of the City of London and the country abroad.

The international development committee report on corruption said it was "incredible" that Britain had failed to implement the organisation for economic cooperation and development's convention on the bribery of public officials. OECD officials have criticised Britain's lack of compliance, unique among developed countries, and bracket the UK with Turkey, Brazil, Argentina and Chile.

The report said: "New legislation is urgently needed to meet our international obligations. We cannot understand why the government has not yet introduced legislation to deal with this shameful situation, especially as the issue is unlikely to be controversial."

As long as the convention was not implemented, the committee said, Britain could not credibly continue to make improvements in other countries' governance a condition of development aid.

The committee also criticised the "entirely unsatisfactory" practice, confirmed by Treasury officials, whereby British companies that pay bribes wholly outside the UK can claim tax relief on them. Evidence presented to the committee from pressure groups suggested western businesses paid bribes conservatively estimated at £53bn a year, with the arms and construction industries the worst offenders.

Though it welcomed government plans to update the laws against money laundering, the report said Britain's response to the problem of corruption was uncoordinated and piecemeal, with enforcement bodies underfunded and underresourced. "We are deeply concerned about the vulnerability of one of this country's most valuable financial assets - the City of London," the report said.

Weaknesses in the banking system were highlighted last month, the report noted, with the publication of an investigation by the financial services authority into accounts linked to the family and associates of the late Nigerian president Sani Abacha. It found that 42 accounts held at 23 banks in the UK had a turnover of £0.87bn between 1996 and 2000. Fifteen of the banks, including Barclays and Midland, had "significant control weaknesses"; seven have been ordered to correct failings, which may lead to prosecutions.

A particular weakness was identified as the "patchy" reporting of suspicious transactions to the national criminal intelligence service, especially by lawyers and accountants who are prime targets for money launderers.

Lawyers, under the cloak of client confidentiality, can mask the beneficial owners of accounts. Both professions, the report said, should be given mandatory training on the prevention of money laundering.

The Conservative chairman of the committee, Bowen Wells MP, said yesterday: "We have not at the moment got any effective defence against these practices. We are a world centre for laundering the proceeds of bribery and fraud."

A number of senior executives from BP, Unilever and Balfour Beatty admitted to the committee that they paid low-level "facilitation payments" abroad to get things done quickly.

But the committee was unequivocal that this was corruption, and should be made illegal: "We see no difference between bribery and facilitation payments."

fields.headline: MPs attack emergency loans to poor
fields.trailText: The government's drive to abolish child poverty is being undermined by an emergency loans scheme intended as a lifeline for the poorest in society, according to a report by a committee of MPs.
fields.body:
The government's drive to abolish child poverty is being undermined by an emergency loans scheme intended as a lifeline for the poorest in society, according to a report by a committee of MPs.

Far from helping deprived people, the discretionary social fund is "adding to the poverty and social exclusion of families with children" by plunging them further into debt and denying them access to basic necessities, says the study, out today.

The report, following an inquiry by the social security select committee, presses the government to overhaul the fund, which issues grants and lends money at low rates of interest to families in need. The crisis loans are intended to pay for essentials such as cookers and fridges.

The fund, which is overseen by the Department for Social Security, has been criticised by poverty campaigners and the Liberal Democrats for forcing poor families who take out the loans into deeper poverty as they attempt to keep up with repayments while they are living on benefits.

Helen Dent, of the Family Welfare Association, a charity which provides crisis grants for poor families who slip through the welfare net, called on the government to switch from an emergency loans system to grants.

She said: "Families on low incomes simply can't afford to repay these loans - they are already on breadline money. There is no point tinkering with the system. We must have a fundamental review of the fund."

Today's report points out that less is being spent on the discretionary social fund now than five years ago, "with no evidence of diminution of need".

The committee, chaired by Lib Dem Archy Kirkwood, warns: "The huge gaps and inconsistencies caused by the inadequacies of the social fund risk undermining important initiatives aimed at tackling homelessness, helping victims of domestic violence reestablish their lives, supporting vulnerable people in the community, and resettling people from institutions.

"Above all, the present social fund system is working against the government's key aim of reducing child poverty."

It calls for the level of loan repayments and the repayment period to be made more flexible in order to reduce the hardship experienced by claimants and avoid them getting into further high-priced debt.

Applicants for loans need to be given better advice and information, and methods for claiming should be simpler, the report says.

In a clear attempt to head off criticism over the report, the DSS on Monday announced £3m extra funding for the social fund pot used for non-repayable grants. The above-inflation increase would help those most in need, especially the disabled and families with children, said the social security minister, Angela Eagle.

A DSS spokesman said the fund would remain "an integral tenet" of the government's welfare policy.

Steve Webb, Lib Dem social security spokesman, welcomed the report and called for a shift towards more loans and fewer grants for applicants.

The Conservatives have said they would cut the fund by £90m to fund pension increases for the over-75s.

webTitle: New calls to scrap asylum vouchers

fields.headline: New calls to scrap asylum vouchers
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: There were renewed calls to scrap the voucher scheme for asylum seekers yesterday, as the Home Office confirmed that an official review of the scheme is unlikely to submit its report this side of the general election.
fields.body:
There were renewed calls to scrap the voucher scheme for asylum seekers yesterday, as the Home Office confirmed that an official review of the scheme is unlikely to submit its report this side of the general election.

On the first anniversary of the scheme, Oxfam, the Refugee Council and the Transport and General Workers' Union criticised the delay and demanded that the vouchers handed out to asylum seekers be replaced by cash benefits to meet their needs while they wait for a decision on their claims to refugee status.

A Home Office spokesman confirmed that the intention had been for the review to report early in the new year, but it had taken longer than expected. "We do not have a date as yet. Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, has visited a lot of supermarkets herself to see how it is working."

He said the review had run into contractural difficulties when questions such as issuing vouchers in smaller denominations had been considered.

The review was promised to avert a defeat for the government on the issue at the Labour party conference last autumn. It was expected at least that as a result the rule denying asylum seekers any cash back if they spent less than the value of a voucher at a store would be scrapped.

Bill Morris, TGWU general secretary, said: "The scheme is a crude, cruel and expensive way of dealing with a complex issue. The T&G wants to see vouchers replaced with a cash benefits system."

The Refugee Council urged the government to honour its commitment to increase the value of vouchers in line with inflation. A single asylum seeker gets £37 worth of vouchers a week. Nick Hardwick, chief executive, said: "One year on and the voucher nightmare gets worse."

Oxfam said it would continue to boycott the scheme, not accepting vouchers in its shops.

fields.headline: Major praises Tory moderates
fields.trailText: John Major has delivered a powerful rebuke to William Hague by warning the Tory leader that he is wrong to exclude moderate "one nation" Conservatives from his frontbench team.
fields.body:
John Major has delivered a powerful rebuke to William Hague by warning the Tory leader that he is wrong to exclude moderate "one nation" Conservatives from his frontbench team.

In a damaging pre-election intervention, the former prime minister told Mr Hague that he should never forget that the Tory party was a broad church which achieved success by encompassing conflicting views.

Mr Major, who is exasperated by the way in which Mr Hague has abandoned the "one nation" Toryism he championed, pointedly made his remarks in the constituency of the dissident pro-European MP, Ian Taylor.

A press release issued by the Esher and Walton constituency said Mr Major lavished praise on Mr Taylor's performance as science and technology minister in his government. The statement added: "John Major hoped the day would soon come when Ian would return to the frontbench since the Conservative party has always been a broad church and must make the best use of all of its talented members."

Moderate Tories saw Mr Major's remarks as a barely coded attack on Mr Hague who has been criticised by the party's left for drifting to the right on a range of issues, including Europe, asylum and law and order. The former prime minister, who delivered his speech four days after Mr Hague's controversial "foreign land" speech, made clear that he sympathised with the moderates when he told the Esher lunch: "The Conservative party must reach out to all in our society and offer hope and opportunity."

Mr Taylor has been a vociferous opponent of Mr Hague since he resigned as a shadow Northern Ireland minister in November 1997 in protest at Mr Hague's hardening of his opposition to the European single currency.

Friends of Mr Major said last night that his remarks showed his determination to ensure Mr Hague embraces all strands of thought within the party.

"John feels very strongly on the broad church issue," a friend said.

Moderate Tories are keeping their powder dry in the run up to the general election, but are preparing to attack Mr Hague after his expected defeat. Chris Patten, the European commissioner and former party chairman, is planning to criticise him for losing all sense of balance over Europe.

Other moderates are angered that the rightwing Tory MP Tim Collins, is playing a pivotal role in drafting Mr Hague's election speeches. Mr Collins played an instrumental role in drafting Mr Hague's 'foreign land" speech.

fields.headline: Protester who hit PM guilty of harassment
fields.trailText: A woman who hit Tony Blair with a tomato during a protest against sanctions against Iraq was yesterday convicted of a public order offence.
fields.body:
A woman who hit Tony Blair with a tomato during a protest against sanctions against Iraq was yesterday convicted of a public order offence.

Lynn Coles, left, of Eastville, Bristol, admitted throwing the tomato at Mr Blair when he visited Bristol on January 9, but denied a charge of intentionally causing harassment, alarm or distress. Bristol magistrates, who found her guilty, gave Coles a one-year conditional discharge and ordered her to pay £50 towards costs.

Friends, including house-mate Jo Wilding, who was convicted at another trial of the same offence after throwing a mouldy tangerine, clapped loudly at the sentence.

Sarah Regan, prosecuting, told the court that in a police interview Coles, 26, apologised for any offence she caused by throwing the tomato. "Ms Coles said, 'I admit I was very naughty and shouldn't have done it. I did throw a rotten, squishy, very soft, not that offensive tomato, it was all very much a spur-of-the-moment thing'. "

Pc Roger Curry told the court: "The defendant was, very pleased she was being arrested. She was shouting 'Got him with veg, got him with a tomato'. " Coles said she had grabbed the bag of tomatoes from another member of the crowd who had been throwing them "because I thought I was a better shot". Press Association

fields.headline: Day 44: what a shambles
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The environment minister, Michael Meacher, last night caused embarrassment for Tony Blair when he jumped the gun by announcing that there will be a public inquiry into the foot and mouth outbreak once the crisis is over, including an examination of alternative farming methods.
fields.byline: Michael White, Martin Wainwright and Lucy Ward
fields.body:
The environment minister, Michael Meacher, last night caused embarrassment for Tony Blair when he jumped the gun by announcing that there will be a public inquiry into the foot and mouth outbreak once the crisis is over, including an examination of alternative farming methods.

As both Mr Blair and William Hague toured the frontline hot spots yesterday on the 44th day of the crisis - with 1,000 cases and 2m animals marked down for slaughter - it was one of a series of errors and misjudgments:

 No 10 promised that "lessons will be learned" from the outbreak, but told Mr Meacher that "no decision has been taken on the form of the inquiry";

 Mr Hague asked for the army to be given full operational control over the slaughter, transport and destruction of infected animals, only to be told by the senior officer in Cumbria that he is happy with current arrangements;

 Officials admitted that almost 900 sheep and cattle buried in a disused quarry in Tow Law, County Durham, against the advice of the environment agency, will have to be dug up and reburied amid fears of local water pollution;

 Ministers admitted that, as reported in yesterday's Guardian, official website figures on the daily rise in cases and the numbers of animals awaiting slaughter have been "confusing" and "insufficiently robust".

But it was Mr Meacher's burst of candour at the launch of the Countryside Agency's annual report which caused most alarm. Though a public inquiry is the most likely option - as it was after the 1967 and 1952 outbreaks - ministers may want to narrow its terms and direction.

Mr Meacher appeared to pre-empt Mr Blair's options. "Unquestionably, there will be [an inquiry] this time, to ascertain the cause and how it happened, and the way we can prevent it happening again. We will want to know how the disease got such a hold and the levels of animal transport across the country."

But significantly, the man in charge of the rural taskforce added that the wider future of farming and the rural economy will also be examined, possibly leading to more emphasis on organic production, small abattoirs and local production methods.

No sooner had the Tory farms spokesman, Tim Yeo, complained that the minister was slipping out an important statement than No 10 gently slapped him down. "Mr Meacher is a very fine minister. No decision has been taken on the form of the inquiry."

He was not the only politician in hot water. Though Hague aides later claimed that the Tory leader had informed the army before suggesting it take full operational control of the clean-up, the army's response was cool.

Brigadier Alex Birtwistle, the officer in charge of the military team in Cumbria, told ITN : "It is quite right and proper for it to be a Maff-led operation. To be frank, I don't want to lead this operation. It would be too much trouble, too difficult to do."

At Tow Law, army diggers will set to work on Friday to dig up the 650 sheep and farmer Douglas Forster's prize herd of thoroughbred cattle because officials fear that the polluted material will filter through gravel beds into a spring which supplies water to local farms.

The environment agency explained that it had warned that the site was not suitable "but, for whatever reason, that advice was not followed."

The army suggested there had been a mix-up in instructions between two local sites. Mr Forster called it "an honest mistake". In another sign of the authorities being stretched to their limits, a pyre in Cumbria with 200 cows waiting to be burned will have to be dismantled after fears for the health of nearby villagers.

Downing Street's admission that Maff website data is confusing was blamed on the fact that "bureaucracy and paperwork has not been a priority".

fields.headline: Decision day for untested Bush
fields.standfirst:
President steers steady course to solution

Special report: China
fields.trailText: President steers steady course to solution.
fields.body:
Today George Bush faces the most difficult day of his presidency so far, as he decides how to respond to Beijing's apparent determination to force concessions from the US administration in return for the release of the 24 crew members of the American spy plane detained in China.

Yesterday in the White House rose garden, Mr Bush made his second brief statement on the trial of strength with Beijing over the plane and its crew. The tone was more terse than when the president spoke on Monday.

"It is time for our servicemen and women to return home. It is time for the Chinese government to return our plane," President Bush said before turning on his heels and disappearing back into the White House without answering shouted questions about whether he considered the crew to be hostages.

When Mr Bush and his national security team gathered in the White House situation room on Sunday to weigh their response to the emergency landing of the plane - damaged when it collided with a Chinese warplane above a disputed area of sea claimed by China - they hoped that the drama would not turn into a crisis.

The group agreed quickly on the generally low-key tone that prevailed in the first three days of Washington's handling of the issue - a tone that is provoking mounting dissent among Republican hawks in and out of the administration.

At first, the fiercest debate around the table focused on two issues, according to US reports.

Should Mr Bush telephone President Jiang Zemin right away to demand the return of the plane and its crew? And should he address the nation on TV about the incident? The discussion went back and forth, but in the end, the answer to both was, no.

Mr Bush and his team decided to play the embryonic crisis tough but cool. They would make clear how they expected China to respond, but they would do it through diplomacy, not TV.

"We really want to work this out through diplomatic channels," the US ambassador to Beijing, Joseph Prueher, said yesterday. "The lead will stay with the state department," a Pentagon official confirmed.

Whether that determination can hold if things become more heated is another matter. The White House described last night's meeting between US diplomats and the 24 members of the spy plane's crew as a "positive development" but there was no sign of the apology Beijing wants coming from Washington - which is not alone in rejecting China's attempts to claim a swath of the South China sea.

The Bush administration put on a show of business as usual yesterday but the tactics appeared to change when Mr Bush made his brusque statement on the developing crisis at 9pm after he returned to Washington from a brief trip to Delaware to promote his education reform package.

Vice-president Dick Cheney and the White House's national security team led by Condoleezza Rice had all kept in the background during the day, as they have throughout the standoff. The defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, kept out of sight and the secretary of state, Colin Powell, kept his remarks brief and concilatory.

The White House and the state department cancelled their daily on-the-record press briefings, showing that the ad ministration was seeking to exert maximum control over its message, ensuring that Beijing would receive only signals conveyed directly by Washington. The situation was "very delicate, very difficult", a White House official said.

Only the Pentagon press spokesman, Admiral Craig Quigley, carried out a regular press briefing yesterday before Mr Bush made his statement.

The line in Washington so far has been that the administration is anxious "to give the Chinese time to get to the right decision", as one official put it yesterday. Mr Bush repeated that phrase in his statement.

The US does not want things to spiral into a confrontation with China, not least because relations are about to be stormy anyway over US plans for new military sales to Taiwan.

Officials continue to treat the aerial encounter and the emergency landing of the US plane on Hainan as "an accident not an incident".

Underlining that normality was the aim, yesterday's introduction of a regular daily UPS parcels delivery flight from the US to Shanghai went ahead as planned.

Senator Jesse Helms, the influential Republican chairman of the senate foreign relations committee, said yesterday that he had "very strong opinions" on the stand-off, but said that he "did not want to aggravate the situation by giving those opinions".

Washington's initial stance of making firm demands for the return of the crew and the plane, was giving way yesterday to a private recognition that China had much of the initiative.

webTitle: New calls to scrap asylum vouchers

fields.headline: New calls to scrap asylum vouchers
fields.trailText: There were renewed calls to scrap the voucher scheme for asylum seekers yesterday, as the Home Office confirmed that an official review of the scheme is unlikely to submit its report this side of the general election.
fields.body:
There were renewed calls to scrap the voucher scheme for asylum seekers yesterday, as the Home Office confirmed that an official review of the scheme is unlikely to submit its report this side of the general election.

On the first anniversary of the scheme, Oxfam, the Refugee Council and the Transport and General Workers' Union criticised the delay and demanded that the vouchers handed out to asylum seekers be replaced by cash benefits to meet their needs while they wait for a decision on their claims to refugee status.

A Home Office spokesman confirmed that the intention had been for the review to report early in the new year, but it had taken longer than expected. "We do not have a date as yet. Barbara Roche, the immigration minister, has visited a lot of supermarkets herself to see how it is working."

He said the review had run into contractural difficulties when questions such as issuing vouchers in smaller denominations had been considered.

The review was promised to avert a defeat for the government on the issue at the Labour party conference last autumn. It was expected at least that as a result the rule denying asylum seekers any cash back if they spent less than the value of a voucher at a store would be scrapped.

Bill Morris, TGWU general secretary, said: "The scheme is a crude, cruel and expensive way of dealing with a complex issue. The T&G wants to see vouchers replaced with a cash benefits system."

The Refugee Council urged the government to honour its commitment to increase the value of vouchers in line with inflation. A single asylum seeker gets £37 worth of vouchers a week. Nick Hardwick, chief executive, said: "One year on and the voucher nightmare gets worse."

Oxfam said it would continue to boycott the scheme, not accepting vouchers in its shops.

webTitle: Spy plane crisis: Conflicting stories of how the aircraft collided

fields.headline: Conflicting stories of how the aircraft collided
fields.standfirst:
War of words Washington and Beijing set out their versions

Special report: China
fields.trailText: Conflicting accounts began to emerge yesterday from Beijing and Washington of Sunday's clash between a US spy plane and the Chinese fighters that challenged it over an area of the South China claimed by Beijing - an encounter that has triggered the worst Sino-American crisis in a decade.
fields.byline: John Gittings in Shanghai and Julian Borger in Washington
fields.body:
Conflicting accounts began to emerge yesterday from Beijing and Washington of Sunday's clash between a US spy plane and the Chinese fighters that challenged it over an area of the South China claimed by Beijing - an encounter that has triggered the worst Sino-American crisis in a decade.

The Chinese foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, claimed that the US EP-3 had been detected at 8.36am on Sunday carrying out electronic surveillance offshore from Sanya, the second biggest town on Hainan island.

He described in more detail how the US plane allegedly veered sharply to the left after being hemmed in by two Chinese fighters, hitting one of them flying parallel with the US plane on its tail. The Pentagon estimated the time of the collision at 9.15am, but provided no details of how it happened. The Chinese pilot, named as Wang Wei, parachuted out of his jet but is still missing.

An unconfirmed report from Taiwan intelligence sources said that the US plane was trying to gather data on a Russian-made Sovremenny-class destroyer in the area. Though the Sanya area is a popular holiday resort, Hainan island contains important naval and air facilities for China's control of the South China sea.

Washington disputed Beijing's claim that the EP-3 had no right to fly over what China has designated an "exclusive economic zone". Beijing admits the US plane was not in its airspace. Rear Admiral Craig Quigley, the Pentagon spokesman described the claim of a special zone as "moot".

One unofficial claim on the mainland said that the Chinese fighters were attempting to escort the US plane away from their territory when one of them was downed. The US reconnaissance plane is an unarmed aircraft.

In Washington, the Pentagon did not release details of the collision, other than to say that the left wing and one of the engines of the EP-3 had been damaged.

Chinese and Taiwanese unofficial accounts claimed that the US plane initially hoped to escape in another direction, but that the remaining Chi nese fighter forced it to land. Admiral Quigley, said however, that the plane had been forced to land because of the damage it sustained.

"The aircraft commander clearly felt that the aircraft was in danger, and he had 24 lives that he was responsible for. So his goal was to put that aircraft down as quickly as he could and broadcast his intentions via 121.5 on the international air distress frequency, and put down," Admiral Quigley said. He said it took 15 to 20 minutes for the damaged plane to fly the 70 miles from the point of the collision to Hainan. After that, he said there had been another radio transmission from the plane to confirm that it had landed and the crew was safe, and a last transmission about 20 minutes after landing. After that, the plane fell silent, he said.

webTitle: Spy plane crisis: An explicit threat - but only in Chinese

fields.headline: An explicit threat - but only in Chinese
fields.standfirst:
Beijing Hints that the crew could be subject to legal action in China

Special report: China
fields.trailText: It was China's turn yesterday to raise the stakes in the spy plane row with the United States: a series of statements piled on the pressure during the day. As so often with Chinese diplomacy, it was a mixture of tough talk and subtle hints needing careful study of the original text.
fields.body:
It was China's turn yesterday to raise the stakes in the spy plane row with the United States: a series of statements piled on the pressure during the day. As so often with Chinese diplomacy, it was a mixture of tough talk and subtle hints needing careful study of the original text.

The all-important threat from the Chinese foreign ministry to put the crew of the US spy plane through a potentially lengthy legal process came right at the end of an extensive statement from the ministry's spokesman, Zhu Bangzao.

Even then, the threat was given only in the Chinese version - the whole phrase was omitted from the otherwise full English summary of Mr Zhu's remarks put out last night.

State department analysts will be studying word by word his declaration that when China has completed its investigation, it will "deal appropriately with the crew and plane according to law".

The verb to "deal with" ( chuli ) can also be translated as "to punish", especially when used with the phrase "according to law" ( yifa ). But it is a threat rather than a cast-iron commitment, no doubt designed to make Washington think again.

The official followed up with another tough demand: the US should "cooperate conscientiously with the Chinese investigation" and make a full apology.

Washington is the primary audience for this Chinese offensive, but Beijing's political tacticians will have designed it with domestic listeners in mind too. In the crisis public opinion has emerged as a factor the Chinese government must consider.

A wide range of outspoken unofficial views have been expressed on popular websites - including one run by the official People's Daily newspaper. Some contributors are criticising the official line as too "diplomatic."

"In the past 'public opinion' was mostly dictated by what the newspapers and the government laid down," according to a strategic analyst in Beijing, Gao Chaoqun. "Now it can express itself in a more independent way, particularly through the voices of younger people on the web."

The dominant mood of anger was summed up yesterday in a website message declaring that "Blood must be repaid with blood: Americans - listen!"

"When you are thousands of miles from our land," it asked, "what pretext do you have for allowing your warplanes to fly in our airspace?" (Beijing concedes this was not its airspace.)

Other contributors bitterly recalled the US bomb that fell on Beijing's embassy in Belgrade two years ago when Nato was bombing targets across Serbia during the Kosovo conflict. Many Chinese doubt that the embassy bombing was an accident.

Several called in terms once used by Mao Zedong for the Chinese people to "stand up and not kneel down". Some have complained that the government adopted too low a profile initially: there were sarcastic comments about the main story in Monday's People's Daily, which was said read more like an account of an official tree-planting ceremony than of a mid-air crash.

Many have suggested that the government should harden its line by "raising the price" (as Mr Jiang has now done) for meeting US demands for the return of its 24 crew members.

Outside observers are not sure whether the government is being moved by public pressure or is being steered in a direction it intends to take anyhow: perhaps both are at work.

Not everyone is calling for retribution. Cautious unofficial voices have warned that too hard a line could put ammunition in the hands of the US pro-Taiwan lobby.

"We should give back the plane and its crew and show compassion," argued one contributor to the People's Daily website. "Our main task is to prevent Taiwan from getting advanced weaponry from the US."

President Jiang Zemin, too, indicated yesterday that he still hopes the US-China relationship will return to a normal track. All his advisers have been urging him to give President George Bush the benefit of the doubt in spite of the anti-China noises from the new US administration.

Mr Gao, the strategic analyst, said that public opinion was a short-term factor, but that the government would be more guided by the need to takea long-term view on policy towards the US. But the spy plane crisis is putting such moderation under immense strain.

The existence of a US surveillance programme against China - though well known in government and military circles - has now entered the public domain in one dramatic stroke.

Popular newspapers have published details - taken directly from the US media - of the capabilities and crew of the EP-3 aircraft, and of its spying operations against China.

Having made the demand that such missions should stop, will Beijing pretend nothing is happening if they go on?

The US claim that it was over international waters has not gone down well at the official or popular level, though Beijing admits the US plane was not in Chinese airspace. Washington's image has also suffered from its failure to express sadness over the missing Chinese airman who must now be presumed dead. The pilot was named yesterday as Wang Wei. Chinese news agencies reported that he had parachuted out of his F-8 jet after the collision but he has not been found.

But the Chinese media have made a point of stressing Mr Jiang's concern about the pilot - which also took some time to emerge.

Beijing's case now includes complex but significant arguments about the legality of the US spy flights.

Mr Zhu argued that although the collision did not happen in Chinese airspace, it was over an "exclusive economic zone" which Beijing claims in the South China sea - a territorial claim that is disputed in the region.

He argued that while UN law allows peaceful transit over such areas this did not cover spying activities. He also revealed that the US and China had reached an agreement last year on "avoiding military risks in sea areas" - which the US had now violated.

The Chinese are arch-negotiators, but they are angry and not inclined to roll over to what they call US hegemonism.

webTitle: Spy plane crisis: 'I hope they don't interrogate him'

fields.headline: 'I hope they don't interrogate him'
fields.standfirst:
Families speak of fears for men held on Hainan

Special report: China
fields.trailText: Families speak of fears for men held on Hainan.
fields.body:
A Californian woman says she fears for the life of her former husband, a US navy cryptographic technician who is one of the 24 crew members from the grounded US aircraft.

"I'm hoping they won't figure out what his job is, because then they'll interrogate him," Darlene Edmunds told the Sacramento Bee newspaper. "He's trained not to give out information and he's very patriotic."

She told CNN: "I do think it's going to be highly stressful. I don't know what measures they are going to take to find out what they want to know ... but since they have access to the plane, they are already going to be tipped off on a lot of these things."

The crew member, Petty Officer First Class Josef "Joe" Edmunds, 30, speaks Chinese and Cambodian.

Ms Edmunds, who divorced her husband a few months ago after 10 years of marriage, is so hopeful the standoff will end soon that she has not told her children - Sierra, eight, Aspen, six, and Tullen, five - that their father was on the plane. "I know that they would be very worried about their father," she said.

Josephine Mercado, whose son Ramono was also on the aircraft, told CNN: "I could not sleep. I could not look. I was in some sort of shock. I didn't expect it to happen to my son."

Jackie Flint, a former teacher of one of the pilots, said: "He was the kind of student that I think is going to act well under pressure."

The US aircraft carried 22 navy personnel, one marine and one member of the US air force. It was based at Whidbey island naval air station near Seattle, Washington, and 14 of the crew members have families living on the base.

The navy has assigned officers to assist the crew's families.

fields.headline: Merrill takes helm at Chat
fields.trailText: 9.30am: Paul Merrill has been named new editor for Chat magazine replacing Keith Kendrick, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Paul Merrill has been named as the new editor for Chat magazine, replacing Keith Kendrick, who has just joined Loaded as editor.

Mr Merrill, who is currently the assistant editor of the magazine, has been in charge of Chat's features and practicals department for the past four years.

He has edited many of Chat's successful one-shots and specials, including Chat Crime and Passion and the Chat Lottery Special.

Mr Merrill said: "If Chat was a member of Hear'Say it would be Kim - sparky, in your face and up for it."

Meanwhile, Chat's deputy editor Mary Bryce takes over the role of specials editor at the title.

The appointment comes as the title's former editor, Keith Kendrick, is undergoing a baptism by fire in his new job.

This week Loaded staff leaked the contents of a memo to MediaGuardian containing details of his "vision" for the magazine.

The "vision" has prompted revolt in the Loaded offices.

fields.headline: 'Double whammy' for deprived areas
fields.standfirst:
Rural economy undermined

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The regions hardest hit by the foot and mouth epidemic are already among those most at the mercy of economic downturns, according to a new report.
fields.body:
The regions hardest hit by the foot and mouth epidemic are already among those most at the mercy of economic downturns, according to a new report.

The Countryside Agency's third annual audit of the state of the countryside found that remote parts of Cumbria, Northumberland and the south-west rank among the most deprived rural areas in England. Their dependence on a combination of farming and tourism has made them particularly vulnerable to the effects of the foot and mouth outbreak, the report said.

Ewen Cameron, chairman of the agency and a member of the rural taskforce tackling the consequences of the outbreak, yesterday called for more investment to broaden the economic base of remote rural areas, warning: "Their economies and communities are already fragile and now in many of these areas foot and mouth has devastated farming and tourism, with little other business to cushion the blow."

Improved communications infrastructure, including fast broadband links to areas such as the Lake District, could encourage the growth of new IT companies, creating a "Silicon Lakes", Mr Cameron said.

He called on the chancellor, Gordon Brown, to offer tax breaks to people wanting to invest in their own rural businesses.

At the launch of the report, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, acknowledged the special needs of businesses in the northern Lakes, one of the epidemic's worst blackspots.

But while the report highlighted the depth of deprivation in some rural areas, it found that for most countryside dwellers the picture was "relatively happy". In general, people living in rural England enjoyed better levels of income, health and education and lower crime levels than those in urban areas.

But the prognosis for agriculture remained bleak, with the industry's direct contribution to the economy falling to its lowest level for 25 years in 2000 - just £7,800 a head of population.

fields.headline: Beeb.com sticks to shopping
fields.trailText: 9.15am: The BBC's commercial website, Beeb.com, has reaffirmed its commitment to shopping following a review, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The BBC's commercial website, Beeb.com has reaffirmed its commitment to shopping following a six-month review of its strategic focus.

Julian Turner, chief executive officer of Beeb Ventures, said beeb.com would be sticking with shopping and that the strategy was starting to pay off.

"We're starting to see good results and remain focused on adding value to the whole experience of shopping," he said, refusing to give figures.

BBC Worldwide was widely criticised last year when it threw caution to the wind and decided to rebrand as a shopping portal, setting up a clear boundary between its public service and commercial internet services.

Beeb.com's main selling point became internet shopping for those that are computer illiterate, a campaign it spent £7m on last year.

The shopping portal will now develop a price comparison service that will enable users to search and compare product prices.

It was originally thought Beeb.com would buy up ShopSmart.com's comparison technology, but reports earlier today suggest ShopSmart.com will be bought by Barclays to merge into Indigosquare.

However, Mr Turner said he didn't rule out acquisitions of clever pieces of technologies from struggling dot.coms that could enhance Beeb.com's website.

The next step for Beeb.com is to develop more interactive TV applications and launch the shopping guides and comparison service on mobile devices.

Meanwhile, Beeb Ventures's other business, the subscription-free ISP beeb.net, claims to have entered profitability and is boasting a membership base of 140,000.

Beeb Ventures is majority owned by BBC Worldwide, although last year US firm TH Lee Global took a 13.5% stake in the business for £32.5m.

fields.headline: What will MPs do now?
fields.standfirst: Tony Blair's decision to delay the general election has left MPs with a difficult question - what will they do to fill their time? Matthew Tempest explains what legislation is currently going through parliament.
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's decision to delay the general election has left MPs with a difficult question - what will they do to fill their time? Matthew Tempest explains what legislation is currently going through parliament.
fields.body:
When the Queen delivered her speech to the House of Lords last December spelling out the government's plans for the next parliamentary session, very few MPs expected more than a smattering of the 15 bills to complete the trek through both chambers and gain royal assent before a general election.

As with all pre-election legislative programmes, the Queen's speech was packed with eye-catching, headline-grabbing measures on issues such as the yob culture and benefit fraud.

The prime minister's decision to put back a general election to June 7 means that instead of dissolving parliament by Thursday this week for a May 3 election, MPs and peers are now faced with more space than they bargained for in their legislative programme.

However, with parliament breaking up next week for a two week Easter recess, there will be little more than a fortnight's extra time to push through bills, before May 14 - the latest date that parliament can be dissolved for a June 7 general election.

First, the home secretary, Jack Straw, must get through emergency legislation to delay the local elections in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. With cross party support, that could be done in two days - however, Conservatives are now calling for the local elections to be postponed indefinitely, and could thereby hold up legislation in the Lords if they wished.

But because the leader of the house, Margaret Beckett, decides each Thursday the business for the following week, which bills the government will press ahead with remains to be seen.

They could push ahead with the hunting bill, but with the Lords having voted against it in large numbers last month, and the foot and mouth crisis in the countryside, Mr Blair may leave the bill to die.

Similarly, Mr Straw's bill to restrict trail by jury may be thought too controversial to be in the headlines just before the campaign.

Thus the options facing the prime minister, and his advisers, on which bills to push, are almost as delicately poised as the decision to delay the election itself.

This is the current state of play of all 15 pieces of legislation unveiled in the Queen's speech:

Finance bill
Puts into effect the chancellor's March budget.
Commons second reading April 9.
 Minister in charge: Stephen Timms

Criminal justice and police bill
Raises child curfew age to 16, fixed penalty notices for public disorder, powers to close rowdy pubs and arrest kerb crawlers.
Now having second reading in Lords.
 Minister in charge: Jack Straw

Private security industry bill
Will regulate bouncers, wheel clampers and private investigators through a new authority body.
Awaiting Commons committee stage.
 Minister in charge: Lord Bassam of Brighton

Vehicles (crime) bill
Make scrap dealers keep records of salvaged cars to help fight car crime.
Just had third reading in Lords, awaiting third reading in Commons.
 Minister in charge: Jack Straw

Criminal justice (mode of trial) bill
Remove right of jury trial from some 14,000 defendants in "either way" offences.
Yet to be introduced to Commons or Lords in this session.
 Minister in charge: Jack Straw

Social security (fraud) bill
Two strikes and you're out for benefit cheats, plus forcing banks to pass on details in suspected cases - Now in Commons committee stage  Minister in charge: Alastair Darling

Health and social care bill
Allows public-private partnerships in primary care, integrates health services and social care in care trusts, allows nurses to prescribe drugs.
Lords provisional report stage expected this week.
 Minister in charge: Alan Milburn

Tobacco advertising and promotion bill
Bans tobacco advertising.
Awaiting a date for Lords committee stage.
 Minister in charge: Alan Milburn

Special educational needs and disability bill
Strengthens rights of children with special needs to be treated in mainstream schools.
Provisional committee Commons stage this week.
 Minister in charge: David Blunkett

Children's commissioner for Wales bill
A children's tsar for Wales to oversee schools and hospitals after previous abuse scandals.
Currently before Lords committee.
 Minister in charge: Paul Murphy

Regulatory reform bill
Powers to cut red tape across business, and allow pubs and restaurants to open later.
Awaiting Commons report stage.
 Minister in charge: Lord Falconer of Thornton

Homes bill
Vendors must provide a "sellers pack" including survey and local authority search to speed up house sales.
Awaiting a date for Lords committee stage.
 Minister in charge: John Prescott

Hunting bill
Ban on hunting with dogs. MPs voted for outright ban, peers overturned this.
Now awaiting provisional Lords committee date.
 Minister in charge: Jack Straw

International criminal court bill
Allow UK to try suspected war criminals.
Awaiting second reading in Commons.
 Minister in charge: Robin Cook

Armed forces bill
Routine bill introduced every five years to update military law and bring it into line with civilian legislation. Has passed second reading in Commons and is now in Commons committee stage.
 Minister in charge: John Spellar
