fields.headline: Gaza hit by Israeli backlash
fields.standfirst: Helicopter gunships pound key Palestinian targets, injuring more than 30, after Jewish baby is hit in mortar attack
fields.trailText: Helicopter gunships pound key Palestinian targets, injuring more than 30, after Jewish baby is hit in mortar attack.
fields.byline: Suzanne Goldenberg  and  Ewen MacAskill  in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Israeli combat helicopters rocketed the Gaza Strip last night in response to a mortar attack that injured a Jewish baby, adding impetus to the cycle of revenge attacks.

The punitive raid, which injured at least 77 Palestinians including policemen, was the second in less than a week, and saw Israeli helicopter gunships pounding Palestinian security installations in Gaza city, and the towns of Deir al-Balah, Khan Yunis, and Rafah, in the south of the territory.

It lasted for half an hour - twice as long as last week's air attacks - and more than 70 rockets were fired.

The reprisal was ordered after the Israeli right accused the hardline prime minister, Ariel Sharon, of failing to deliver on election promises to improve security. It took place d on a day when members of his rightwing Likud party rejected a tentative peace initiative from Egypt and Jordan.

In Rafah, the focus of Israel's wrath last night, missiles were fired at Palestinian Authority offices and buildings used by the elite Force 17 security detail and police and intelligence units.

Gaza city also suffered damage, with shells landing on a small coastguard station, Force 17 compounds, and an arms store near Yasser Arafat's house. But residents described the damage as relatively light. Seven explosions were heard in Gaza city.

A resident of Rafah said: "Everybody is scared here _ this is not like it was with [the former prime minister, Ehud] Barak. This is like a war, a serious war."

In Gaza city, Nora Ingdal, of Norwegian People's Aid, said "It's been going on for half an hour, and we stopped counting, at least 20 missiles in last half hour, it's one every minute. We are sitting in the dark there is no electricity. The phone lines are cut."

Palestinians began bracing themselves for an attack after hearing of the injured Israeli baby. In Rafah, which lies on the border with Egypt, their fears grew when an Israeli spy plane was spotted about 6pm local time. The bombardment began two hours later. Most of the injuries were from shrapnel and none was serious.

The condition of the baby hit in the mortar attack was described as serious in Beersheba hospital in southern Israel. The boy, described on Israeli television as being 15 months old, was hit by shrapnel. His mother was also taken to hospital but her injuries were said to be slight. Israeli television showed their car, with windows shattered.

Three mortars were fired at the Israeli settlement of Atzmona, part of a large Jewish settlement bloc which separates the Palestinian-ruled south of the Gaza Strip from the coast. The mortars may have been fired from Rafah.

A spokesman for the Israeli army said: "We are attacking targets that are involved in terrorism after the barbaric and unbearable attack against the baby today by mortar." This was echoed later by Mr Sharon who said his government's first and foremost obligation was to restore Israeli residents' security and added that it would continue to work towards this goal.

"The Palestinian Authority is not working to prevent attacks and is leaving Israel with no choice but to act tenaciously and vigorously to frustrate terrorist attacks and protect Israeli citizens' security," he said.

Speaking from Paris, the foreign minister, Shimon Peres, said: "The violent actions against us have reached a height that cannot be tolerated." But he said he would go ahead with a planned meeting today with the Palestinian cab inet planning minister, Nabil Sha'ath, the first high-level contacts between the two sides since Mr Sharon became prime minister in February.

A senior Palestinian optimistically predicted that "something might have been offered" during a meeting on Tuesday between the US president, George Bush, and the Egyptian prime minister, Hosni Muba rak, in Washington. But Danny Naveh, a minister from Mr Sharon's Likud party, made it clear that the government was not interested in an Egyptian-Jordanian peace initiative.

He said that the peace plan, presented on Monday by Mr Mubarak, was merely a dressed-up "Palestinian initiative" which he said was aimed at dragging Israel "into nego tiations under fire". The killing of a 10-month-old Jewish settler by a sniper in Hebron last week set off a series of tit-for-tat killings.

Mr Sharon's orders for punitive action have failed to quell criticism within Israel, especially among Jewish settlers, some of whom dumped a bullet-riddled car outside his office in Jerusalem yesterday.

fields.headline: Cash crisis pushes PSINet to the brink
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: PSINet, the largest independent internet access provider in the US, yesterday warned that it was running out of cash and was likely to file for bankruptcy protection. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
PSINet, the largest independent internet access provider in the US, yesterday warned that it was running out of cash and was likely to file for bankruptcy protection.

The company, which was founded in 1985 and listed on the stock exchange 10 years later, is one of the largest corporate casualties from the meltdown in the valuation of internet-related shares.

Trading in PSINet shares was halted on the Nasdaq exchange yesterday after the company outlined the extent of its financial travails. The shares were frozen at 18 cents, down from a year's high of $34. At yesterday's level the company, which operates in 27 countries on five continents as a result of its expansion over the past five years, was valued at less than $36m.

PSINet also revealed that PricewaterhouseCoopers, its financial auditor, might officially question its ability to continue as a going concern. A statement issued before markets opened yesterday blamed "rapidly changing circumstances impacting the company".

At the end of March the company held cash or equivalents of $254m, about $27m of which is being used as credit security. With more than 4,000 employees, the company is burning large amounts of cash each month. Like many internet companies struggling to reach the consumer market, PSINet has also spent heavily on advertising.

In its statement yesterday, PSINet admitted that even a proposed sale of its assets might not cover debts. "Cash generated by the expected proceeds from asset sales are not expected to be sufficient to meet the company's anticipated cash needs" in the absence of "successful imple mentation of one or more financial or strategic alternatives currently under consideration.

"Even if one or more of such alternatives is successfully implemented by the company, there can be no assurance that the company will not run out of cash."

Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, has already been appointed to look for a strategic alliance or sale of all or part of the company. Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein has been hired to look at ways of restructuring its debts.

PSINet said yesterday that such reorganisation was "likely to involve the company's reorganisation under the federal bankruptcy code". Once a company files for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, prospective purchasers avoid responsibility for its debts.

Authorities at Nasdaq requested more information from the company, which has 15 days to file a financial statement based on a new valuation of its "potentially impaired assets". The company went on to add that even if its attempt to restructure was successful "there can be no assurance that the company will not run out of cash".

fields.bodyText: PSINet, the largest independent internet access provider in the US, yesterday warned that it was running out of cash and was likely to file for bankruptcy protection. The company, which was founded in 1985 and listed on the stock exchange 10 years later, is one of the largest corporate casualties from the meltdown in the valuation of internet-related shares. Trading in PSINet shares was halted on the Nasdaq exchange yesterday after the company outlined the extent of its financial travails. The shares were frozen at 18 cents, down from a year's high of $34. At yesterday's level the company, which operates in 27 countries on five continents as a result of its expansion over the past five years, was valued at less than $36m. PSINet also revealed that PricewaterhouseCoopers, its financial auditor, might officially question its ability to continue as a going concern. A statement issued before markets opened yesterday blamed "rapidly changing circumstances impacting the company". At the end of March the company held cash or equivalents of $254m, about $27m of which is being used as credit security. With more than 4,000 employees, the company is burning large amounts of cash each month. Like many internet companies struggling to reach the consumer market, PSINet has also spent heavily on advertising. In its statement yesterday, PSINet admitted that even a proposed sale of its assets might not cover debts. "Cash generated by the expected proceeds from asset sales are not expected to be sufficient to meet the company's anticipated cash needs" in the absence of "successful imple mentation of one or more financial or strategic alternatives currently under consideration. "Even if one or more of such alternatives is successfully implemented by the company, there can be no assurance that the company will not run out of cash." Goldman Sachs, the investment bank, has already been appointed to look for a strategic alliance or sale of all or part of the company. Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein has been hired to look at ways of restructuring its debts. PSINet said yesterday that such reorganisation was "likely to involve the company's reorganisation under the federal bankruptcy code". Once a company files for chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, prospective purchasers avoid responsibility for its debts. fields.headline: Online traders 'breaking the law'
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Thousands of British firms that trade over the internet are breaking the law, according to a new report. By Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Thousands of British firms that trade over the internet are breaking the law, according to a new report.

A whopping 96% of those polled for the London Chamber of Commerce said they had not sought any legal advice when setting up a website and almost half said they had no policy for staff use of emails.

The London chamber's acting chief executive Peter Bishop rebuked fly-by-night internet companies for failing to give themselves adequate legal protection.

"Firms must act quickly to ensure they are complying with the law and are protected from the improper use of theiInternet by their own staff," he said, pointing to the now infamous Claire Swire email as a damaging example.

"Incidents arising from improper email use can be massively costly. In 1997 Norwich Union had to make an out-of-court settlement of £450,000 and in 1999 British Gas paid £101,000 in damages resulting from derogatory comments in e-mails."

Other employees have been sacked for firing off denigratory missives about company bosses.

Recently a Credit Lyonnais analyst was sacked after criticisin ghis bosses in emails to clients, while George Bush regrettably had to close his email account once he became president for fear of electronic indiscretions.

The survey of 300 UK businesses found only 44% of online retailers complied with the basic requirements of the Data Protection Act by giving visitors information about how their registration details might be used by other parties.

fields.headline: Great Filibuster on the rampage
fields.trailText: Sometimes, working in the Commons, I feel a bit like David Attenborough. Here I am on the pampas, hiding unobserved in the press gallery, camouflaged by a dark suit and grey shirt, making sure I am downwind of the air conditioning.
fields.body:
Sometimes, working in the Commons, I feel a bit like David Attenborough. Here I am on the pampas, hiding unobserved in the press gallery, camouflaged by a dark suit and grey shirt, making sure I am downwind of the air conditioning.

Spread before me is a magnificent vista. The green benches stretch away to the horizon. A pitiless sun beats down, at least until the automatic blinds are raised.

Tiny points of order scamper through the long grass. A small flock of parliamentary questions grazes undisturbed nearby. A ten-minute rule bill pokes its head out nervously, then retreats to the safety of its warren.

Then suddenly everything changes. Legislators stop nibbling on acacia leaves, or at least their fingernails, and sniff something sinister in the breeze. Some smaller creatures begin to run for cover. In the distance we can hear the footfall of the most feared predator of them all.

Crash! Smash! Ripping flora and fauna apart, crushing fragile insects under its feet as it strides across the landscape, comes the Great Filibuster. David's voice drops even lower.

"For years scientists thought that the Filibuster was extinct. Now we know, and these astounding pictures prove, it was only living deep in the undergrowth. But is this the last survivor of an almost extinct species, or is it half of a breeding pair?"

And indeed we have seen very few recent examples of the great, scaly, omnivorous Filibuster. It is only the freak atmospheric conditions brought about by the present government that has brought it back to its old feeding grounds. For the government wants to force the bill postponing local elections through all its stages today - unlike other bills which take months to go through the process. Yesterday MPs had to debate not the bill itself, but the timetable for the bill, even though that timetable had not yet been published.

This is a very New Labour arrangement. Have the vote first, then find out what you've voted on. And why ever not? The result will be exactly the same anyway.

The Filibuster lurched across the grasslands. Nicholas Winterton demanded explanatory notes, several times. He insisted on being reassured by "the safeguard of the good offices of a programme sub-committee".

Douglas Hogg, voice piping like an insistent bat, said at enormous length that local government representatives might want to make representations. Ministers yawned in desperation.

Angela Browning, one of nature's prey, was wearing a sage coloured jacket. The woebegone wildebeeste, the gnu in green, made her interventions brief. She could afford to, for the Filibuster was on the rampage.

Eric Forth, his gleaming in the tropical sun, hammered on for an eternity. Gwynneth Dunwoody, a Labour backbencher, said drily that it would not be the very first time that MPs had tabled amendments without any idea of what was in the bill.

The Filibuster thundered through the chamber until the Speaker left and his deputy, a great white hunter called Alan Haselhurst, took his place. Sir Alan crisply warned two Tory MPs, including the former attornney-general Nicholas Lyell, that they were trespassing on the patience of the chair.

Suddenly the Filibuster was dead, and with a mighty shriek of rage and pain, collapsed on the floor of the house. (David Attenborough's The Secret Life of Parliament is on BBC2 this Sunday.)

fields.headline: UK broadcasters bid for South Park creators' new show
fields.trailText: 8.30am: That's my Bush, a sitcom parody from Matt Stone and Trey Parker, is heading for the the UK, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The new series from the creators of South Park, sitcom parody That's My Bush, is heading for the UK.

British broadcasters are getting a first look at the hotly anticipated show - created by Matt Stone and Trey Parker - at the MipTV programming market in Cannes this week.

Sky One and Channel 4, which already broadcast South Park, are understood to be interested in That's My Bush, along with the BBC and Channel 5.

That's My Bush stars Timothy Bottoms and Carrie Quinn Dolin as a bumbling George Bush and his sensible First Lady Laura.

But the show is more concerned with parodying 1970s sitcoms such as Benson than offering biting political satire.

The show features over-the-top applause and laughter from a fake studio audience.

However, That's My Bush also contains the gross-out Stone/Parker humour that made South Park such a controversial hit.

The first episode includes an appearance by an aborted pro-lifer, who has managed to survive in the form of angry foetus puppet.

That's My Bush premieres on US cable channel Comedy Central this week.

The US broadcaster has brought seven 30-minute episodes of the show to Cannes and is expecting to wrap up a deal with a UK broadcaster within weeks.

fields.headline: 'Nasty' Nigel in legal row over Popstars follow-up
fields.trailText: 8.30am: ITV and 'Nasty' Nigel Lythgoe could become embroiled in a legal row between the creators of Popstars and the follow-up Pop Idol show, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
ITV and "Nasty" Nigel Lythgoe could become embroiled in a legal row that has erupted between the creators of the TV hit Popstars and the follow-up Pop Idol show.

The Australian owner of the Popstars format has threatened to sue the companies behind the new ITV show after they flew in to a TV market in Cannes this week where the show is on sale.

Executives at the company say they are astounded by the alleged similarities between Popstars and Pop Idol and are talking to their lawyers.

ITV commissioned Pop Idol last month following the runaway success of Popstars, which has launched the careers of the five wannabes selected through the TV show for the group Hear'Say.

Pop Idol will also involve a TV search for new talent, but instead of a band it is seeking to launch the career of a solo artist and will allow viewers to votes for their favourites.

The show is expected to be screened later this year and will be produced by Mr Lythgoe, who has just quit ITV for an executive role at 19TV, the company that will co-produce Pop Idol with Pearson TV.

Pop Idol is being showcased at the MipTV programme market in Canne. Pearson TV, which developed the show, is hoping it can secure several deals to sell the format overseas.

Screentime, the Australian owner of the Popstars format, and Target, its UK-based distributor, have now consulted their lawyers about potential action.

"We have come under enormous pressure from broadcasters around the world, who have seen the new Pearson format as a potential threat to their hugely successful Popstars franchise," a spokeswoman for the companies said.

"As a result, we are briefing our legal representatives in Sydney and London to take whatever action necessary to protect our and our broadcasting clients' interests around the world

Screentime executive director Des Monaghan added: "When we got here we were amazed about the breadth and depth of the reaction. This is a fundamental issue for us - the programme has been a huge success."

Target and Screentime have already appealed to the Format Recognition And Protection Association, an informal TV industry body formed to adjudicate in disputes of this kind.

A Pearson Television spokesman declined to comment.

fields.headline: Bridget Jones targets email 'singletons'
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Publishing phenomenon Bridget Jones is about to extend her inimitable diary to mobile phone owners, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Not content with taking over the big screen, publishing phenomenon Bridget Jones is now about to extend her inimitable diary to mobile phone owners.

Helen Fielding, the woman that brought the word "singleton" into public consciousness and portrayed women in their twenties as weight-obsessed, chain-smoking menaholics, has signed a two-year deal with a mobile entertainment company.

From Friday April 13, fans of Bridget Jones will be able to sign up for daily text message doses of the infamous diary.

Topics covered include the number of calories eaten, drinks drunk, men snared and various vital statistics such as inner poise, weight and trim thighs.

Helen Fielding has agreed to work with Riot-E, the text messaging company, to develop Bridget-type content for personality tests, dieting techniques and dating strategies

"For singletons like Bridget, the phone is becoming a major means of human contact. Texting allows one to be much more obsessive even than email.

"You can be in communication with significant others anytime and anywhere (or not, which can be heartbreaking and obviously requires major analysis and discussion through further texting)," said Ms Fielding.

"I have no doubt that after pioneering email flirtation Bridget has by now become an SMS junkie."

The service will target women in their late twenties and early thirties, as well as "curious men".

Sign up at Riot-e.com

webTitle: Youth jail violence alarms prison inspectors

fields.headline: Youth jail violence alarms prison inspectors
fields.standfirst: More about prisons
fields.trailText: Evidence of "horrendous" levels of violence with more than 700 reported injuries to young prisoners has been uncovered inside a young offender institution by the chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
Evidence of "horrendous" levels of violence with more than 700 reported injuries to young prisoners has been uncovered inside a young offender institution by the chief inspector of prisons.

Sir David Ramsbotham was so disturbed by the violent culture discovered inside Stoke Heath YOI, near Market Drayton, Shropshire, that he immediately wrote to the home secretary, Jack Straw, demanding that no more children be housed in two of its wings.

The damning report on yet another young offender institution contrasts sharply with a report published this week on Swinfen Hall YOI in Staffordshire, which was described as a centre of excellence.

The Stoke Heath report, published today, says the level of injuries found was unprecedented, with "assaults, fighting and violence endemic" among the 600 inmates inside residential wings of the youth jail.

It says that over an eight-month period last year some 717 acts of violence had been recorded involving injuries to the teenage inmates. There were 268 injuries caused by assaults by other inmates, a further 282 during fights, 116 from incidents of self-harm, and 95 were minor injuries from staff using control and restraint methods. Sir David said the figures were the highest he had seen in five years of inspecting youth jails.

The inspection, which took place last October, also disclosed that six out of 10 inmates said they were put through some sort of initiation test when they arrived. All the juveniles who arrived in the 10 days before last year's inspection said they were "very frightened and in constant fear of assault from other children".

One child who had been there for two weeks, had two black eyes and was considerably distressed. He told inspectors that he had been attacked four times since he had arrived.

"The prison service must ensure that basic standards for the treatment of children in custody are never allowed to deteriorate to the level found at Stoke Heath," said Sir David. "It is quite clear that too many children and young people in Stoke Heath neither felt, nor were, safe. I have never before had to report such a horrendous number of reported injuries to children and young prisoners.

"It is important that no more children should be sent to the juvenile induction and remand wings until decent and humane treatment and conditions are in place."

Immediately before the inspection the governor and deputy governor had been removed from their posts and replaced by an acting governor and deputy from another youth jail.

The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, denied that Stoke Heath was either unsafe or inhumane: "It is an establishment which has shown real evidence of weathering a period of turbulence, to regain a sense of stability and purpose."

He said a range of proven anti-bullying measures had been introduced and the number of completed injury report forms had more than halved since the inspection last October. The use of restraint techniques by staff had also fallen by almost 70%.

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
As foot and mouth creeps ever closer, our diarist concentrates on the hard labour of lambing

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: As foot and mouth creeps ever closer, our diarist concentrates on the hard labour of lambing.
fields.body:
On Sunday night we received a phone call, and the news was bad: a confirmed case of foot and mouth, much too close for comfort. We've had the ordnance survey map out on the kitchen table. The infected farm lies just over a mile south-east of us as the crow flies - or more alarmingly as the geese and seagulls fly, as we suspect the birds could be responsible for bringing foot and mouth here.

There is another farm and a reservoir between us, and consequently we are all concentrating on our heavy lambing workload - and keeping our eyes wide open.

More and more cases are coming up in Northumberland, seemingly in a random, pepperpot manner. Since neighbouring farms are also taken out as dangerous contacts, huge areas of the county are now empty of livestock. Many farmers - our friends and colleagues - simply have no lambing to do. Our friends, the Howards at Allendale, and the Browns, where Tigger our terrier was born, have lost their flocks and now their fields and fells lie silent and empty.

We've another suspected case a similar distance to the east, but we are hoping this one proves to be negative. I've also heard of a previous suspected case where the ewes in a flock had eaten a straw barrier laid on an open road through their field, and this chemically laced snack caused painful mouth blisters. Luckily the tests proved negative and the sheep recovered.

The handling of this affair on the ground is still far from satisfactory. Neighbouring farms still wait for days before being told if they are at risk and the slaughter of animals is often held up, as is the disposing of the bodies. When this is finally over, we, as an industry, want a full public inquiry.

Meanwhile Ian, our lambing assistant, says it is so busy in the shed he feels like he's been here for a fortnight already. In fact he's done a week, with a day off on Saturday. Twenty-six sheep lambed before breakfast yesterday. I spent hours in the shed at the weekend as we had a series of slow lambs unable to suckle without assistance. I've always called these lambs "duck eggs" and this particular one was a classic. I spent ages feeding him on Saturday - four times from his mother, and then I still had to top him up with powdered milk. Then on Sunday morning, James found that the ewe had lain on the lamb in the night and squashed him.

Every mule ewe that lambs in the field is brought in her own individual pen. We make sure they have a water bucket, hay to eat and clean straw. Their lambs are checked within the first few hours to make sure they have suckled, and help is given if they have not.

We check every lamb each evening in case we've missed a hungry one, and we spray strong iodine solution on their navels to help them heal and to prevent infection. Within the first 24 hours, castration and shortening of the tails (to prevent fly-strike, when flies lay their eggs in the sheep's wool) is carried out.

Lambs are then marked with matching numbers for twins, a letter of the alphabet for triplets and a single dot for a single lamb. This makes it easier for Graham and Peter to make sure each sheep family is properly mothered up in the evening - lost lambs are at risk overnight from predators, the cold and hunger.

Twice a day the sheep in the shed receive concentrated food. Some ewes are so greedy, and after living here for up to five years know our system so well, that they gobble their own ration and then leap into other pens, disrupting the feeding for the rest of the flock.

Hay and water is topped up as many times a day as we can manage - a minimum of six times. Clean straw is added to each pen at least twice a day in an effort to keep any infection away. Each little family unit remains in the shed for up to 48 hours. Then they are taken away in a two-berth trailer by Archie (our visiting shepherd) or Graham across the road and to the pasture. Each vacated pen has disinfectant powder sprinkled on the dirty bedding, more clean straw put on top and a fresh bucket of water put in.

Dorothy, who helps us out a few hours each week, has just arrived. She had a phone call yesterday to say that we and another farm had gone down, but so far we're both still here.

The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. Her diary will be back on Friday.

fields.bodyText: On Sunday night we received a phone call, and the news was bad: a confirmed case of foot and mouth, much too close for comfort. We've had the ordnance survey map out on the kitchen table. The infected farm lies just over a mile south-east of us as the crow flies - or more alarmingly as the geese and seagulls fly, as we suspect the birds could be responsible for bringing foot and mouth here. There is another farm and a reservoir between us, and consequently we are all concentrating on our heavy lambing workload - and keeping our eyes wide open. More and more cases are coming up in Northumberland, seemingly in a random, pepperpot manner. Since neighbouring farms are also taken out as dangerous contacts, huge areas of the county are now empty of livestock. Many farmers - our friends and colleagues - simply have no lambing to do. Our friends, the Howards at Allendale, and the Browns, where Tigger our terrier was born, have lost their flocks and now their fields and fells lie silent and empty. We've another suspected case a similar distance to the east, but we are hoping this one proves to be negative. I've also heard of a previous suspected case where the ewes in a flock had eaten a straw barrier laid on an open road through their field, and this chemically laced snack caused painful mouth blisters. Luckily the tests proved negative and the sheep recovered. The handling of this affair on the ground is still far from satisfactory. Neighbouring farms still wait for days before being told if they are at risk and the slaughter of animals is often held up, as is the disposing of the bodies. When this is finally over, we, as an industry, want a full public inquiry. Meanwhile Ian, our lambing assistant, says it is so busy in the shed he feels like he's been here for a fortnight already. In fact he's done a week, with a day off on Saturday. Twenty-six sheep lambed before breakfast yesterday. I spent hours in the shed at the weekend as we had a series of slow lambs unable to suckle without assistance. I've always called these lambs "duck eggs" and this particular one was a classic. I spent ages feeding him on Saturday - four times from his mother, and then I still had to top him up with powdered milk. Then on Sunday morning, James found that the ewe had lain on the lamb in the night and squashed him. Every mule ewe that lambs in the field is brought in her own individual pen. We make sure they have a water bucket, hay to eat and clean straw. Their lambs are checked within the first few hours to make sure they have suckled, and help is given if they have not. We check every lamb each evening in case we've missed a hungry one, and we spray strong iodine solution on their navels to help them heal and to prevent infection. Within the first 24 hours, castration and shortening of the tails (to prevent fly-strike, when flies lay their eggs in the sheep's wool) is carried out. Lambs are then marked with matching numbers for twins, a letter of the alphabet for triplets and a single dot for a single lamb. This makes it easier for Graham and Peter to make sure each sheep family is properly mothered up in the evening - lost lambs are at risk overnight from predators, the cold and hunger. Twice a day the sheep in the shed receive concentrated food. Some ewes are so greedy, and after living here for up to five years know our system so well, that they gobble their own ration and then leap into other pens, disrupting the feeding for the rest of the flock. Hay and water is topped up as many times a day as we can manage - a minimum of six times. Clean straw is added to each pen at least twice a day in an effort to keep any infection away. Each little family unit remains in the shed for up to 48 hours. Then they are taken away in a two-berth trailer by Archie (our visiting shepherd) or Graham across the road and to the pasture. Each vacated pen has disinfectant powder sprinkled on the dirty bedding, more clean straw put on top and a fresh bucket of water put in. Dorothy, who helps us out a few hours each week, has just arrived. She had a phone call yesterday to say that we and another farm had gone down, but so far we're both still here. The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. webTitle: America the Horrible is now turning into a pariah

fields.headline: America the Horrible is now turning into a pariah
fields.standfirst:
Let no one 'misunderestimate' Bush and his abandonment of Kyoto

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: In his own inimitable words, let no one "misunderestimate" George W Bush. He is the most rightwing president in living memory. If this is compassionate conservatism, what does the other sort look like?
fields.body:
In his own inimitable words, let no one "misunderestimate" George W Bush. He is the most rightwing president in living memory. If this is compassionate conservatism, what does the other sort look like? In less than 100 days he has turned America into a pariah, made enemies of the entire world, his only friends the dirty polluters of the oil industry who put him there. His foreign non-policy is a calamity, brilliantly uniting Russia and China with gratuitous offence and threat.

The Republican leader of the senate environment committee's last-minute cancellation of an urgent global warming meeting with the EU environment commissioner on Monday was like a cold war tactical snub from the Khrushchev era. Europe gets the message, so did an outraged Japan. The rest of the world draws instinctively together in its repudiation of the Bush Jnr White House. Through this strange global vandalism, the leader of the free world has become the rogue. Ungracious in victory, absolute power corrupting absolutely, the only super-power is morphing into an evil empire of its own.

Where to begin on America the Horrible? Start with it tearing up the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty to install a national missile defence system, recreating a new cold war with China as No 1 enemy. North Korean "sunshine" detente is over. NDM only gives the US an illusion of invulnerability in a world it makes more dangerous. World trade negotiations were wrecked by US self- interest. Not a cent has been paid of the US promised $600m for third world debt-relief. While US wealth soared in the last decade, only 20% of its citizens gained but his budget includes a $1.6 trillion tax cut, most for the richest. The toxic Texan (he left behind the filthiest state) denies global warming and urges oil drilling in the Alaskan National Wildlife Arctic Refuge. He even abolished regulations limiting arsenic in drinking water and cut black-lung benefits. This richest nation on earth will never lead a redistributive global politics while so unconcerned about third world poverty among its own. No, there is no lack of material for a thoroughly satisfying rant.

It was at a press conference an insulting half an hour before meeting German Chancellor Gerhard Schröder that Bush spoke his heart on the Kyoto climate change treaty. Those words will become a classic clip, pursuing him through eternity. It was the way he thumped the podium and smirked as he said it, (even this was inarticulate): "We will not do anything that harms our economy, because first things first are the people who live in America." There we have it. Screw the world, Americans always come first.

In the past presidents always gave Americans a self-image that was noble, a global purpose in the vanguard of democracy, spiritually still a young revolutionary state, with quotes aplenty. That raw energy and self-belief has always thrilled and mesmerised outsiders. Whatever hot debates about America's true intentions (selfishness lurks beneath altruism in all international horse-trading), the country always had a fine story to tell itself about its mission. Late and reluctant into two world wars, the star-spangled cavalry did arrive at last. Delinquent or deluded in Vietnam, there was a fight to be had for freedom against Ho Chi Minh's communist invaders, a good story to be told.

In Kosovo the zero-body bag cowardice of fighting from too high to hit the targets was matched by the nobility of fighting at all in a place so far from Kalamazoo. American huddled masses yearning to breathe free always needed the Hollywood version of their politics and quite rightly so. Who can bear to be bad? So the brazen nudity of Bush's words must have shocked millions of Americans from coast to coast - and in that is the best hope of better to come.

The global response was instant and visceral. Blistering editorials poured out of the press from Brazil to Belgium, Tokyo to Turin. Politicians were barely more controlled. Some 45 editorials across American newspapers condemned their president. Our own John Prescott said: "The US cannot sit in glorious isolation ... It must know it cannot pollute the world while free-riding on action by everyone else." What next? Attack! Boycott Gallo wines, McDonald's, Texaco and Exxon-Mobil. Why not? It may satisfy revenge, it may even deliver a jolt or two, but as official policy this is as unlikely to change hearts and minds in the evil empire as futile gesturing was against the USSR in cold war days.

One way or another the US has to be persuaded to take global warming seriously. The fierce argument among Kyoto signatories is how to do it. The US agreed (but never ratified) cutting emissions by 7% from its 1990 levels, by 2010. Due to Clinton's self-destruction and his "third way" ducking of anything difficult when faced with republican obstruction, that commitment is now effectively impossible. The US boom means it would now take a 30% cut to hit the target. Cheap fuel is designed into America's unimaginably vast prairies of suburbia without buses or town centres. True, the fashion for four-wheel drive monsters has eaten up all technological gains in fuel efficiency. True, that $1.6 trillion tax cut should go on public transport and clean energy, but only a cultural revolution could deliver a one third reduction now.

Since a quarter of the world's carbon output is here, letting America progress at a slower pace makes sense. Blame is satis fying, but survival depends on results.

It was the detail of this debate that made Prescott storm out of the stalled Hague negotiations in November. He said realism required letting the US cheat a bit by buying spare emissions from Russia and planting forests. Greens said their calculations showed this meant the US need make no other effort at all to change its ways. But getting Americans to accept the idea of fundamental change is the crucial first step. The world needs a 60% cut within 50-100 years and the crunch will come. If Kyoto progresses to ratification by all the other countries, the hope is that the US will want to join a carbon emissions trading bloc. The threat of trade tariffs against US goods to balance their unfair lack of pollution control was posed by the EU environment commissioner: "Why should the US play by other rules than European companies?"

With all eyes fixed on US public opinion, some polls find 75% "very concerned", but Californian black-outs make energy shortages hotter news. Democrats and some Republicans think Bush has made a bad political mistake: his mangled words will have to be eaten soon. For the rest of the world, how much threat and fury, how much backroom dealing it will take to reel the rogue state back in, is a delicate calculation: there must be no further splits. Good, bad or ugly, saving the world without America may not be impossible, just exceedingly unlikely.

fields.headline: US rebuffs Europe on climate
fields.trailText: An EU delegation hurriedly dispatched to Washington after the Bush administration disowned the Kyoto treaty on global warming last week expressed disappointment yesterday that US negotiators ruled out any role in implementing the agreements and offered no alternatives.
fields.byline: Julian Borger in Washington and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
An EU delegation hurriedly dispatched to Washington after the Bush administration disowned the Kyoto treaty on global warming last week expressed disappointment yesterday that US negotiators ruled out any role in implementing the agreements and offered no alternatives.

Kjell Larsson, the Swedish environment minister who led the delegation, said he was happy that the Bush environment team accepted the existence of global warming - a conclusion widely challenged in the US - and that a US delegation would be sent to Bonn in July for talks on climate change.

However, the Europeans failed to win an undertaking from Christine Todd Whitman, the head of the US environmental protection agency (EPA), to attend the meeting in person. "She has not committed to that," an EPA spokesman said yesterday.

The Europeans also made no progress in persuading the administration to soften its outright rejection of the 1997 Kyoto Protocol and its targets for greenhouse gas emissions.

"We had hoped for a small opening," Mr Larsson said, "and we didn't get that."

The delegation was snubbed by the head of the Senate environment committee, Bob Smith, a rightwing Republican from New Hampshire who cancelled a meeting on Monday and refused to reschedule it. In fact, the Europeans did not meet any of the administration's real power-brokers.

Instead, they held talks with Gary Edson, a mid-level White House official with environmental responsibilities, and Ms Whitman, whose own ad vice to support the Kyoto deal was ignored by Mr Bush.

After the meeting, Ms Whitman restated the president's objections to Kyoto, saying it was "unfair to the United States and to other industrialised nations" because it exempted developing nations.

"Today I emphasised to members of the European community that I continue to be as optimistic as the president that, working constructively with our friends and allies through international processes, we can develop technologies, market-based incentives, and other innovative approaches to global climate change," she said in a written statement.

However, Margot Wallstrom, the EU commissioner for the environment, said there appeared to be little substance behind Ms Whitman's expressions of good will.

She said: "We tried to interpret in a positive way what was being said here - that they are interested in continuing international relations, but they do not for today have any answers on how to do that."

On Friday Ms Wallstrom and the environment ministers of Sweden and Belgium will begin a tour taking them to Russia, Iran, China and Japan.

Brussels is making clear that even if the final message from Washington is that the US is pulling out of the agreement, the EU is sticking with it - and looking for allies who will follow suit.

Further pressure on the US came last night from the German environment minister, Jürgen Trittin. "If they don't want to participate, we expect that the United States will tolerate the process and not block it," said Mr Trittin, a Green.

fields.headline: Gap in the formation
fields.standfirst:
Founder quits 365 Corporation
More net news
fields.trailText: The founder and chief executive of 365 Corporation, the media content provider best known for its football website, yesterday abruptly announced his departure.
fields.body:
The founder and chief executive of 365 Corporation, the media content provider best known for its football website, yesterday abruptly announced his departure.

Dan Thompson described by associates as a serial entrepreneur, surprised colleagues with his resignation and the shares fell 2.5p to 20p.

Mr Thompson holds 6.5m shares - a stake of 3.2%. Nearly half of the holding is subject to a lock-up agreement which expires when the company issues results for the year to April.

Martin Turner, the finance director who has stepped up as deputy chief executive, said he was confident Mr Thompson would do nothing to damage the company. Asked if the resignation had surprised the board, he said it had "to some extent".

"Dan is very much an entrepreneur and has been involved from the beginning," Mr Turner said. "He indicated that it was time for him to move on."

The board had not begun to look for a successor to Mr Thompson, who would stay until the end of June and then perform occasional consultancy work.

Cazenove, the house broker, forecast profitability for 365 by 2003. It predicted revenues of £50m and pretax losses of £11.6m for the full year.

Under publishing director Danny Kelly, the firm is noted for its irreverent football website, but 92% of revenues are generated by telephone services.

fields.headline: Rail budget blow
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Almost three-quarters of the strategic rail authority's budget of £1.3bn will this year go in subsidies to ailing train operating firms and services, the SRA confirmed yesterday.
fields.body:
Almost three-quarters of the strategic rail authority's budget of £1.3bn will this year go in subsidies to ailing train operating firms and services, the SRA confirmed yesterday.

It said that it would be paying more than £900m in subsidies to most of the train firms under an agreement with the Tory government before the last election.

This leaves the SRA with only £400m to plan for future expansion, much less than Sir Alastair Morton, the SRA's chairman, would like for his new strategy expected to be published after the election.

The budget shows the SRA's room for manoeuvre is limited, and demonstrates that the Treasury is maintaining a tight hold on spending.

The SRA has come to the rescue of Anglia, one of the smaller rail firms, with a £1m grant for extra trains this year.

Mike Grant, the SRA's chief executive, said that Angia had already benefited from more than £3m in extra funding and that "rural routes will receive a substantial boost".

If train operating firms fail to meet their franchise commitments the SRA has the authority to take over and run them on behalf of the government. One operator was about to be handed over to the SRA two years ago but was taken over by anotherfirm at the last moment. Anglia is said to be facing problems - in part due to the Hatfield train crash.

fields.trailText: The management of Russia's main independent television station was purged yesterday in what was seen as a huge blow to media freedom in the country.
fields.body:
The management of Russia's main independent television station was purged yesterday in what was seen as a huge blow to media freedom in the country.

In the climax to a year-long battle for control of NTV, Gazprom, the state-controlled gas corporation which owns 46% of the station, summoned an emergency meeting of NTV shareholders to remove the exiled media mogul, Vladimir Gusinsky, and his associates from its board.

NTV is the key asset in Mr Gusinsky's media empire. The meeting, denounced as illegal by his associates and most of the channel's staff, resulted in Gazprom executives taking six of the nine board seats, including chairman, director, and editor-in-chief of news and current affairs.

The boardroom coup raised fears that it will now join Russia's two state TV channels as Kremlin mouthpieces, meaning that the Russian president, Vladimir Putin, has engineered a clean sweep of the key electronic media.

Last night's flagship news bulletin on NTV was presented as a defiant swan song, the television screens marked with a logo reading "protest".

The channel's staff lined up behind the newsreader, following a staff meeting held outside the station's studios, at which its journalists vowed to resist yesterday's takeover.

Russia's best-known current affairs presenter, Yevgeny Kiselev, was sacked. Before his removal he had been NTV's director-general and editor-in-chief. In recent months he had become a high-profile standard-bearer for the free press in Russia and a trenchant opponent of the Kremlin.

A controversial American businessman of Russian ancestry, Boris Jordan, replaced Mr Kiselev as head of NTV. The head of Gazprom's media subsidiary, Alfred Kokh, became chairman of the board. A candidate handpicked by Gazprom, Vladimir Kulistikov, head of the RIA state news agency, became editor-in-chief.

In the past year Russia's two main state television channels had already been cajoled into providing supportive coverage of the government and the president.

With a similar regime apparently beginning at NTV, the Kremlin can now savour the prospect of a clean sweep of the key electronic media.

The US has complained that Mr Gusinsky was being harassed for criticising Mr Putin's policies, and on Monday the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe demanded that NTV be spared state interference.

NTV journalists pinned the blame for yesterday's boardroom coup on President Putin.

"President Putin is being informed of what is going on and bears responsibility for the consequences," the journalists said in a statement broadcast on the channel yesterday. The aim of yesterday's board meeting was "to establish full political control" of the channel, they said.

Gazprom, 38% owned by the state, argues that it is acting solely on financial grounds. It is trying to recoup hundreds of millions of pounds owed to it by Mr Gusinsky's businesses, and to turn a profit at NTV.

The tycoon is in Spain, from where the Russian authorities are demanding his extradition on fraud charges. But in a Spanish court hearing last week, Mr Gusinsky was granted bail, suggesting that he will not be extradited.

The impact of yesterday's boardroom coup could be dramatic, with NTV staff threatening to strike and further courtroom tussles inevitable.

Up to 20,000 people demonstrated in Moscow last weekend in support of NTV and press freedom, denouncing Gazprom as the enforcer of the Kremlin's campaign to muzzle free speech.

The television station, generally viewed as the best in Russia, has been a consistent critic of Mr Putin; its reporting of the war in Chechnya and of last year's Kursk submarine disaster particularly irked him.

The takeover is likely to trigger a haemmorhaging of staff.

"NTV will survive whether they want to work with us or not," Mr Jordan stated bluntly as he prepared to head for the studios last night. "I have a strict mandate from shareholders to make the company profitable."

Gazprom,with 46% of the shares, was able to call and control yesterday's board meeting because a further 19% of the channel, and the voting rights which go with it, were frozen by a recent court ruling, giving the state gas monopoly the opening it needed.

Russia's TV battles

 A little more than a year ago, Oleg Dobrodeyev, an NTV founder and Putin supporter, was appointed head of RTR, Russia's second state channel; since that time the station has become an uncritical Kremlin supporter

 The first state channel, ORT, has been traditionally docile. Mr Gusinsky's media mogul rival, Boris Berezovsky, controlled ORT and fell out with President Vladimir Putin after his election. This January he conceded defeat and handed over his 49% share in ORT to a businessman close to the Kremlin

 TVTs owes its loyalty to the Moscow mayor, Yuri Luzhkov. Although, unlike ORT, RTR and NTV, it does not broadcast nationally, the channel is important to the Kremlin in the key Moscow region. The media minister, Mikhail Lesin, last year threatened to withdraw its broadcasting licence. Following that threat, it has toned down its content

webTitle: Rebuke for insurers on genetic testing

fields.headline: Rebuke for insurers on genetic testing
fields.standfirst: Special report: the ethics of genetics
fields.trailText: The government is planning to intervene to stop the growth of an uninsurable genetic underclass, as a committee of MPs yesterday called for a two-year moratorium on further genetic testing.
fields.body:
The government is planning to intervene to stop the growth of an uninsurable genetic underclass, as a committee of MPs yesterday called for a two-year moratorium on further genetic testing.

Ministers are considering the idea of providing subsidies to people in high-risk categories as well as a legally enforceable moratorium.

Yvette Cooper, the health minister, is known to be increasingly concerned about the need to protect individuals from unfair discrimination over insurance.

In a damning report on the secrecy, irresponsibility and ineptitude of the insurance industry's handling of such a sensitive subject, the MPs accuse insurance firms of misleading them over the extent to which they were already using test results to assess premiums.

The science select committee accuses insurers of being "far more interested in establishing their future right to use genetic test results in assessing premiums, than in whether or not they are reliable or relevant."

The MPs also attack the government for failing to regulate, leading to an "atmosphere of confusion and ignorance". It also warns that regulatory bodies are either underfunded or inappropriately contain representatives from the insurance industry. During the inquiry, the Norwich Union and the Prudential changed their evidence and admitted they were using tests not approved by the government's genetics and insurance committee.

The human genetics commission, charged with advising ministers, is already studying the future of insurance. It is likely to recommend that high-risk subscribers should be able to receive protection from a reinsurance pool, probably through some form of government subsidy.

The commission on Friday looked at reinsurance as "a middle way" between public opposition to companies having any access to tests and the companies' contrary view.

The government has already warned that the science of genetics will in the foreseeable future increase the premiums of high-risk subscribers.

The MPs say the Association of British Insurers "must act as a matter of urgency to convince the public and government that that code of practice is being complied with". They points out that some companies, such as Virgin Direct, are not signatories to the code.

So far the genetics and insurance committee (GAIC), the regulatory body, has only given permission for life insurers to use test results for assessing the risk of Huntingdon's disease. It is also studying applications for familial early onset Alzheimer's disease.

But the insurance companies have insisted wider tests can be used prior to their approval or otherwise by the GAIC. The committee demands that the "insurance companies should immediately cease to use the positive results from any genetic test that has not been explicitly approved by the GAIC".

The MPs warn that polls showed that only 7% of the country believed insurance firms could be trusted to use genetic data responsibly.

The committee opposes an outright ban on use of all genetic information by insurers, since this would deny those with a bad family history and a good genetic test result the opportunity of obtaining insurance on a standard rating.

The ABI responded by saying it was already reviewing its code and would never ask anyone to take a genetic test to obtain insurance. It added: "Insurers can only ask to see existing genetic test results where medical experts have identified the test as reliable and relevant for insurance purposes."

fields.headline: Milosevic faces death penalty
fields.standfirst:
Former leader to be charged over murders
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Slobodan Milosevic could soon be charged with crimes that carry the death penalty, such as ordering the murders of political rivals during his 13 years in power.
fields.byline: Jonathan Steele in Belgrade and Ian Black in Brussels
fields.body:
Slobodan Milosevic could soon be charged with crimes that carry the death penalty, such as ordering the murders of political rivals during his 13 years in power.

The implicit threat of capital punishment was made yesterday by Serbia's interior minister, Dusan Mihailovic, who told reporters on a visit to Vienna: "There are indications that Slobodan Milosevic was involved in severe criminal acts for which the death penalty is provided."

Mr Mihailovic did not elaborate but Serbia's prime minister, Zoran Djindjic, told the Boston Globe that the former Yugoslav president would be charged within two months with ordering the murders of personal and political enemies.

The jailed ex-president's close colleague, Rade Markovic, his former security chief, is already being investigated for the suspicious road accident which killed three bodyguards and the brother-in-law of Vuk Draskovic, a leading opposition politician.

Mr Milosevic could be questioned and charged over that event, and also in connection with the assassination of Slavko Curuvija, the editor of a Belgrade newspaper, who was gunned down at his front door after writing a critical piece on the president.

Meanwhile, President Vojislav Kostunica criticised the police operation to arrest Mr Milosevic as bungled and clumsy. He also denied that it was linked to the American decision to release $50m (£35m) of new aid for Yugoslavia.

"I would have been happier if the arrest was done earlier. But the decision was not made under threat. The day before the arrest one could already see that the US decision would be positive," he said.

Although Yugoslavia needed the money, as well as International Monetary Fund loans, "to survive and rebuild" he described it as "extremely little when compared to the $30,000m of damage caused by the Nato bombardment".

Mr Kostunica said that the decision to transfer Mr Milosevic to the Hague was "not in the president's competence". It would be taken by Momcilo Grubac, the justice minister, who said that the draft billl on cooperation with the Hague should be in force by the end of next month.

The European Union signalled yesterday that aid to Serbia could become conditional on the handover of Mr Milosevic to the Hague war crimes tribunal, though it said it would not set any deadline.

Gunnar Weigand, a spokesman for the EU's external relations commissioner, Chris Patten, said that €90m (£55m)-worth of aid for 2001 still had be programmed, and that its delivery would depend on "political developments".

Jean-Jacques Joris, political adviser to the Hague prosecutor, Carla del Ponte, said that the tribunal was prepared to wait a "few months" for the handover, but added: "Further cooperation is something they will also have to deliver on. This includes access to documentation and to witnesses and the most visible part, the transfer of indictees."

In announcing the $50m of aid, Colin Powell, the US secretary of state, threatened not to help to convene a donors' conference for Serbia this summer unless Yugoslavia went on cooperating with the tribunal.

However, Mr Kostunica insisted: "Conditioning will not be there in the case of the donors' conference. Blackmail doesn't work." Yugoslavia was happy to co-operate with the international community but "it doesn't mean accepting everything or putting a handful of dollars above national dignity".

Mr Milosevic's appeal against the order jailing him for 30 days pending investigation into corruption and other charges was rejected by a Belgrade court yesterday, as expected.

In a long defence plea the former president argued that he could not tamper with witnesses because his phone was tapped nor could he escape because his villa was guarded. But he admitted for the first time that he had secretly made funds available to the Bosnian Serb and Croatian Serb armies to fight their wars.

While defending himself against misuse of funds, he may have aided the prosecuting lawyers in the Hague by showing his closeness to military operationsin Bosnia and Croatia.

 The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, is to fly to Belgrade tomorrow for talks with Mr Kostunica, when he will press for Mr Milosevic to be handed over to the Hague tribunal.

webTitle: Putin shuns the US in favour of Europe

fields.headline: Putin shuns the US in favour of Europe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin signalled a potentially momentous shift in Russian foreign policy yesterday, choosing in future to ignore the US in favour of promoting European integration.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin signalled a potentially momentous shift in Russian foreign policy yesterday, choosing in future to ignore the US in favour of promoting European integration.

In his annual state-of-the-nation address to both chambers of parliament in the Kremlin, Mr Putin, by adjusting his gaze to Europe, reversed decades of making Washington the priority for Moscow's foreign policy.

He neglected to mention the USA at all in his passage on foreign policy, instead stressing the need for partnership between Russia and the EU.

"A course of integration with Europe will be one of the main directions of our foreign policy," Mr Putin stated in his one-hour speech.

The new Bush administration in Washington has shown its intent to downgrade Russia as a foreign policy priority and Mr Putin responded in kind yesterday, declaring that Russia's policy should reflect the country's economic interests.

He also took a sideswipe at Nato, asserting that Russia wanted to cooperate with the western alliance but only if it respected international law and observed the strictures of the UN security council.

"Unfortunately, in its decision making, this organisation ignores the views of the international community," he said.

By contrast, he said, in its relations with the rest of the world, Russia would always be "a trustworthy and predictable partner".

The keenly awaited speech focused mainly on Russia's domestic problems, dwelling more on diagnosing its ills than the prescriptions for their cure.

Boris Nemtsov, a liberal former deputy prime minister, criticised the speech for being too vague.

The thrust of Mr Putin's message was stability and continuity, with an emphasis on law and order. He spoke of the planned reforms of the judiciary, taxation, land and property rights, education, health, and pensions, without being too specific in any area.

Capital was fleeing Russia at the rate of $20bn (£14bn) a year because of a lack of business confidence, he said. To its detriment, the Russian economy remained dependent on raw material production and export, and serious structural reform was non-existent.

The decade since the collapse of the Soviet Union, he said, had been a revolutionary time but those days were now gone.

"There will be no more revolutions or counter-revolutions."

webTitle: 'The new authorities want to sully my work'

fields.headline: 'The new authorities want to sully my work'
fields.standfirst:
Edited extract from Slobodan Milosevic's defence against allegations of abuse of power
Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: "The investigation document states that I incited the highest officials of the federal government to commit illegal acts and acquire gain for others from 1994 until October 5 2000. But the people who profited were solely our state and people, the defence and security of our country and economy.
fields.body:
"The investigation document states that I incited the highest officials of the federal government to commit illegal acts and acquire gain for others from 1994 until October 5 2000. But the people who profited were solely our state and people, the defence and security of our country and economy.

"The money put into the economy through the Beogradska Banka went to help the most vulnerable social and economic hotspots during conditions of crisis. They were not stolen by anyone.

"As for the funds spent on weapons and ammunition and the other needs of the Bosnian Serb Republic Army and the Croatian Serb Republic Army, as these were state secrets they could not be shown in the budget, which is a public document. The same is true of the expenses for equipping the security forces and counter-terrorist forces.

"I was not involved in questions of party financing for the last 10 years. It would not be logical for anyone to demand that of me considering my vast state obligations, and my party comrades did not ask me. I never used a single dinar or any material goods belonging to the party, nor any party vehicle.

"I want to repeat that never, either directly or through anyone else, did I receive money for my personal needs. Except for my salary as President of Serbia and Yugoslavia I had no other income.

"I am not bothered by any investigation of my life but I am bothered at being treated like a criminal for doing my best for my state. I consider these court proceedings to be politically staged under orders from the new authorities to demean and sully my long years of work, and especially the fact that I opposed the world's powerful in the interest of the state and people."

webTitle: Francis Wheen: Slobo proves them all wrong

fields.headline: Slobo proves them all wrong
fields.standfirst: Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: John Simpson, world affairs editor of the BBC, feared the worst. "To have tried and failed to arrest Slobodan Milosevic is nothing less than a political disaster," he wrote in the Sunday Telegraph last weekend.
fields.body:
John Simpson, world affairs editor of the BBC, feared the worst. "To have tried and failed to arrest Slobodan Milosevic is nothing less than a political disaster," he wrote in the Sunday Telegraph last weekend. "This morning, no one at the top of Yugoslav politics seems to be questioning that."

Well, it depends on what you mean by "this morning": by the time the report was published Slobo was in custody - thus making a nonsense of Simpson's predictions of a lengthy stand-off in which support for Milosevic would have "time to build up" while "feverish negotiations went on at the villa".

You would think that Simpson might have learned something from his previous attempts at entrail-reading in Belgrade. Last June, on the first anniversary of the retreat from Kosovo, he revealed in the Sunday Telegraph that Milosevic's position was now "even stronger" than during the war: "The challenge to him has peaked and faded away." The opposition consisted of no more than "a few hundred young idealists" who were unlikely to get anywhere. "They do not have the resources to organise the huge demonstrations that alone can bring Mr Milosevic down ... They do not constitute a serious threat ... Like Saddam Hussein, Mr Milosevic has full control of his state system. And like Saddam, he could be with us for some time."

Four months later, he was driven from power.

There ought to be a phrase - the opposite of idiot savant - for highly intelligent people who are also bloody fools. During the Nato campaign two years ago, dozens of generals, historians, politicians and pundits assured us that Milosevic would not withdraw his troops. With the honourable exception of Sir John Keegan, who wrote a thoughtful mea culpa in the Daily Telegraph, not one of them later admitted error. Instead they began a new chorus: because of the defeat, Milosevic was now "politically impregnable" (Simon Jenkins, the Times) and "more popular with his people than ever" (Paul Routledge, Daily Mirror). "All observers agree," Lord Healey declared, "that the bombing has strengthened Milosevic's political position in Yugoslavia."

Why have all observers been so consistently wrong about the Balkans over the past decade? Because they took Slobodan Milosevic at his own estimation, despite all the evidence that he was a liar and a fantasist. During the Bosnian war he posed as the disinterested statesman who could bring peace, even though it was he who had instigated and prosecuted the conflict; international envoys therefore treated him as the solution rather than the problem, praising his restraint and pleading with the UN "to keep Mr Milosevic on side". Later, when Milosevic vowed that Nato would never get him out of Kosovo, all observers again believed him. Even last weekend, Simpson was warning of the likelihood that "he will turn himself into a martyr", since "Milosevic is said to have shouted that he would not be captured alive".

As all observers agree, if Slobo says something then it must be true. When Douglas Hurd was foreign secretary, he insisted that Milosevic was a man we could do business with. After leaving the cabinet and taking a top job at NatWest Markets, Hurd duly went into business with him by arranging the sale of a 49% stake in the Serbian telephone monopoly. (Telecom Italia bought 29%, and the other 20% was sold to the Greek company OTE.) Hurd explained that this was "in the interests of the west", since it would help Milosevic to dismantle his "old style command economy" and "begin to liberalise and privatise". That was what Slobo told him and he had no reason to doubt it.

Less gullible financiers knew perfectly well that real privatisation was anathema to Milosevic, who was actually strengthening his central control of companies which had previously been run under the socialist self-management system. True, some new private firms and banks were created, but many of them turned out to be sanctions-busting scams or money-laundering operations run by Slobo's unlovely cronies. There is, of course, no suggestion that Hurd was aware of any rake-offs. In a brief statement to the BBC programme File on Four last weekend, he described his association with the Butcher of the Balkans as "a legitimate commercial transaction". When Slobo goes on trial, I trust that he will summon Hurd and a few other members of the All Observers club as character witnesses.

A look in the rear-view mirror and they would have seen Maxwell coming

I spent last Sunday confined to bed with a vicious but unknown ailment. My medical adviser, after ruling out foot and mouth and election fever (both of which require the attention of a spin doctor), diagnosed a bad case of Maxwell's Disease. The only cure is to stop reading the vast, indigestible DTI report on Robert Maxwell.

Anyone would feel sick after listening to all those arguments about whether such culpable negligence could or couldn't "happen again"; the fact is that it has already happened again and again while the DTI inspectors carried out their nine-year inquiry.

Worse still are the dry-eyed apologies. Maxwell's auditor, John Cowling of PriceWaterhouseCoopers, is severely criticised in the report for keeping quiet about Cap'n Bob's rigging of the accounts. "We accept we fell short of the very high standards we set ourselves," a spokesman for the firm says. "This has been very painful to us and we are sorry." But not all that sorry, to judge by the fact that Cowling is still a partner in the firm.

The true feeling in the City was best expressed by an anonymous banker who told the Daily Telegraph that if a company's chairman "turns crooked" you can't expect its auditors, lawyers, bankers or brokers to stop him. "To roast the City for the actions of a crook is unfair."

On the record, however, most of those involved have felt obliged to accept some responsibility - while simultaneously shrugging it off on the grounds that no one doubted Maxwell's probity at the time.

Here is Samuel Montagu, the stockbroker which produced a misleading prospectus for the Mirror Group's flotation: "We are sorry that events that took place took place. We accept that, with hindsight, our judgment about Robert Maxwell was wrong."

And Goldman Sachs, accused of aiding and abetting Maxwell's manipulation of the stock market: "We deeply regret this and, with the benefit of hindsight and with the information now available to us, would have acted differently." And even Kevin Maxwell: "With hindsight you wish that certain people had acted more boldly and strongly with my father."

Ah, hindsight! My medical adviser, Bruce Page, who is also a poetic chap, has prescribed a small ditty to help me through my convalescence: "The financier of London/He has no forward sight./His eyes are in his arsehole/And insensitive to light./But still he trundles onward/And never fears a crash./His snout is deeply sensitive/And leads him to the cash."

How much rear-vision did these reckless rogues need? Even at the time, they could have had the "hindsight" to read the DTI's report from 1973, which found that Maxwell was unfit to run a public company. They might also have looked a little further back and noticed the ominous slogan which Maxwell devised for his ridiculous I'm Backing Britain crusade in the late 60s: "Help Britain - Help Yourself."

fields.body:
In a report headed Leader of struggle to free the Nuba dies, page 17, yesterday, we somehow added a zero to the number of the Nuba people of central Sudan displaced this year, making it 150,000 instead of what we intended to say, 15,000.

Anna Davis, the author of a piece headed Rumour at the top, page 8 (Women), G2, yesterday, was a student on the Manchester University MA course in novel writing on which she now teaches, and not on the course at East Anglia. The mistake was ours.

In our report on 2002 university entry (Chaos theory, Education page 10, March 27) our table gave AS-level scores incorrectly. An A grade at AS-level is worth 60 points, a B 50 points, a C 40 points and so on. For a full table see www.ucas.ac.uk

In a report headed 'Race not issue' over accused Met officer, page 5, yesterday, we referred to "the Googoosh, an Iranian music festival". Googoosh is, in fact, Iran's most celebrated female pop singer. She performed at Wembley Arena in January.

We spelt Isabel Hilton's name incorrectly in our index, The two-minute Guardian, page 2, yesterday. It is Isabel not Isobel. Apologies.

We used the wrong photograph with a piece about D:Ream, page 15, G2 (Arts), yesterday. It showed Jamie Petrie, not Peter Cunnah.

The painting of the opening of the Stockton and Darlington railway line in 1825, page 4, G2, April 2, which appeared without credit and in addition was reversed was, in fact, by Terence Cuneo. It is signed and dated bottom right (or backwards bottom left in our version): Cuneo, Dec 1949. Thanks to the artist's daughter, Carole Cuneo. See: www.terencecuneo.co.uk

webTitle: Goldman tumbles to 11th in European advisers' league

fields.headline: Goldman tumbles to 11th in European advisers' league
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs has been toppled from the top ten league of investment banks, raising speculation that it will be forced to cut jobs after last year's hiring spree.
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs has been toppled from the top ten league of investment banks, raising speculation that it will be forced to cut jobs after last year's hiring spree.

The most prestigious of all the investment banks, Goldman was last night facing up to its humiliating slide from the top slot among advisers to big companies on mergers and acquisitions in Europe to 11th on the basis of deals announced so far this year.

City sources believe that the omens for the coming months are also worrying for Goldman - which ended its partnership status two years ago - as it is thought to have few deals in the pipeline at a time when the scramble to win big corporate clients is becoming increasing desperate.

The closely watched tables released by Thomson Financial yesterday show that the merger mania of recent years - which has resulted in a bonus bonanza for deal makers - has come to a shuddering halt amid uncertainty about the global impact of any recession in the US.

In the first three months of this year, the value of deals completed in Europe almost halved to $155bn (£110bn) compared with the same period last year.

Globally, a mere $454bn of deals have been announced so far, compared with a record breaking $1.1 trillion in the early part of last year.

Goldman's tumble through the rankings allowed arch-rival Morgan Stanley - pipped at the post by Goldman last year - to claim top slot, and allowed UBS Warburg to move to second place from seventh.

Goldman, which employs the chancellor's confidant, Gavyn Davies, tried to play down the significance of its sudden displacement in the league tables. "In the current market environment it would be a mistake to extrapolate from one quarter's numbers," a spokesman said. However, sources noted that the bank had increased its head count in Europe by more than 40% last year to 5,100, and was now expected to lay off 5% of staff considered to be "underperforming".

The bank is also in the process of refurbishing and expanding its offices on London's Fleet Street.

Goldman warned last month that conditions were becoming increasingly tough when it reported a 13% fall in pre-tax profits for the first three months of its financial year. However, at the time Wall Street was relieved as it had anticipated an even worse performance from the bank.

More accustomed to being in the premier position, Goldman was able to take that title when the tables were calculated on the basis of the US dollar value of completed international mergers and acquisitions deals.

City sources pointed out that Goldman may have suffered in the downturn in business because it more usually advises big companies on large deals, of which very few have been announced this year.

Sectors which have suffered a downturn in activity include telecommunications, where the partial flotation of Orange by France Télécom was regarded as particularly difficult at a time when once heavy demand for stocks was waning.

Mighty in M&A

Top merger advisers in the first quarter of 2001 (1Q2000 in brackets)

Morgan Stanley 1 (2)

UBS Warburg 2 (7)

JP Morgan 3 (11)

Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein 4 (6)

Merrill Lynch 5 (9)

Rothschild 6 (16)

Salomon Smith Barney 7 (12)

CSFB 8 (3)

Lehman 9 (8)

Deutsche 10 (4)

Goldman 11 (1)

Source: Thomson Financial, based on European deals announced between January 1 and March 31 2001
