fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Abbey hit by double debit
fields.body:
Abbey hit by double debit

A computer error yesterday caused 100,000 Abbey National customers to have their bank accounts debited twice with mortgage payments, causing some to incur overdraft charges.

For an average Abbey National customer paying £450 a month off a mortgages that would have meant £900 disappearing from the account.

Abbey said the mistake was entirely the fault of Royal Bank of Scotland, which processes some of its mortgage payments. Direct debits to collect April mortgage payments from "a small percentage" of Abbey National customers were taken out twice. RBS would reimburse anyone out of pocket as a result of the "unfortunate mistake".

FSA gives voice to consumers

Gordon Brown yesterday appointed the financial services authority's first managing director with specific responsibility for consumer interests.

The Treasury said John Tiner would join the FSA from Andersen where he was head of worldwide financial services. Carol Sergeant replaces Philip Thorpe as managing director of regulatory process and the risk directorate.

Ovaltine closes UK factory

A factory which has been making the Ovaltine malted drink since 1913 is to close with the loss of 245 jobs. Production at Kings Langley, Hertfordshire, will end in May next year to improve competitiveness.

Novartis Consumer Health said production will be increased at its other European factory in Switzerland.

The company, which sells 10m jars of Ovaltine in Britain every year, said it was also ending UK production of malt extract.

Orange nets 3G financing deals

Orange has clinched €3.45bn (£2.1bn) of loans from suppliers for its French, German and British third-generation mobile phone networks.

The group said it had agreed €2.3bn of deals to build the networks with Nokia, Ericsson and Alcatel - which will provide it with financing worth 150% of the contracts. The announcement is the latest in a series of moves by mobile phone operators to extract short-term cash from their suppliers, to help cope with the huge debts taken on to buy 3G licences from the government.

Carpetbagger on the agenda

The Nationwide building society yesterday confirmed that a demutualising motion from Andrew Muir and his nomination as a board director would go forward to a board meeting on April 16.

Six proposals put forward by pro-mutuality campaigner Tim Tanner would also be considered. He wants to make it easier for the society's 10m members to propose resolutions at agms, and allow them to vote on directors' pay and proposals for mergers.

The society said that Mr Muir had submitted 820 signatures in support of demutualisation and his nomination as a director.

fields.headline: Corus pays £2m to sacked chiefs
fields.trailText: The two failed chief executives of Corus, the £1bn loss-making Anglo-Dutch steel group that is shedding 6,000 UK jobs, received pay-offs worth more than £2m after their enforced resignations last December.
fields.body:
The two failed chief executives of Corus, the £1bn loss-making Anglo-Dutch steel group that is shedding 6,000 UK jobs, received pay-offs worth more than £2m after their enforced resignations last December.

John Bryant, 57, who joined the former British Steel in 1967, was given a "termination payment" of £876,310 after his dismissal on December 5. He had just signed a new two-year contract. Mr Bryant, who is thought to have recently taken on a non-executive directorship in his native Wales, is now also enjoying a Corus pension of some £206,319 a year.

Wales will lose more than 4,000 well-paid steelworkers, including 3,000 at the Llanwern plant near Newport, Gwent, earning £20,000-£25,000 a year - and likely to take on new jobs, if at all, at half of that salary. Redundancy payments for long service employees are unlikely to top a year's salary.

Fokko van Duyne, Mr Bryant's Dutch fellow co-chief executive, received a pay-off of £1,147,205, according to Corus's annual report yesterday. This includes two years' pre-pension payment under Dutch law. Another Dutch director was awarded £633,563.

In the 15 months from the merger of British Steel and Hoogovens to form Corus, Mr Bryant earned £509,843 while Mr van Duyne earned £555,644. The pair also had extensive share options that have now lapsed.

According to the annual report, Corus, which lost £1.15bn last year at the operating level, paid out no executive bonuses but it has set up a new bonus scheme and this week awarded new share options to board members.

Sir Brian Moffat, chairman and acting chief executive, was paid £356,660 - down from the £520,362 in 1998-99 when he combined both roles. Since resuming the role of chief executive last December his remuneration is "under review".

Sir Brian Moffat, chairman and acting chief executive, was paid £356,660 - down from the £520,362 in 1998-99 when he combined both roles. Since resuming the role of chief executive last December his remuneration is "under review".

webTitle: Recognition Systems hit by US slowdown

fields.headline: Recognition Systems faces up to US impact
fields.trailText: Recognition Systems yesterday added its name to the list of technology companies warning that profits are being hit by the slowdown in the US market.
fields.body:
Recognition Systems yesterday added its name to the list of technology companies warning that profits are being hit by the slowdown in the US market.

The Birmingham business, which develops and sells customer relationship management software and systems, said revenue for the year to the end of September would be hit by the slowdown in the US and saw its shares drop 77p to 37.5p.

Recognition, which has almost a third of its 145 staff in the US, added that it had seen a delay in purchases of its software by clients attempting to conserve cash.

"Recognition Systems' recent expansion in the UK, Australia and the Far East has progressed over the past 18 months but growth from these regions is unlikely to be sufficient to offset the current slowdown in the US market," the company said.

Analysts now expect revenues for the full year to be around £13m instead of the anticipated £19m.

The company emphasised that revenue for the six months to the end of March was expected to be in line with market expectations of £6.5m. Martin Andrews, the finance director, said job losses were not being considered at the moment.

"We are looking at the cost base very, very hard, but people are an important resource and we don't intend to cut back on our people," Mr Andrews said.

The company, which floated in 1996 to raise money for expansion into the US, was due to break even by 2001, but said another loss was now likely. Cuts are planned in pre-sales and advertising costs. According to Mr Andrews, the company has enough cash to trade through the bear market. He would not comment on how much money the company has left or how long it was likely to last. Recognition Systems had £13m in the bank in September 2000.

 Gameplay yesterday said it has been holding "informal discussions" with unnamed companies about its future.

In February the online games retailer dismissed a third of its staff, shut its UK stores and split the group into two operating units - boxed games and technology - in a restructuring to push it to profitability. It has appointed Commerzbank Securities to help review options.

The board expressed the belief that the current market valuation "does not reflect the true underlying performance or potential of Gameplay".

The shares - which have underperformed the FTSE 100 by 88% in the past six months - fell 7p to 17p.

webTitle: AEA in talks with potential buyers

fields.headline: AEA in talks with potential buyers
fields.trailText: AEA Technology, the last business to be privatised by the Conservatives, is in talks with potential buyers after falling on hard times.
fields.body:
AEA Technology, the last business to be privatised by the Conservatives, is in talks with potential buyers after falling on hard times.

Shares in the former commercial arm of the atomic energy authority rose 30% but the company was still valued at less than a fifth of the £1bn capitalisation it had at its peak.

AEA, which came to the market in September 1996, said it had received "preliminary expressions of interest both for certain of the group's businesses and for the company itself".

It warned that there was no certainty of a sale and declined to say with whom it is talking. The City believes it is negoti ating with venture capital companies and trade buyers.

AEA announced plans to sell its nuclear engineering and consultancy businesses and concentrate on rail and environment in October when it issued its first profit warning.

In February AEA said it would speed up this disposal programme after admitting its full-year results to March 31 would be "significantly below current market estimates".

Management blamed a downturn in orders from state-owned British Nuclear Fuels and a slowdown in software engineering deals for much of the problem.

But the City believes some of the pain was self-inflicted, notably through cost overruns and difficulties at recently ac quired environmental company ERG. Some analysts say the famed science research centre at Harwell could be under threat if AEA pulls out.

At the halfway stage the company announced pretax profits of £2.7m, down from £8.9m. Operating profits fell from £11.8m to £1.4m while sales remained almost static at £171.9m.

Chief executive Peter Watson tried to inject new life into the company through the appointment of Stephen Thornton from BOC as chief operating officer.

AEA said yesterday it was still committed to providing shareholder value through delivering its sell-off strategy. It is in final negotiations with an unknown bidder to dispose of its nuclear engineering activities.

Charles Pick, analyst with Prudential-Bach, said the publicity surrounding the takeover talks could flush out more buyers. "This promises to bring a welcome exit route for many investors."

Mr Pick said the businesses AEA would most want to retain were likely to be the ones that would interest other buyers. Engineering and consultancy firm WS Atkins and business services group Serco typified potential buyers for AEA's rail operation.

But there is a feeling that only venture capital companies would want to take on the risks associated with the whole group, especially unwinding nuclear assets.

fields.headline: This is a lottery that rewards failure
fields.standfirst: Corus provides pay-off contrast
fields.trailText: "The Company's policy on executive remuneration," intones the annual report of Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, "is geared to attracting, retaining and motivating individuals of the appropriate calibre and with the necessary skills to manage and develop the Company successfully in each of the countries where the Group has activities."
fields.body:
"The Company's policy on executive remuneration," intones the annual report of Corus, the Anglo-Dutch steel group, "is geared to attracting, retaining and motivating individuals of the appropriate calibre and with the necessary skills to manage and develop the Company successfully in each of the countries where the Group has activities."

Well, it may - questionably - be now, but it certainly was not last year. Together John Bryant and Fokko van Duyne, who "resigned" as co-chief exec utives on December 5, pocketed more than £2m between them in pay-offs. This pair of high-calibre executives, who each earned around£500,000 a year, drove Corus into losses of more than £1bn and the pay-offs are their reward.

On top of that Mr Bryant, a lifelong steelman, can sit back in his Welsh home enjoying a £206,319 annual pension - the stuff of lottery dreams for his 3m fellow citizens, especially the more than 4,000 Welsh steelworkers facing the chop with pay-offs of a maximum £25,000 after years of surpassing productivity targets.

This is not to impugn the honour of Messrs Bryant and van Duyne who were effectively sacked for keeping plants open and jobs safe while Corus's losses - caused by the strong pound and weak British demand - spiralled out of control. But it is to damn a remuneration system across British industry that continues to reward executive failure extravagantly and offers a few shekels to loyal, dedicated employees.

Such grotesque anomalies won't figure in New Labour's business-friendly election campaign. Even the main and ultra-moderate steel union, the ISTC, is keeping mum as it tries to wrest a figleaf of concessions from Corus over its restructuring plans.

At least some lottery money goes to good causes; this system is simply chucking shareholder funds and employees' added value at incompetents.

Fail safe

On the subject of rewards for failure, the bonus deal secured by Luc Vandevelde at Marks & Spencer has all the characteristics of a particularly fine example. Mr Vandevelde is in line for a £650,000 performance bonus this year, for meeting some unknown "strategic and qualitative targets".

Let us not dwell on whether such targets should be kept secret from shareholders. But what could they be? Delivering clothes nobody wants to wear? Rolling out concept stores which backfire badly? Highlighting the importance of internationalism to the 21st century retailer only to close down - belatedly - all M&S's overseas adventures? Or maybe it is simpler: grossly underperforming the competition?

Mr Vandevelde has a very lucrative contract with M&S, including a share deal that could generate more than £10m in three years if he manages to turn the company around. If he can wave his magic wand, no shareholder, employee or even customer is likely to begrudge him his Midas moment.

The £650,000 payment was part of his signing-on deal and it is unlikely Marks & Spencer will be able to abandon it without his agreement. Shareholders would then be perfectly entitled to object loudly. As a gesture of his commitment and goodwill he should announce that he will not accept it - or at least delay it for another 12 months.

Money matters

Reuters' website boasts that the company has spent 150 years providing financial information, with an unrivalled reputation for "speed, accuracy, integrity and impartiality".

That superlative service does not extend to providing investors with a decent reason for pressing ahead with the £2bn flotation of a hi-tech subsidiary in the middle of a slow-motion stockmarket crash.

Analysts were left spluttering with disbelief yesterday as Reuters refused to budge on its plans to spin-off Instinet, its online broking service. Reuters seems to be oblivious to the fact that dealing screens have remained resolutely red for almost a month.

Charitable observers came up with a few possible reasons - one pointed out that Instinet needed an injection of funds to pay for a diversification of its services away from pure equities. More fancifully, another wondered whether Reuters was planning to use Instinet shares as a currency for acquisitions - could a bid for the London Stock Exchange be in the offing?

Reuters' communication skills were resolutely lacking. A spokesman declared that the amount raised in the offering was not important, because the move was "strategic" rather than "a device to raise money".

When asked what the strategic rationale was, he replied: "To realise value for shareholders." Clearly nothing to do with money, then.

webTitle: German gnomes put out to grass

fields.headline: German gnomes put out to grass
fields.trailText: The chill winds of low-cost competition have blown over one of Germany's most emblematic firms.
fields.body:
The chill winds of low-cost competition have blown over one of Germany's most emblematic firms.

Rot-Ceramic, purveyors of top-quality garden gnomes to the Teutonic lower middle classes for more than a century, has filed for bankruptcy - the victim, according to its owner, of an influx of cut-price gnomes from eastern Europe.

The family company's demise not only strikes a blow at the core of Germany's national identity, but also gives a sample of what many Germans fear could lie ahead when the European Union extends its borders eastwards.

Made from plastic with cheap labour, Polish and Czech gnomes sell for almost a third of the price of their German ceramic cousins. Conscious of their price advantage, eastern merchants have for several years taken to lining frontier roads with their wares to tempt German visitors. In 1998, there were even reports that rogue gnome dealers were paying gangs to raid gardens across the border in Germany and smash or steal the gnomes to boost sales.

German manufacturers and officials have done everything possible to stem the tide of alien garden ornaments. Border posts in the east were issued with a book containing the portraits of all Germany's native gnomes so customs officials could identify and tax unwanted 'immigrants'.

More than mere lucre was - and is - at stake. According to Günther Griebel, "The garden gnome mirrors the very depths of the German soul."

His father founded Rot-Ceramic in 1957 after fleeing into west Germany from the communist east and moving to the town of Rot-am-See in the south of the country. At its earlier base at Gräfenroda in Thuringia, however, the Griebel family had been manufacturing ceramics since 1874.

Thuringia is the spiritual home of the gnome cult which first took root around 1900. But it was not until after the second world war that the idea of owning a model of a little man in a pointy red cap became a national obsession.

"People took refuge in trivia after 1945. The intellectuals had their coffee tables. Ordinary folk had gnomes," said Mr Griebel. In the late 1980s a court ruling banned gnomes from communally owned gardens to avert disputes. His firm produced a model which can be seen as oddly prophetic.

It was called "Neighbour's Victim" - it had a knife sticking out of its back.

fields.headline: Investors cast off Kewill
fields.trailText: Investors in supply chain software specialist Kewill Systems were heading for the exit yesterday as market chatter of an imminent profit warning was taken seriously by company watchers.
fields.body:
Investors in supply chain software specialist Kewill Systems were heading for the exit yesterday as market chatter of an imminent profit warning was taken seriously by company watchers.

Kewill shares, at £27.30 a year ago, closed a session of heavy trading 29p lower at 105p.

Guy Feld, an analyst at Teather & Greenwood who cut his rating to "hold", said the rumours were likely to be well founded, given evidence from other parts of the sector. Overnight, US rival Ariba announced plans to cut a third of its staff as it said second-quarter revenue would be lower than anticipated. This followed a similar warning from i2 Technologies, another software rival.

Mr Feld says the warnings point to a sharpening US slowdown in the market for efficiency enhancing software.

Kewill is due to issue a trading statement in the next two weeks.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: • Farewell Dan Thompson, chief executive of 365 Corporation, who announced that he was stepping down to spend more time with his money. One group that may not be sorry to see him go is the investors whose shares have fallen from more than £2 a year ago to 20p now.
fields.body:
 Farewell Dan Thompson, chief executive of 365 Corporation, who announced that he was stepping down to spend more time with his money. One group that may not be sorry to see him go is the investors whose shares have fallen from more than £2 a year ago to 20p now.

Then 365 was one of the first of the dot.com companies to float in London, guided to the market by trustworthy and reliable bankers at Durlacher, and so has ridden both ends of the dot.com rollercoaster. The really remarkable thing about 365 was how it managed to convince investors that it was a dot.com - it now meaninglessly styles itself a "digital media company" - even though most of its staff, turnover and profits came from its humdrum leased telecoms operation. Within that the big profits came from "adult" chat lines, of the sort advertised on late night television. Since then the company has squandered plenty of cash buying fashionable websites - despite the adult operations being the only part making a decent profit.

 Speaking of adult activities, and though there's enough porn on the internet as it is, an extraordinary new smutty website has come to my attention. "After tiring of the frustrated sighs of co-workers that adore Alastair Campbell," it reads, "I have set up this website out of a sense of civil responsibility, to help ease your pain." Readers are invited to send in pictures and sightings of the PM's spokesman. "He runs five miles at a time and according to my sources is 'stunning when dripping with sweat'," the site gushes. See it yourself at www.sexyalastair.co.uk.

 Signs that the apocalypse is upon us (part 72): the Financial Times reported yesterday that a new brand of bottled water is to go on sale here. Unexceptional, you might think, except that Voss (Norwegian for waterfall) will cost £2.50 for 375ml (that's not much larger than a can of Coke). Even the FT was moved to describe the price for unadulterated water as "insanely expensive".

 The heart always leaps when a press release arrives, especially when it's from one of Britain's many excellent rail companies. "Prime minister enjoys punctual journey with Anglia Railways today between London and Colchester," read one from Anglia on Monday. So I ring to ask the inevitable question. "No, we don't put out a press release every time a train runs on time," says weary press officer Jonathan Denby. "We get fed up with people writing scurrilous stories about trains being late that are completely made up. That was the only reason we put this press release out." Thank you, and keep up the good work.

 One wonders if Marks & Spencer has done the wisest thing in closing its outlets in France. Not only is the French government puffing about the legitimacy of the closures, but at M&S's store in Chailly-en-Bière, near Fontainebleau, there are two condolence books outside the entrance - and after two days the books were almost full, with a long queue of shoppers waiting to write their comments. "Remember Dunkirk," was one, along with a more pointed "Non la politique de Tony Blair". The staff first heard they were losing their jobs over the radio. Charming.

webTitle: At this price?  Fusion Oil & Gas

fields.headline: At this price?  Fusion Oil & Gas
fields.trailText: The western coast of Africa is one of the hottest spots in the global oil industry with BP, Shell and other majors making large discoveries in deep water off Angola, Congo and Nigeria.
fields.body:
The western coast of Africa is one of the hottest spots in the global oil industry with BP, Shell and other majors making large discoveries in deep water off Angola, Congo and Nigeria.

Drilling that starts off in Mauritania this Friday could decide whether that bonanza extends further north.

Fusion Oil & Gas, a tiny company brought to the Alternative Investment Market in September, has a 6% stake in two wells to be drilled by Woodside Petroleum, the Australian group that is at present the target of a hostile takeover by Royal Dutch Shell. Italy's ENI group is also involved through its Agip subsidiary.

Alan Stein, the managing director of Fusion, is bullish about prospects for Mauritania, hinting that seismic surveys of the area have been promising.

Certainly some of the value given to another independent, British-Borneo, when it was taken over by ENI was attributed to its foothold in north-west Africa.

If Mauritania is successful it would have a knock-on effect on other countries in the region, such as Ghana, which have been licensing their deep water tracts .

Fusion will soon start drilling in Ghana and has acreage on the median line between Senegal and Guinea-Bissau. Some £3.4m is to be spent on exploration this year.

Yesterday Fusion reported an after-tax loss of £179,000, but that is of little importance compared to the £15m it has in the bank from the flotation.

Shareholders so far have had a mixed ride. Following initial success after the 50p float, the shares dipped to half that price by January as seed corn investors who came in at 5p bailed out and institutions failed to become involved.

Drilling that starts off in Mauritania this Friday could decide whether that bonanza extends further north. Fusion Oil & Gas, a tiny company brought to the Alternative Investment Market in September, has a 6% stake in two wells to be drilled by Woodside Petroleum, the Australian group that is at present the target of a hostile takeover by Royal Dutch Shell. Italy's ENI group is also involved through its Agip subsidiary. webTitle: A huge survey of the Victorian era

fields.headline: The way we weren't
fields.standfirst: A huge survey of the Victorian era
fields.trailText: A huge survey of the Victorian era.
fields.body:
What do we think of that tribe, the Victorians? They don't like sex; they're sentimental, hypocritical and obsessed with religion. Their women simper, their menfolk are domineering and pompous. They bully and starve their working classes into submission. They love money and they're immensely proud of themselves and their achievements. Thank God they've gone.

There's another view: they're never satisfied, always tinkering with new ways of living - if it's not Marxism, it's free love and atheism. The workers are always organising some rally or strike; their womenfolk are out and about dispensing charity. And they're all dreadful worriers - constantly questioning the type of society they have brought into being. If only we could be a bit more like them.

The V&A's new blockbuster, Inventing New Britain: the Victorian Vision, reflects both these views. Consensus there will never be on the Victorians, and why should there be, on what was 64 years of tumultuous change?

The exhibition is the museum's response to the centenary of the death of Victoria; and perhaps it is deference to its founders that has led the V&A to place - misplace - so much emphasis on the royal family. There are five sections to the show - Society, Nature, World and Technology - but the first is Royalty. This expresses the idea that the century's "progress" flowed from its royal family, but the available evidence shows that the reverse was true.

In fact, the more interesting story is the effort made by Victoria and her husband to ingratiate themselves with their people. A huge PR campaign had to swing into operation to promote the royals as a dynamic, close-knit young family, thoroughly in tune with the nation. Albert had brought over from Saxe-Coburg, on his marriage in 1840, the much-loathed figure of Baron Stockmar - openly pilloried in the press for being a foreign influence. It was widely believed that the royal couple spoke only German in private; fashionable society deplored the dullness of court life. As late as 1887 there were anti-monarchist riots. But Victoria has been made pivotal to this show though she was in fact tangential. No amount of cult of personality will make it otherwise.

Still, the show has its strong points. Certain objects lodge in the mind. There are Indian emeralds; the world's first machine gun; a "naïve" Yoruba wood carving of Victoria; a vile silver dinner-table ornament designed by Albert to celebrate his dogs; and the so-called Empire typewriter.

It is worth a visit for the paintings alone. Frith's three panoramas, Derby Day, The Railway Station and Ramsgate Sands, hang together for the first time, while George Clausen's The Stonebreakers gives a picture of rural poverty following the collapse of farming in the 1870s. In the World section, The Secret of England's Greatness (1863) by Thomas Jones Barker depicts Victoria handing one of her loyal subjects a Bible. This section is strangely depoliticised, conflating the empire's plunder and tribute with objects freely traded with such countries as Japan and the South American states. John Bell's Octoroon (1854) is a statue in marble of a woman garlanded by chains and her own long hair, with breasts and buttocks peeping out to titillate the viewer. The curators miss the opportunity to take apart Victorian racism: what type of mind would set itself to naming a human who had one-eighth negro blood?

This is an exhibition built around the obsessions of our own age. So we're told when the first football international was played (1872); when women could study at London University (1846); the launch date of the News of the World (1843); when sodomy ceased to be a capital offence (1861 - though no one had actually been hanged for it since the early 1830s). There is little on the cataclysmic, but to us deadly dull, divisions within the Anglican church, which tore the Victorians' world apart. A glance at any Hansard of the century will show the vast amount of parliamentary time taken up by debating, in tedious detail, rates and land ownership issues in Ireland. But do we care? The "Woman Question" of the late 19th century is sexy. The ceaseless (often successful) campaigning of the Quakers on humanitarian issues is not.

You long for some low art, a voice from the gutter. There is now a body of items reflecting organised labour and other working-class institutions, and it would be good to see a major exhibition covering that. You sometimes feel that the "multiplicity" of this show is simply people at the same dinner party in 1870 drunkenly debating the issues of the day.

 Inventing New Britain: the Victorian Vision is at the Victoria and Albert Museum, London SW7 (020-7942 2000), until July 29.

fields.headline: The empire strikes back
fields.standfirst: Culture secretary Chris Smith has just told the V&A to get its act together. Now it faces its first test, with the opening of two new exhibitions.  Sarah Wise checks out BB Turner's landscape photographs
fields.trailText: Culture secretary Chris Smith has just told the V&A to get its act together. Now it faces its first test, with the opening of two new exhibitions. Sarah Wise checks out BB Turner's landscape photographs.
fields.body:
The countryside is in crisis and farming is on its knees. Prices for produce are being driven ever lower. Local shops are disappearing as farmers sell up and agricultural workers move to the town in search of a better living. Those who stay are relying on money from the public purse to augment their wage. Church congregations are falling. No one can see a way out of this decline.

It is the 1840s, and it's the 1820s. It is also the 1750s, and many other points in history as far back as you care to go. The countryside has a past as chequered with change as any town or industrial area. But the idea of the country as a place of stability and continuity is the one constant thing about it, and one of its most ardent believers was one Benjamin Brecknell Turner (1815-1894) - businessman and townie incarnate, who lived most of his life in the Haymarket, central London.

Turner's lucrative soap- and candle-manufacturing firm gave him the money to buy a licence to use one of Henry Fox Talbot's photographic cameras; and he had the time to travel around England by means of another new invention, the railways. The astonishing results of Turner's country excursions are now on display at the Victoria and Albert Museum - 60 photographs taken between 1852 and 1854 of English rural life, ruined abbeys and castles and tottering Tudor buildings. The large (11in by 16in) paper prints feature barns, cottages, rutted lanes, hedgerows, knotty, sculptural trees and farmyards artfully strewn with agricultural paraphernalia, and in none of them does the 19th century intrude. Carts, ploughs, barrels, fences, ladders are all ruggedly hand-crafted, with no smooth edge of machine-manufacture in sight. So the barbed wire in the picture Scotch Firs, Hawkhurst, comes as a surprise. It's a shot that captures textures so brilliantly your hands prickle with imaginary splinters from the firs' bark or the unvarnished palings in the foreground. Turner's loyalty to paper negatives, as most other early practitioners went over to glass negatives, helped to enhance the textural qualities he was exploring: the image seeped into the paper, instead of sitting on top of a hard surface.

By excluding the present, Turner was presenting a vision of eternal England; but his work is much more than some crass attempt at oaks'n'yokels nationalism. They are also worlds away from the revolting mawkishness of many early photographic efforts at pastoral - winsome wives and children dressed as gypsies and posed in a sylvan setting. One third of his album Photographic Views From Nature (the single copy is held by the V&A) features the Worcestershire village of Bredicot, and its quietly crumbling wattle-and-daub, clapboard and thatch buildings seem to be dozing their way through an eternal summer afternoon.

This no-time, all-time quality of Turner's work derives partly from the near absence of shadows - a result of the paper negative's inability to render half-tones as well as the rival glass process. The utter stillness of this world reflects the windless conditions required in an age when exposure times were 30 minutes to one hour (and Turner had to spend the same amount of time developing the image on the spot in his portable tent-darkroom). There is never any indi cation of what time of day or atmospheric conditions each shot shows: the bleached-out skies were another feature of choosing paper over glass, but there is evidence that Turner manipulated the negative to block out features from his skies to ensure vast empty heavens. And where is everybody? It's like coming upon an abandoned village, with the objects that were left behind caught on the point of returning to the materials from which they were crafted by fleeting, disruptive humankind.

Always out of shot in the Bredicot pictures is the railway, which passed right behind one of his favourite subjects, Bredicot Court, from 1840, pumping steam across its farmyard; and there is no reference whatever to the massive structural changes brought by the enclosure of local farmlands in 1846. Organic change was Turner's true subject - he captured the secret life of inanimate things. His shots of Ludlow Castle show ivy engulfing the ruins; at Whitby Abbey, the stones of the collapsed tower are returning to earth from where man dragged them.

Barns appear to emerge from the straw surrounding them; stone houses from the boulders at their base, rocks from the river water swirling around them - this was a time when moving water could not be captured on camera, and Turner's shots at Lyndale, north Devon, show the river as a treacly mass, caught halfway to solidifying into rock. Vegetation is triumphant in Hedgerow Trees, Clerkenleap, Worcestershire, the only Photographic View to feature a human - a listless-looking figure slumped alongside two savagely pollarded oaks whose new shoots are erupting like hands raised in victory.

It is a shock to see Francis Frith's cheesy, later-19th-century shots of Stonehenge, Devon beaches, Italian towns and various points around the globe robbed of flavour and served up to the armchair tourist. Frith's photographs mark the start of the companion exhibition Where Are We?, in which curator Martin Barnes follows through the 20th-century issues Turner's pictures raise in the minds of the modern viewer. Where Are We? encompass American work, but its Visions of Britain section asks: whose countryside is it? What type of Briton is welcome there? Is tourism the saviour or ruin of rural areas? Vinca Peterson's new age travellers - the focus of so much early 1990s hubbub as fields were appropriated for raves - are captured in lurid laserjet prints. Ingrid Pollard's series explores the invisibility of non-white Britons in the countryside; what role do quiet hamlets, portrayed and portraying themselves as the quintessence of Englishness, have in breeding intolerance? When will black faces cease to be presumed urban?

In Keith Arnatt's black and white Scenes from an Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty (1982-84) a mouldering camper-van, bits of old carpet and various unsavoury items litter the foreground, while beyond, the Wye Valley broods on in misty beauty. Arnatt's work isn't nearly as misanthropic as such a description suggests, and has a wistful humour that's also there in Paul Graham's Looking North (1981), an across-the-fields shot of the A1 of his childhood - pylons, factory chimney, the motorway cafe and petrol station glowing comfortingly in the gloaming.

The people of Bredicot cannot accept Martin Barnes's invitation to a private view of the Turner exhibition. Foot-and-mouth means they may not leave the area. The countryside is in crisis.

 Rural England through a Victorian Lens and Where Are We? are at the Canon Photography Gallery, Victoria and Albert Museum, London SW7 (020-7942 2000), until August 27.

webTitle: Akram Khan's fusion of eastern and western dance

fields.headline: All the right moves
fields.standfirst: Akram Khan infuriates the traditionalists with his mix of eastern and western dance.  Judith Mackrell thinks he's found a perfect balance
fields.trailText: Akram Khan infuriates the traditionalists with his mix of eastern and western dance. Judith Mackrell thinks he's found a perfect balance.
fields.body:
Akram Khan is widely regarded as one of the most original and charismatic artists to arrive on the UK dance scene in ages, and has a slew of awards to prove it. The only problem with this 26-year-old prodigy is that no one quite knows how to define him. While he is prized within the South Asian dance community as a leading exponent of Kathak (the classical style of north India), he's also claimed by the modern dance world as one of its most interesting new choreographers. As for audiences, they can rarely be sure whether Khan's shows will feature pure Indian classicism or experimental choreography with a tough urban edge.

Yet Khan never deliberately chose to be a maverick nor even specifically to be a dancer. He grew up as an ordinary kid in Balham, London, and his career kind of happened along the way. It was his mother who prompted Khan to attend his first dance class at the age of seven. She had been passionate about dance while she was growing up in Bangladesh but her father had disapproved, and she'd had to learn in secret. When she moved to London she was determined her own children shouldn't be similarly deprived, so Khan was sent to study with the great dancer and teacher Sri Pratap Pawar.

Looking back, Khan remembers that this was OK by him, but that he felt no fierce sense of vocation, complaining "when lessons stopped me from watching my favourite programmes on TV". He also seems to have been pretty casual about the first big professional break in his life, which was being cast for Peter Brook's production of Ma habharata at the age of 14. Khan had been talent-spotted by one of Brook's scouts and after auditioning "with loads of Rada boys" had been offered a year and a half's contract to tour the world.

But while the experience was "amazing", Khan wasn't remotely awed by Brook himself, who struck him as a somewhat "annoying old man" because he insisted on delivering all his stage corrections in a barely audible voice. "Every time he wanted to talk to you, you had to stop what you were doing and go right up to where he was sitting." Nor did Khan appreciate how many of his fellow actors were actually "gods of their profession. The adults were really kind to me but I used to laugh at the way they competed to become my mentor. They'd take me aside to give me private acting classes, and they all wanted to teach me different things because they came from all over the world and had different styles."

Khan may not have been star-struck by Brook but he was profoundly moved when, shortly after his return, Pratap Pawar invited him to become his disciple. This is a bond almost like father and son, which bestows on the disciple the rights to his guru's skills and artistic creations, while binding him to honour them in return. Pratap Pawar trained Khan to give his first solo recital at the Commonwealth Institute when he was 18, and in doing so nudged him inexorably towards a professional career.

His mother, ironically, was growing nervous at her son's success and tried to persuade him to get some kind of university qualification. Khan agreed but only so far as to sign up for a degree in dance studies. The course was based in modern dance, a genre of which Khan knew nothing, and he certainly felt himself an oddity. While he had more training and stage experience than most of his peers, his Kathak style kept interfering with his attempts to master the shapes and dynamics of western dance - to the irritation of his teachers. Similarly, his exposure to modern dance began to influence his Kathak dancing, to the considerable annoyance of his guru.

But Khan himself became curious about the conflict going on in his body: "I wanted to investigate what it was that was annoying other people and frustrating me." He started to explore how the percussive rhythms of Kathak's footwork, the virtuoso speed of its turns and the expressiveness of its gestures could be articulated differently through the more full-bodied action of modern styles. He started to understand how the logic of classicism could relate to the "chaos" of modern dance structure in which "a movement can take any route you choose between A and B". At the end of his final year (when he'd transferred to the Northern College of Contemporary Dance) he'd not only invented his own style, but graduated with the highest marks ever awarded there.

His examiners knew what they were doing. Khan is a big, graceful dancer who is capable of both arresting stillness and galvanic speed, and whether he's dancing classical or modern he holds the stage as if it were his personal domain. He can concentrate the air around him in a heroic freeze frame or thresh it into chaos with the ferocity of his spins and the drastic changes of his body's momentum. He plays with tension, tenderness and danger as if he were making up the story of his life on stage.

Since college, Khan's career has moved on a steep upward curve. He's toured several new works, choreographed a film for Channel 4, and been appointed choreographer in residence at the South Bank Centre. This autumn he presents a group piece to music by Magnus Lindberg in a programme involving the London Sinfonietta and artist Bill Viola.

At first his guru was "apprehensive" about Khan's apparent defection from tradition (although he's now "very supportive") and there have been other members of the South Asian community who continue to be critical of his modern tendencies. Like all groups living a long way from home, this small dance world clings fast to its own culture. Yet while Khan is reluctant to discuss his position within that community, he does comment that when he performed his contemporary work in India, classicists there were very enthusiastic: "They didn't see it as a betrayal of Kathak but as a new interpretation."

And even though modern dance has left its marks all over Khan's body, he still studies and performs Kathak, and his new solo show, Polaroid Feet, is very much in classical mode. Performing with a live ensemble of musicians, Khan will not only display the brilliance of his dancing, he will also flaunt the brilliance of his ear as he and the band launch into the flights of improvisation traditional to Kathak. Dancer and musicians bounce rhythms off each other, building up increasingly complex variations within basic metric cycles. It's a jousting of wills and nerve that produces vertiginous fun for the audience as well as the performers. It's jazz and The Weakest Link rolled into one.

As an artist, Khan says he will always return to Kathak as his base. "I need to keep picking the fruits of classicism," he says. As a disciple, he also sees it as his duty. "There are so few male Kathak soloists performing here. I don't want to see the dance dying out."

 Akram Khan is at the Purcell Room, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), from April 8-10.

He also seems to have been pretty casual about the first big professional break in his life, which was being cast for Peter Brook's production of Ma habharata at the age of 14. Khan had been talent-spotted by one of Brook's scouts and after auditioning "with loads of Rada boys" had been offered a year and a half's contract to tour the world. But while the experience was "amazing", Khan wasn't remotely awed by Brook himself, who struck him as a somewhat "annoying old man" because he insisted on delivering all his stage corrections in a barely audible voice. "Every time he wanted to talk to you, you had to stop what you were doing and go right up to where he was sitting." Nor did Khan appreciate how many of his fellow actors were actually "gods of their profession. The adults were really kind to me but I used to laugh at the way they competed to become my mentor. They'd take me aside to give me private acting classes, and they all wanted to teach me different things because they came from all over the world and had different styles." Khan may not have been star-struck by Brook but he was profoundly moved when, shortly after his return, Pratap Pawar invited him to become his disciple. This is a bond almost like father and son, which bestows on the disciple the rights to his guru's skills and artistic creations, while binding him to honour them in return. Pratap Pawar trained Khan to give his first solo recital at the Commonwealth Institute when he was 18, and in doing so nudged him inexorably towards a professional career. His mother, ironically, was growing nervous at her son's success and tried to persuade him to get some kind of university qualification. Khan agreed but only so far as to sign up for a degree in dance studies. The course was based in modern dance, a genre of which Khan knew nothing, and he certainly felt himself an oddity. While he had more training and stage experience than most of his peers, his Kathak style kept interfering with his attempts to master the shapes and dynamics of western dance - to the irritation of his teachers. Similarly, his exposure to modern dance began to influence his Kathak dancing, to the considerable annoyance of his guru. But Khan himself became curious about the conflict going on in his body: "I wanted to investigate what it was that was annoying other people and frustrating me." He started to explore how the percussive rhythms of Kathak's footwork, the virtuoso speed of its turns and the expressiveness of its gestures could be articulated differently through the more full-bodied action of modern styles. He started to understand how the logic of classicism could relate to the "chaos" of modern dance structure in which "a movement can take any route you choose between A and B". At the end of his final year (when he'd transferred to the Northern College of Contemporary Dance) he'd not only invented his own style, but graduated with the highest marks ever awarded there. His examiners knew what they were doing. Khan is a big, graceful dancer who is capable of both arresting stillness and galvanic speed, and whether he's dancing classical or modern he holds the stage as if it were his personal domain. He can concentrate the air around him in a heroic freeze frame or thresh it into chaos with the ferocity of his spins and the drastic changes of his body's momentum. He plays with tension, tenderness and danger as if he were making up the story of his life on stage. Since college, Khan's career has moved on a steep upward curve. He's toured several new works, choreographed a film for Channel 4, and been appointed choreographer in residence at the South Bank Centre. This autumn he presents a group piece to music by Magnus Lindberg in a programme involving the London Sinfonietta and artist Bill Viola. At first his guru was "apprehensive" about Khan's apparent defection from tradition (although he's now "very supportive") and there have been other members of the South Asian community who continue to be critical of his modern tendencies. Like all groups living a long way from home, this small dance world clings fast to its own culture. Yet while Khan is reluctant to discuss his position within that community, he does comment that when he performed his contemporary work in India, classicists there were very enthusiastic: "They didn't see it as a betrayal of Kathak but as a new interpretation." And even though modern dance has left its marks all over Khan's body, he still studies and performs Kathak, and his new solo show, Polaroid Feet, is very much in classical mode. Performing with a live ensemble of musicians, Khan will not only display the brilliance of his dancing, he will also flaunt the brilliance of his ear as he and the band launch into the flights of improvisation traditional to Kathak. Dancer and musicians bounce rhythms off each other, building up increasingly complex variations within basic metric cycles. It's a jousting of wills and nerve that produces vertiginous fun for the audience as well as the performers. It's jazz and The Weakest Link rolled into one. As an artist, Khan says he will always return to Kathak as his base. "I need to keep picking the fruits of classicism," he says. As a disciple, he also sees it as his duty. "There are so few male Kathak soloists performing here. I don't want to see the dance dying out."  Akram Khan is at the Purcell Room, London SE1 (020-7960 4242), from April 8-10.

webTitle: Annie Castledine: British theatre's unsung hero

fields.headline: The power behind the scenes
fields.standfirst: Lyn Gardner meets Annie Castledine, British theatre's unsung hero
fields.trailText: Lyn Gardner meets Annie Castledine, British theatre's unsung hero.
fields.body:
Annie Castledine is one of the arts world's best-known secrets. As a director she has a genius for doing work that is unfashionable - so much so that she once lost her job because of it - yet she has shaped some of the most influential players in British theatre. Over the past 15 years she has had a major role in the careers and productions of Stephen Daldry, Simon McBurney, Neil Bartlett and Kathryn Hunter, to name but a few.

Back in 1981, when the young Daldry landed the artistic directorship of the Gate, the first person he turned to was Castledine. Together they directed the Ingolstadt plays, which became Daldry's calling card in London and established him as a major player. In recent years McBurney's Theatre de Complicite has seldom opened a show before letting Castledine take a look at it. Then there are designers. An entire generation, including Ian McNeil, Rurai Murchison and Antony Ward, had their first big breaks with Castledine when she was artistic director of Derby Playhouse between 1987-90. Her brief reign has passed into legend, not least for her refusal to pander to the bums-on-seats marketing mantra that was sweeping the regional reps. "I hadn't realised regional rep was about money. I thought it was about encouraging the young and being radical," she says.

Castledine did what she has always done and produced work that she found interesting. "As much as anything, I direct for my own personal growth. I am driven by a curiosity to see what can and cannot be achieved," she says. She was one of the first to introduce a European aesthetic on a regional stage and outraged the local populace by casting a black actress as Amanda in a revival of Coward's Private Lives long before colour-blind casting was the norm. The local press was hostile and, perhaps not surpris ingly, it was Castledine's head that was demanded by the council as the price of underwriting the theatre's deficit.

That should have been the end of Castledine's brief but brilliant career. But losing Derby actually turned out to be the best thing that could have happened to her. Over the last 10 years, while the regional repertory system has gone into decline, Castledine has been involved in creating and developing an impressive body of work. She has been associate director with Complicite on The Winter's Tale and The Caucasian Chalk Circle and she has initiated such projects as Goliath, Bryony Lavery's soul-searching adaptation of Beatrix Campbell's book about life on Britain's sink estates. Her most recent project is a production of Bertolt Brecht's The Mother for London's BAC. With her typical flair for the contrary, this is a play set in a time when politics was a matter of life and death rather than spin-doctoring. As Castledine says: "When a play seems most inappropriate it is often the time to do it."

At 62, Castledine has become one of the most energising and dynamic talents in the business. She was always a late starter. The daughter of a Sheffield colliery engineer, she was brought up in a family where the only reason you got let off housework was if you were reading a book. She went to the local grammar school, where she was a bright but disruptive element until she was cast in the school play at the age of 13. She says that the experience socialised her, but since in those days girls of her background were only expected to become nurses or teachers, the idea of making theatre her life never crossed her mind.

It was only at 35, after many years of teaching, that Castledine turned to the theatre after going to York University as a mature student. There she spent most of her time directing plays and her talent was spotted by Michael Winter, the then director of the Theatre Royal, who offered her the chance to be his arts council trainee.

She has never looked back despite being "a self-educated, self-made person" who entered the profession at a time when most directors were still Oxbridge-educated men (a situation that has changed rather less than one might have predicted). When she was a student teacher at Goldsmiths, Honor Matthews, the head of drama, took the young Castledine under her wing, recognising in her something beyond "the raw barbarian down from the hills". Perhaps that is the key to all Castledine's work that combines an English working-class and feminist toughness tempered by a lyric, European sensibility. It explains so much why the love affair with Complicite has developed into an enduring marriage and why they have been so good for each other.

Castledine once described her greatest heroine as being Antigone, the great refusenik. It is an appropriate image for a woman who battles on, creating work she really cares about and who is so seldom feted or rewarded and has sometimes been completely ignored. She has no regrets. "Theatre has been very good to me. It has been an embrace, it has supported me and allowed me to do the work I've really wanted to do. I am not really an Antigone. I really wouldn't have the courage. You know, Brecht wrote a poem about Antigone. It ends: 'And over their atrocities there grew no grass.' That's beautiful, but no, I'd never have the courage. The cost is just too high."

 The Mother is at BAC, London SW11 (020-7223 2223), until April 22.

webTitle: Coach driver jailed for six years after tourist deaths

fields.headline: Coach driver jailed for six years after tourist deaths
fields.trailText: A South African magistrate yesterday sentenced a coach driver responsible for the deaths of 27 British tourists and their local guide to six years in prison after rejecting the prosecution's call for a suspended sentence.
fields.body:
A South African magistrate yesterday sentenced a coach driver responsible for the deaths of 27 British tourists and their local guide to six years in prison after rejecting the prosecution's call for a suspended sentence.

The magistrate told the driver, Titus Dube, that survivors and relatives of the victims of the accident in 1999 were "probably crying out for vengeance and justice" after his coach careered off a winding mountain road near Lydenburg.

Dries Lamprecht added that a harsh punishment was required in part because relations between South Africa and Britain could be affected if outrage in the UK after the crash was not taken into account. Most of the dead were British pensioners.

"The degree of your negligence is so great that this cannot be dismissed with a slap on the wrists," said Mr Lamprecht in delivering a three hour judgment. "You unlawfully killed not one but 28 people and seriously injured eight others in the same process. One of them is still in a coma and the chances of recovery are slim.

"I think that a sentence that is too lenient will ignore the demand for vengeance and do an injustice to society both locally and abroad."

Dube, 41, was banned from driving for six years. The magistrate granted the driver leave to appeal and released him on bail. Dube pleaded guilty in February to culpable homicide. On Monday he told the court that he mistakenly put his foot on the accelerator instead of the brake as the bus ran out of control. The vehicle was travelling at more than 70mph, twice the speed limit, when it left the road.

Mr Lamprecht also blamed what he said was the poor design of the bus for the high number of fatalities.

webTitle: MEPs vote for EU ban on sale of cosmetics tested on animals

fields.headline: MEPs vote for EU ban on sale of cosmetics tested on animals
fields.trailText: The global cosmetics industry suffered a big setback yesterday when the European parliament voted to ban within five years the sale of all products tested on animals throughout the EU.
fields.body:
The global cosmetics industry suffered a big setback yesterday when the European parliament voted to ban within five years the sale of all products tested on animals throughout the EU.

Although the practice of testing cosmetics and their ingredients on animals has been outlawed in Britain since 1998, it is legal to sell beauty and hygiene products that have been tested on animals elsewhere.

Around 38,000 animals are used and killed in developing cosmetics in the EU every year. But MEPs believe that inflicting cruel tests on animals in the name of vanity can no longer be justified.

Although the decision will need to be approved by EU governments, MEPs say they will try to force the measure through if they meet any opposition.

Labour's spokesman on consumer affairs, Phillip Whitehead, hailed yesterday's vote as a significant victory for anyone who supported animal rights. "Cosmetics giants like Procter and Gamble, L'Oreal and Estee Lauder will only prioritise alternative testing methods if we take their products off the market," he said.

The Netherlands and Austria have a similar testing ban to that of Britain. Much of Europe's testing is carried out in France, Italy and Belgium.

However, many of the tests are carried out to comply with EU regulations. The most common involve dripping a new ingredient into a rabbit's eye or applying it to the shaved back of a rabbit or guinea pig. Some toothpaste manufacturers force feed sweets to monkeys to study tooth decay.

Anti-vivisectionists point to other tests that can often be carried out, such as microbiological analyses using computer modelling, in vitro testing and controlled testing on human volunteers.

The animal welfare lobby Eurogroup expressed its delight at yesterday's vote. "The European public have expressed their strong feelings against animal testing for cosmetics," said David Wilkins, its director. "Members of the parliament have once again acknowledged their concerns."

But the European commission, which last year watered down new animal testing laws to allow manufacturers to continue selling animal-tested cosmetics in the EU, warned that the vote could spark a transatlantic trade war. A marketing ban "would very likely run counter to our obligations in the World Trade Organisation", said a spokesman, Per Haugaard.

fields.headline: Women lured by neo-Nazi nationalism
fields.standfirst: The male-dominated, skinhead image of the German far right is rapidly changing with an influx of female recruits
fields.trailText: Women from all walks of life now make up a third of the membership of some far right groups in Germany as neo-Nazi organisations attempt to cement their power base, shed their male-dominated image, boost their social acceptance and move out of the extremes into the mainstream.
fields.body:
Women from all walks of life now make up a third of the membership of some far right groups in Germany as neo-Nazi organisations attempt to cement their power base, shed their male-dominated image, boost their social acceptance and move out of the extremes into the mainstream.

Statistics from a number of states indicate an explosion in female membership across the country as well as an increase in women-only groups, or Kameradschaften, such as the Free Girls' Union and Union of Homeland Loyalists, which aim to promote "pure Germany" and campaign against multiculturalism.

The Thuringian branch of the BVD, Germany's security service, which monitors far right groups, said that in less than a year the proportion of women in far-right groups in the eastern state had risen from 20% to 30%. Lower Saxony and Hessen reported figures of 20% - with 30% in Kameradschaften - and in Bavaria numbers have increased by two-thirds to 16% in just two years.

"It appears that women are increasingly finding emancipation in the scene and taking advantage of this," said Rüdiger Hesse, spokesman for the BVD branch in Lower Saxony. "They are lured by the modern packaging of hatred towards foreigners."

The government has so far taken little interest in the rise of far-right women because they are rarely involved in the increasing number of violent attacks on foreigners. But the nationwide participation of females in far-right crime has increased from 4% in 1996 to 6% last year.

Under Hitler, women were called to support the Nazi cause by staying at home and producing children under the slogan Heim und Herd (home and hearth).

Now, in an attempt to attract young modern women, the Young National Democrats (JN), the youth wing of the German nationalist party (NPD) which is represented in parliament, has sought to turn the traditional approach on its head, recently coining the phrase: "Nationalism is also a girl's concern." It reports a "significant increase" in interest as a result.

This week a documentary by Süddeutsche TV outlined for the first time the cult status the so-called "skingirl" scene has taken on. The programme visited Ehrenhausen in western Germany where 18% of people vote for far-right parties, and where Doris Zutt runs Patriotentreff - Patriots' Haunt - one of 50 similar fashion boutiques in Germany where modern skingirls can get kitted out.

On sale were cropped T-shirts bearing the slogans "White Power" and "My Boyfriend is German". To complete the image, perfumes with names such as Nationalist - "the spicy fragrance of the great Reich" - were on prominent display.

Very few women hold top positions in far-right groups, but as they gain importance behind the scene - organising events, promoting via the internet, distributing leaflets, and taking on the all-important role of child-rearers - there are signs that those days are not far off.

Rainer Fromm, one of the producers of the documentary, said the women in the far right were not all from underprivileged backgrounds. "They are lawyers, nurses, librarians and pianists, from working class and middle class backgrounds, broken and stable homes."

The largest growth in interest was among 15- to 25-year-olds, he added.

One of the new breed is 22-year-old Melanie from Dorsten, north of Essen, who since joining the NJ six years ago has earned a reputation as one of the movers and shakers of the far right. She finances a luxury apartment by writing articles for far-right publications, organising neo-Nazi events and building a "no to multiculturalism" website.

With her short brown hair and ironed blue jeans, she admits she does not fit the skinhead mould. "The question of protecting nationality is also an issue for women, and I want to have a role in that, and for that I can dress as I like," she said.

Her rejection of anything non-German is such that she never drinks Coca-Cola, visits McDonald's or eats doner kebabs.

Melanie marks what observers have identified as a dangerous shift in the far right. "These women are strengthening the scene," said Robert Bihler, spokesman for the BVD in Bavaria. "They make it more attractive to other women and men, and far more mainstream."

Renate Bitzan, a political analyst from the University of Göttingen and one of a handful of German academics to have taken a close look at the new phenomenon, said a variety of reasons attracted women to the scene.

"Some have close emotional ties to their grandparents and want to internalise the Nazi-era experience they had; often others have been sexually abused, and projecting their hatred on to foreign men in particular is a way of offloading this trauma, and for others, if they're white and German, they have an ideology and a group into which they can comfortably fit without trying very hard."

In the past, women have followed boyfriends and husbands into far-right groups, but the recruitment trend has since changed considerably, said Dr Bitzan. "They enter the groups through girlfriends or purely out of personal conviction, and they find a scene which allows them to express themselves."

"They enter the groups through girlfriends or purely out of personal conviction, and they find a scene which allows them to express themselves."

webTitle: Mona Lisa to get a room of her own

fields.headline: Mona Lisa to get a room of her own
fields.trailText: The Mona Lisa was moved to temporary lodgings yesterday as work started on a room of her own that will allow a few more of the Louvre's 6m visitors a year to see her.
fields.body:
The Mona Lisa was moved to temporary lodgings yesterday as work started on a room of her own that will allow a few more of the Louvre's 6m visitors a year to see her.

From today, the world's best-known painting will be displayed in the museum's Rosa gallery while workmen divide her overcrowded former home, the Salle d'Etats, in two to create a special 200 sq metre Mona Lisa room.

The £2.5m revamp, which is designed by the architect Lorenzo Piqueras and funded by Nippon Television of Japan in the largest corporate gift ever made in France for a cultural project, should be finished by 2003.

Over the past 500 years, Leonardo da Vinci's enigmatic masterpiece has survived moves between various French kings' palaces and, more recently, voyages to America and Japan in the 20th century. She even went missing for two years in 1911, when a patriotic Italian tried to smuggle her back to her native land.

But her latest trip - just down the corridor - will be a big relief to all those who have left the Salle d'Etats disap pointed and frustrated after being unable to catch more than a distant glimpse of the painting over the milling throng of tourists.

The Louvre has ruled out taking advantage of the move to restore the work, rejecting the arguments of several international art historians who say the many yellowed layers of varnish applied over the centuries prevent viewers seeing the Mona Lisa as Da Vinci intended when he completed the painting in 1506.

Jean-Pierre Cuzin, the museum's chief curator of paintings, said restoration would be technically feasible but was unnecessary and could do irreparable damage.

"In any case, she isn't as yellowed as all that," he said. "Once she's in her new room and properly lit, you'll see a different painting."

webTitle: Leaders united to get Robinson to stay

fields.headline: Leaders united to get Robinson to stay
fields.trailText: The UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, yesterday confirmed that Mary Robinson had reversed her decision to resign as the organisation's human rights chief and that she would stay on in the job for an extra 12 months.
fields.byline: Peter Capella in Geneva, Owen Bowcott and Rosie Cowan
fields.body:
The UN secretary-general, Kofi Annan, yesterday confirmed that Mary Robinson had reversed her decision to resign as the organisation's human rights chief and that she would stay on in the job for an extra 12 months.

"We discussed the timing of her departure, and I am delighted to say that I have prevailed on her, subject to approval by the general assembly, to stay on for one more year," Mr Annan said in a statement issued in the Kenyan capital, Nairobi.

Two weeks ago Mrs Robinson surprised human rights groups around the world by announcing that she would leave her post in September at the end of her four-year term. She complained about the inadequacy of her $21m (£13m ) budget and spoke of the "constraints" which left her with inadequate resources.

There was nothing yesterday to suggest that she had secured assurances that she would receive extra funds although some sources suggested she had asked for an increase in the high commission's budget, which currently accounts for 2% of the UN budget, as a condition for her staying on.

Mrs Robinson, who was formerly the president of Ireland, is understood to have had second thoughts last week. President Jacques Chirac of France played "a great role" on Friday in applying pressure during a dinner he hosted in Geneva after a speech to the 53-member UN human rights commission, UN sources said.

She was finally persuaded to change her mind by Mr Annan, in Nairobi yesterday. "Mary Robinson is a woman with a great sense of duty, who brought grace and gravitas to the job. She was sensitive to the thought that it was short notice to find a decent successor," a UN official explained.

With Mr Annan seeking a second term in January, there was concern that the secretary-general would not have been able to find support for a successor of similar political stature.

It is clear that Mrs Robinson has restored a lot of respect to the post since she took over in 1997, and won over adversaries with her approach. She has been an outspoken critic of the death penalty in the US.

Amnesty International in London was among human rights groups to welcome her decision. "She has been unafraid to to upset politically intractable world leaders and has not been afraid of undiplomatic language to further human rights," a spokeswoman said. "It's good news if she is prepared to stay."

However, many countries, including Russia and China, have criticised her in the past for what they term harassment. Moscow, in particular, has been unhappy with her outright condemnation of what she called human rights violations in Chechnya.

webTitle: Former SS officer jailed in 'Germany's last big war crimes trial'

fields.headline: Former SS officer jailed in 'Germany's last big war crimes trial'
fields.trailText: At the end of what is expected to be Germany's last big Nazi war crimes trial, a court yesterday convicted an 83-year-old former SS officer of the murder of seven Jewish concentration camp inmates.
fields.body:
At the end of what is expected to be Germany's last big Nazi war crimes trial, a court yesterday convicted an 83-year-old former SS officer of the murder of seven Jewish concentration camp inmates.

Julius Viel, whom the prosecution dubbed "Lord of Life and Death" at the Theresien stadt camp, was jailed for 12 years despite the prosecution's request for a life sentence.

Judge Hermann Winkler said consideration had to be given to the length of time that had elapsed between the crime and the verdict.

The court's leniency will make little difference to Viel, a retired and respected postwar German journalist, who says he is suffering from cancer and will probably die behind bars.

Viel said after the verdict: "I'm sorry for the sake of my wife."

The trial reignited the debate over whether reliable verdicts can be reached on the basis of testimony about events more than half-a-century old.

The defendant had been investigated for the murders in the 1960s, but the case was closed for lack of evidence.

At Viel's trial, there was only one substantive prosecution witness: Adalbert Lallier, a retired Canadian professor of economics, who came forward in 1998 to say that, before going to his grave, he wanted to tell the truth about an incident he had witnessed in the spring of 1945.

As Soviet troops advanced across eastern Europe, Prof Lallier and other SS officer trainees were ordered to supervise the digging of a tank trap by inmates near the Theresienstadt camp in what is now the Czech Republic.

It was a grisly business. At least 33 inmates died before the work was completed, most of them worked to death.

Prof Lallier told the Ravensburg court, however, that the seven were shot in the space of a three- to four-minute period minutes by Viel, then an SS Untersturmführer, or second lieutenant.

But, as the prosecution acknowledged in court, Prof Lallier's testimony was contradictory and far from complete. By the end of the trial, the court still did not know the victims' identities, the day they died or the murder weapon.

Viel's lawyers plan to appeal. They argued during the trial that Viel had been in Vienna when the killings took place.

They also claimed that Prof Lallier had made up his testimony to distract attention from his own Nazi past. Proceedings are under way in Canada to decide whether the 75-year-old academic should have his citizenship withdrawn because of his SS past.

But the court rejected the defence's arguments.

"It is not our view that the witness imagined the incident, or that he was himself implicated and trying to deflect the blame onto another," said the judge.

fields.headline: Fair pay for looking Goofy
fields.trailText: It may have seem like a Mickey Mouse idea to the hierarchy but employees of Walt Disney World have won the right to be be paid for all the time they spend getting dressed as cartoon characters.
fields.body:
It may have seem like a Mickey Mouse idea to the hierarchy but employees of Walt Disney World have won the right to be be paid for all the time they spend getting dressed as cartoon characters.

The decision made by an industrial relations mediator means that countless former employees could be suing the company for back pay. It came in response to a complaint filed last year with the national labour relations board by the service trades council, which represents six unions at Disney World.

The action claimed that in autumn 1999, Disney unfairly stopped paying workers for time spent changing into or out of a costume or uniform, and for the time spent wearing a uniform before they actually started performing.

About 3,000 Disney employees who work at Epcot, the Magic Kingdom and Fort Wilderness Lodge were involved in the action.

Employees are allowed to take their costumes and uniforms home and dress before coming to work. The action brought by the union pointed out that even those who do so have to queue for buses and trains that since they are dressed as Disney characters this should count as work.

Disney has announced that it will fight the ruling.

webTitle: Bus ruling causes riots in Delhi

fields.headline: Bus ruling causes riots in Delhi
fields.trailText: India's capital was gripped by unprecedented commuter rage yesterday as angry mobs in New Delhi set fire to buses and attacked police officers in protest at a well-meaning but ineptly executed scheme to reduce pollution.
fields.body:
India's capital was gripped by unprecedented commuter rage yesterday as angry mobs in New Delhi set fire to buses and attacked police officers in protest at a well-meaning but ineptly executed scheme to reduce pollution.

Police officers responded by firing into the air but found themselves vastly outnumbered in some areas by up to 2,000 disgruntled commuters unable to get to work.

They blocked roads, hijacked private cars, commandeered mopeds and burned at least five buses in protest at a ruling by India's supreme court ordering all commercial vehicles to switch to cleaner fuel or stay off the roads.

Only 1,100 buses left their sheds yesterday, compared with 12,500 before the ruling came into force. Desperate passengers hung perilously from the back of the few buses available, or sat on their roofs.

Others found themselves stranded indefinitely at bus stops. Women wept in the heat.

But what was a curse for most proved a blessing for a minority: Some auto-rickshaw drivers, having already converted their vehicles to compressed natural gas, made a killing.

"This government needs to be bashed up," Shreshat, a booking attendant, said. "I had to wait for two hours before I could board my bus. It was packed liked sardines but I had to get in."

"Do I have to go through this ordeal every day?" he asked.

The full impact of the ruling, which was made a year ago but came into effect on Sunday, caused chaos yesterday when government offices and schools reopened after a bank holiday.

Most private bus operators did not convert their vehicles in time because it would have cost 7,000 rupees (£110) to do so.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: 'Moldovans sold human meat'
fields.body:
'Moldovans sold human meat'

Two beggars have been arrested in the Moldovan capital, Chisinau, for allegedly trying to sell human remains from a cancer clinic as dog food. Police believe the remains were dumped in a bin near the clinic. Reuters, Chisinau

Brockovich lawyer guilty

The lawyer representing Erin Brockovich's ex-husband has been convicted of trying to extort £232,000 from Brockovich and her boss, Ed Masry. John Reiner threatened to slur Ms Brockovich - the subject of an Oscar-winning film - and Mr Masry. AP, Ventura, California

Mrs Mitterrand meets judges

Danielle Mitterrand, widow of the late president, yesterday met judges investigating arms sales worth £350m to Angola that allegedly involve her son, Jean-Christophe.

Mrs Mitterrand has said she knows nothing about her son's supposed involvement. The meeting was held to discuss his activities as an African affairs adviser from 1986-92 under his father and then president, François. AP, Paris
