webTitle: Final push needed to rid world of polio

fields.headline: Final push needed to rid world of polio
fields.trailText: One last major push will eliminate polio, a disease which cripples and kills children, from the planet by the end of next year but only if the political will to do it continues and a further $400m can be found from philanthropists, governments and business, the World Health Organisation said yesterday.
fields.body:
One last major push will eliminate polio, a disease which cripples and kills children, from the planet by the end of next year but only if the political will to do it continues and a further $400m can be found from philanthropists, governments and business, the World Health Organisation said yesterday.

For nearly 20 years, the race has been on to eradicate polio, which used to claim thousands of young victims in the UK before the arrival of a vaccine. But in spite of extraordinary efforts to reach children in remote areas and war zones, the original target of the end of 2000 has been missed.

Yesterday, however, Bruce Aylward, the WHO's global eradication coordinator, said he was confident that the disease could disappear by the end of 2002, leading to the certification of a polio-free world in 2005.

As with smallpox - the only disease successfully eliminated from the planet - stores of the virus in laboratories around the world would be all that remain. Unlike smallpox, however, there would be little likelihood of an aggressor country stockpiling it for potential future weapons use - it is nothing like as virulent.

Case reports are still being counted, but it is likely that there will not have been more than 3,500 worldwide last year, compared with 350,000 cases in 1988 when the WHO initiative was launched. Dr Aylward warned, though, that the endgame will be tough. "The final one per cent will require the same degree of effort as the 99 per cent of the infections so far."

But if we fail to complete the task and eliminate polio now, there may be no second chance. "The worst-case scenario is that the world will have squandered the opportunity to deliver a world free of polio," he said. The virus has slipped through the net twice recently. It travelled on a flight from Angola to Cape Verde and caused an outbreak which left 44 children paralysed this year and there was an outbreak in Haiti and the Dominican Republic in Janu ary which paralysed 17 children when a batch of vaccine reverted to become both virulent and transmissible.

Polio lingers on in 20 countries and in a few there are real difficulties, often caused by wars, in reaching children. Pakistan, Nigeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Angola are the toughest places to crack.

"Angola is the only country on the world where a relatively large population remains untouched," said Dr Aylward. "More than 250,000 children have not been reached in areas under control by rebel forces, particularly in the south-east."

Extraordinary logistical feats have been accomplished since the WHO accelerated the campaign in 1999 involving many thousands of volunteers, millions of children and billions of dollars. In India, 152m children were vaccinated in a three-day blitz. Ceasefires have been negotiated in war zones to allow volunteers to go in with supplies of vaccine.

But sustaining political commitment for a disappearing disease is not easy.

"Polio was once the leading cause of disability in the world and it is now virtually unseen," said Dr Aylward. And in spite of Rotary International, which has raised nearly half a billion dollars for the effort and major donations from Bill Gates and Ted Turner, the polio eradication programme is $400m (£250m) short of the billion it needs between 2001 and 2005 to finish the job.

fields.headline: Arsonists target Monsanto
fields.trailText: Arsonists broke into the Italian depot of the biotechnology firm Monsanto yesterday and set fire to seeds suspected of being genetically modified.
fields.body:
Arsonists broke into the Italian depot of the biotechnology firm Monsanto yesterday and set fire to seeds suspected of being genetically modified.

Flammable liquid was poured over sacks of maize, soya and rape to start four fires in a granary in the northern city of Lodi, causing more than £100,000-worth of damage.

Monsanto said the seeds were conventional ones, ready for distribution to growers.

The seeds were believed to be part of a batch imported last month from the US. Greens suspected they were genetically modified and 300 tonnes were sequestered by the government while samples were examined.

The agriculture minister, Alfonso Pecoraro Scanio, a Green, suggested that the arsonists' aim was to impede analysis of the seeds. "There is mystery around this event, there is no transparency."

A Monsanto spokesman accused environmentalists of whipping up irrational fear.

Police confiscated 79 bags of soya last week on suspicion that they contained traces of a banned genetic strain. Tests showed irregularities but Monsanto distributed the rest of the batch, saying it had not been informed of the results. Mr Scanio promised to suspend Monsanto's import licence.

fields.headline: On the beaten track
fields.standfirst: Tamar Valley
fields.trailText: Tamar Valley.
fields.body:
Homewards from the suburban south-east we cross the expansive arable tracts of Salisbury Plain, succeeded by the pastures of rural Devon, suitable mainly for grass, tended by generations of livestock farmers. Foot and mouth disease has now spread to the South Hams, where there are still valuable herds of indigenous South Devons. Further north, a herd of Ruby Reds has been culled and no one is optimistic about the future of meat production - traditional organic or intensive. Dull, wet weather adds to the gloom and despondency, particularly in mid-Devon, the epicentre of this crisis, where market towns like Hatherleigh are deserted and hundreds of people in associated occupations have been laid off or made redundant. The picturesque winding lanes and narrow bridges are completely unsuitable for huge lorries bringing in tons of fuel for pyres or carrying out bodies for rendering or mass burial. Infected farms are left stogged in deep ruts, deserted outbuildings to be disinfected, large pits and lagoons dug for dung, rubbish and surface run-off, before restocking can even be contemplated.

Home in the Tamar Valley, dainty wood anemones spread out from Nanie Rowe's Wood along New Road; banks down Morden Hill are thick with primroses; Alexanders flower amongst rain-soaked daffodils on Boetheric's hedges. Queenie and George's ewes have finished lambing and licence has been granted to move some sheep to off-fields, supervised by vets and subject to rigorous disinfection. Across and upriver, three miles as the crow flies, is an outbreak near Morwellham.

Dull, wet weather adds to the gloom and despondency, particularly in mid-Devon, the epicentre of this crisis, where market towns like Hatherleigh are deserted and hundreds of people in associated occupations have been laid off or made redundant. The picturesque winding lanes and narrow bridges are completely unsuitable for huge lorries bringing in tons of fuel for pyres or carrying out bodies for rendering or mass burial. Infected farms are left stogged in deep ruts, deserted outbuildings to be disinfected, large pits and lagoons dug for dung, rubbish and surface run-off, before restocking can even be contemplated. Home in the Tamar Valley, dainty wood anemones spread out from Nanie Rowe's Wood along New Road; banks down Morden Hill are thick with primroses; Alexanders flower amongst rain-soaked daffodils on Boetheric's hedges. Queenie and George's ewes have finished lambing and licence has been granted to move some sheep to off-fields, supervised by vets and subject to rigorous disinfection. Across and upriver, three miles as the crow flies, is an outbreak near Morwellham.

fields.headline: No 1853
fields.standfirst: Stereo MC's
fields.trailText: No 1853: Stereo MC's
fields.body:
Should that apostrophe really be there? Probably not, but it's too late to change it.

How come? It's been there a while.

Hmmm, so who are they? The name rings a vague bell. They had a record out in 1992.

And since then? They've been working on their second album. After nine years, it's about to come out.

Is that a record? Probably - they make the Stone Roses, who took five years to produce a second album, look speedy.

Have they been unemployed and starving? Nope, they made sure they sold out before dropping out. Royalties from mobile phone ads using their last album's title song, Connected, have kept them in jelly babies.

Is it worth the wait? Critics say they sound just like they used to.

How's that? Innovative dance-wise electric funk-hop turntable pop.

Who's the creative talent? Nick "The Head" Hallam and Rob "Grasshopper" Birch. They were at the forefront of what is now DJ culture.

Where do they hang out, the Bronx? No, Brixton.

What have they been up to in the meantime? Playing table football and recharging their batteries. They produced 400 tracks (30 or so albums' worth) they didn't like much.

How come? You know what these artistes are like ...

So this new effort is really polished? Er, they say it's still got rough edges, since they wanted to keep the mix "kinda live". It's not cool to be perfect.

Are their fans still up for it? Apparently. After Connected sold 1.5m, they headlined Glastonbury and toured America, so they had a few. And recent warm-up gigs in Britain have been big sell-outs.

Most likely to say: "Turn on, tune in, take a siesta."

Not to be confused with: the Stone Roses, the number 73 bus, Godot ...

webTitle: TV review: The Investigators; Masterchef; New Eastenders

fields.headline: Sick and tired and uninspired
fields.trailText: TV review
fields.body:
"Tonight," says John Simm in his best sonorous tones, "private investigators are on the trail of a suspect... [pause for effect] faking sick leave."

Faking sick leave. Not grand larceny, emerald smuggling or opium rings. No white slave traders, internet pornographers or gun runners, but folks who take sickies. Now, I know fraudulent sick leave costs British business billions of pounds every year and it is really terrible for the CBI and yada yada yada, but tracking down its perpetrators is hardly a case for Philip Marlowe. Or even Pru, Maggie and Fred from CATS Eyes.

But, as Craig, one of The Investigators (BBC1) notes, "A lot of people fall in love with the title thinking it's going to be dead glamorous. It's not. It's just a job." Clearly, Craig is referring to TV producers and whoever commissioned this flimsy, humdrum documentary for BBC1.

Watching the detectives (you really thought I would resist that line?) turned out to be as appealing as a docusoap about the drying of paint. What with the case of a fostered son attempting to contact his birth mother, a dodgy geezer dealing in car parts and The Case Of The Sick Leave Scoundrel, the best bits of The Investigators were the shots of Manchester cityscapes (especially the night-time ones - so many pretty lights).

In a move akin to Carol Smillie being recruited to present a revamped The Antiques Roadshow in which Anne McKevitt offers tips on how to liven up that 18th-century mahogany dining-room table ("What it needs is a bit of decoupage with silver foil and blue fake fur stapled round the edge for a real contemporary look!") so Gary Rhodes pops up on Masterchef (BBC2). Worse still, he appears in a suit which makes him look like Amanda Burton.

With all the charisma of a (soiled) toilet brush, Rhodes presides over a more straightforward competition, but one sadly lacking in the joie de vivre that Loyd Grossman brought to the show. So while the contestants must include two ingredients in their meal - which isn't as Ready Steady Cook as it sounds - Gary and guest Gordon Ramsay grumped and humphed like two old women judges at a jam-making competition. "I would never stuff a best end of lamb", noted Gordon snootily. "Very worrying", nodded Gary, sounding a bit too excited that one of the contestants would be getting nil points for committing such a cardinal sin.

Hence, the end result wasn't much fun. As Gina, Paul and Philippa (who helpfully informed the pair that, "I've taken the walnuts out of their shell" ) slogged their guts out in their coloured kitchens, Gordon and Gary hovered around like spiteful home economics teachers, raising eyebrows and wrinkling noses. If you've had a spiteful home economics teacher, you'll know how unappetising that is.

We can, I think, safely assume that none of the New Eastenders (BBC2) shot Phil Mitchell. They might have chopped him in half lengthways and pickled him in a glass box, but attempted murder with a stolen shooter is a bit Harlesden for those taking up residence in E1.

Actually, that Damian Hirst reference is a bit passé for the artists featured. One painted armadillos, another installed his sculpture on a bit of waste ground in Hoxton, to symbolise the estrangement of real artists from the East End, and a third painted big canvases black with a really small brush. There wasn't even a hint of dead farm animals. More, alas, than can be said for the rest of the country.

Providing an insight into the world of the art scene, you might have expected the New Eastenders to dispel the notion of the rarified hemisphere of the frightfully polite art dealer and the grungey hemisphere of the artists, with both spouting pretentious nonsense round about the equator. But no. Dealer Victoria Miro, for example, employs artists instead of builders to refurbish an old warehouse for her new gallery and then looks very worried when they seem to be falling behind schedule. "In a way," she says dreamily, "artists are like extended family." And would you trust your second cousin, a burger flipper in McDonalds, to do you a mural for your living room? Exactly.

All your preconceptions about Young British Artists are resolutely confirmed by New Eastenders. One thing it does bring to light, however, is that most artists have heads which you could turn upside down and they'd still look the same. Which is very Phil Mitchell.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
There's no preview tape so all that can be said about the new comedy, The Leopard In Autumn (11.30am, Radio 4), is that it looks promising (don't they all?). With a cast which includes Sian Phillips and a script by Punch contributor Neal Anthony, it's set in the crumbling Italian city-state of Monte Guano in 1521 (possibly because Luther was then creating mayhem at the Diet of Worms).

Norman Lebrecht opens a new season of his up-market chat show, or "interactive cultural forum" as the BBC prefers. The first session of lebrecht.2live (6.45pm, Radio 3) is sited on such a sitting duck that no true sportsman would even raise his gun. Why, Lebrecht asks, do so many people treat soap operas as having greater reality than their own lives? More to the point, why do their talentless stars get such plum parts in other shows?

Professor Tom Kirkwood addresses what may be this century's overarching theme in The Reith Lectures 2001 (8.0pm, Radio 4) - that the world's population is living far beyond a span that nature or economic theory anticipated. He starts by looking warily on the bright side. What we are facing is a new country for which we must brace ourselves, a Brave Old World. Many of "the old" are already in far better physical shape than their ancestors, and it's reasonable to assume that coming generations will live up to 25 years longer than their forebears.

webTitle: Satellite, cable, digital pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable & digital
fields.body:
Films

One Of Our Aircraft Is Missing (Michael Powell, Emeric Pressburger, 1942) 7pm, Carlton Cinema A British bomber crew bales out over occupied Holland in Powell and Pressburger's gripping second world war flag-waver. Paranoia rules as the six airmen, including stalwart Eric Portman, head for the coast, helped by Dutch resistance, but stalked by the Nazis.

The Avengers (Jeremiah Chechik, 1998) 8pm, Sky Premier A sadly flat Hollywood version of the bubbly TV series, though there are things to enjoy. The plot has Sean Connery's evil weatherman Sir August de Wynter (geddit?) holding the British climate to ransom: an admirably loopy idea that would have appealed to the original's writers, while Stuart Craig's design creates a surreal blend of the 60s and 90s. Ralph Fiennes makes a decently furled umbrella of John Steed, but Uma Thurman's cat-suited Emma Peel lacks claws. The fleeting presence of Patrick Macnee, the original Steed, as Invisible Jones is another reminder of what a classy, charming act the small-screen version was.

Sense And Sensibility (Ang Lee, 1995) 8pm, FilmFour Assured and delicate adaptation of Jane Austen's novel about the Dashwood girls (Emma Thompson, Kate Winslet, Emilie François), who are obliged to seek good marriages when their mother (Gemma Jones) falls on hard times. Thompson's Oscar-winning screenplay stays close to Austen's ironic social and personal perceptions, and Lee is much at home with this cool comic critique of early 19th-century values. Hugh Grant and Alan Rickman are among the suitors.

The Crying Game (Neil Jordan, 1992) 10.30pm, FilmFour Somehow it grips despite the thematic lurches: opening as a thriller about the IRA, it shifts into hostage drama, then urban love story. Pulling it together is Stephen Rea's Fergus, an IRA man who gets too close to squaddie hostage Forest Whitaker, then is fascinated by the latter's lover, played by the astonishing Jaye Davidson. Excellent, apart from Miranda Richardson's hysterical gunwoman, and a perfunctory final shoot-out.
Paul Howlett

The Trouble With Harry (Alfred Hitchcock,1955) 5.0pm, The Studio Hitchock on rare caper form here, but even at his lightest the humour's pretty dark. The trouble with Harry is that he won't stay still - even though he's dead. The residents of the sleepy New England town where he was shot all seem to think they are responsible, and so Harry spends his time being buried, dug up and reburied by a succession of well-meaning murder candidates - including Shirley Maclaine (in her first big-screen role), John Forsythe, Edmund Gwenn and Jerry Mathers. It also marks Hitchcock's first collaboration with the mighty Bernard Hermann, whose soundtracks later propelled films like Psycho, Vertigo and North By Northwest to greatness. Richard Vine

Sports

Live Curling 2pm & 7.30pm, British Eurosport It's not often that we get the chance to see live curling on British screens (well, not in England anyway), so this is an opportunity too good to miss. It's the World Championships from Lausanne in Switzerland, and both matches on today involve the USA playing Germany, still in the preliminary group phase. The women's teams, which are both pretty good, play in the afternoon while the men's, which aren't, wait until the evening.
Simon Burnton

fields.headline: The fame game
fields.trailText: The Today green room, where guests wait balefully to be interviewed, is one of the world's less glamorous places.
fields.body:
The Today green room, where guests wait balefully to be interviewed, is one of the world's less glamorous places. It's a ten-by-ten glass kennel with carpet tiles stolen from a Louisiana motel in 1972, a recalcitrant coffee machine and bits of croissant half-chewed by Jim Naughtie.

And then there's the guests.

Important, clever people who run the country; people from Select Committees and quangos, very serious businessmen and furious, radical campaigners. Interesting people, yes - but glitzy? Hard to argue, really. The glitziest we usually get is Iain Duncan Smith and that nice chap from the Soil Association. Glitzy isn't really our thing.

But then, for a moment last week, a little stardust was sprinkled on the Today programme. At 7.15 in the morning, sitting on the strange purple sofa in our green room - between a lady from the Monetary Policy Committee and Thought For The Day - was Chrissie Hynde, who had, inexplicably, accepted our invitation to debate the rectitude or otherwise of eating meat. So I went up and said hello.

"Why don't you have any soya milk?" she asked, as an opener, looking disdainfully at the breakfast spread. My usual response - "because only mad people drink it" - dissolved on this occasion and instead I just grinned like an imbecile.

Then, having inquired as to whether Antony Worral Thompson, her co-debator, was "a fox", she asked what the name of the show was. "It's the Today programme", I said, and the disdain increased.

"Never heard it. Don't like hearing other people's opinions in the morning. I listen to Radio Three."

Ah, but she's a star. And they're so few and far between round here. We had Cliff Richard on ages ago and The World Tonight once got an interview with Sir Paul McCartney (on the excellent pretext that he'd recorded a song called "The World Tonight". This made us briefly consider changing our name to "I Should Be So Lucky, Lucky, Lucky, Lucky", and then banging in a request for Kylie.) But it doesn't happen often.

Chrissie proved it could be done, though. And the following day, the interview requests went in: David Bowie on foot and mouth disease; Ronaldo on the date of the general election; Sarah Michelle Geller on Railtrack's poor share results. But they all said no. Maybe we're not cut out for that sort of journalism.

A few years ago we interviewed Julie Goodyear - that's Bet Lynch - who had just been made an Ambassador for Liverpool, or something. She wasn't very familiar with the programme either. Who'll be doing the interview, she asked, and when we told her John Humphrys, replied: "Ooh, the John Humphrys? Brilliant! I love him! He's fantastic! Is he still doing Are You Being Served?"

 Rod Liddle is the editor of Radio 4's Today programme

fields.headline: Astronomers identify 20 planets
fields.standfirst: Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: Two British astronomers have counted up to 20 "free floating" planets, drifting in the constellation of Orion.
fields.body:
Two British astronomers have counted up to 20 "free floating" planets, drifting in the constellation of Orion.

They told the National Astronomy Meeting in Cambridge yesterday that they had identified the "signature" of water vapour in the infrared spectrum of faint points of light in the Orion nebula.

This is a vast cloud of gas and dust 1,300 light years from Earth, but visible as the middle "star" in the sword of the constellation of Orion.

They add: "The chances of finding life on one of these is about the same as finding life on Jupiter - minimal."

fields.headline: Lord Hartwell
fields.standfirst: Last of the press barons, whose miscalculation cost his family the Daily and Sunday Telegraphs
fields.trailText: Last of the press barons, whose miscalculation cost his family the Daily and Sunday Telegraphs.
fields.body:
Lord Hartwell, who has died aged 89, was the last of Britain's real press barons. Alone among the scions of the prewar dynasties that dominated Fleet Street for three-quarters of a century, he was a lifelong, fulltime newspaperman, and chairman and editor-in-chief for 30 years of the family's Daily and Sunday Telegraphs - until his dedicated, but idiosyncratic, stewardship delivered them into the hands of the Canadian entrepreneur Conrad Black in December 1985.

The painful and humiliating circumstances in which he lost control of the two papers, to which he had devoted all his energies from the day he returned from war service, was a blow from which he never recovered.

As Michael Berry, he took over the Daily Telegraph in 1954, when his father, the first Viscount Camrose, died, and his elder brother, succeeding to the title, opted for more gentlemanly pursuits than Fleet Street offered. Young Berry - he was 43 - arrived with all the right establishment qualifications: Eton, Christ Church, Oxford, and a wartime colonel in the artillery. He had edited the Sunday Mail in Glasgow from 1934-35, and been managing editor of the Financial Times from 1937-39.

He was not, however, in the traditional famous-father-foolish-son mould of Beaverbrook's heir, Max Aitken. He inherited not merely a thriving, prosperous Conservative newspaper but his chapel- going forebears' capacity for hard work and single-minded enterprise. Starting with a modest magazine, the Berry brothers - two young Welshmen from Merthyr Tydfil - had built up an empire of 26 newpapers by the 1930s, when they decided to divide it, with William (Camrose) taking the Daily Telegraph, and Gomer (later Viscount Kemsley) getting the Sunday Times.

Under Michael Berry, the Telegraph rapidly expanded its base among archetypal Tories with an editorial policy that concentrated on the most comprehensive hard news coverage of any daily - including fuller accounts of all the juiciest crimes and sex cases than the popular papers carried - but almost no feature articles. All this was primly packaged in an austere typography that became a synonym for sub- urban respectability. Yet, despite its sobriquet, the "Torygraph", the paper took its owner's very independent view of Conservative, and, in the lady's day, Thatcherite, policies.

Encouraged by steadily rising sales, Berry launched the Sunday Telegraph in 1961, to split overheads and cash in on the daily's highly-profitable advertising pull. It was to prove a costly misjudgment of the market; the Sunday Telegraph kept going but became a financial millstone round the company's overstretched neck.

Lord Hartwell - he was given a life peerage by Harold Wilson in 1968 - was a shy man with a slight stammer. He left the public spotlight to his vivacious wife, Pamela, a worthy daughter of the first Lord Birkenhead (the great advocate FE Smith), whose notable salon nurtured a generation of assorted celebrities. After her death in 1982, he became even more withdrawn from social life.

As editor-in-chief, he put in a six-day week, working closely with the Daily Telegraph editor William (now Lord) Deedes, a former Tory minister. Both were unwilling to face the fact that their once-solid readership was dying off, and the new consumer-classes wanted something trendier. In their hands, circulation had gone from 900,000 to almost 1.5m, but was now back down to 1.2m - and still falling. In an age of changing modes and neo-Toryism, the good, grey Telegraph became even greyer, if anything, reflecting Hartwell's isolation from the wider world.

As Peregrine Worsthorne, editor of the Sunday Telegraph for three years, put it: "It was a boring paper, but the great thing was that it seemed to be what people wanted. It never shocked or upset readers with views they didn't like. As it stood, the fact that so much of it was unreadable worked in its favour and was one of its strengths."

Management, however, was not one of its strengths. Poring over his beloved printer's proofs, correcting solecisms, Hartwell had failed to realise that, in modern commercial terms, the Telegraph had become a ramshackle anachronism. Plagued by costly union fiddles, with neither proper budget nor financial structure, deferential executives told him only what they thought he wanted to hear, and were themselves never taken into his confidence, even when financial crisis erupted in the spring of 1985.

Forced to raise £105m to fund ambitious plans for new-technology printing plants in Manchester and London's Docklands - plans that had never been realistically costed - Hartwell was shattered to find that the City's ardent Tories were unwilling to put their money where their political sympathies lay.

It was then that Andrew Knight, editor of the Economist, tipped off his friend Black, a sharp, erudite pre- dator of 41 with a finger in innumerable transatlantic pies, that the Hartwell empire could be up for grabs. Hartwell had never heard of Black but, making a lightning decision that ran counter to his record of canny procrastination, flew to New York by Concorde with a bewildered entourage to seek Black's help.

Within 24 hours, he had done what he thought was a very smart deal with the impressive, cultured Canadian - an injection of some £10m in return for 14% of the share capital. There was one fateful "if" clause; should more funds be needed, Black would have the option of the rights on the Berry family shares. Hartwell was confident the company would now need no more money. But it did - much more. Hartwell had handed his birthright on a silver salver to the rescuing white knight.

Nine months later, Black had 51% of the shares, took over effective control and installed his new men, Andrew Knight and Max Hastings, as respectively chief executive and editor, with a mission to drag the ailing "Torygraph" into the late 20th century.

Hartwell lingered on as nominal chairman and editor-in-chief for 18 months, his sinecure cruelly underlined by the unkindest cut of all, when he was moved out of his handsomely furnished room, with its silver and Sèvres collections, to make way for City office staff. He retired in September 1986, aged 76, never having set foot in the Docklands complex he had planned with such pride.

With the dismemberment of the Sunday Times's reputation in another corner of the wood, it was a sad and ignominious end to the once-proud Berry dynasty.

Hartwell is survived by two sons and two daughters.

 William Michael Berry, Baron Hartwell of Peter- borough Court in the City of London, newspaper magnate, born May 18 1911; died April 2 2001

fields.headline: Irene Thomas
fields.standfirst: Her phenomenal memory made her queen of the quiz programmes
fields.trailText: Irene Thomas, who has died aged 81, was the first woman to win both the BBC radio general knowledge quiz Brain Of Britain and the three-yearly contest of its winners, Brain Of Brains.
fields.body:
Irene Thomas, who has died aged 81, was the first woman to win both the BBC radio general knowledge quiz Brain Of Britain and the three-yearly contest of its winners, Brain Of Brains.

Once established, she lasted several decades on radio and television, becoming queen of the arcane question in such other programmes as Round Britain Quiz - on which she featured for more than 20 years - Round Europe Quiz, Transatlantic Quiz, Ask Me Another, Mastermind, Criss Cross Quiz, Crossword On Two, My Word, the Gardening Quiz, Who Said That? and X Marks The Spot.

The first time she took part in Brain Of Britain in 1961, she discovered, after the team left the studio, that all the other (male) contestants had made off for the (all-male) Garrick club without her - the last time, she was proud of recalling, they ever did. Tall, fine-featured and with twinkling, but piercing, blue eyes, she was good at nego-tiating, with humour, what she saw as the English obsession with class and gender.

Thomas was part of that rich crop of quick-thinking, well-informed, grammar-school people who missed out on university largely because of the war. Part of her strength was that she never pretended to be anything other than someone who was good at solving puzzles.

Though she painstakingly eradicated the accent with which she had been born, she was what she called, in her 1979 autobiography, A Bandsman's Daughter, upper working-class. Born Irene Ready in Feltham, Middlesex, her father had been an army clarinettist and a meter reader for the Gas Light and Coke Company. Her mother was a seamstress who worked for the department store Gorringes. Their daughter went to Ashford county grammar school, where she discovered she was good at examinations and bad at sports. "I couldn't hit a cow's bottom with a banjo," she once confessed.

She was also a useful piano player and, while still in her teens, played for concert parties - until her hair was bobbed and she could no longer pose as an infant prodigy. She worked in an Inland Revenue office after leaving school at 15, briefly tried teaching, but doubted her ability to keep pupils' interest and discipline, was married to Wesley Baldry at 19 (they divorced in 1949) and served in the fire service through the second world war.

When Covent Garden reopened for opera after 1945, she sang in the chorus and took small roles as a light mezzo-soprano. She also met her second husband Eddie Thomas, another singer; they were married in 1950.

She slid from grand opera into singing for ice shows, television variety programmes and, after 1955, rendering advertising jingles for the newly-established ITV. She also worked as a session musical, a chorus girl at the London Palladium and for the Black and White Minstrel Show (for which she had her face painted not black for the TV cameras, but green).

She joined Mensa in 1961, in the days before her skill with puzzles became public. She was given an IQ rating of 160, which put her in the top 2% of its members, and encouraged her to enter Brain Of Britain. She won, and followed up her success by capturing the title Brain Of Brains the following year.

It had taken seven years of dauntless effort to get Thomas accepted by the BBC - and even then she got her chance only because another (male) contestant had been taken ill. She kept a file of producers' letters of excuse for not giving her a chance, labelled with typically un-sour humour, Lovely Replies.

For many years, she wrote a column in Woman And Home magazine and, in 1986, became the first patron of the Polite Society, an organisation supporting good manners. She was active in church life around her home in Chiswick, west London.

Irene Thomas is survived by her husband, a retired teacher.

 Irene Thomas, quiz panellist, radio and television personality, and singer, born June 28 1920; died March 27 2001

fields.headline: Yousif Kuwa
fields.standfirst: The lost leader of Africa's persecuted Nuba people, he tempered armed resistance with justice
fields.trailText: The lost leader of Africa's persecuted Nuba people, he tempered armed resistance with justice.
fields.body:
In the days before he died, at the age of 55, Yousif Kuwa wanted two things: to see the latest biography of Nelson Mandela, and to publish an open letter to the United Nations secretary-general Kofi Annan on behalf of the Nuba people of Sudan, whose struggle for survival Yousif led for 16 years. The letter asked why, despite all its promises, the UN continued to abandon the Nuba to the depredations of the fundamentalist generals who rule Sudan.

Yousif's death has robbed Africa of one of its most visionary leaders. It has robbed the Nuba, long perceived as an underclass in Arab-ruled Sudan, of the man who gave them a new pride and confidence in their Africanness. And it has robbed the Sudan People's Liberation Army (SPLA) of a commander who demonstrated that armed struggle is not incompatible with respect for human rights and civil society.

A teacher by vocation, with a longing to farm once the struggle was over, Yousif fought all his life for a just peace - not only for the Nuba, but for all Sudanese, regardless of race, religion or sex. For him, there was no alternative to resistance in the Nuba mountains of central Sudan, sealed off from the world since the National Islamic Front seized power in 1989.

But he respected those who chose to flee to government garrisons where they were promised - but seldom given - food, clothes and medicine. He was that rare thing in any society, especially in an impecunious society under arms: a leader who was loved.

Yousif was born into the Miri tribe, one of more than 50 ethnic Nuba groups. In the days before Sudan's rulers began enforcing an Arab-Islamic identity down the barrel of a gun, his parents were happy to raise him as a Muslim, and gave him an Arab name in preference to that traditionally given to first-born Nuba boys, Kuku. Yousif grew up believing he was an Arab. "If you told me otherwise," he once said, "I would hit you."

All this changed in second- ary school, when his headmaster stopped teaching him, saying: "What is the use of teaching Nuba who are going to work as servants in houses?" "What's a Nuba?" Yousif asked.

He discovered the answer as a political science student at Khartoum University, immersing himself in Nuba history. At the house of a Nuba friend one evening, he was dismayed to hear one child say to another, "You are a good singer. But, unfortunately, you are black." In that moment, he said, "I started to reject assimilation. I said, 'I will build my civilisation, and then I will forgive anyone who humiliated me before.'"

While still at university, he helped create the Komolo, the first political organisation of Nuba youth. In 1981, he was elected to the Kordofan regional assembly, but found himself accused of racism whenever he spoke of the Nuba. Despairing of political change, he joined the SPLA.

For him, liberation meant respect for the rights of all. He sought self-determination in its original sense - for the Nuba to have the right to choose what kind of government they would have, and with whom.

Yousif's years as SPLA governor-commander in the Nuba mountains set new standards of rebel behaviour. He refused to tolerate abuses, and brought some indisciplined soldiers before firing squads. He built a civil ad ministration that was unique to SPLA-controlled areas, and let the Nuba freely choose between resistance and surrender. They voted, overwhelmingly, for resistance.

Yousif was the embodiment of the traditional Nuba values of political and religious tolerance. He fathered a renaissance of Nuba culture, and gave the Nuba a self-confidence that was their strongest weapon when Khartoum declared holy war against them in 1991. Encouraged by him to be self-reliant, the Nuba fought Khartoum's blockade by creating a teachers' training college and a nursing school, despite having almost no educated class.

I n 1993, after two years of famine in which thousands died unseen, Yousif found his way to Europe to seek help for his people. He returned almost empty-handed, disappointed by his first encounter with the west. "We are like a sinking man in the river, and they are standing on the bank shouting encouragement," he said. "We do not fear bullets, but we feel bitter when a lot of people - especially children - die because of malaria."

Told he had bone cancer 15 months ago, Yousif had one wish - to see a just peace before he died. That was not to be. With the exploitation of oil by foreign companies, which have suddenly overcome their abhorrence for Khartoum, peace seems further away than ever.

He is survived by his three wives - Fatima, Hanan and Imm Masaar - and 14 children.

He returned almost empty-handed, disappointed by his first encounter with the west. "We are like a sinking man in the river, and they are standing on the bank shouting encouragement," he said. "We do not fear bullets, but we feel bitter when a lot of people - especially children - die because of malaria." Told he had bone cancer 15 months ago, Yousif had one wish - to see a just peace before he died. That was not to be. With the exploitation of oil by foreign companies, which have suddenly overcome their abhorrence for Khartoum, peace seems further away than ever. He is survived by his three wives - Fatima, Hanan and Imm Masaar - and 14 children.  Yousif Kuwa Mekki, Nuba resistance leader, born August 1945; died March 31 2001

webTitle: Hanratty campaign unfazed by DNA match

fields.headline: Hanratty campaign unfazed by DNA match
fields.trailText: Campaigners seeking the quashing of James Hanratty's murder conviction insisted yesterday that they were still confident of clearing his name, despite tests which showed that his DNA "perfectly matches" strands found on the victim's clothes.
fields.body:
Campaigners seeking the quashing of James Hanratty's murder conviction insisted yesterday that they were still confident of clearing his name, despite tests which showed that his DNA "perfectly matches" strands found on the victim's clothes.

Sources at Scotland Yard confirmed that the tests, conducted by the forensic science service after Hanratty's body was exhumed two weeks ago, were positive, and that there was a "one in 100m chance" that the DNA came from another person.

The evidence will be central to the crown's case to the court of appeal that the conviction of Hanratty 39 years ago for the murder of Michael Gregsten is safe. The killer also raped and shot the civil servant's lover, Valerie Storie, 22.

Hanratty, 25, a petty thief, went to the gallows at Bedford prison on April 4 1962 for what became known as the A6 murder.

Though the DNA tests appear to be conclusive, lawyers acting for Hanratty's family said they were neither surprised by the results nor despondent about their prospects at the appeal hearing, expected this autumn.

They will argue that the tests are not relevant because DNA from Hanratty's clothes that were confiscated at the time of the original investigation may have been mixed with two garments, a handkerchief and Storie's knickers, gathered from the crime scene.

If the appeal court is not satisfied that the two sets of clothes were kept entirely separate, the DNA results could be deemed insignificant.

The problem for both sides is that nobody knows what happened to the underwear and the handkerchief in the 30 years before they were found in a laboratory drawer in Lambeth, south London, in 1991.

Doubts about the safety of the conviction led the criminal cases review commission to refer the case to the appeal court.

"We know the clothes were kept in paper envelopes and that they were brought to court at the time of the trial and examined by expert witnesses for the prosecution and the defence," said Tamsin Allen, a lawyer acting for Hanratty's relatives.

"We say the clothes could easily have been contaminated, so these latest DNA results have not come as a surprise. All the other evidence suggests that Hanratty was not there at the time of the murder."

Previous tests showed a match between the DNA of Hanratty's relatives and DNA found on Storie's knickers. The latest round of tests was ordered by Lord Woolf, the lord chief justice, in the "interests of justice".

Scotland Yard refused to comment on the case yesterday, but Norman Brennan, director of the Victims of Crime Trust, criticised campaigners for rubbishing the latest tests. "Had the DNA results said Hanratty was not guilty, I am sure the family and their solicitors would be rubbing all our noses in it."

The A6 murder has become one of the most contentious of the alleged miscarriage of justice cases. Hanratty was accused of being the gunman who burst into Gregsten's Morris Minor as he sat with Storie in a cornfield at Dorney Reach, Buckinghamshire.

The couple were forced to drive to Deadman's Hill, south of Bedford, where Gregsten, a scientist, was murdered and Storie was raped, shot five times, and left for dead. She survived but was paralysed.

Hanratty was arrested when detectives found spent cartridges from the murder weapon in a London guesthouse he often used. Storie picked him out at an identity parade, and criminals gave evidence against him.

Nevertheless, Hanratty's father was convinced of his son's innocence and began a campaign to clear his name.

Eleven witnesses have since claimed that Hanratty was in Rhyl, north Wales, at the time of the murder, and Storie's identification of him has been questioned.

fields.headline: Police informer jailed for £400,000 swindle
fields.trailText: A police informer was jailed yesterday for stealing £400,000 in a mobile phone scam that allegedly involved two detectives, who have been suspended after an investigation by Scotland Yard's anti-corruption squad.
fields.body:
A police informer was jailed yesterday for stealing £400,000 in a mobile phone scam that allegedly involved two detectives, who have been suspended after an investigation by Scotland Yard's anti-corruption squad.

Geoffrey Brennan, 48, was sentenced to three and a half years by Judge Brian Barker, who described his actions as audacious. "You have clearly lived the life of deliberate risk," he said.

Though Brennan's trial at the Old Bailey brought to an end an extraordinary and complex case which shed light on the murky relationship between informants and their handlers, it also left question marks over claims that two officers were directly involved.

Brennan has alleged he paid his Metropolitan police handlers, Detective Inspector John Redgrave and Detective Constable Michael Charman, £50,000 from the £400,000 deal. He later withdrew the claim.

The officers have been suspended for seven years while an inquiry by the Met's complaints investigation bureau, into this and other matters, has been continuing.

Richard Latham QC, prosecuting, described how Brennan, who owned a phone dealership in Welling, Kent, duped two American businessmen into buying a batch of new mobile handsets in July 1993.

Sam and Tom Wang paid £400,000 for the 3,000 Motorola phones and waited for delivery. But Brennan took the money from his business account and almost immediately stopped trading, the court heard.

He bought a new home with the cash and left a string of unpaid debts.

Mr Latham told the jury that Brennan had then turned to the two detectives to help him concoct a cover story that would explain why he had received such a large amount of money.

The smokescreen to deter any police inquiry was an undercover operation, which involved Mr Redgrave and Mr Charman, to expose gun smuggling between the US and the UK, the court heard.

But when Brennan realised that officers at Bexleyheath CID were pursuing the theft - following complaints from the US businessmen - he panicked, and turned to Scotland Yard's newly formed CIB for protection. In a pre-trial abuse of process hearing, the judge heard that Brennan had confessed the scam to a CIB investigator, Superintendent Roger Gaspar, and claimed that he had paid the two detectives £50,000.

The interview was taped but could not be used as evidence during the trial because Brennan was not under caution.

Brennan later withdrew the allegations, saying he had been coerced into making the claims about the officers.

Bexleyheath police continued to investigate the theft from the Americans, and Brennan was arrested in November 1996.

He denied the charge, claiming he was an informer who had been working undercover for the police, supplying officers with valuable information.

Giving evidence during the trial, Brennan said the mobile shipment had been a front to import arms from Hong Kong.

Andrew Trollope, defending, said Brennan had supplied information of "the greatest import to security."

He claimed that Brennan had given had given police "great assistance in the war against crime. There is no question but that a major arms conspiracy was afoot in the latter months of 1993 and up to 1994.

"It was Geoffrey Brennan who gave the police the information about that. Brennan was an informant at the time and was passing on genuine information about drug trafficking... and was also passing on information about arms dealing."

The prosecution said Brennan's involvement in covert operations only started after the theft of the money, and the complex undercover inquiries were used as cover for his crime.

Sentencing Brennan, Judge Barker said: "It has been an extraordinary case and you have clearly lived the life of deliberate risk. You have been convicted by the jury on clear evidence of an opportunistic theft. You used your connections ... to take advantage of the Wangs."

Mr Redgrave and Mr Charman are still suspended. They have not been charged over any matter. Speaking to the Guardian last year, Mr Redgrave said: "I have been suspended in relation to a complaint that is six years old. This has caused the complete destruction of every aspect of my personal and professional life."

Scotland Yard refused to comment after the case.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Family murder charge
fields.body:
Family murder charge

David Morris, 38, a scrap metal dealer of Craigcefnparc in the Swansea valley, was remanded in custody until next month when he appeared at Swansea crown court accused of murdering three generations of one family. Doris Dawson, 80, her daughter Mandy Power, 34, and granddaughters Katie, 10, and Emily, eight, were bludgeoned to death in their home at Clydach, Swansea, in 1999.

Rush to join new police force

Almost 8,000 people have applied for 240 training places to go equally to Protestants and Catholics in Northern Ireland's new police service. The government and an independent recruitment agency in charge of the initial selection, Consensia, think there will be no problem reaching the 50/50 quota.

FCUK posters censured

Advertising for French Connection will be vetted after it was ruled by the advertising standards authority to have brought the industry into disrepute. Posters promoting fcukinkybugger.com could cause "serious and widespread offence", the authority said after 132 complaints. It was the clothing retailer's second censure in a year.

Boy awarded £2.5m damages

The high court in Manchester has awarded £2.5m damages to Kevin Roberts, 13, of Radcliffe, Greater Manchester, who was left with severe brain damage after he almost drowned in a hotel swimming pool in Majorca in 1993. The judge divided responsibility half to the hotel, a third to the tour operator, Sunworld, and the remainder to the parents, who did not give the boy armbands although he was unable to swim.

GM maize sites announced

The government has announced 25 sites in England and three in Wales where genetically modified maize is to be planted this spring as part of farm trials. The aim is to have 32 sites. Details on www.detr.gov.uk

webTitle: Foot and mouth outbreaks set to pass 1,000

fields.headline: Outbreaks set to pass 1,000
fields.standfirst:
New high in number of animals to be slaughtered

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: A further 23 were confirmed by yesterday afternoon, bringing the official total to 970.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth epidemic could breach the 1,000 cases mark today after a further 23 were confirmed by yesterday afternoon, bringing the official total to 970. The number of cattle condemned reached 1,010,000, and the backlog of animals waiting to be slaughtered was at a new high of 379,000

Worryingly for the government, there were new outbreaks in Shropshire, in areas which have largely avoided the epidemic so far. There were nine outbreaks in Cumbria, taking the total there to almost 400, and one on a city farm in Bristol. Several new cases have been confirmed near the high fells of the Lake District and the north Pennines, raising more fears that the uplands would be devastated.

But there were sharp disagreements as to whether the slaughter policy was working. As many Cumbrian farmers claimed that the situation was worsening, NFU leaders were more optimistic, predicting the cull of up to 400,000 sheep in and around infected farms was likely to be complete in 10 days, a similar figure given by the army a week ago. The problems of getting the slaughtered animals to burial sites was nowhere near being solved, with a record figure of 192,000 waiting in fields or barns to be buried.

Yesterday the government renewed appeals to hauliers and vets for help. The army presence increased to 1,500.

But the NFU appears to have temporarily won the vaccination battle. The minister of agriculture, Nick Brown, on a brief visit to Cumbria, admitted that the government was "encountering resistance" from NFU leaders who want the current slaughter policy to be given more time to work.

But the influential National Trust, which owns 98 farms in Cumbria, renewed its calls for selective vaccination of the Herdwick flocks of sheep, saying the Lake District "faced a cataclysmic situation" if the slaughter policy extended to the high fells.

"There is a real risk to the whole Lakes District and tourism. We are not arguing for mass vaccination, but ring fencing of outbreaks," said Peter Nixon, the trust's estate director.

He dismissed NFU leaders' concerns about the loss of exports, saying: "The market is compromised. There isn't going to be great enthusiasm [for British meat] after this."

It was unclear last night how a city farm in Bristol could have contracted the disease. The Lawrence Weston Community Farm had closed as a precaution at the start of the epidemic but yesterday all its animals, including goats, ducks, chickens, donkeys and sheep, were slaughtered.

The outbreak has raised concerns about the safety of animals at the nearby Bristol Zoo, which reopened to the public this week. Elephants and hippopotamuses there are at risk. The outbreak also brings fresh fears for the herd of wild deer at the Ashton Court estate in Bristol.

Zoos across Britain were yesterday hoping the government would agree to a vaccination programme to save their animals from slaughter. The Federation of Zoos has been lobbying the government for permission to carry out the protective measures.

webTitle: Message in a bottle sealed atrocity in a time capsule

fields.headline: Message in a bottle sealed atrocity in a time capsule
fields.trailText: A tangle of rusty metal, on public display today for the first time, has dredged up memories of a British first world war atrocity, when the crew of an English vessel abandoned 16 German airmen to drown in the icy waters of the North Sea.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A tangle of rusty metal, on public display today for the first time, has dredged up memories of a British first world war atrocity, when the crew of an English vessel abandoned 16 German airmen to drown in the icy waters of the North Sea.

The Germans had lost contact with their base at Tondern, and the truth of their deaths might have sunk with them, except for the extraordinary chance that a bottle containing their last messages was washed up on the Swedish coast six months later.

The wreckage has been in government and museum stores for most of a century, since the German Zeppelin L19 crashed into the sea with her crew in February 1916, on her maiden flight. There were two notes in the bottle. One, from the captain, Oto Lowe, gave a bleak technical report on their situation, ending: "February 2, towards 1 pm, will apparently be our last hour".

The other, from an unnamed crew member, told a dramatic story: "My greetings to my wife and child. An English trawler was here and refused to take us on board. She was the King Stephen and hailed from Grimsby."

By the time the bottle was found, a German U-boat had sunk the King Stephen. All the crew were rescued, interned in Germany, and returned safely to England in 1918.

The tragedy became a German propaganda sensation, and was taken up in turn by the British media, which applied a radically different spin to the story.

It was reported that the unamed English captain feared that since there were more German airmen than he had sailors, his vessel might be hijacked.

The bishop of London fanned the flames, by commenting that leaving "the German baby-killers" in the water was understandable. A German newspaper said he had "acted less as an apostle of Christian charity than as a jingoistic hate monger."

German sources insist the captain and crew of the English vessel were blacklisted and found it hard to get work for the rest of their lives.

At the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, where the salvaged wreckage will go on display today in the new London gallery, curator John Graves explained the L19 took off with an experienced crew of 16 in a convoy of 10 airships, on February 1, 1916.

It was one of two which lost its bearings, and bombed civilian targets in Wednesbury, in the west Midlands, believing that they were over Liverpool.

Ignominy at sea

Other shameful incidents:

August 19, 1915 Lieutenant Godfrey Herbert of the merchant ship Baralong sank German submarine U-27 and shot 10 survivors in the water. Some of the Germans sought refuge aboard the SS Nicosian, which had been abandoned by its crew. Herbert sent marines aboard the Nicosian who killed the four remaining survivors.

September 24, 1915 HMS Baralong, renamed Wiarda, lured a German submarine U-41 into range and sank the U-boat with gunfire. After the Wiarda left the area two survivors climbed aboard an abandoned lifeboat. About three hours later the Wiarda returned and deliberately ran down the lifeboat.

April 13, 1940 The British navy sank the German ship the Erich Giese. The captain Karl Smidt reported that while the crew of 200 men were in the water, British destroyers opened fire on them.

May 20,1941 A convoy of 21 German ships was attacked by British warships off the coast of Crete during the night. Witnesses said the British ships scanned the sea with searchlights looking for the survivors, and opened fire on them. One survivor, Corporal Walter Segel, said: "I saw at least 20 groups of survivors who were illuminated by the British and then sprayed with bullets."

Laura Milne

The Germans had lost contact with their base at Tondern, and the truth of their deaths might have sunk with them, except for the extraordinary chance that a bottle containing their last messages was washed up on the Swedish coast six months later. The wreckage has been in government and museum stores for most of a century, since the German Zeppelin L19 crashed into the sea with her crew in February 1916, on her maiden flight. There were two notes in the bottle. One, from the captain, Oto Lowe, gave a bleak technical report on their situation, ending: "February 2, towards 1 pm, will apparently be our last hour". The other, from an unnamed crew member, told a dramatic story: "My greetings to my wife and child. An English trawler was here and refused to take us on board. She was the King Stephen and hailed from Grimsby." By the time the bottle was found, a German U-boat had sunk the King Stephen. All the crew were rescued, interned in Germany, and returned safely to England in 1918. The tragedy became a German propaganda sensation, and was taken up in turn by the British media, which applied a radically different spin to the story. It was reported that the unamed English captain feared that since there were more German airmen than he had sailors, his vessel might be hijacked. The bishop of London fanned the flames, by commenting that leaving "the German baby-killers" in the water was understandable. A German newspaper said he had "acted less as an apostle of Christian charity than as a jingoistic hate monger." German sources insist the captain and crew of the English vessel were blacklisted and found it hard to get work for the rest of their lives. At the National Maritime Museum in Greenwich, where the salvaged wreckage will go on display today in the new London gallery, curator John Graves explained the L19 took off with an experienced crew of 16 in a convoy of 10 airships, on February 1, 1916. It was one of two which lost its bearings, and bombed civilian targets in Wednesbury, in the west Midlands, believing that they were over Liverpool. Ignominy at sea Other shameful incidents: August 19, 1915 Lieutenant Godfrey Herbert of the merchant ship Baralong sank German submarine U-27 and shot 10 survivors in the water. Some of the Germans sought refuge aboard the SS Nicosian, which had been abandoned by its crew. Herbert sent marines aboard the Nicosian who killed the four remaining survivors. September 24, 1915 HMS Baralong, renamed Wiarda, lured a German submarine U-41 into range and sank the U-boat with gunfire. After the Wiarda left the area two survivors climbed aboard an abandoned lifeboat. About three hours later the Wiarda returned and deliberately ran down the lifeboat. April 13, 1940 The British navy sank the German ship the Erich Giese. The captain Karl Smidt reported that while the crew of 200 men were in the water, British destroyers opened fire on them. May 20,1941 A convoy of 21 German ships was attacked by British warships off the coast of Crete during the night. Witnesses said the British ships scanned the sea with searchlights looking for the survivors, and opened fire on them. One survivor, Corporal Walter Segel, said: "I saw at least 20 groups of survivors who were illuminated by the British and then sprayed with bullets." Laura Milne

webTitle: Millions of hours wasted waiting for the plumber

fields.headline: Millions of hours wasted waiting for the plumber
fields.trailText: Householders often complain of spending half their lives waiting for plumbers to arrive or new appliances to be delivered.
fields.body:
Householders often complain of spending half their lives waiting for plumbers to arrive or new appliances to be delivered.

A survey has found that they are not far off the mark: British employees spend up to 56m working days a year waiting for goods or repairers.

The study suggests that the average employee wastes two working days a year hanging around at home. Forty-four per cent of delivery staff and repairers turn up late and 40% fail to arrive. Almost 50% of customers are given no clear idea of when to expect someone.

It identifies deliverers of electrical goods and furniture as the worst culprits, with 32% and 16% of customers respectively complaining about their timekeeping.

Cable and satellite TV installers were the most prompt workers, with only 1% of customers griping about delays.

"It is staggering to think that we are still wasting so much time waiting around for delivery and repair companies," said Ambrose McGinn, director of retail e-commerce at Abbey National, which carried out the survey. "People attach high value to time, so it's surprising that today's businesses are not learning lessons about how they can make their customers' lives easier."

The bank's annual survey of business flexibility also suggested that companies were failing to meet demands of a 24 hour a day society. Half of those interviewed wanted to be able to collect prescriptions, visit their GP or use public transport at any time of the day or night, and a third believed that most service providers had not improved their opening times.

Young people and Londoners had the highest expectations of services. More than 60% of 16 - to 24-year-olds believed that banks, doctors and chemists should be open round the clock, while almost 60% of Londoners wanted post offices to be open day and night.

fields.headline: New look at 'Robocop' corruption inquiry
fields.trailText: The meandering course of one of Britain's longest but least productive internal police inquiries is to be reviewed as part of Home Office plans to reform forces' discipline and complaints procedures.
fields.body:
The meandering course of one of Britain's longest but least productive internal police inquiries is to be reviewed as part of Home Office plans to reform forces' discipline and complaints procedures.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, has ordered a detailed investigation of the £5m Operation Lancet into alleged police corruption in north east England and the role of "Robocop" Detective Superinendent Ray Mallon.

A retired chief constable, Sir John Hoddinott, will audit the management of the four-year inquiry, which failed to make any of 393 criminal allegations against officers stick.

The review will also look at the initial suspension of Mr Mallon and 53 other officers in the Cleveland force.

The superintendent was cleared of allegations of abusing police procedure, which led to his suspension soon after he won national headlines and approval from both Conservative and Labour home secretaries for his version of "zero tolerance" policing.

A Home Office spokesman said: "The purpose is to look at how the operation was carried out in order to inform the new complaints procedure we are working on."

Mr Mallon, 44, who has been suspended from duty since December 1997, said yesterday: "I have been calling for some time for a full investigation"

Sir John, 56, is a former chief constable of Hampshire, but made his name during two decades of anti-gang operations in the Metropolitan police, where he also tackled corruption in the force. He helped to set up the national crime squad. Before retiring in 1999 he chaired a number of committees of the Association of Chief Police Officers on ways of tackling police corruption.

fields.headline: Brain damaged boy gets £2.5m damages
fields.trailText: A boy who was left with severe brain damage after he almost drowned in a hotel swimming pool in Majorca has been awarded £2.5m damages.
fields.body:
A boy who was left with severe brain damage after he almost drowned in a hotel swimming pool in Majorca has been awarded £2.5m damages.

Kevin Roberts, then aged six, of Radcliffe, Greater Manchester, was a non-swimmer who was not wearing armbands when he went into the pool on a family holiday almost eight years ago. His parents were only 10ft away but had taken their eyes off him as they were looking after their other child.

The swimming pool at the three-star Jupiter Saturno complex in Alcudia slopes dramatically after a few metres, which could cause difficulties for a non-swimmer. At the time, there was no lifeguard on duty, nor was there poolside resuscitation equipment.

Kevin, now 13, was rescued by a German tourist and was later found by his father in a hotel corridor, not breathing and with his heart stopped. He was revived when a doctor injected adrenalin into his heart.

He was awarded damages by Manchester high court after a judge decided responsibility should be shared between the hotel, tour operator and the boy's parents. The hotel will pay half of the damages and the tour operator Sunworld will pay a third of the costs.

The Package Tour Operators Act makes companies responsible for negligence of subcontractors - in this case the hotel. Lawyers representing Sunworld said the boy's parents should share the blame.

The money will be used to provide round-the-clock care for Kevin, who is unable to walk or speak.

webTitle: Bomb blast cadet tells of ordeal

fields.headline: Bomb blast cadet tells of ordeal
fields.trailText: A 14-year-old described yesterday for the first time how he was blinded and had part of his arm torn off by a terrorist bomb disguised as a torch, but said: "I'm not going to let this ruin my life."
fields.body:
A 14-year-old described yesterday for the first time how he was blinded and had part of his arm torn off by a terrorist bomb disguised as a torch, but said: "I'm not going to let this ruin my life."

The bomb went off when Stephen Menary, a cadet, carried it into the Territorial Army centre in Shepherd's Bush, west London. He repeatedly blacked out as blood poured down his face, he said, and his left arm had "felt dead and smashed to pieces".

Although almost completely blind, he vowed he would recover his eyesight sufficiently to watch his beloved Chelsea win the FA Cup and to learn to drive.

He spoke as he was preparing to leave Chelsea and Westminster hospital for his family's new home in east Acton. Over six weeks he has had five operations. The teenager joked with his mother, Carol, but the pain was etched on his face.

Police had asked him not to speak about finding the bomb, and he cannot remember exactly what happened on February 22.

He did recall the immediate aftermath of a bomb that exploded with such force that half of his left arm was blown off and his face and chest were severely injured.

"It just went off and I was in total shock," he said. "I didn't really know, to start off with, what had happened." The teenager, whose hearing was also damaged, continued: "My arm felt like it was dead, it felt like it was broken, all smashed to pieces.

"My stomach was stinging and sore but my face felt OK. I didn't really notice anything wrong."

"I remember being on a stretcher in the ambulance. There was lots of noise, and people were trying to help me. I was blacking out from time to time, and gradually starting to realise what had happened."

The boy lost the sight in his left eye but had been blind in his right eye before the bomb, after having suffered from cancer as a baby.

He insisted he did not feel anger towards the terrorists. Scotland Yard said it was "keeping an open mind" as to their identities.

"I'm a big lad," he said. "I'm just glad that it wasn't someone smaller, because that would have been worse. I just need to get on with my life now. I want to go back to school, I want to start doing my maths and my English again, I just want things to be back to normal. I know it's not going to be easy, but I'm going to keep trying. I'm not going to let this ruin my life."

The teenager had been so keen to join the TA that he persuaded them to allow him in a year early. He admitted having felt miserable in the three weeks following the attack, but said: "Things are now a lot better."

Even the pain of the operations had had a positive side, he said, since he enjoyed the sensation of being put to sleep by gas.

He can detect some difference between light and dark, but doctors believe it will be two years before they know if he will recover his sight.

Yesterday, however, he was positive. "What I really want now, and my dream, is to see Chelsea win the FA Cup," he said, while joking that another goal was to pass his driving test before his mother.

"She'd be a terrible driver and I'm sure I'll pass the test before she does."

He added: "I'm determined I'll see again.".

webTitle: Letters: our stake in the railways

fields.headline: Our stake in the railways
fields.trailText: With £1.5bn of taxpayers' money going into Railtrack and £3.5bn into Stagecoach (Railtrack says that £1.5bn gift is too little, April 3), we have become unwitting stakeholders - with much at stake but no holding.
fields.body:
With £1.5bn of taxpayers' money going into Railtrack and £3.5bn into Stagecoach (Railtrack says that £1.5bn gift is too little, April 3), we have become unwitting stakeholders - with much at stake but no holding. I don't recall reading anything about how these private companies, not renowned for the quality of their services, will be made accountable for these sums.

Meanwhile, in the public sector where I work, scarcely a month goes by without an accountability exercise or audit of some kind, and this for sums far less than these rail handouts. To get to work to do our accountability exercises, I stumble through London's grubby and wheezing public transport system - the selfsame system for which Gordon Brown will not countenance public ownership, because, we gather, the public sector cannot run it as efficiently as the private sector.

It's time the public had some direct involvement in these companies in exchange for the "welfare handouts" so munificently donated from our earnings. And as we've already stumped up, can we have that now, please, not as manifesto fodder for the next election?
Brian Rosen
London
brian.rosen@which.net

 Those who believe Railtrack should be renationalised are constantly told it would cost too much. Surely the solution is simple. Every pound given to Railtrack should be in exchange for shares. At the rate at which that company asks for our money, it would soon be back in public ownership.
Mike Clutten
Leicester

 Ian Jack (The crash that stopped Britain, G2, April 2 and 3) points to the broken rail caused by cracking, induced at the gauge corner by centrifugal force. This force depends on the train's speed and the radius of the curve. All UK high-speed trains must be capable of running on existing tracks, where the curves are still at a radius chosen for trains running below 100mph.

Most other countries run their high-speed trains on specially constructed tracks with gentler curves. Now trains are contemplated which will run at even higher speeds on existing track. Tilting trains offer a number of benefits, but will not reduce the stress at the gauge corner. Unless we accept that high-speed trains need high-speed tracks, we will continue to overload the track, with predictable results.
Stan Andrew
Hinckley, Leics

 The Hatfield disaster closed the east coast main line for three weeks, a ludicrously long period for which the health and safety executive must take most of the blame, spurred on by a media which puts deaths in rail accidents in a different category to deaths on the roads. At 08.32 last Tuesday, a much more severe rail accident took place on the line between Brussels and Liege, with a head-on collision between two trains, in which eight people died. The Belgian rail authorities had the line open in time for the morning commuter traffic on Thursday, less than 46 hours later. In the days when a principal objective was to keep the trains running, we used to be able to deal with the aftermath of rail accidents in the same way.
Chris Davies MEP
cdavies@europarl.eu.int

 A retired engineer told Ian Jack "the uninspected inevitably deteriorates". My grandfather spent virtually every morning of his working life - except 1914-18 - walking the nine or 10 miles of track from Goole to Thorne in south Yorkshire, and every afternoon checking the sidings at Goole. Unlike many lines since he retired in the 60s, this one is still in use - but I bet there's no modern equivalent of George Burkitt.
Alan Burkitt-Gray
London

fields.headline: Cherie's not to blame
fields.trailText: It is regrettable that Jeanette Winterson (G2, April 3) aims so much of her anger in the case of lesbian teacher Shirley Pearce at Cherie Blair, rather than at Pearce's colleagues, particularly the headteacher.
fields.body:
It is regrettable that Jeanette Winterson (G2, April 3) aims so much of her anger in the case of lesbian teacher Shirley Pearce at Cherie Blair, rather than at Pearce's colleagues, particularly the headteacher.

The law must be changed, but it is deeply worrying that in an education system which is ethically bound to promote equality, tolerance and compassion, such indifference to harassment was allowed to go on for five years. What action has been taken by the governors or Portsmouth education authorities in the light of such appalling absence of care? How many parents have withdrawn their children in protest? If the head is a member of a professional association, have any moves been taken to expel her? Would a bullied pupil have been told to "grit her teeth"?

All these questions are more important than the barrister who represented the school. The ethos of a school derives ultimately from the commitment of its staff and head to the principles enshrined in the policy statements. Education authorities, governors and inspectors must ensure they are implemented in respect of staff as well as pupils.
Rose Galt
Glasgow
rose@kildrum.demon.co.uk

 Cherie Booth was not arguing that sexual orientation is not a human rights issue, but that the prosecution was mistaken to use sexual discrimination legislation in this case. The Sex Discrimination Act protects lesbians just as much as straight women, and blacks and the disabled too for that matter, but it would be just as inappropriate to cite the race discrimination act in this case if the plaintiff happened to be black. It is also not the remit of barristers, however well connected, to argue for new laws to be enacted within the context of individual cases; that is parliament's job.
Philip Marsden
London
phil@philmarsden.fsnet.co.uk

fields.headline: All-women shortlists are the only way
fields.trailText: The inevitable fall in the number of women MPs after the next election (Analysis, April 3) provides a compelling justification for the equal opportunities commission's view that the law must be changed.
fields.body:
The inevitable fall in the number of women MPs after the next election (Analysis, April 3) provides a compelling justification for the equal opportunities commission's view that the law must be changed to enable political parties to boost the numbers of women candidates.

The early findings of research being conducted for the EOC, looking at levels of women's representation in seven countries, demonstrate that the use of special measures - such as all-women shortlists, twinning or zipping - is the single most important factor influencing the numbers of women selected.

If the increase in the number of women MPs in 1997 is not to be seen as a historical blip, and if we do want genuinely representative government, then political parties must be able to use positive action to make women in politics the norm rather than the exception. I hope the Home Office review will make our political leaders realise that legal change is the only way to bring real results.
Julie Mellor
Chair, equal opportunities commission

 Michael White (Comment, March 27) is right to take politicians to task for neglect of the internet, but he underestimates the importance of the email campaign by the US Republican party in the last presidential election. It is widely believed by those connected with the party that its broad and sophisticated use of emails represented not just an ancillary benefit. Jim Nicholson, the party chairman, called it "the key to victory". The Republicans continue to devote significant resources this year despite the absence of any major election.

As an adviser to the company that conducted the Republicans' email campaign, ClickAction, I have followed this with interest. As a lifelong Labour supporter, I have observed the party's plans to continue relying on old technologies, while talking up the role of new technology, with dismay.
David Crook
London

 Sin Simon was not "given" my safe seat of Birmingham Erdington (Diary April 3). He was on a shortlist of four, on which the local party was consulted. He was chosen by members in a secret ballot because he made the best impression.
Robin Corbett MP
