webTitle: Leader: Kostunica must stop shielding Milosevic

fields.headline: A man in a muddle
fields.standfirst:
Kostunica must stop shielding Milosevic

Special report: Serbia
fields.trailText: Mr Kostunica agrees that Slobodan Milosevic must answer for his numerous crimes. But in complaining that the former dictator's arrest last Sunday was clumsily executed, he almost appears to suggest that it should not have been attempted.
fields.body:
Vojislav Kostunica needs to sort his ideas out. The Yugoslav president agrees that Slobodan Milosevic must answer for his numerous crimes, including war crimes. But in complaining that the former dictator's arrest last Sunday was clumsily executed and badly thought out, he almost appears to suggest that it should not have been attempted.

His irritation may partly be explained by the fact that he was not consulted in advance by the Serbian government. But harder to understand is Mr Kostunica's continuing, adamant insistence that Milosevic will "never" face the UN's international tribunal for the Balkans.

The president says he backs draft legislation that would allow all war crimes suspects to be extradited. But he maintains that Milosevic is a special case. The demands of the chief UN prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, that he be handed over are "not legitimate".

Mr Kostunica's confusions do not stop there. He says he favours cooperation with Nato, but attacks K-For troops for not doing enough to curb ethnic Albanian extremism, and suggests Nato's leaders should also be investigated by the Hague over their 1999 Kosovo campaign. He welcomes western aid, but appears to believe this support should be given unconditionally, as if by way of recompense to a victimised Serb nation.

Mr Kostunica portrays the domestic trial of Milosevic as vital to a process of "social catharsis" in Serbia. But in doing so, he seems to oppose a thorough clear-out of Milosevic's cronies and to deny the equal right to justice of all the many non-Serbs who were Milosevic's victims, too.

Mr Kostunica is undoubtedly in a difficult position. He was unexpectedly propelled into power last autumn by a wave of anti-Milosevic revulsion, rather than by some mass endorsement of his personal leadership qualities. As Yugoslav president, his powers are limited, ever more so given Milosevic's success in all but destroying the federation. Indeed, if Montenegro decides to secede later this year, his job will effectively cease to exist.

The election of a reformist Serbian government led by Zoran Djindjic has threatened further to eclipse Mr Kostunica. His recent, dubious attempts to revive Belgrade's ties with Bosnia's Serbs, his use of the Macedonia crisis to highlight the regional threat posed by ethnic Albanian "terrorists", his warnings of catastrophe should Montenegro and Kosovo gain independence, and his repeated bearding of the west and the UN are all actions of a man under pressure.

But Mr Kostunica is a man in a muddle, too, a man whose patriotic, nationalistic reflexes often seem to get the better of his common sense. Serbia cannot afford such self-indulgence any longer. Chauvinism and sentimentality have caused too much damage in the past - and Serbia's past still very much threatens its future. Mr Kostunica's head surely tells him, even if his heart rebels, that Milosevic must face international as well as national justice - for his crimes, as framed by the Hague's indictments, were a universal abomination. The pragmatic course is to seek a compromise as to venue, timing and jurisdiction, leading perhaps to a trial in Belgrade under joint UN-Yugoslav auspices.

Mr Kostunica must surely also know that western help to advance Serbia's economic regeneration is a necessity, not an option. He is not in a position to dictate terms, nor can he responsibly allow continuing arguments over Milosevic's fate to imperil this assistance. And when Mr Kostunica speaks of catharsis, he must surely see that this means catharsis for all. Yugoslavia owes everybody an explanation, not just the Serbs.

fields.headline: Cut it out
fields.trailText: I take exception to the phrase "notorious for his drunken behaviour since coming out as gay in 1995" in your story about the drowned man in Michael Barrymore's pool (Man found in star's pool was uninvited, April 2).
fields.body:
I take exception to the phrase "notorious for his drunken behaviour since coming out as gay in 1995" in your story about the drowned man in Michael Barrymore's pool (Man found in star's pool was uninvited, April 2).

The cuttings will show that Barrymore's behaviour had been in evidence long before he "came out" and was not a result of his "coming out".
Michael Cashman
London

 "Barrymore decided to admit that he was gay" (Tears of a clown, April 3). Admit is to imply weakness or wrongdoing; being gay is neither. Acknowledge, yes; admit, no.
Peter Denton
London

fields.headline: Take away your stereotypes
fields.trailText: Your reporting of the source of the foot and mouth outbreak (Smuggled meat blamed, March 27) perpetuates racist stereotypes of the British Chinese community.
fields.body:
Your reporting of the source of the foot and mouth outbreak (Smuggled meat blamed, March 27) perpetuates racist stereotypes of the British Chinese community: involvement in smuggling, connection with Far Eastern criminal organisations, eating suspicious or bizarre meat.

These 19th-century stereotypes continue to paint the Chinese community as foreigners, criminals, and a corrupting influence. The truth is that we are British. As well as waiters and takeaway owners, our ranks also include doctors, writers, businessmen, lawyers, teachers, nurses and more. We do not eat "cow's nostrils, monkey meat, elephant ... and smoked grubs" (Illegal meat trail leads to infected coun tries, March 28), and no one I know in the community has links to secret Far Eastern sausage-smuggling groups.

Your later report (Chinese restaurants feel the pinch, April 2) is too little, too late. There has been a 40% drop in trade in the intervening six days. If this continues, there will be a knock-on effect on wholesale butchers, since Chinese restaurants obtain all their meat from British suppliers (it's cheaper!), and eventually on the beleaguered British livestock farmer. Needless hardship has been caused by these unsubstantiated stories and stereotypes to thousands of families in the Chinese community.
Jack Tan
Editor, www.dimsum.co.uk

webTitle: World Cup can wait - Sven has an election to win

fields.headline: World Cup can wait - Sven has an election to win
fields.trailText: England's crucial game against Greece is one day before the rescheduled general election. The future of government could rest on the result.
fields.body:
Sven-Goran has enough on his smorgasbord without having to worry about the result of the general election. Or so he thinks.

But yesterday a number of political commentators placed England's crucial World Cup qualifier against Greece on June 6 alongside pensions, interest rates, the unemployment figures and the latest on the hospital waiting list as one of the significant events that could influence the outcome on polling day, which, we assume, will be June 7.

You might, in that rather off-hand way of yours, dismiss this as the ramblings of a lunatic. But remember when Bobby Moore seized the gleaming Jules Rimet at Wembley in 1966?

The PM, Harold Wilson, took so much credit that we could all imagine that he had masterminded the tactics chewing his pipe over a Subbuteo at No10. The real manager, Sir Alf Ramsey, appeared to decline into a monosyllabic sulk.

Four years later Wilson went to the country again, with all the polls predicting another Labour victory. But England lost their World Cup quarter-final against Germany in Mexico, after being in a strolling, 2-0-up position in the second half, and Wilson was thrown out on his ear a few days later.

Tony Blair, a jacket-off sort of a politician, will probably resist the temptation to jostle for a place alongside Sol Campbell in England's back four, or even to bang on to Sven about the possibility of a third way to get round the back of the Greeks.

But even though he would struggle to put a positive spin on an England defeat he is shrewd enough to appreciate the importance of their performance on the eve of his big day.

We might not take football quite as seriously as the man who gunned down the Colombian defender Andres Escobar for scoring an own goal in the 1994 World Cup finals. Remember that? Twenty-four hours later the BBC issued an apology after the pundit Alan Hansen snarled: "The Argentine defender wants shooting for a mistake like that."

But we do take football, and all sport for that matter, very seriously indeed. And the feelgood/bad factor is something the spry politician is well aware of.

The government was fast off its blocks to celebrate last year's Olympic successes in Sydney. And when Ellen MacArthur became the youngest and fastest woman to sail round the world, the greatest single sporting achievement of the past year, she was 10 minutes late for her press conference because of a telephone call from Blair.

No10's Mr Bean, John Major, is a cricket fanatic, though wisely he has been seen supping his pint of warm beer while watching Surrey more than England in recent years.

Twenty years ago, when England so dramatically beat Australia in the Ashes series, a number of Conservative MPs were quick to point out that it was all because of the Tory government. Cricketers, establishment folk, are mostly Tory. And the last time England won an Ashes series, in 1986-87, Maggie Thatcher ruled the Downing Street roost.

We may not consciously blame, or credit, politicians directly for our sporting performances. But subconsciously we do it all the time.

Professor David Collins, the chair of physical education and sporting performance at the University of Edinburgh, told me yesterday: "It would be more appropriate if a government took the credit for victory in sport according to how seriously they funded it.

"However, we have plenty of precedents to show that a sporting success story can give a huge lift to the mood of the nation."

Another sports psychologist, Jack Lamport-Mitchell, who was once employed by the Yorkshire village side Emley before they played West Ham in the FA Cup, said: "It could backfire on the government.

"If England do that well in Athens everyone will be so plastered they will be unable to vote. But we often look to sport at the end of the week, along with our pay packets, to cheer up a humdrum life.

"And when we're really fed up, which everyone is now with the foot and mouth epidemic, the result of a sports fixture can have an even bigger effect on our emotions. The disappointment of defeat could also lower the election turnout."

And Sven-Goran thought he had a headache with Andy Cole...

webTitle: LGA and ministers in rift over care trusts proposals

fields.headline: Bill at breaking point
fields.standfirst: LGA and ministers in rift over care trusts proposals
fields.trailText: LGA and ministers in rift over care trusts proposals
fields.body:
Tension over the balance of power between the NHS and social services in the government's proposed "care trusts" has erupted in a spectacular falling-out between minsters and the Labour-controlled Local Government Association. In a statement this week, the association (LGA) has declared a breakdown in negotiations on the issue, called for the care trust provisions to be taken out of the health and social care bill, and warned of "the end of social care under democratic control".

Sir Jeremy Beecham, LGA chair, says: "We are dismayed that the proposed trusts would be treated as NHS bodies with local councils as junior partners, despite the role of councillors as elected local representatives. This could effectively graft social services on to the NHS, handing over care of some of the most vulnerable members of the community to unelected quangos."

Care trusts are envisaged as joint health and social care bodies, formed by local agreement, although the bill would give ministers power to impose them where services were not running smoothly. As recently as last week, health and social care minister John Hutton was reassuring social services leaders - at a joint Guardian/National Institute for Social Work conference - that they would face no takeover by the NHS.

However, the LGA has failed to get safeguards written into the legislation. It says it has been left with no alternative but to campaign for the deletion of the care trust proposals from the bill. It is claiming the support of a range of organisations, including charities Age Concern, Help the Aged and Leonard Cheshire.

Frances Hasler, of the National Centre for Independent Living, which is also backing the LGA, warns that the current proposals for care trusts will "set back by years" the implementation of a social model of disability.

 Hutton announced at the conference that the government, if re-elected, would go ahead with reform of social work training. From 2003, there would be a three-year degree level qualification, bringing Britain in line with the rest of Europe.

webTitle: Calls for free care for all disabled people

fields.headline: Calls for free care for all disabled people
fields.trailText: Disability charity Leonard Cheshire today launches a national petition calling for free personal - as well as nursing - care for all disabled people. The initiative will raise the profile of the issue during the anticipated general election campaign.
fields.body:
Disability charity Leonard Cheshire today launches a national petition calling for free personal - as well as nursing - care for all disabled people. The initiative will raise the profile of the issue during the anticipated general election campaign.

The petition's launch comes immediately after consultation on Labour's plans to tackle variation in charges for home care. The charity is hoping to force some changes in the plans, due to take effect no later than 12 months hence.

Labour has set its face against free personal care, as recommended by the royal commission on long-term care, although Scotland is going ahead with the concession. Ministers have, however, appeared willing to look again at some of the detail of the planned guidance on home care charges.

John Hutton, social care minister, said last week in the Commons: "I must emphasise that the draft guidance is precisely that", adding that "we may not have all the answers".

An estimated 80,000 disabled people under age 65 in England and Wales receive help from local authority social services departments. An audit commission survey found that charges for similar services could range from nothing to £100 a week, with 30% of councils even charging people on income support.

Together with other welfare groups, Leonard Cheshire is most concerned that the draft guidance on charging proposes to take account of up to 55% of an individual's earnings; to have no cash limit on any charge; to allow the taking into account of benefits such as disability living allowance, intended to help with the extra costs of disability; and to continue to allow the charging of people receiving income support and other income or benefits - provided they are not brought "below the level of income support".

Lord (Alf) Morris, the Labour peer who was Britain's first disability minister, is backing the petition. He says that charging disabled people for home care services could be the difference between life and death - or, at least, hospital admission.

Morris cites the case of Colin Hughes, a disabled BBC producer who in 1999 was threatened with the loss of a government grant for round-the-clock care because his savings were judged too high.

"For people like Colin, this is a tax on breathing," says Morris. "He has to have a carer day and night. If you restrict help in this way, you are sending some people down the road to a scarce and very costly hospital bed."

In a Commons adjournment debate last week, Linda Perham, Labour MP for Ilford North, raised concerns of Leonard Cheshire and other groups. Hutton replied that free personal care for all disabled and elderly people would cost an extra £1bn a year and would "do nothing to improve frontline services". But he stressed that draft charging guidance was not set in stone. On the 55% of earnings rule, in particular, he acknowledged the "many representations" received and urged MPs to appreciate "our willingness to reconsider whether it achieves the removal of disincentives to work".

webTitle: Charities board rebrand seen as green light for more radical changes

fields.headline: Big name game
fields.standfirst: Charities board rebrand seen as green light for more radical changes
fields.trailText: Charities board rebrand seen as green light for more radical changes
fields.body:
From next week, the national lottery charities board will be known as the "community fund". But the change will be much more than cosmetic, as the grant distributor takes the opportunity to fine tune its operation.

It is now seven years since the board opened for business and a good time to reassess what it does, says Lady Brittan, who has chaired the organisation since 1999. A new chief executive needs to be appointed; the last original board member is due to step down; and a new strategic plan has to be drawn up (and consulted on) over the next 12 months.

"The hope is that by renaming ourselves, re-doing our literature and rethinking perhaps some of our operations on the ground, it becomes crystal clear to our community and voluntary groups - and maybe to the general public - exactly what we do," says Brittan.

The inference is that what the board does has until now been less than clear. And it is true that, after six years in which it has disbursed more than £1.8bn to 36,000 groups, it still has to deal with many inquiries and applications that should be going to other grant dis tributors and even lottery operator Camelot. Brittan believes the new title will help end such confusion, as well as being pithier and reflecting more accurately what they do.

"The word 'board' is more fitted to the 19th century than the 21st," she says. "It was an extremely bureaucratic name and didn't really convey that what we do is give money to people."

The new logo of community fund, which will carry the strapline "lottery money making a difference", emerged from a consultation exercise which cost £130,000. Brittan stresses that this represents 0.3% of the board's administration budget, or 0.003% of the total budget. In that context, she says, it is a "minuscule" sum for a name that will "fix us firmly in the family of lottery funders".

Beyond the name change, and the adoption of a "fresh green" corporate identity, there will be adjustments to the board's grants programme. There will be a single main grants stream, instead of two, and a new, simple scheme for groups wanting up to £60,000 will be tested in London, the south-west and Scotland.

From next year, the international grants stream will become continuous - ending the practice of closing dates across the entire programme - and there is to be a new, £8m-a-year kitty for research grants in the field of health and social well-being. Finally, there are plans for a launch in 2002 of a UK-wide initiative that Brittan is prepared to describe only as "a completely different and innovative way of doing things".

The board recently announced that it wished to target grants to groups helping rural communities, in view of the foot and mouth epidemic. Brittan, whose home is in North Yorkshire, says: "We would be irresponsible if we did not see this as something we should be responding to."

However, the board will not be setting aside any special funds for foot and mouth areas. Priority will go to them within the normal grant programme only if usual criteria are met and all other things are equal.

webTitle: Who will be wired up to the web?

fields.headline: Who will be wired up to the web?
fields.trailText: Almost 12,000 homes in six deprived localities are to be given computers and internet access under the government's "wired up communities" initiative.
fields.body:
Almost 12,000 homes in six deprived localities are to be given computers and internet access under the government's "wired up communities" initiative.

The idea has been pioneered in the Kensington district of Liverpool, where more than 400 homes have already been supplied with the technology and a further 1,600 are due to benefit by the summer.

Now the scheme is to be extended to the Carpenters estate in Newham, east London (750 homes and a school); Framlingham in Suffolk (1,500 homes and a school); east Manchester (4,500 homes and all local schools); the Whitebirk estate, Blackburn (2,500 homes and five schools); Alston in Cumbria (1,200 homes, local farms and three schools); and Brampton upon Dearne, south Yorkshire (1,500 homes and laptops for all primary school children).

Under the £10m initiative, training and support will be offered to those receiving equipment.

webTitle: New scheme takes IT training to disadvantaged communities

fields.headline: New scheme takes IT training to disadvantaged communities
fields.standfirst: It's not easy learning new skills - especially when they involve new technology.  Radhika Holmstrsm  on a scheme that is taking IT training right into the heart of disadvantaged communities
fields.trailText: It's not easy learning new skills - especially when they involve new technology. Radhika Holmstrsm on a scheme that is taking IT training right into the heart of disadvantaged communities.
fields.body:
It's around three months ago that Paul Bagnall took his first steps towards computer literacy. "It used to amaze me to see my 10-year-old daughter whizz through and pick things up," he says. "Now I can see what she was doing - and it wasn't difficult. But to go back to college at my age, late 30s, and be in a classroom and realise how out of touch you are would be very, very hard."

Bagnall, who lives on a housing estate in North Tyneside, is typical of the people who are supposed to be getting online in the technological 21st century world - but find that what's on offer, in terms of formal training, just isn't going to work for them.

Everyone knows they need computer skills in today's workplace. "No matter which job you go for now, something has to be done with a computer. I want to work - not necessarily to be a computer whizzkid, but just have the basics."

A multiplicity of government initiatives and taskforces are working on e-government, e-empowerment, e-skills and so on. The "UK online" campaign launched last September was intended to coordinate these, and introduced a new "on-line network of e-learning services", to get people with no knowledge of computers over the first hurdle. The problem is that however much they want to get over that hurdle, any association with educational institutions is going to put some people off.

Rob Cawthron, community development officer for the Newcastle-based Home Housing Association, explains: "On some of the estates where we work, three or four generations have been unemployed. People have been marginalised. There are all sorts of issues about exclusion, underachievement, and learning. Using the standard approach of institutions seemed a bit of a non-starter - if people felt school wasn't for them, what was the point of getting an educational institution to supply training?" In other words, as more people overall become e-familiar, these groups will be excluded further.

Housing associations and others are tackling this in different ways. Home Housing audited the training provision available and found that tenants wanted local, estate-based training, which wasn't necessarily directed towards a qualification. "Lots of people just won't travel very far. We had to offer something flexible - informal learning - where you can just turn up and get used to working with computers as a useful tool rather than something to be afraid of."

One way to get round the problem of fixed institutions - and meet the needs of people like Bagnall - is to use something which literally isn't fixed. Home Housing opted for training based in a "mobile learning centre" - a specially converted van with eight workstations and two trainers on board. The centre started on five estates where, Cawthron says, "if it could work, and be seen to work, it could work anywhere". A year into a three-year access and training programme, the vehicle is now working throughout the north-east, including special sessions for groups such as Asian women, excluded teenagers, and refugees and asylum seekers. It has also worked with homeless young people and with women's refuges.

Alan Shields works for Computer Gym, a separate company which provides the training and the vehicle. Like Cawthron, he treats the project as much more than just a training exercise. In fact "sometimes the computer side takes a bit of a back seat. People come in and have a chat for about five minutes before they actually touch a computer". By far the most important element, he says, is building up trust and fitting into the local community. "At the beginning, it's important to get right down to ground level, pushing leaflets through doors so that people come out and ask what you're doing. You have to make yourself known to people who wouldn't otherwise come - we often attract people by standing outside and having a chat."

However, Shields is just as keen on getting local people across the digital divide. "There's a real shortage of computer skills, especially in the north-east, so it's important that we're giving them not just a community centre, but skills they need. You've got to start showing people what to do and overcoming their lack of confidence. Even if they only spend a couple of minutes, they're really pleased with what they do and decide to come back next week."

Bagnall decided to give it a go. "The Computer Gym vehicle was on the estate where I lived, and I went in, had a look and sat down. It was just a total one-off. I went in full of trepidation, thinking: 'I'm going to make a fool of myself.'

"The staff started by asking me a few questions, I told them I didn't even know how to turn the machine on, and they said, 'We'll start from the basic level, then.' They didn't make me feel stupid. The hardest bit is making sure you go on a regular basis, because the tuition moves at your own pace. You have your own file and move through the programmes, but nobody pushes you through. But you also get a lot of one-to-one which you wouldn't in a classroom situation."

Both Shields and Cawthron are pleased with the number of people who have come back and stuck with the training. They are also pleased both with "hard" results - a good number of trainees have gained formal qualifications, moved on to other courses or found work - and the "softer" one of overall confidence around computers.

Shields adds: "We found the second stage brought in a lot more adults, because we knew how to tackle the communities better. We try to cater to their needs, rather than offer them particular job skills or qualifications - we say, 'Right, you want to do this, let's do it.' One lady was physically shaking at the thought of touching a computer on her first day. Six months later, she'd got a qualification through us, was about to finish a college course and was applying for jobs for the first time in years."

Meanwhile, Paul Bagnell is now looking either at a college-based course or at getting work using his new skills. "From being very wary, pretty scared of making a fool of myself, I reckon I could take someone through the basic course now. And my kids think it's excellent. They come home, go through their homework and can talk to me about it. I can sit down and teach them how to do it."

A van may seem like an unlikely place to start "bridging the digital divide", but it's getting a significant number of people on the first step of the bridge.

webTitle: The changing face of Britain's Arndale centres

fields.headline: Centre shifts
fields.standfirst: Trivial Pursuits aficionados would know that two Yorkshiremen gave bits of their names to create Arndale. But the effect they had on British shopping culture was far from trivial - and the change is still continuing.  Christopher Middleton  reports
fields.trailText: Trivial Pursuits aficionados would know that two Yorkshiremen gave bits of their names to create Arndale. But the effect they had on British shopping culture was far from trivial - and the change is still continuing. Christopher Middleton reports
fields.body:
Take a look at Britain from above, and straight away it becomes clear that, like Kilroy, Arndale was here. Whereas most French towns will have at their heart a cobbled square and town hall, the chances are that your average UK conurbation will have an Arndale centre - or at least a close relative.

That's been the case since 1971 in Wandsworth, south London - until now. For the decision has been taken not just to demolish half the centre and build a 16-screen cinema plus health club, but - more significantly - to give the place a new name: the Wandsworth Shopping Centre.

"We feel the word Arndale has a few too many connotations," says the centre's marketing manager, Yuri Illukumbre. "Even the name Wandsworth is only an interim solution. We are looking at Southside Shopping Centre as a possible final name."

In opting for de-Arndalisation, Wandsworth is following in the footsteps of eight other centres up and down the country. The Arndale at Poole in Dorset, for example, is now called the Dolphin Centre; the Leeds Arndale has become the Crossgates Centre, and the main shopping precinct in the Lancashire town of Nelson has been relaunched as the Admiral.

Most Wandsworth residents agree than the upgrade has not come before time. As far back as 1985, the local newspapers were talking wishfully about "Facelift for the Arndale" and, over the past decade, the grubbiness of its car parks and the sheer unloveliness of its exterior has led to a decline in what its marketing team call the "retail offer".

First, Sainsbury's moved out, then Tesco, then the fruit and veg market, and recent years have seen the influx of so many downmarket shops that it's become hard to buy anything at the centre for over £1.

Now, though, some £50m is to be spent on improving not just the shopping centre but the blocks of high-rises which were built on top of it - and which helped the development qualify for the description "one of London's great architectural disasters" in the local history society's guidebook.

That, maintains the centre's marketing team, is all in the past, and architects Leslie Jones have come up with a scheme that will sweep away the centre's anonymous, grey-clad frontage and replace it with a dramatic blue entrance portal. Meanwhile, talk is of "shopper high-dwell" parts of the centre - as opposed to places where people just sit and have a fag.

No question, then, that in this and other parts of the country the Arndale name is considered well past its sell-by date. However, it wasn't always so. Back in the early 1960s, the arrival of an Arndale was seen as the resurrection of many a moribund town centre.

But who on earth was Arndale? Was he a lord? A construction method? It is a fact known only by property professionals and players of Trivial Pursuit (it's actually one of the questions) that there was not one creator of these centres, but two.

Enter, carrying rolled-up plans, Arnold Hagenbach, a third generation Wakefield bakery magnate, whose parents originally came from Switzerland.

Alongside him is fellow Yorkshireman, Otley-born Sam Chippindale, who started out as a small-time estate agent above a Bradford barber's shop.

Put the "Arn" of Arnold with the "Dale" of Chippindale, and you've got a twin-headed beast that has had more buildings named after it than the Queen Mother. There's even a sundial memorial to Chippindale in the middle of his home-town square.

Of the two partners, Chippindale had the higher profile by far. According to author Oliver Marriott, who wrote a 1968 book called The Property Boom, Chippindale's biggest assets in the eyes of those northern councillors who approved his projects were that he was a straight talker and didn't come from London.

The borough treasurer of Jarrow, on Tyneside, is quoted as saying: "He was a bit blunt and outspoken, and he impressed some of my councillors who were more than a little difficult to impress. He spoke a language we understood." Jarrow became home to the first Arndale (albeit an open-air development) in 1961 - and it still stands today.

The sheer number of Arndales built (18, at the last count) is testimony to the benefits these new centres brought to towns which had previously offered shoppers nothing but rambling, often war-damaged high streets. The pie shop at the Jarrow Arndale, for example, was reported to be the busiest in the entire north-east. And this was in a town which had famously been in serious decline.

"Both Hagenbach and Chippindale had been to the US and seen the growth of shopping malls," says Peter Edwards, of Oxford Brookes University's school of planning. "It was really they who introduced to this country the idea of a shopping centre as somewhere you might go for a day out.

"There's no doubt, too, that Chippindale had a nose for property, for sniffing out undervalued and underused land. Just before the M62 was built, he spotted a large amount of land in Batley that he realised would become accessible from all five Yorkshire cities. At the time, he never got the scheme through, but what's standing there today? An enormous Ikea store. He knew a good opportunity when he saw one."

Nevertheless, while 1960s shopkeepers and developers were rubbing their hands, and shoppers were enjoying being able to get out of the rain, the more aesthetically motivated members of the public were altogether more anti-Arndale.

"There are people today amassing stupendous fortunes by systematically destroying our historic centres," raged architectural writer James Lees-Milne, in 1964. "Eventually, all the buildings of the area - good, bad and indifferent - are replaced with chain stores, supermarkets and blocks of flats devoid of all distinction, and all looking alike."

Back in those days, such criticisms could be dismissed as fuddy-duddy polemic. Now, though, having had 40 years to get used to the idea of shopping centres, the British public wants more from its malls than concrete walls and a water feature. And for those occasions when pulling the whole place down and starting again just isn't an option, a change of name can be a start.

Hence the Bolton Arndale is now Crompton Place, and the Bradford Arndale is now the Kirkgate. Note here the feelgood history factor that is built into these new names: Crompton, the 18th-century industrial giant and inventor of the spin ning mule; Kirkgate, ancient point of access for cross-Pennine travellers.

Mind you, there are some Arndales which are happy with their name, and sticking to it. Even after the massive rebuilding operation to the Manchester Arndale following the 1996 IRA bomb blast, owner Prudential (which bought it from P&O) decided to stick with the name the centre was given at its opening 21 years previously.

Legal & General, owner of the Eastbourne Arndale, East Sussex, toyed with the idea of a name change, but found that when it suggested it to shopper focus groups, it got back a resounding "no". The same went for Luton when, in 1994, the centre got a facelift but the public said it did not want a new name.

"For us, the key was to introduce more light," says Luton Arndale manager Brian McFarland. "When Arndales were originally built, the concept was to make the walkways dark, so as to allow the shops to shine out. We've now introduced a lot more light throughout the centre, and that's been enough. We haven't needed a new name."

In fact, if a centre does re-christen itself, it can often have difficulty shaking off the Arndale tag. "We changed our name in 1989 and have spent a small fortune on rebranding," says Kathy Murdoch, manager of the Crossgates Centre, Leeds. "But to this day, people still call this centre the Arndale."

None of which is enough to persuade the Wandsworth centre's owners to reinstate the name of Arndale. "In its day, this place was the biggest indoor shopping centre in Europe," says Illukumbre. "Because it was built right over the River Wandle, it was considered something of an architectural and engineering achievement.

"The fact is, though, that the Arndale here has served its purpose. It's time to move on."

"Eventually, all the buildings of the area - good, bad and indifferent - are replaced with chain stores, supermarkets and blocks of flats devoid of all distinction, and all looking alike." Back in those days, such criticisms could be dismissed as fuddy-duddy polemic. Now, though, having had 40 years to get used to the idea of shopping centres, the British public wants more from its malls than concrete walls and a water feature. And for those occasions when pulling the whole place down and starting again just isn't an option, a change of name can be a start. Hence the Bolton Arndale is now Crompton Place, and the Bradford Arndale is now the Kirkgate. Note here the feelgood history factor that is built into these new names: Crompton, the 18th-century industrial giant and inventor of the spin ning mule; Kirkgate, ancient point of access for cross-Pennine travellers. Mind you, there are some Arndales which are happy with their name, and sticking to it. Even after the massive rebuilding operation to the Manchester Arndale following the 1996 IRA bomb blast, owner Prudential (which bought it from P&O) decided to stick with the name the centre was given at its opening 21 years previously. Legal & General, owner of the Eastbourne Arndale, East Sussex, toyed with the idea of a name change, but found that when it suggested it to shopper focus groups, it got back a resounding "no". The same went for Luton when, in 1994, the centre got a facelift but the public said it did not want a new name. "For us, the key was to introduce more light," says Luton Arndale manager Brian McFarland. "When Arndales were originally built, the concept was to make the walkways dark, so as to allow the shops to shine out. We've now introduced a lot more light throughout the centre, and that's been enough. We haven't needed a new name." In fact, if a centre does re-christen itself, it can often have difficulty shaking off the Arndale tag. "We changed our name in 1989 and have spent a small fortune on rebranding," says Kathy Murdoch, manager of the Crossgates Centre, Leeds. "But to this day, people still call this centre the Arndale." None of which is enough to persuade the Wandsworth centre's owners to reinstate the name of Arndale. "In its day, this place was the biggest indoor shopping centre in Europe," says Illukumbre. "Because it was built right over the River Wandle, it was considered something of an architectural and engineering achievement. "The fact is, though, that the Arndale here has served its purpose. It's time to move on."

fields.headline: Spotlight on the twilight years
fields.standfirst: Professor Tom Kirkwood, this year's BBC Radio 4 Reith lecturer
fields.trailText: Profile: Professor Tom Kirkwood, this year's BBC Radio 4 Reith lecturer
fields.body:
Life is first boredom, then fear, Philip Larkin famously wrote. Whether wasted or well-used, it drifts into old age, then dribbles into "the only end of age". Tom Kirkwood is as sober-suited as an undertaker, yet he's as optimistic about the elderly as Larkin was glum. He's not a poet; he's a gerontologist, and he is delivering this year's BBC Reith lectures - on ageing.

Larkin's phrase, slightly adapted, has been chosen as the title for the series - The End of Age. But don't rush to turn off Radio 4 tonight when the first lecture is broadcast, because Kirkwood has a thoughtful take on how society regards - and should treat - older people.

There have been astounding increases in life expectancy over the past 150 years, he says; and his thesis is that we still haven't adjusted, as a society, to take account of the potential offered by this longevity.

It might seem that disaffection of the young is the only item of social concern popularly discussed, but elderly people gradually have been getting themselves back on the national agenda. Last year, there was Age Concern's grand, policy-forming forum, Debate of the Age, and the conclusion of the "better government for older people" exercise. Last week, ministers decreed that the NHS must give the elderly the same priority as other age groups.

Now the BBC is giving the Reith platform over to the subject of old age and, in Kirkwood, has selected an academic who has combined several disciplines in a way which makes him unusually well placed to pontificate (though gently is his way) on ageing and the aged.

For the past 18 months, Kirkwood has been head of the gerontology department, and professor of medicine, at Newcastle University - a rare achievement for someone who never trained as a medic. At Cambridge, he studied maths, followed by a PhD in biology in 1983. Just 10 years later, at Manchester, he became Britain's first professor of biological gerontology.

Although he has played a leading role in research into ageing - at 26, he put forward the widely accepted "disposable soma" theory, to explain the how and why of humans growing old - he has a passion for bridging gaps between disciplines, where researchers ought to be cooperating.

"It's crucial that we look at the challenge of ageing in a joined up way," he says. "We've got to consider both scientific and societal changes, because they interact in a huge way."

The good news is that science is telling us we are not programmed to die at any given time. "Once we realise we're not programmed with a specific date of death in our genomes, we see what determines how long we live is the gradual build up of faults in the cells and tissues. If we can find ways of reducing exposure to damage, boosting the natural repair and maintenance systems, there's no reason why we shouldn't extend our health span, and add a significant degree of well-being to the extra years."

So the science is bright, but our social attitudes are dismal. For while more and more of us are surviving longer and longer, "we are, if anything, more negative about old age, because it's lost its status and because we see that there are organisational challenges ahead".

Kirkwood is not one of those academics who refuses to think about the social consequences of his research. Over the years, he has grown increasingly concerned to bridge the policy/practice divide. He has been an adviser on ageing to a string of international organisations. Currently, he is chairing a government "foresight taskforce", identifying the healthcare needs of future retirees.

So where do we start to get rid of ideas about the elderly that are, as he puts it, "outmoded and fatalistic"? Almost anywhere, he says, for so much needs to be done. "We need to recognise that when we think of old people as a burden, by seeing it in this negative way, we make it worse for ourselves. If we under-invest in opportunities for old people to maintain their independence and well-being, we will end up having to foot a heavier bill for social and medical dependency. If we help by restructuring housing, transport and shopping, and focus on education and leisure, we'll see a greater economic participation by the elderly in coming decades."

Several of his thoughts on changes in social and economic policy are familiar, such as the desirability of a flexible retirement. But his dislike of our present "archaic, 19th-century idea" of a fixed retirement age may seem unusual, coming from a scientist.

Then again, Kirkwood has a social conscience and a sociologist's powers of observation. That sheltered housing in the Lancashire village where he once lived: rebuilt, with the best of intentions, half a mile from the centre - isolating its residents. Bad planning. The struggle he had to find an uncomplicated mobile phone for his mother. Bad design.

As well as the high-level international interchanges with experts, the everyday feeds into his thinking. Take our obsession with youth and beauty. How strange, he says, that the old who go to lengths to maintain a youthful appearance are held up as icons. And he adds: "I personally find that an older face, with its lines and wrinkles, is extremely beautiful and interesting."

Kirkwood, 50 this year, is fascinated to observe the ageing of his own mind and body. He hopes to be productive long into old age, but - a question everyone asks a gerontologist - he does not expect to live unusually long. However, he knows how to enjoy his span. He recently started piano lessons, which he says he is enjoying greatly. Maybe the ability to surprise oneself, at any age, is a telling piece of Reithian wisdom.

The Reith lectures start on BBC Radio 4 tonight at 8pm. They continue at the same time each Wednesday until May 2.

webTitle: Malcolm Dean: Left agenda is the new right

fields.headline: Left agenda is the new right
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: Manifesto time approaches. Inside the Downing Street policy unit, members have been hard at work exploring themes and policies for months. Outsiders have been invited to address insiders on the key issues for a second term.
fields.body:
Manifesto time approaches. Inside the Downing Street policy unit, members have been hard at work exploring themes and policies for months. Outsiders have been invited to address insiders on the key issues for a second term. Pressure groups have been publishing their policy positions. The Tories, who have gone through several drafts, were reported last week to have ditched their latest effort because the photos were too glum, but kept David "Two Brains" Willetts's words.

The good news for progressives is that the zeitgeist remains with the left. Ideas are tumbling from left-leaning groups, while the right's remain stale, repetitious and sour. Compare the negative response of Willetts, the most intelligent Tory analyst, to the Guardian's two-day special on public services with the Labour and Liberal Democrat contributions.

Another heartening thought is that Thatcher's social policy revolution (good and bad) only began in the third term - and then much of it on the hoof. Internal purchaser/provider markets - in health, education and social services - only began after the 1987 election. So did compulsory competitive tendering in essential local government services. Ditto opted-out schools, housing action trusts, and Griffiths's community care plan. It was not until 1988 top rate tax was cut from 60% to 40%.

Remember, too, though Thatcher's squeeze on public expenditure and her frequent disparagement of public services led to dilapidation and a damaging loss of morale, she only rolled back the welfare state on two fronts: housing and pensions.

Against this background, a second term for Labour ought to be a sweet period for progressives. The only radical element in Labour's last manifesto was its modesty. But Labour has changed tack. Two comprehensive spending reviews are putting public spending back on track. Last November, Tony Blair turned this into a virtue. Even more significantly, the Tories tucked in behind, no longer labelling record increases for health and education "irresponsible", but promising to match them.

The three leading think tanks - the Institute for Public Policy Research, Fabian Society, and Child Poverty Action Group - have all rightly placed reducing the UK's gross inequalities as a first priority. Public spending may have been restored to respectability, but not redistribution yet.

Moreover, spending - still below the GDP levels set by Wilson, Heath and Thatcher - will have to be lifted further if public service standards are to be raised. This is where last year's Fabian report on taxation takes its bow. Turning the anti-tax tide is the next challenge.

webTitle: National petition calls for free care for all disabled people

fields.headline: Personal is political
fields.standfirst: National petition calls for free care for all disabled people
fields.trailText: National petition calls for free care for all disabled people
fields.body:
Disability charity Leonard Cheshire today launches a national petition calling for free personal - as well as nursing - care for all disabled people. The initiative will raise the profile of the issue during the anticipated general election campaign.

The petition's launch comes immediately after consultation on Labour's plans to tackle variation in charges for home care. The charity is hoping to force some changes in the plans, due to take effect no later than 12 months hence.

Labour has set its face against free personal care, as recommended by the royal commission on long-term care, although Scotland is going ahead with the concession. Ministers have, however, appeared willing to look again at some of the detail of the planned guidance on home care charges.

John Hutton, social care minister, said last week in the Commons: "I must emphasise that the draft guidance is precisely that", adding that "we may not have all the answers".

An estimated 80,000 disabled people under age 65 in England and Wales receive help from local authority social services departments. An audit commission survey found that charges for similar services could range from nothing to £100 a week, with 30% of councils even charging people on income support.

Together with other welfare groups, Leonard Cheshire is most concerned that the draft guidance on charging proposes to take account of up to 55% of an individual's earnings; to have no cash limit on any charge; to allow the taking into account of benefits such as disability living allowance, intended to help with the extra costs of disability; and to continue to allow the charging of people receiving income support and other income or benefits - provided they are not brought "below the level of income support".

Lord (Alf) Morris, the Labour peer who was Britain's first disability minister, is backing the petition. He says that charging disabled people for home care services could be the difference between life and death - or, at least, hospital admission.

Morris cites the case of Colin Hughes, a disabled BBC producer who in 1999 was threatened with the loss of a government grant for round-the-clock care because his savings were judged too high.

"For people like Colin, this is a tax on breathing," says Morris. "He has to have a carer day and night. If you restrict help in this way, you are sending some people down the road to a scarce and very costly hospital bed."

In a Commons adjournment debate last week, Linda Perham, Labour MP for Ilford North, raised concerns of Leonard Cheshire and other groups. Hutton replied that free personal care for all disabled and elderly people would cost an extra £1bn a year and would "do nothing to improve frontline services". But he stressed that draft charging guidance was not set in stone. On the 55% of earnings rule, in particular, he acknowledged the "many representations" received and urged MPs to appreciate "our willingness to reconsider whether it achieves the removal of disincentives to work".

webTitle: Minister backs primary care ideas to end outpatients

fields.headline: Break with tradition
fields.standfirst: Minister backs primary care ideas to end outpatients
fields.trailText: Minister backs primary care ideas to end outpatients
fields.body:
Millions of patients should get specialist treatment from GPs, nurses, therapists and pharmacists rather than face long waits to see hospital consultants in often chaotic outpatient departments, according to the NHS Confederation. Indeed, the body representing health authorities and trusts is urging "an end" to traditional outpatient services.

The call comes with the launch this week in England of more than 100 primary care trusts with the power both to commission and provide health services. The confederation says this is an ideal opportunity to re-examine the way care is organised and delivered.

Significantly, the ideas are being endorsed by Alan Milburn, health secretary. He says: "The NHS must continually ask itself whether it can do things better. This is a demonstration that it can."

More than 12m people make a total of 43m outpatient visits annually - most referred by GPs, but an increasing number sent by consultants within the same hospital. In a report, Modernising Outpatients, the confederation argues that simply providing more money and staff will not solve problems caused by poorly managed clinics, overbooked appointments and patients not turning up. It commends pioneering moves in areas such as Berkshire and Bradford, where GPs and others in primary care have stopped "tossing the problem over the fence" to hospital-based specialists.

Nigel Edwards, the confederation's head of policy and author of the report, proposes a range of alternative services, some provided by new clinics providing "one-stop" diagnosis, treatment and multidisciplinary care. Staff might include consultants who would traditionally work in hospitals, or GPs with special interests - perhaps undertaking endoscopic examinations to view internal organs or carrying out skin treatments and minor surgical procedures.

Consultants and other health professionals could also liaise better electronically to determine whether referrals to clinics were strictly necessary. The report cites evidence from the Department of Health's national patients access team, suggesting that between 30% and 70% of work in outpatients adds no value for the individual. Edwards says: "We are short of consultants, we are short of GPs and we need to make the best use of what we have got."

Wokingham primary care group, in Berkshire, has been developing systems for joint analysis of referrals by professionals across the primary/secondary care divide. The report says this is improving the quality of referral decisions, facilitating integrated "care pathways" and making a case for primary care ownership of waiting lists.

Bradford South and West primary care trust has meanwhile been building a "specialist GP" scheme, addressing longstanding problems in key clinical areas. By agreement, GPs are closely integrated with secondary care teams in provision of services such as endoscopy. A next step, says the report, is for other primary care professionals to become specialists in the same way.

Stephen Thornton, the confeder ation's chief executive, says such radical measures are inescapable. Investing more in existing outpatient clinics, or switching their location, will not of itself deliver shorter waiting lists or fashion a more patient focused service.

In fact, the report warns that expanding outpatient capacity - the single factor upon which the government's NHS plan is said to place most weight - may make existing problems worse. "The way outpatient services are run, and the relationship with primary care, is the product of the 1930s and represents the British tradition of queuing," says Thornton. "We now need to make a leap of imagination."

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: letters
fields.body:
Site less costly

You note that council tax is "massively unpopular [and] hugely expensive to collect" (Heavy duty, March 28). Brian Briscoe, of the Local Government Association, accepts that "property taxes are always more difficult to collect". There is a better option for local taxation: taxing the value of land, whether it lies beneath property or is undeveloped.

This has the advantage of being far cheaper to collect than property taxes. While the occupiers of a property may change regularly, and be hard to track down, the ownership of land is a matter of public record. And if undeveloped land is taxed at the same rate as developed, then this acts as an incentive for development and better use of brownfield sites.

Liverpool council has passed a motion asking the Department of the Environment to allow it to pilot site value rating, one method of taxing local land values. Surely now is an opportune time for other councils to follow suit.

Jon Mendel
Leamington Spa

 The council tax system has always been an unfair and anomalous way of collecting local taxes and, particularly in recent years, the demands have risen way ahead of take-home pay. This is why non-collection of tax is rising and so many more people receive housing benefit.

I have lived in the same three-bedroom house for 32 years and remember a time (not too dim and distant) when council tax plus water rates equalled one week of my net wage. The demand for 2001-02 means I shall have to work almost five weeks to cover the cost of council tax and a total of six weeks to pay for both council tax and water rates.

Politicians would be wise to remember that the public is now more widely travelled and can make comparisons with other countries. When I retire, I am seriously thinking of going to live in a warmer climate (Spain or Cyprus maybe) where petrol tax, prescriptions, dental treatment etc are cheaper and local taxes are around £100 a year - leaving ample room for necessary insurance cover.

Brenda Eagles
Doncaster

Sweet harmony

Chris Arnot should take a closer look at the carillon-topped building on Bournville village green (Poetic justice, March 28). It's the local primary school, not a church.

It was a wonderful place for its pupils, of whom I was one in the 1950s and early 60s, and it had very strong associations with the chocolate factory. We had Christmas entertainment in the factory theatre, learned to swim in the "Girls'" (ie women's) baths, and had our sports day on the factory sports ground.

In our final term before we left the school, we were escorted up the carillon tower to hear and see it in action, and then taken on a tour of the chocolate factory. The smell of chocolate is enough to bring all the memories flooding back.

Judith Eversley
Bath

 It is interesting to reflect on the position of the "poor" who are still being housed by the Bournville Village Trust.

Alan Shrimpton, the trust's estates director, states that the vast majority of incoming tenants are on housing benefit, but omits to mention that social housing tenants provide the greater sum of money needed to maintain the "green and pleasant land".

Figures for the year ending December 1999 reveal that the trust's costs for estate maintenance and management were £1.4m. Income from sources other than housing amounted to just £864,838. The balance is funded from the rent paid by social housing tenants.

The tenants have argued, without success, for clear separation to be established between social housing finance and the other business activities of the trust, including the management of the estate.

The developing situation is that an increasing proportion of the rent surplus is being derived from housing benefit, so that the state - and tenants on modest incomes, often pensioners, who do not qualify for benefit - are subsidising the estate.

The final twist in the tale is that the maintenance charge to freeholders, based upon a formula determined by the high court, is in the order of £60 a year. This is close to one week's rent for many of the trust's tenants.

I wonder what George Cadbury and Dylan Thomas would make of this situation?

Cyril Bezant
Birmingham

Release muddle

Amid all the concern about the regime at Feltham and other young offenders' institutions, I have come across a worrying matter concerning a 12-year-old in custody.

This boy is serving an 18-month detention and training order, the first half of which is spent in custody and the other half under supervision in the community. The boy has been serving the custodial sentence in local authority secure accommodation.

He and his social worker were told from the start that his release date was March 1 and all his preparations were based on that date. However, come March 1, with his social worker at the gate to collect him, he was told that a mistake had been made and he had a further month to serve. Apparently there had been confusion as to whether a month on remand should be included in calculating his nine months in custody. It had been included, mistakenly it seems.

It is known that prisoners often go through a variety of acute emotions prior to release. The psychological damage to a 12-year-old boy - in care, with both parents missing - could be considerable.

My role was to organise a family group conference. I expected to see the wrong corrected, but my faith in the system was misplaced.

Andrew Papworth
London

fields.bodyText: Site less costly You note that council tax is "massively unpopular [and] hugely expensive to collect" (Heavy duty, March 28). Brian Briscoe, of the Local Government Association, accepts that "property taxes are always more difficult to collect". There is a better option for local taxation: taxing the value of land, whether it lies beneath property or is undeveloped. This has the advantage of being far cheaper to collect than property taxes. While the occupiers of a property may change regularly, and be hard to track down, the ownership of land is a matter of public record. And if undeveloped land is taxed at the same rate as developed, then this acts as an incentive for development and better use of brownfield sites. Liverpool council has passed a motion asking the Department of the Environment to allow it to pilot site value rating, one method of taxing local land values. Surely now is an opportune time for other councils to follow suit. Jon Mendel Leamington Spa  The council tax system has always been an unfair and anomalous way of collecting local taxes and, particularly in recent years, the demands have risen way ahead of take-home pay. This is why non-collection of tax is rising and so many more people receive housing benefit. I have lived in the same three-bedroom house for 32 years and remember a time (not too dim and distant) when council tax plus water rates equalled one week of my net wage. The demand for 2001-02 means I shall have to work almost five weeks to cover the cost of council tax and a total of six weeks to pay for both council tax and water rates. Politicians would be wise to remember that the public is now more widely travelled and can make comparisons with other countries. When I retire, I am seriously thinking of going to live in a warmer climate (Spain or Cyprus maybe) where petrol tax, prescriptions, dental treatment etc are cheaper and local taxes are around £100 a year - leaving ample room for necessary insurance cover. webTitle: New scheme takes IT training to disadvantaged communities

fields.headline: Upwardly mobile
fields.standfirst: It's not easy learning new skills - especially when they involve new technology.  Radhika Holmstrsm  on a scheme that is taking IT training right into the heart of disadvantaged communities
fields.trailText: It's not easy learning new skills - especially when they involve new technology. Radhika Holmstrsm on a scheme that is taking IT training right into the heart of disadvantaged communities
fields.body:
It's around three months ago that Paul Bagnall took his first steps towards computer literacy. "It used to amaze me to see my 10-year-old daughter whizz through and pick things up," he says. "Now I can see what she was doing - and it wasn't difficult. But to go back to college at my age, late 30s, and be in a classroom and realise how out of touch you are would be very, very hard."

Bagnall, who lives on a housing estate in North Tyneside, is typical of the people who are supposed to be getting online in the technological 21st century world - but find that what's on offer, in terms of formal training, just isn't going to work for them.

Everyone knows they need computer skills in today's workplace. "No matter which job you go for now, something has to be done with a computer. I want to work - not necessarily to be a computer whizzkid, but just have the basics."

A multiplicity of government initiatives and taskforces are working on e-government, e-empowerment, e-skills and so on. The "UK online" campaign launched last September was intended to coordinate these, and introduced a new "on-line network of e-learning services", to get people with no knowledge of computers over the first hurdle. The problem is that however much they want to get over that hurdle, any association with educational institutions is going to put some people off.

Rob Cawthron, community development officer for the Newcastle-based Home Housing Association, explains: "On some of the estates where we work, three or four generations have been unemployed. People have been marginalised. There are all sorts of issues about exclusion, underachievement, and learning. Using the standard approach of institutions seemed a bit of a non-starter - if people felt school wasn't for them, what was the point of getting an educational institution to supply training?" In other words, as more people overall become e-familiar, these groups will be excluded further.

Housing associations and others are tackling this in different ways. Home Housing audited the training provision available and found that tenants wanted local, estate-based training, which wasn't necessarily directed towards a qualification. "Lots of people just won't travel very far. We had to offer something flexible - informal learning - where you can just turn up and get used to working with computers as a useful tool rather than something to be afraid of."

One way to get round the problem of fixed institutions - and meet the needs of people like Bagnall - is to use something which literally isn't fixed. Home Housing opted for training based in a "mobile learning centre" - a specially converted van with eight workstations and two trainers on board. The centre started on five estates where, Cawthron says, "if it could work, and be seen to work, it could work anywhere". A year into a three-year access and training programme, the vehicle is now working throughout the north-east, including special sessions for groups such as Asian women, excluded teenagers, and refugees and asylum seekers. It has also worked with homeless young people and with women's refuges.

Alan Shields works for Computer Gym, a separate company which provides the training and the vehicle. Like Cawthron, he treats the project as much more than just a training exercise. In fact "sometimes the computer side takes a bit of a back seat. People come in and have a chat for about five minutes before they actually touch a computer". By far the most important element, he says, is building up trust and fitting into the local community. "At the beginning, it's important to get right down to ground level, pushing leaflets through doors so that people come out and ask what you're doing. You have to make yourself known to people who wouldn't otherwise come - we often attract people by standing outside and having a chat."

However, Shields is just as keen on getting local people across the digital divide. "There's a real shortage of computer skills, especially in the north-east, so it's important that we're giving them not just a community centre, but skills they need. You've got to start showing people what to do and overcoming their lack of confidence. Even if they only spend a couple of minutes, they're really pleased with what they do and decide to come back next week."

Bagnall decided to give it a go. "The Computer Gym vehicle was on the estate where I lived, and I went in, had a look and sat down. It was just a total one-off. I went in full of trepidation, thinking: 'I'm going to make a fool of myself.'

"The staff started by asking me a few questions, I told them I didn't even know how to turn the machine on, and they said, 'We'll start from the basic level, then.' They didn't make me feel stupid. The hardest bit is making sure you go on a regular basis, because the tuition moves at your own pace. You have your own file and move through the programmes, but nobody pushes you through. But you also get a lot of one-to-one which you wouldn't in a classroom situation."

Both Shields and Cawthron are pleased with the number of people who have come back and stuck with the training. They are also pleased both with "hard" results - a good number of trainees have gained formal qualifications, moved on to other courses or found work - and the "softer" one of overall confidence around computers.

Shields adds: "We found the second stage brought in a lot more adults, because we knew how to tackle the communities better. We try to cater to their needs, rather than offer them particular job skills or qualifications - we say, 'Right, you want to do this, let's do it.' One lady was physically shaking at the thought of touching a computer on her first day. Six months later, she'd got a qualification through us, was about to finish a college course and was applying for jobs for the first time in years."

Meanwhile, Paul Bagnell is now looking either at a college-based course or at getting work using his new skills. "From being very wary, pretty scared of making a fool of myself, I reckon I could take someone through the basic course now. And my kids think it's excellent. They come home, go through their homework and can talk to me about it. I can sit down and teach them how to do it."

A van may seem like an unlikely place to start "bridging the digital divide", but it's getting a significant number of people on the first step of the bridge.

Who will be wired up to the web?

Almost 12,000 homes in six deprived localities are to be given computers and internet access under the government's "wired up communities" initiative.

The idea has been pioneered in the Kensington district of Liverpool, where more than 400 homes have already been supplied with the technology and a further 1,600 are due to benefit by the summer.

Now the scheme is to be extended to the Carpenters estate in Newham, east London (750 homes and a school); Framlingham in Suffolk (1,500 homes and a school); east Manchester (4,500 homes and all local schools); the Whitebirk estate, Blackburn (2,500 homes and five schools); Alston in Cumbria (1,200 homes, local farms and three schools); and Brampton upon Dearne, south Yorkshire (1,500 homes and laptops for all primary school children).

Under the £10m initiative, training and support will be offered to those receiving equipment.

webTitle: Could foot and mouth allow us to rethink sheep farming?

fields.headline: An end to woolly thinking
fields.standfirst: Could foot and mouth allow us to rethink sheep farming?
fields.trailText: Could foot and mouth allow us to rethink sheep farming?
fields.body:
It seems insensitive to talk of silver linings when the clouds in question are winter floods and foot and mouth disease - but there are some, and they start in the hills and valleys which have been most affected in the past six months.

The flooding has led us to revise the way we see the role of rural river valleys. Reedbeds, water meadows, bogs, lakes and marshes seem likely to be welcomed back as natural safety valves: ideal for stopping stormwater engulfing downstream homes and high streets. More broadleaved woodland on the upland slopes can also play a positive role in flood control. About a quarter of the rain that falls on outstretched leaves and branches evaporates. The rest drips slowly to the ground and soaks into the spongy leaf mould of the woodland floor, reducing run-off, soil erosion and the risk of flooding.

So what has all this got to do with foot and mouth? The answer lies with sheep, and our treeless upland landscape can be largely blamed on them. One conservationist I know calls them "woolly maggots", and in many landscapes that's a pretty apt description. In moderation, sheep maintain a rich mosaic of different habitats - but the days of moderation disappeared a long, long time ago. For many years, the various forms of hill farm subsidy have tended to encourage serious overgrazing. So many sheep now roam the hills that ecological diversity is destroyed, soils erode for lack of vegetation, and there isn't a hope in hell of tree seedlings surviving.

In the Welsh mountains, the Scottish glens, the Lakeland fells, the Shropshire hills and the cloughs and gulleys that run off the heather moorlands of the Dark Peak, Devon, Cornwall and the northern Pennines, the only native trees that still survive tend to be very old, and inaccessible. Each blade of grass and germinating tree seedling is inevitably grazed to death.

Saddest of all are the old oak woods that still survive on some fellsides and mountain slopes. Their veteran trees may well be centuries old, but there are almost never any saplings following on, no undergrowth, few woodland flowers or butterflies and hardly any songbirds. In a few exceptional cases, where a conservation charity or the forestry commission has invested heavily in sheep-proof fencing, you can see just how dramatically these sleeping beauties can come back to life. Keep out the sheep, and lifeless woods begin to sprout and grow and flower within a single season.

Now, due in part to foot and mouth, we may have a chance to change our approach to sheep farming. It's time to use the national flock more wisely. There is no doubt that sheep can be a powerful tool for keeping landscapes free from trees, and in some of our uplands that may well be what we want. By contrast, in the drinking water gathering grounds we should be striving to stop soil erosion and to filter out pollution through the greater use of native broadleaved woodland. Here, it is difficult to see why we should bring the sheep back after foot and mouth.

We need to use our sheep much more creatively. With care, they can help us to restore a rich diversity of landscape, and in this task the hefted flocks are vital. These are extended families of local sheep, and they are quite extraordinary: anational treasure which may be lost if Maff continues with its policy of supporting wholesale slaughter.

Hefted flocks have inbred knowledge of their own mountain, built up over countless generations. The old "weathers" can lead the flock to safety when the snow clouds gather. They know where the natural salt licks are; which patch of green will have the most medicinal herbs. In other words, a hefted flock is intimately tuned in to its own hereditary landscape. In any future model of sustainable upland management, these sheep must surely have a vital role to play, but definitely not in such abundance.

Hill farmers need to make a living from their flocks without resorting to the overgrazing that has wiped out so much of the subtle detail in our upland landscapes over recent years. We need to find a way of giving farmers back their dignity, by paying them for skillful land and livestock management, and even in landscapes where we favour trees instead of sheep there will still be a need for sensitive, lasting care.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: environment news
fields.body:
GM doubt

The government has appointed Martin Doughty, one of its regional favourites, as chair of English Nature - and the former chair of the Peak District National Park and leader of Derbyshire county council has a good record as a countryside fighter. He may have to modify his views on GM, however. The council, under his leadership, was quick to sign up to the five-year GM freeze campaign, and Doughty himself called for a moratorium on the growing of genetically engineered crops for commercial purposes because "not enough is known about the potential long-term effects on people's health from eating genetically modified foods, so it is sensible for us to adopt a precautionary approach". English Nature also has reservations about GM, but has gone very quiet on the massive new programme of farmscale testing now getting under way.

Farmed out

With English and Welsh agriculture ministers overwhelmed by foot and mouth, Scotland's first minister, Henry McLeish, could not have chosen a worse time to abolish the country's environment department and to make most green issues the responsibility of his beleaguered farming minister, Ross Finnie. The shake-up was precipitated by the resignation, on health grounds, of environment minister Sam Galbraith, whose first action on taking office last year was to turn down an application by Lafarge Redland for a controversial superquarry that would have destroyed much of the remote Hebridean island of Harris. But conservationists fear the lack of a separate environment ministry will be bad news for renewable energy, recycling, coastal water quality and other areas where, they complain, Scotland's record is already poor. If the the quarry company appeals, as expected, then Finnie's green credentials will be put to the test.

Mersey beat

Eco Soundings' barmy council of the week award goes to Wirral council, which - against the advice and opinion of the Ramblers' Association and more than 40 local community, civic, heritage, environmental, sports and other organisations on Merseyside, representing more than 100,000 people - wants to stop public access to the historic waterfront. So who will have access to one of the most evocative views of the Mersey? Why, only lorry drivers and freight terminal workers.
