The shake-up was precipitated by the resignation, on health grounds, of environment minister Sam Galbraith, whose first action on taking office last year was to turn down an application by Lafarge Redland for a controversial superquarry that would have destroyed much of the remote Hebridean island of Harris. But conservationists fear the lack of a separate environment ministry will be bad news for renewable energy, recycling, coastal water quality and other areas where, they complain, Scotland's record is already poor. If the the quarry company appeals, as expected, then Finnie's green credentials will be put to the test. Mersey beat Eco Soundings' barmy council of the week award goes to Wirral council, which - against the advice and opinion of the Ramblers' Association and more than 40 local community, civic, heritage, environmental, sports and other organisations on Merseyside, representing more than 100,000 people - wants to stop public access to the historic waterfront. So who will have access to one of the most evocative views of the Mersey? Why, only lorry drivers and freight terminal workers.

webTitle: India's treatment of foot and mouth

fields.headline: Unholy mess
fields.standfirst: Britain should take lessons from India on how to deal with the problem of foot and mouth disease, argues  Vandana Shiva
fields.trailText: Britain should take lessons from India on how to deal with the problem of foot and mouth disease, argues Vandana Shiva
fields.body:
In Britain, we see the army mobilised to kill a million or more farm animals and bury them in mass graves merely because of a suspicion that they might be carrying a disease that is neither fatal to humans nor animals. In India, the cow is held sacred, and from my philosophical and religious perspective, parallels can be drawn with ethnic cleansing in Serbia and the blowing up of the Bamiyan Buddhas by the Taliban in Afghanistan. This war against farm animals reflects the insanity of those who promote globalised, industrialised food systems which create, promote and spread disease, but who simultaneously want a "disease free national herd".

This zero tolerance for disease has led to a zero tolerance for animals. Farm animals and farmers have been made the "endemic" enemy. The countryside has been turned into a war zone. Just as the silent Buddhas had to be demolished for a false sense of security and pride by the Taliban, so our hoofed neighbours are being slaughtered and burnt for a false sense of security and safety by the British government. Animals are killed on the basis of unjustified exaggeration of the impact of foot and mouth disease, which has been called a "fearful plague", "a demon", "a serial killer" and a predator at large.

But, as we know, FMD is actually quite harmless, though highly contagious. It does not harm humans, and it only rarely kills animals. The virus takes a toll on productivity, but not generally of life. The disease lowers milk production and reduces the working ability of animals. In a month they recover. Animals can, however, die of other diseases like haemorrhagic septicaemia when their immunity has been lowered by FMD. In India, 400 animals have died in the past couple of months not of FMD but haemorrhagic septicaemia, which infects the throat and blocks the respiratory tract.

FMD is endemic to India, and used to be in Europe. It has been traditionally treated through indigenous veterinary medicine. Vaccines are also available and have been used. Nowhere in the world have entire herds been exterminated.

In India, we hold cattle sacred, because without them we could not renew our soil fertility.

Ecologically, the cow has been central to Indian civilisation. Both materially and conceptually, Indian agriculture has built its sustainability on maintaining the integrity of the cow, considering her inviolable and sacred, seeing her as the mother of the prosperity of food systems.

The integration of livestock with farming has been the secret of sustainable agriculture. Livestock perform a critical function in the food chain by converting organic matter into a form that can be easily used by plants. Can you imagine a British agricultural minister saying, as KM Munshi, India's first agriculture minister after independence, did: "The mother cow and the Nandi are not worshipped in vain. They are the primeval agents who enrich the soil -nature's great land transformers - who supply organic matter which, after treatment, becomes nutrient matter of the greatest importance. In India, tradition, religious sentiment and economic needs have tried to maintain a cattle population large enough to maintain the cycle, only if we know it."

The sanctity of the cow as a source of prosperity in agriculture was linked to the need for conserving its integration with crop production. By using crop wastes and uncultivated land, indigenous cattle do not compete with man for food; rather, they provide organic fertiliser for fields and thus enhance food productivity. Within the sacredness of the cow therefore, lies this ecological rationale and conservation imperative.

There are three aspects to the reaction of the FMD epidemic that make me terribly uneasy.

First, while it is clear that globalisation of trade and increased movement of animals has spread the disease, the UK government continues to support increased liberalisation of agricultural trade in the World Trade Organisation. The half million livestock being killed are a ritual sacrifice to the gods of global markets. Shutting the countryside down while keeping borders open to trade will not prevent spread of disease - either coming in through imports or going out through exports.

Second, the export obsession that is an intrinsic part of globalisation also leads to a blindness to the welfare of animals and farmers. Thousands of livestock can be annihilated, hundreds of farmers ruined to maintain the "vaccine free" status of exports. Neither the farmers nor farm animals count in the calculus of free trade. That is why farmers are committing suicide in thousands in India, and animals are being killed in thousands in the UK.

Third, the same agencies that refuse to act in the public interest on issues of food safety related to GMOs are willing to cull farm animals infected by a non-fatal disease.

These are double standards. On the basis of the precautionary principle, the UK government should ban GMOs instead of killing harmless animals if it is concerned about safety of food and agriculture.

The crisis in the UK should make us all think more seriously about globalisation of food and agriculture. We need to explore what is the most reliable way to produce safe food, protect human and animal health, build immunity and resilience in our farming. The crisis needs a systems response, not military operations.

The problem is not the occurrence of disease and infection, but vulnerability to it. The very idea of disease-free animals and disease-free people fuels the appetite for genetic engineering. It decreases our levels of tolerance and resilience. It breeds fear, anxiety and paranoia - the kind of fear that is moving the military might of Britain to declare a war against its hoofed inhabitants.

This paranoia suits the genetic engineering industry perfectly. By exterminating farm animals, the option of small organic farms is eroded. By creating a fear of disease, a new market is created for Dolly, and Polly and Tracy and all their clones.

We should stop this war against farm animals. Without them we will never be able to build a sustainable farming future.

Dr Vandana Shiva, a physicist and ecologist, has in India established Navdanya, a movement for biodiversity conservation and farmers' rights.

webTitle: The launch of the government's new youth health service

fields.headline: Life support system
fields.standfirst: Raekha Prasad  on a new service helping teenagers make the transition to adulthood
fields.trailText: Raekha Prasad on a new service helping teenagers make the transition to adulthood
fields.body:
Connexions, the government's much vaunted new youth service, goes live in 12 parts of England this week. But the service, billed as the muscle behind Labour's rhetorical assault on the drop-out generation, is already raising serious doubts that it will deliver.

Elements of Connexions have been tested since last April in 13 pilot areas and the plan is to introduce it throughout the country in coming years. There are concerns, though, that the scheme is being launched before it has proved itself.

Personal advisers are at the heart of the service. Deployed in schools, further education colleges and the community, their task will be to steer young people towards goals and guide them to relevant services. The personal adviser will become a new profession, but the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) has yet to establish a standardised qualification for the role.

This is leaving youth workers fearing that Connexions will undermine their profession, diluting a service already overstretched, and that it will focus on career development at the expense of personal development. In most of the pilot areas, the privatised careers service led the partnerships - prompting concern that profit will rule.

"No one can deny the principles behind Connexions are right, but the fact that it's evolutionary is a bit of a worry," says Richard Parson, head of development at the National Youth Agency. "Partnerships are starting before the specifications of Connexions seem to be tied down."

Another worry, according to Jennifer Izekor, deputy chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Youth Services, is that many groups working with disaffected young people have not felt involved in planning the new service. "A Connexions partnership has the task of trying to build relationships with a plethora of organisations," she says. "That is our fear: until local networks exist, it's going to be hard to be involved."

Meeting targets set by the government is also a concern. At a training session for advisers in the south Yorkshire pilot - covering Sheffield, Doncaster, Barnsley and Rotherham - one trainee remarks: "The DfEE are telling us that Ben Nevis has to be reached. But these young people don't even know it exists - forget wanting to go there."

Another of the trainees, who are drawn from backgrounds as diverse as the careers service, youth offending teams and women's refuges, observes that social services and education are still not up to speed about what Connexions is, or how it works, and do not yet recognise the legitimacy of personal advisers in the referral process. "It should not be up to us to fight this battle," the trainee says. "It's not up to us to go and ask these authorities to work with us."

But cooperation among services in the region is well established, insists David Gault, head of Sheffield's youth service. Indeed, there is even a sense of reinventing the wheel. "There was a feeling of déjà vu," he says. "But the basis for working together is right. It's about improving things for young people."

Research by the Local Government Association (LGA) does suggest that, in planning Connexions, the DfEE has not fully involved schools and colleges - where much of the service will be delivered. Martin Liddle, a member of the national executive of the National Association of Head Teachers, says that the number of personal advisers available to work in schools is "nothing like the resource originally planned". He thinks schools will end up sharing advisers.

"Personal advisers have to be credible to pupils and parents," says Liddle. "They've got to understand the workings of the school. I'm not sure too many of those people exist."

The presence of personal advisers within schools also raises questions about confidentiality. A young person may not want information shared with one individual to be passed on to another. Ruth Vincent, the Association of Director of Social Services' representative on education, says a protocol on confidentiality is just beginning to be worked on. But it will be decided at local, rather than national level.

Vincent believes the universality of Connexions will act as a "leveller". "The personal adviser is a very different role to a social worker," she says. "It carries no stigma and will make children with social workers more like other children."

The launch of this new, coherent strategy aimed at all young people - but giving priority to those most at risk of underachievement or disaffection - is a response to some bleak trends among modern youth. Bridging the Gap, the 1999 social exclusion unit report, seen as the genesis of Connexions, said that 9% of 16 to 18-year-olds were not in education, training or work - a figure that had not changed in six years.

That report identified 16 as a critical age: at the end of compulsory education, clear paths and goals often fall away and the teenager may descend into relationship, family and health problems, including homelessness, persistent offending or problem drug use. The government hopes that under-16s will be kept on course by Connexions, reducing exclusions and truancy.

Young people dropping out, or failing to achieve in full-time education, cost an estimated £350m a year, according to the DfEE. Funding for Connexions, which amounts to £420m in the first instance, is by comparison only £177m more than the careers service already receives. So the Treasury is not looking at a big net outlay - if the idea works.

Ultimately, Connexions is about meeting targets. It aims to reduce time lost though truancy and cut the number of permanent exclusions by 33% by 2002. Targets also include increasing GCSE achievement by 16-year-olds by the same year; increasing the number of care leavers in employment, training or education; and reducing the number of young people offending, using illegal drugs or becoming pregnant.

Much of the pilot's work has focused on setting up the bureaucratic framework to deliver the service, as well as appointing managers and training personal advisers.

Malcolm Wicks, DfEE minister for life-long learning with responsibility for Connexions, acknowledges that the service is "still at a relatively early stage". He says: "This is a very complicated piece of social policy. It's bound to vary from area to area. In some areas some agencies are more involved and committed than others. I understand that it's difficult to translate our vision into local practice."

Wicks insists, however, that Connexions will not be just a rebadged careers service. "I want some people to work in the adviser role who are not conventional people in the welfare state, but [who] within their own community have shown a real talent with working with young people."

The LGA says its research into the embryonic Connexions scheme did show its potential benefits. However, the research also found that genuine partnerships could not be created overnight. Although some areas had forged relationships relatively quickly, the LGA says, many were struggling to meet "unreasonable" timescales imposed upon them.

The anxiety among the Connexions pioneers is that expectations will be unreasonable too.

Growing concern

Connexions will be a universal youth support service for 13 to 19-year-olds in England, aiming to provide an improved universal careers service as well as additional help and support to prepare for the transition to work and adult life.

Statutory agencies, the voluntary sector and the careers service will work together to provide every young person with a personal adviser. This may include advice on education and employment options, helping with family or peer group difficulties, or working with specialist services to overcome serious problems such as drug abuse or homelessness.

A Connexions national unit, based at the DfEE, will oversee the service. Regionally, Connexions partnerships based on learning skills councils areas will be responsible for planning and funding. The daily delivery of the service will be run by committees, most of which will be based on local authority boundaries.

In Wales, the national assembly has rejected a Connexions approach in favour of boosting the youth service.

Teenage advice schemes earn praise for partnership: full story at www.societytheguardian.com/socialcare/

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: clippings
fields.body:
Spells trouble
The high priest of British white witches broke his leg when he tripped over one of the 10 black cats at his home in St Leonards, East Sussex.
Brighton Argus, 22.3.01 (E Leslie, Shoreham-by-Sea)

Row fermenting
A cider maker is challenging Hereford's ban on drinking in the street because he insists that he and other small-scale producers need to offer tasters to customers at the city's farmers' market.
Hereford Times, 8.3.01 (Anne O'Brien, Pembridge)

Counter attack
Undercover police who set up a second-hand shop in Manchester as part of an operation to combat crime did a roaring trade in stolen goods.
Manchester Evening News, 24.3.01 (Gillian Oakes, Cheadle)

Bags of cheek
Two robbers in a car grabbed a trolley full of groceries from a woman in an Oxford supermarket car park and dragged the bags inside as they drove off.
Oxford Mail, 19.3.01 (Joel Brookfield, Oxford)

Tidy haul
A burglar who broke into a house in Great Leighs, Essex, vacuumed up broken glass from the window before making off with jewellery, cash and a bottle of champagne.
Essex Chronicle, 23.3.01 (John McGarvey, Chelmsford)

Waste of money
The owner of a store in Waterlooville, Hampshire, fooled an armed robber by handing over a bag filled with rubbish instead of cash.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 19.3.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

We wuz robbed
A Sunday league football match in Walsall, West Midlands, was abandoned when the referee and both teams chased after thieves seen breaking into players' cars.
Express and Star, 20.3.01 (Steve Lewis, Wolverhampton)

Charm offensive
Scarborough council, Yorkshire, is insisting that cab drivers undergo compulsory 'customer care' training as a condition of their licence.
Yorkshire Post, 16.3.01 (John Rossington, Bradford )

Last words
A woman from Midhurst, West Sussex, left a gift for family and friends by having her secret recipe for carrot cake printed on hymn sheets at her funeral.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 14.3.01 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Hair-raising
Town elders in Alnwick, Northumberland, are objecting to the new owners of a coaching house, where Robbie Burns is reputed to have stayed, changing its name from the Black Swan Inn to the Hairy Lemon.
Western Morning News, 17.3.01 (John Hoyle, Broadhempston)

Healthy change
An 83-year-old woman who had just stood up to change television channels escaped being hit by a Rolls-Royce that crashed through the wall of her home in Pleck, West Midlands.
East Anglian Daily Times, 15.3.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Fine gesture
Warders at a young offenders' institution near Belfast had a collection to pay the £200 motoring fines of an inmate so that he could be freed to be with his partner, who was having a baby.
Belfast Telegraph, 16.3.01 (T Dougan, Belfast)

Nothing to fear
A sign reading 'Beware of the Elderly' near an old people's residential home in Powys has been replaced by one saying 'Be Aware of the Elderly'.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 23.3.01 (Simon Briggs, Bearwood)

Top of the range
A supermarket chain is piloting a scheme near the Queen's Sandringham estate in Norfolk to use unmarked Range Rovers to make deliveries to the homes of wealthy customers.
Metro, 21.3.01 (George Hoskins, New Malden)

Cuttings, preferably from local papers, which reflect interesting or amusing aspects of life in Britain, must be sent on a postcard (with source) to: Society, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. £15 will be paid for each one used.

webTitle: Minister backs primary care ideas to end outpatients

fields.headline: Minister backs primary care ideas to end outpatients
fields.trailText: Millions of patients should get specialist treatment from GPs, nurses, therapists and pharmacists rather than face long waits to see hospital consultants in often chaotic outpatient departments, according to the NHS Confederation. Indeed, the body representing health authorities and trusts is urging "an end" to traditional outpatient services.
fields.body:
Millions of patients should get specialist treatment from GPs, nurses, therapists and pharmacists rather than face long waits to see hospital consultants in often chaotic outpatient departments, according to the NHS Confederation. Indeed, the body representing health authorities and trusts is urging "an end" to traditional outpatient services.

The call comes with the launch this week in England of more than 100 primary care trusts with the power both to commission and provide health services. The confederation says this is an ideal opportunity to re-examine the way care is organised and delivered.

Significantly, the ideas are being endorsed by Alan Milburn, health secretary. He says: "The NHS must continually ask itself whether it can do things better. This is a demonstration that it can."

More than 12m people make a total of 43m outpatient visits annually - most referred by GPs, but an increasing number sent by consultants within the same hospital. In a report, Modernising Outpatients, the confederation argues that simply providing more money and staff will not solve problems caused by poorly managed clinics, overbooked appointments and patients not turning up. It commends pioneering moves in areas such as Berkshire and Bradford, where GPs and others in primary care have stopped "tossing the problem over the fence" to hospital-based specialists.

Nigel Edwards, the confederation's head of policy and author of the report, proposes a range of alternative services, some provided by new clinics providing "one-stop" diagnosis, treatment and multidisciplinary care. Staff might include consultants who would traditionally work in hospitals, or GPs with special interests - perhaps undertaking endoscopic examinations to view internal organs or carrying out skin treatments and minor surgical procedures.

Consultants and other health professionals could also liaise better electronically to determine whether referrals to clinics were strictly necessary. The report cites evidence from the Department of Health's national patients access team, suggesting that between 30% and 70% of work in outpatients adds no value for the individual. Edwards says: "We are short of consultants, we are short of GPs and we need to make the best use of what we have got."

Wokingham primary care group, in Berkshire, has been developing systems for joint analysis of referrals by professionals across the primary/secondary care divide. The report says this is improving the quality of referral decisions, facilitating integrated "care pathways" and making a case for primary care ownership of waiting lists.

Bradford South and West primary care trust has meanwhile been building a "specialist GP" scheme, addressing longstanding problems in key clinical areas. By agreement, GPs are closely integrated with secondary care teams in provision of services such as endoscopy. A next step, says the report, is for other primary care professionals to become specialists in the same way.

Stephen Thornton, the confederation's chief executive, says such radical measures are inescapable. Investing more in existing outpatient clinics, or switching their location, will not itself deliver shorter waiting lists or fashion a more patient focused service.

In fact, the report warns that expanding outpatient capacity - the single factor upon which the government's NHS plan is said to place most weight - may make existing problems worse. "The way outpatient services are run, and the relationship with primary care, is the product of the 1930s and represents the British tradition of queuing," says Thornton. "We now need to make a leap of imagination."

Modernising Outpatients is available at £8.50 inc. p&p from NHS Confederation Publication Sales, DSI NE, 1 Enterprise Way, Jarrow, NE32 3DP (0870-444 5841).

webTitle: Foot and mouth crisis: Portrait of a village

fields.headline: Portrait of a village
fields.standfirst: Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: The people of Castleton, a honeypot village in the Peak District's limestone country, are desperate to tell anyone who will listen that their village is wide open, despite foot and mouth warning signs to the contrary.
fields.body:
The people of Castleton, a honeypot village in the Peak District's limestone country, are desperate to tell anyone who will listen that their village is wide open. There have been no outbreaks of foot and mouth in the Peak national park. But at every entrance, big red signs warn of the disease and explain that paths and bridleways are closed. Tourists have been frightened off, say those who run businesses in the village.

The tea lounge

The Creme de la Creme, run by Tony and Barbara Singleton
"Visitors imagine that we will be antagonistic if they come. They seem to think we are going to stone them.
"Yesterday we took £2.75 in the cafe and didn't sell anything in the shop.
"Last week we took £19.75 between Wednesday and Friday. Our rent is £175 a week.
"It's an idyllic situation. I think I'm on holiday every day and unfortunately I am at the moment. This is the time for the oldies to be out here before the hordes arrive.
"But they are the very people who are responsible and feel they must do nothing to cause further problems. So they stay away. Yet they would have a far better experience if they came now because there are no crowds about."

The hotel

The Cheshire Cheese, run by Ken Slack
"We have just over 300 rooms available in the village and on the first weekend after the outbreak almost all were booked. But visitors turned up to occupy only 17 of those rooms.
"Those big red warning signs might just as well say 'Keep out'. We've been told of drivers telling people getting on buses at Sheffield, 'Don't go to Castleton - it's closed.' A couple of overzealous national park wardens were flagging down cars and advising drivers to turn round.
"Three-quarters of the people who come here never step off tarmac to walk in the fields. But even they are not coming. I'm certain some businesses will fail.
"If they are working on a £20,000 overdraft and cash flow stops, they will go under."

The shop

The Old Barn (gifts, ice cream and walking gear), run by Brian Johnson
"It's now 11.5am and I haven't had a customer yet. Yesterday we had only 16 transactions adding up to less than £100. We are just tootling along. We are talking about tightening belts and switching off lights. I haven't booked a family holiday this year."

The visitor attraction

Peak Cavern, run by John Harrison
"In the past four years, the number of visitors to the cave has gone up by about 40% to 35,000 a year. In the past few weeks, it's gone down by 65%. I've got a new car park, website and leaflets. You feel powerless. It's so disappointing.

The village store and cafe

Run by Sheila and Morris Burkinshaw and son Guy
"There has been a 25% drop in trade. If this goes on, we are going to be hit very hard.
"But there's not a lot we can do. We worry an awful lot because we feel so helpless. We would hate to be feel responsible for bringing foot and mouth into the valley so we are wary of pushing too much to bring people in."

The book shop

Hawkridge, run by Irene Tierney
"I think they are beginning to come back to the village now. We have done quite well because we sell a lot of books through the internet. I have had six customers in this morning."

webTitle: Personal safety is main worry for young people in London

fields.headline: Capital concerns
fields.standfirst: Personal safety is main worry for young people in London
fields.trailText: Personal safety is main worry for young people in London
fields.body:
Violence and unsafe streets have emerged as the main worries of children in London, after a survey of almost 3,000 youngsters in the capital.

The level of concern about personal safety dwarfed issues such as poverty, housing or transport. It easily outstripped anxiety over topics including racism, drugs and bullying.

The finding, from research for the new office of the London children's rights commissioner, appears to confirm the startling conclusions of a study carried out among 10-year-olds in Peckham, south London, which found that murder was their chief concern - even before the high-profile killing of Damilola Taylor.

The new survey was conducted to inform the work of the commissioner's office, established with funding from charitable trusts and the national lottery charities board. Five thousand questionnaires and postcards were sent to schools, play centres, youth clubs and young people's groups, with almost 2,500 returned. A further 500 youngsters were interviewed.

Part of the survey involved choosing four topics, from a list of 18, which the commissioner's office should focus on. "Violence" and "being safe on the streets" - shown as two separate topics - were selected by 1,367 respondents, of whom 252 opted to talk about them at length.

An 11-year-old boy from Hackney, east London, said: "Anyone can come and kill any person, even you, and on my street a person chopped off another person's arm." A 12-year-old boy from Newham, also in the east end, said: "I think violence is very important in London because in order to stay safe, feel safe and be happy, violence needs to be stopped."

Child abuse was chosen as a priority issue by 1,053 youngsters; drugs by 1,029; bullying by 936; and racism by 899. Nancy Kelley, programme director with the commissioner's office, said the findings showed young people had an acute level of awareness of what was going on around them. "You like to think that we protect children from the darker side of life, as it were, but it's clear that this is not happening."

The survey findings will be published in a report, Sort it Out!, to be presented tomorrow to London mayor Ken Livingstone.

Sort it Out! is available free from the London Children's Rights Commissioner, 94 White Lion Street, London N1 5PF (020- 7278 4390).

webTitle: Youth jail violence alarms prison inspectors

fields.headline: Youth jail violence alarms prison inspectors
fields.trailText: Evidence of "horrendous" levels of violence with more than 700 reported injuries to young prisoners has been uncovered inside a young offender institution by the chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
Evidence of "horrendous" levels of violence with more than 700 reported injuries to young prisoners has been uncovered inside a young offender institution by the chief inspector of prisons.

Sir David Ramsbotham was so disturbed by the violent culture discovered inside Stoke Heath YOI, near Market Drayton, Shropshire, that he immediately wrote to the home secretary, Jack Straw, demanding that no more children be housed in two of its wings.

The damning report on yet another young offender institution contrasts sharply with a report published this week on Swinfen Hall YOI in Staffordshire, which was described as a centre of excellence.

The Stoke Heath report, published today, says the level of injuries found was unprecedented, with "assaults, fighting and violence endemic" among the 600 inmates inside residential wings of the youth jail.

It says that over an eight-month period last year some 717 acts of violence had been recorded involving injuries to the teenage inmates. There were 268 injuries caused by assaults by other inmates, a further 282 during fights, 116 from incidents of self-harm, and 95 were minor injuries from staff using control and restraint methods. Sir David said the figures were the highest he had seen in five years of inspecting youth jails.

The inspection, which took place last October, also disclosed that six out of 10 inmates said they were put through some sort of initiation test when they arrived. All the juveniles who arrived in the 10 days before last year's inspection said they were "very frightened and in constant fear of assault from other children".

One child who had been there for two weeks, had two black eyes and was considerably distressed. He told inspectors that he had been attacked four times since he had arrived.

"The prison service must ensure that basic standards for the treatment of children in custody are never allowed to deteriorate to the level found at Stoke Heath," said Sir David. "It is quite clear that too many children and young people in Stoke Heath neither felt, nor were, safe. I have never before had to report such a horrendous number of reported injuries to children and young prisoners.

"It is important that no more children should be sent to the juvenile induction and remand wings until decent and humane treatment and conditions are in place."

Immediately before the inspection the governor and deputy governor had been removed from their posts and replaced by an acting governor and deputy from another youth jail.

The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, denied that Stoke Heath was either unsafe or inhumane: "It is an establishment which has shown real evidence of weathering a period of turbulence, to regain a sense of stability and purpose."

He said a range of proven anti-bullying measures had been introduced and the number of completed injury report forms had more than halved since the inspection last October. The use of restraint techniques by staff had also fallen by almost 70%.

webTitle: Helping teenagers make the transition to adulthood

fields.headline: Helping teenagers make the transition to adulthood
fields.trailText: Connexions, the government's much vaunted new youth service, goes live in 12 parts of England this week. But the service, billed as the muscle behind Labour's rhetorical assault on the drop-out generation, is already raising serious doubts that it will deliver.
fields.body:
Connexions, the government's much vaunted new youth service, goes live in 12 parts of England this week. But the service, billed as the muscle behind Labour's rhetorical assault on the drop-out generation, is already raising serious doubts that it will deliver.

Elements of Connexions have been tested since last April in 13 pilot areas and the plan is to introduce it throughout the country in coming years. There are concerns, though, that the scheme is being launched before it has proved itself.

Personal advisers are at the heart of the service. Deployed in schools, further education colleges and the community, their task will be to steer young people towards goals and guide them to relevant services. The personal adviser will become a new profession, but the Department for Education and Employment (DfEE) has yet to establish a standardised qualification for the role.

This is leaving youth workers fearing that Connexions will undermine their profession, diluting a service already overstretched, and that it will focus on career development at the expense of personal development. In most of the pilot areas, the privatised careers service led the partnerships - prompting concern that profit will rule.

"No one can deny the principles behind Connexions are right, but the fact that it's evolutionary is a bit of a worry," says Richard Parson, head of development at the National Youth Agency. "Partnerships are starting before the specifications of Connexions seem to be tied down."

Another worry, according to Jennifer Izekor, deputy chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Youth Services, is that many groups working with disaffected young people have not felt involved in planning the new service. "A Connexions partnership has the task of trying to build relationships with a plethora of organisations," she says. "That is our fear: until local networks exist, it's going to be hard to be involved."

Meeting targets set by the government is also a concern. At a training session for advisers in the south Yorkshire pilot - covering Sheffield, Doncaster, Barnsley and Rotherham - one trainee remarks: "The DfEE are telling us that Ben Nevis has to be reached. But these young people don't even know it exists - forget wanting to go there."

Another of the trainees, who are drawn from backgrounds as diverse as the careers service, youth offending teams and women's refuges, observes that social services and education are still not up to speed about what Connexions is, or how it works, and do not yet recognise the legitimacy of personal advisers in the referral process. "It should not be up to us to fight this battle," the trainee says. "It's not up to us to go and ask these authorities to work with us."

But cooperation among services in the region is well established, insists David Gault, head of Sheffield's youth service. Indeed, there is even a sense of reinventing the wheel. "There was a feeling of déjà vu," he says. "But the basis for working together is right. It's about improving things for young people."

Research by the Local Government Association (LGA) does suggest that, in planning Connexions, the DfEE has not fully involved schools and colleges - where much of the service will be delivered. Martin Liddle, a member of the national executive of the National Association of Head Teachers, says that the number of personal advisers available to work in schools is "nothing like the resource originally planned". He thinks schools will end up sharing advisers.

"Personal advisers have to be credible to pupils and parents," says Liddle. "They've got to understand the workings of the school. I'm not sure too many of those people exist."

The presence of personal advisers within schools also raises questions about confidentiality. A young person may not want information shared with one individual to be passed on to another. Ruth Vincent, the Association of Directors of Social Services' representative on education, says a protocol on confidentiality is just beginning to be worked on. But it will be decided at local, rather than national level.

Vincent believes the universality of Connexions will act as a "leveller". "The personal adviser is a very different role to a social worker," she says. "It carries no stigma and will make children with social workers more like other children."

The launch of this new, coherent strategy aimed at all young people - but giving priority to those most at risk of underachievement or disaffection - is a response to some bleak trends among modern youth. Bridging the Gap, the 1999 social exclusion unit report, seen as the genesis of Connexions, said that 9% of 16 to 18-year-olds were not in education, training or work - a figure that had not changed in six years.

That report identified 16 as a critical age: at the end of compulsory education, clear paths and goals often fall away and the teenager may descend into relationship, family and health problems, including homelessness, persistent offending or problem drug use. The government hopes that under-16s will be kept on course by Connexions, reducing exclusions and truancy.

Young people dropping out, or failing to achieve in full-time education, cost an estimated £350m a year, according to the DfEE. Funding for Connexions, which amounts to £420m in the first instance, is by comparison only £177m more than the careers service already receives. So the Treasury is not looking at a big net outlay - if the idea works.

Ultimately, Connexions is about meeting targets. It aims to reduce time lost though truancy and cut the number of permanent exclusions by 33% by 2002. Targets also include increasing GCSE achievement by 16-year-olds by the same year; increasing the number of care leavers in employment, training or education; and reducing the number of young people offending, using illegal drugs or becoming pregnant.

Much of the pilot's work has focused on setting up the bureaucratic framework to deliver the service, as well as appointing managers and training personal advisers.

Malcolm Wicks, DfEE minister for life-long learning with responsibility for Connexions, acknowledges that the service is "still at a relatively early stage". He says: "This is a very complicated piece of social policy. It's bound to vary from area to area. In some areas some agencies are more involved and committed than others. I understand that it's difficult to translate our vision into local practice."

Wicks insists, however, that Connexions will not be just a rebadged careers service. "I want some people to work in the adviser role who are not conventional people in the welfare state, but [who] within their own community have shown a real talent with working with young people."

The LGA says its research into the embryonic Connexions scheme did show its potential benefits. However, the research also found that genuine partnerships could not be created overnight. Although some areas had forged relationships relatively quickly, the LGA says, many were struggling to meet "unreasonable" timescales imposed upon them.

The anxiety among the Connexions pioneers is that expectations will be unreasonable too.

Elements of Connexions have been tested since last April in 13 pilot areas and the plan is to introduce it throughout the country in coming years. fields.headline: Growing concern
fields.trailText: Connexions will be a universal youth support service for 13 to 19-year-olds in England, aiming to provide an improved universal careers service as well as additional help and support to prepare for the transition to work and adult life.
fields.body:
Connexions will be a universal youth support service for 13 to 19-year-olds in England, aiming to provide an improved universal careers service as well as additional help and support to prepare for the transition to work and adult life.

Statutory agencies, the voluntary sector and the careers service will work together to provide every young person with a personal adviser. This may include advice on education and employment options, helping with family or peer group difficulties, or working with specialist services to overcome serious problems such as drug abuse or homelessness.

A Connexions national unit, based at the DfEE, will oversee the service. Regionally, Connexions partnerships based on learning skills councils areas will be responsible for planning and funding. The daily delivery of the service will be run by committees, most of which will be based on local authority boundaries.

In Wales, the national assembly has rejected a Connexions approach in favour of boosting the youth service.
